description:
# tl;dr
A fresh install of graphviz cannot render PDF or PNG.

# Full description:

On a fresh Xubuntu 16.04 install, I install graphviz like this (not using the one from the repo b/c the one from the repo is outdated and does not have a working sfdp):
```bash
wget https://graphviz.gitlab.io/pub/graphviz/stable/SOURCES/graphviz.tar.gz
gunzip graphviz.tar.gz
tar xvf graphviz.tar

sudo apt install -y libgts-dev
sudo pkg-config --libs gts
sudo pkg-config --cflags gts

cd graphviz-2.40.1/
sudo ./configure --with-gts --prefix ~
sudo make
sudo make install
```
However when I try to render s/th  I get:
```bash
kratz@kratz-VirtualBox:~/tmp$ time sfdp -Goverlap=prism -Tpng nelout.gv > nelout.png
Format: "png" not recognized. Use one of: canon cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot dot_json eps fig gv imap imap_np ismap json json0 mp pic plain plain-ext pov ps ps2 svg svgz tk vml vmlz xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4 xdot_json
```

Same problem for PDF!

summary: Create a diagram in several languages
description:
I have the following code to generate a diagram with -Kfdp.

`
digraph habitLoop {
    bgcolor = steelblue
    edge [penwidth = 4.0 ]
    node [fontcolor = white, fontsize = 60, style = filled]

    spur   [pos = "4,4!" color = red]
    habit  [pos = "7,1!" color = darkgreen]
    reward [pos = "1,1!" color = blue]

    spur:e   -> habit:n
    habit:w  -> reward:e
    reward:n -> spur:w

    copyright [
                pos       = "4,.75!"
                color     = steelblue,
                fontcolor = black,
                fontsize  = 14,
                label     = "© Cecil Westerhof\nTimeManagement@Decebal.nl",
                shape     = plaintext
              ]

    spur   [label = "Spur"]
    habit  [label = "Habit"]
    reward [label = "Reward"]
}
`

But I like to generate it in Dutch also. So I also have:
`digraph habitLoop {
    bgcolor = steelblue
    edge [penwidth = 4.0 ]
    node [fontcolor = white, fontsize = 60, style = filled]

    spur   [pos = "4,4!" color = red]
    habit  [pos = "7,1!" color = darkgreen]
    reward [pos = "1,1!" color = blue]

    spur:e   -> habit:n
    habit:w  -> reward:e
    reward:n -> spur:w

    copyright [
                pos       = "4,.75!"
                color     = steelblue,
                fontcolor = black,
                fontsize  = 14,
                label     = "© Cecil Westerhof\nTimeManagement@Decebal.nl",
                shape     = plaintext
              ]

    spur   [label = "Prikkel"]
    habit  [label = "Gewoonte"]
    reward [label = "Beloning"]
}
`

But when I change something I now have to change it at two places. That is an accident waiting to happen. Is there a way to do this in a DRY way?

By the way: what am I doing wrong? Because the preview does not display the code correctly.

summary: sfio does compile time benchmarknig
description:
graphviz-2.40.1/lib/sfio/features/sfio does benchmarking at compile time to decide which version of a function to use.

It does this for 3 functions: memchr memccpy mmap

This creates variations in build results across the openSUSE build workers that vary in type of system and parallel build load.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

Would be nice to have a cleaner way of disabling that than the attached patch
[reproducible.patch](/uploads/f172041f98f03b7f2eb2d3901524b3f8/reproducible.patch)

summary: HTML-labels wrong centre alignment
description: dot - graphviz version 2.38.0 (20140413.2041) For nodes that have HTML-labels where two rows have different font sizes, the center alignment is off. Minimal example: ``` digraph { node [shape=box]; foo[label=longer text below longer text below longer text below>] } ``` Produced svg (dot g.txt -Tsvg -o g.svg) ``` ``` The lower text is more to the left than center. Not sure why graphviz uses text-anchor="start" and then miscalculates the start position. Currently I'm fixing it by changing to text-anchor="middle" and replacing x with the polygon center coordinate.

summary: Want dot to directly support edges between clusters, and/or FDP to support rankdir=BT or gravity
description:
I am trying to autogenerate a complex dependency diagram, with some nodes being represented as cluster subgraphs (containing sub-dependency diagrams) which are still nodes as well (they are not just containers of nodes, but are actual things that arrows can point to), such that the dependency arrows all point at least somewhat "up" the page, or at least don't point "down". A dependency diagram, at least in my case, should form a directed acyclic graph (DAG) with a single node as the "root" node which is directly or indirectly dependent on all other top-level nodes.

I have spent several days trying to accomplish this, and have achieved only partial success. This is frustrating, since this seems to me like a fairly basic use-case for GraphViz and hence the sort of thing that GraphViz should be able to easily support 'out of the box' without excessive tweaking, yet I have had to resort to strange workarounds:

1. If I use the 'dot' layout, in order to use subgraphs as nodes, I apparently have to create an invisible dummy node in each subgraph, and have edges that "should" go to any subgraph boundaries instead target the subgraph's dummy node, and use "ltail" and "lhead" attributes on those edges to reference the containing subgraph's name, so the arrows get clipped on the subgraph boundaries instead of extending all the way to the dummy nodes. 

    (Note: This is per StackOverflow https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2012036/graphviz-how-to-connect-subgraphs).

    I've gotten this working, but it has the unfortunate side effect that each invisible dummy node has a definite location within its parent cluster, and therefore the arrows drawn to it are drawn to target that location (before clipping) rather than drawn as if they were going to target the center of the cluster. This looks OK when the invisible dummy node ends up roughly in the center of the subgraph, but not so good when it ends up sitting near one corner.

2. Nonetheless, for "dot", I can use "rankdir=BT" to get arrows pointing generally up the page rather than down (although for some reason, nodes inside clusters often seem to ignore rankdir and are often right-to-left instead...?)

3. If I use the 'fdp' layout, clusters seem to be supported as first-class objects, so I don't need all of the "dummy node" and "lhead/ltail" workarounds (I can just create an edge from one cluster's name to another node or cluster name, for instance). Unfortunately, rankdir=BT seems to have no effect in such a case (but I don't see any documentation that says so), so my dependency arrows seem to end up pointing in various random directions, which would be fairly confusing for someone looking at the diagram.

So, in short, if I want to have some nodes be clusters in my diagram, and I want dependency ordering to be generally (exclusively?) bottom-to-top, I don't seem to have any good options.

I would like to have a way to accomplish this. I would also prefer that this way be fairly "clean" and not require nonintuitive workarounds. Some suggestions:

1. If the 'dot' algorithm is going to continue to require this workaround for drawing edges between clusters, then at least please provide some way to automate it. For instance, if a graph had "compound=true', then inside each cluster subgraph, the tools could automatically create an invisible zero-size dummy node named after the cluster (with possibly some prefix to make it unlikely to overlap user's node names), and then if dot found an edge which was sourced or targeted at a cluster name, it could substitute the dummy node name and automatically add an "lhead" or "ltail" attribute referencing the cluster name. (Right now, the dot algorithm seems to treat cluster names as if they refer to nonexistent nodes).

2. It would be nice to have a way to force any such dummy nodes to be placed at the exact center of their clusters, rather than being placed wherever the placement algorithm sees fit to put them in the cluster.

3. It would be even nicer if dot just allowed use of clusters as sources or targets of edges, and drew edges to clusters as if they were to the center of the cluster, but clipped at its boundary as via lhead and ltail, without the need for any dummy nodes.

4. With regards to the 'fdp' algorithm, it would be nice if there was a way to directly specify rankdir=BT, or to at least achieve a similar effect as rankdir. If rankdir can't be implemented directly due to the nature of the algorithm (which to my limited understanding seems to involve some kind of physics model), then perhaps at least the algorithm could introduce some notion of "gravity" in an arbitrary direction (specified by rankdir or some other attribute) pulling on nodes away from some given node or set of nodes which were designated as "fixed" at the top, bottom, left, or right of the diagram. Thus in my case, a root node could be fixed at the bottom of the page, and the other nodes could "float upwards" as high as they could due to gravity pulling upwards, constrained by spring tension of edges.

In summary: Please provide a way to create a graph such as a "dependency diagram with arrows pointing upwards" which supports some nodes being clusters, and which is expressible directly in GraphViz with a minimum of workarounds required.

summary: Long label intersects box
description:
```
digraph test {

}

summary: unable to show big graph whith subgraphs
Looking for beta testers for a new Graphviz Visual Editor web application
description:
Apologies if posting here is inappropriate.

I've developed a web application for interactive visual editing of graphs described in the DOT language that I'm looking for beta tester for. A few feature highlights:

* Insert node shapes by click or drag-and-drop.
* Draw edges between nodes.
* Select nodes and edges by click or by area drag and mark them in the text editor.
* Delete selected nodes and edges.
* Cut/Copy-and-paste a selected node.

Try it live at http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/.

See the [README](https://github.com/magjac/graphviz-visual-editor/blob/master/README.md) for more features.

Any feedback in the form of bug reports or enhancement requests is welcome as [issues](https://github.com/magjac/graphviz-visual-editor/issues). For questions, discussion and other feedback, please contact me at the [d3-graphviz Slack channel #graphviz-vis-editor](https://join.slack.com/t/d3-graphviz/shared_invite/enQtMzMwODQzMDI5MDA5LTExYTgyYThhNzI3YjJlODRiMzQ3MWM3YWI5ZjAyMTI2MmI4YWIwMDM4ZmY5MDQzNjkzMDY4YTRmMTU1YzIzNTY).

summary: Mention GraphViz Dot in dijkstra man page  & help
description:
`dijkstra` has no mention of origin or author, nor most importantly of input format.  
refereed to as simply 'streamed graphs'  
It is of course near useless to do a meaningful web search on the term 'dijkstra'
so on a systen where one did not recently personally install GraphVis there is no clue as to what format the input should take.

suggest adding the words `Graphviz dot` and perhaps an example sporting a `.gv` suffix 


```
NAME
       dijkstra - single-source distance filter

SYNOPSIS
       dijkstra [ -adp?  ] [ sourcenode dotfile ]

DESCRIPTION
       dijkstra  reads  a stream of GraphViz Dot formatted graphs and for each computes the distance of every node from sourcenode. 
...
 
```

summary: Next stable release?
description:
Hello!

Are there any plans to issue the next stable release?

The latest stable release is of Graphviz stable_release_2.40.1.  
It has a critical bug, it crashes on a significant class of DOT inputs, the simplest is:  
`digraph test { A; B; { rank=sink; A } }`  
The bug is fixed at head, I checked that it works on the latest snapshot, 2.41.20181004.0037.  

I'm using [Viz.js](https://github.com/mdaines/viz.js) that is an automated translation of Graphviz into JavaScript.  
Viz.js owner uses the latest stable release of Graphviz, that is reasonable.  
But as a result all the recent versions of Viz.js are affected by this critical bug and this makes them unusable for me.  
See the corresponding Viz.js [issue](https://github.com/mdaines/viz.js/issues/98).  
Now I started to face problems with the old version of Viz.js that I'm stuck on, so really need to upgrade.  
That's why a new stable release would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks!  
Danila

Replace `char*` with `const char*` in functions arguments
description: Cgraph uses `char*` as string types. This is OK for C, however, ISO C++ forbids automatic cast of `const char*` to `char*`, which is very painful when using Cgraph with a C++ compiler. summary: Windows Build Failure
description:
Hello,

I have Visual Studio 2015, and windows 10.

I've tried to build the repository, as according to the instructions at http://www.graphviz.org/doc/winbuild.html for the latest version.  

I unpack a copy of the repository to C:\graphviz\
I've then run 'git init' and 'git submodule update --init' in C:\graphbiz\graphviz-master\ directory.

At this point, windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities is a directory, that is empty.

I add 'C:\graphviz\graphviz-master\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities'
to my PATH environmental variable.

Now, opening the solution I get the following error:
Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs: Failed to backup file as C:\graphviz\graphviz-master\windows\Backup\Properties\AssemblyInfo.cs
Stackoverflow suggests that I just create a new copy of it.

I go to project properties, Assembly Information, and create a new assembly called 'Graphviz'.  I leave everything else blank.

I then compile the application.  It can browse to files, but immediately crashes upon opening them.

Any hint as to what I need to do?

I'm guessing that git submodule update --init failed somehow, but I didn't get any warnings or errors as such, so I don't know if that's the issue.

summary: Color "lightgreen" is not recognized
description:
The gv file below returns the error "Warning: lightgreen is not a known color". The "lightgreen" color is listed in the documentation of X11 color schemes. This has something to do with the subgraph - if I delete the subgraph and add some nodes under the main digraph the warning goes away. The rendered image has no lightgreen in it.

~~~~
digraph Logic {
    color = lightgreen
    subgraph cluster_PList004 {
        Match000
        }
    }

> dot -Tpng Logic.gv -o Logic.png
Warning: lightgreen is not a known color.

> dot Logic.gv -o Logic.png  # (Simpler command line)
Warning: lightgreen is not a known color.

Locations
ante-chamber
chieftain-crypt
false-crypta
hall-of-the-dead
orc-camp
oxhaven
portico
star-chamber
temple-chamber
trapped-hall
>]; } } ``` ### Command ``` $ dot -Tpng output/shuffled.dot > output/shuffled.png; fish: “dot -Tpng output/shuffled.dot >…” terminated by signal SIGSEGV (Address boundary error) ``` ## Expected Behaviour PNG with table on the bottom.

summary: Warning: transparent is not a known color
description:
When `colorscheme` is set to value `svg`, the following warning is emitted when running dot:

```
Warning: transparent is not a known color.
```

MWE dot file:

```dot
graph g {
  colorscheme="svg";
}
```

Observed on Fedora 29 with GraphViz 2.40.1.

summary: Graphviz flow chart: SyntaxError invalid syntax
description:
I try to create a flow chart whereof I want to change the colors of the nodes.
The code of the first flow chart that I created was:
```
import graphviz
d=graphviz.Digraph()
d.edge('hello','world')
d.edge('new','hello')
d
```
It works perfectly, although I can not find how to change the colors of the nodes.
I tried a few things but it doesn't work.

So I tried something else:
```
digraph {
    a -> b;
    b -> c;
    c -> d;
    d -> a;
}
```
With this code I should be able to change the colors of the nodes if I am correct.
But this code gives me a SyntaxError: 
File "<ipython-input-282-ded44b06c721>", line 1
    digraph {
            ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

So maybe I'm mixing stuff up here. But I'm getting lost.
Is there a way to color the nodes with the first code?
If not, how do I get the second code working and how do I then color the nodes?

Note: Graphviz 2.38 was installed on my Windows computer and the path was added to the environment variables.

Thanks in advance!

summary: gvpr does not recognize pseudo-attribute "root" in function
Polygon contour of nodes
description:
Hello!

I have a directed graph whose strongly connected components I want to denote with a polygon contour.

I known which vertices make up each SCC.
What I don't know is how to define a polygon whose edge coordinates will be such that it will enclose the final (post-compilation) formation of vertices.

Is this possible?
Thanks

P.S. I find it weird to ask this question as an issue, but it was suggested here: http://www.graphviz.org/contact/, so here it is.

summary: Incorrect rendering of labels with percent (%) sign
description:
I need to render in a directed graph labels with the percent (%) sign.

My expectation is that if I quote them with double quotes, they should be correctly rendered.

What happens, however, is that they are garbled.

Here is an example:

```
andrea@SPADACCIO-LAP:~$ dot -V
dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304)

andrea@SPADACCIO-LAP:~$ cat test.dot
digraph g {
  "%foo%" -> "bar"
}

andrea@SPADACCIO-LAP:~$ dot -Tpng <test.dot > test.png
```

Output (test.png):

![test](/uploads/daf6eb60320395c992e8e93430548082/test.png)

Am I missing something? Thanks!

summary: Visualization of relationships
description:
Hi,

I'm searching for visualization of relationships extracted fro a relational database. The visualized data ( < 30 nodes ) should be used for demo  and analysis purposes.

Because I'm a newby, I'd like to get some suggestions for certain products / plugins.

The main requirements:

1. Every nodes has a type (e.g. company, product, employee,...)
2. Every type has a default image displayed on the node
3. Some nodes have individual image ( e.g. employee picture)
4. The data should be imported (e.g. from csv)
5. Nodes and edges should be edited on the UI as well

Could you please give me some suggestions (products / plugis, ...)  ?

Thanks a lot in advance !

Regards,

Michel

summary: Feasibility and performance Question (Just Learned out About GraphViz)
description:
I have a series of .csv files with connection information (effectivly a series of linked list) to generate an image in LabVIEW. The data begins as a table with the following format:

[(int)ItemNumber],[(String)ItemName],[(String)GroupName],[(bool)LeftOrRightSide]

For example the table:

0,GRND1,GRND,T

1,GRND2,GRND,T

2,P1_1,Net 1,T

3,J1_1,Net 1,F

4,P1_2,Net 2,T

5,J1_2,Net 2,F

6,P1_3,Net 3,T

7,J1_3,Net 3,F

8,P2_1,Net 4,T

9,J2_1,Net 4,F

Yields the following image:

![image](/uploads/1328400dc50d376821f349be7bf66a86/image.png)

Can I easily replicate this in GraphViz? Additionally about how long would GraphViz take to make this image from a table of 100 to 1000 items?

summary: macOS fixes/improvements
description:
#1445 is already tracking the build failures with Xcode 10, but there are other improvements for macOS which I'd like to work on:
 * a [QuickLook plugin](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/Quicklook_Programming_Guide/Introduction/Introduction.html) so graphs could be previewed from the Finder, Mail, etc.
 * it would be really cool to make a self-contained Graphviz.app, so viewer-only users wouldn't need to bother with a .pkg or Homebrew. Maybe even put it in the Mac App Store if possible.
 * If a self-contained app is possible, maybe a .pkg is unnecessary?

summary: Segmentation Fault (121229287)
description:
Hello graphviz team,

As part of our fuzzing efforts at Google, we have identified an issue affecting
graphviz (tested with revision * master bbb7e2227436b815c91043eba55f9d4fcfeca50b).

To reproduce, we are attaching a Dockerfile which compiles the project with
LLVM, taking advantage of the sanitizers that it offers. More information about
how to use the attached Dockerfile can be found here:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/

Instructions:
`unzip artifacts_121229287.zip`
`docker build --build-arg SANITIZER=address --tag=autofuzz-graphviz-121229287 autofuzz_121229287`
`docker run --entrypoint /fuzzing/repro.sh --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_121229287/poc-ef09f81eaafdab402f5ac49737e61354a7947f36ac388bf8b2a651135f39bec1_min:/tmp/poc autofuzz-graphviz-121229287 "" /tmp/poc`

summary: labeljust=l doesn't work
description:
Hi, I want to use `labeljust = l` to align the label to the left of the node `n`. However, it doesn't work.

```
digraph test {
	labeljust = l;
	node [shape = record]
	n [label="{aaa|bbbbbbb|ccc}"]
}
```

![](https://imgur.com/ErIzZny.png)

I hope it should be:

![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/rQiHdJu.png)

Use `\l` for each line is very inconvenient, so I want to use `labeljust`. How to get it to work. Many thanks!

summary: invbisible edges should only be consided in determining node ranks but not on layouting edges
Make Graphviz buildable as a cmake subproject/subdirectory
description: Sometimes it might be convenient to just add graphviz as a subdirectory and manually build it in your cmakelists, however, it looks like currently it's prevented by the use of `CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` in a few places (which would link to the topmost CMakeLists.txt), when it should've been `CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR` (so relative paths would be correct). Maybe there are other issues, I haven't investigated further.

summary: How to get overlapping boxes
description: Is there a way to get one box to overlap another? For [reference](https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&source=images&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwiU57T--fDfAhUHKqwKHefLCi4QjRx6BAgBEAU&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.freepik.com%2Ffree-icon%2Ftwo-overlapping-rectangular-boxes_706841.htm&psig=AOvVaw1_2DIMogQWRfas94cltNlg&ust=1547681756269015)

summary: "dot -V" writes to stderr instead of stdout
description:
Unexpected behavior (See:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment) is violated by executing "dot -V".  

Current behavior:  
$ dot -V > stdout.txt  
dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)  
$ cat stdout.txt  
$  
  
Expected results:  
$ dot -V > stdout.txt  
$ cat stdout.txt  
dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)  
$  
  
Unexpected results:  
$ dot -V 2> stderr.txt  
$ cat stderr.txt  
dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)  
$  
  
This is problematic due to the following "intuitive" test:  
  
  
$ if dot -V | grep "2.40.1" ; then echo "OK"; else echo "FAIL"; fi  
dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)  
FAIL

summary: looking for 3D example
description:
I'm looking for an example that works with dot and an example that works with fdp.  I plan on testing with vrml.

thanks

summary: MSB4018 The NativeCodeAnalysis task failed unexpectedly.
description:
I'm trying to build Graphviz from source on Windows. (I'm using latest master, although I would have no problem with going back a bit.)

Per [the build instructions](https://graphviz.org/doc/winbuild.html), I've initialized the submodules. Then I modified the local PATH as instructed in PowerShell and launched Visual Studio from the same session:

```
$env:Path = "$pwd\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities;$env:Path"
& "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\Common7\IDE\devenv.exe
" ".\graphviz.sln"
```

With that background, I'm getting this error repeatedly:

> MSB4018	The "NativeCodeAnalysis" task failed unexpectedly. 

The error seems to be reported for each project, against line 407 of C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\MSBuild\Microsoft\VisualStudio\v15.0\CodeAnalysis\Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Targets

Did I miss a step?

summary: Using Graphviz from .NET Core
description:
Is there a right way to link Graphviz with a .NET Core project? When I installed the Nuget package, I found it was compiled with .NET Framework 4.6.1. I'm attempting to build the project so I can try compiling it to .NET Core, but that's certainly not how I would prefer to work this.

On a related topic, has any thought been given to targeting the Nuget package to .NET Standard? I'm not familiar with your dependencies, but Graphviz seems like a natural candidate for using that feature.

summary: Does Graphviz-2.38 compatible with Windows 10
description:
Hello,

I would like to know if Graphviz-2.38 is compatible with Windows 10?

Sincerely,

summary: neato - curved edges in cyclic directed graph: make edge directions emphasize cycles
[Dot] Missing edges when using splines=curved
Select a node or region using mouse and identify which node(s) are selected by a user
description: I am new in ZGRViewer's applications. I am generating visual plots of graphs in a Jpanel from a dot file. I am using ZGRViewer, a GraphViz/DOT Viewer. Now my requirement is: using mouse user may want to select a node or region in the visual plots (generated by ZGRViewer![Screenshot__25_](/uploads/2740d4e332fbfc1069e73a80e61033b5/Screenshot__25_.png)) of the graph and want to know which node(s) are selected by the mouse click/mouse motion. In reference to the attached file, user may want to select a node like, C_8 or want to select a region, containing nodes C_8, C_9, N_7, O_10 using the mouse and identify nodes/node label(s) associated with mouse click or selection.

summary: How to show edges labels when edges are dense?
description:
When edges are relatively dense, it becomes difficult to see the
corresponding edges of edge labels in graphviz generated figure Is
there something similar to ggrepel, to add a short line to connect the
labels and the corresponding edges to make the labeling more readable?
Thanks.

https://blog.exploratory.io/ggrepel-when-things-get-too-crowded-ffefd845665f

summary: Out of memory exception
description:
Hello,

I'm using GraphViz Windows command line to create a graph, in general it has worked perfectly in the past, this is using dot. 

But right now a new (huge) graph has to be created, it has over 2.000.000 nodes. When the file is fed to dot.exe it starts loading the model and soon (about 3 or 4 seconds in) it sends an out of memory exception and simply crashes.

Now, I know this is a huge graph, and even if it was able to be loaded it would take some time to finish. But my question is if there is any  way, argument option or something that could alleviate GraphViz's memory usage while loading this file?.

Thank you in advance for any help you could provide.

summary: tooltip rendering in the GUI app would be great
description:
As I debug my program, instead of printfs or logging, I use a statement that writes to a debug.dot file, which I have open in the GraphViz app. Whenever the file is overwritten, the GraphViz app refreshes from it. This is a really nice way to work.

I tricked out my dot output with tooltips on td tags in html tables, but they don't work in the app, at least not on macOS.

It would be really nice if tooltips would work.

Version 2.40 (2.40.1)
macOS 10.14.3

summary: GraphViz app and multiple files in a sequence
description:
As I debug my program, instead of printfs or logging, I use a statement that writes to a debug.dot file, which I have open in the GraphViz app. Whenever the file is overwritten, the GraphViz app refreshes from it. This is a really nice way to work.

I also have the app write out a sequence of files, debug1.dot, debug2.dot, etc.

It would be nice if the app would notice that a numbered file has been opened and allow cycling back and forth through the files in the implied sequence, using the left-arrow and right-arrow keys.

Extra credit: allow playing an impromptu movie at some frame rate, composed from a range of the numbered input files.

Version 2.40 (2.40.1)
macOS 10.14.3

summary: The GraphViz app sometimes doesn't render a perfectly good dot file
description:
Until this is fixed, or even if it is fixed, a cmd-R keyboard shortcut to refresh from the file on disk would be great.

macOS 10.14.3

summary: GraphViz as library: How to query the installed layouts and renderers at run-time?
description:
I'd like to present the user with lists of available layouts and renderers in a GUI desktop app before displaying a graph of the data at hand. Perhaps this is documented somewhere, but I couldn't find any way to do this except for parsing the config6 file (which may or may not be available), or just letting `gvLayout()` and `gvRenderData()` error out if the particular layout and/or renderer isn't available.

Is there a more elegant way of doing it? Please note that I am not using graphviz as a stand-alone command-line utility, nor am I calling `system()` to invoke it; rather, it is built into the application which calls the C API functions in the shared libraries.

summary: Memory cleanup for multiple rendering after one single layout job?
description:
If I call `gvLayout()` and then `gvRenderData()`, I should usually call `gvFreeRenderData(), gvFreeLayout(), agclose()`, and `gvFreeContext()` in that order to clean up the allocated memory.

Is it possible to reuse the layout for use with multiple renderers, or is this unwise? For example, I would do `neato` layout with a graph DOT file, then render using `plain` in order to read the generated graph size from the first line of output, then resize a display window in my GUI app, and then render the same layout as an SVG file. I imagine that I would have to call `gvFreeRenderData()` after each rendering, but call `gvFreeLayout(), agclose()` and `gvFreeContext()` only once after the routine finishes.

Is this OK or will I leak memory and/or crash?

summary: Width of record/TD element UTF-8
typo 'douible' in gvpr man page
description:
From man gvpr:
```
       X : douible
              the X coordinate of a node. (Assumes the node has a pos attribute.)

       Y : douible
              the Y coordinate of a node. (Assumes the node has a pos attribute.)

```

Note typo 'douible' instead of double.

Find a patch attached: [0001-Fix-typo-douible-in-gvpr.1.patch](/uploads/794ff6e40ec2620a8ab8a62b64c1abb9/0001-Fix-typo-douible-in-gvpr.1.patch)

summary: GV as library: Same graph, new layout -- is it enough to call gvFreeLayout() before making a new layout?
description:
Before invoking `gvLayout()` with an appropriate layout string, I must call `gvContext()` to fetch a valid `GVC_t*` and `agread()` (or `agmemread()`) for a valid `Agraph_t*`.

Let's assume that I have made a layout and rendered the graph with some layout and rendering engine. Now if I want to do a different layout with a different engine using the same graph data already stored, do I need to call anything except `gvFreeLayout()` before invoking `gvLayout()` again (assuming that the memory allocated by the renderer has been freed correctly by calling `gvFreeRenderData()`)?

Thanks!

summary: Question about rendering in "plain" format
description:
According to the documentation of the "plain" output, when the line is describing an edge:
>  n is the number of control points defining the B-spline forming the edge. This is followed by 2 ∗ n numbers giving the x and y coordinates of the control points in order from tail to head.

Will there always be at least one control point, or can there be none? If there are none, will the number `n` be output as 0, or will it be skipped?

summary: Perl and PHP bindings check doesn't work with SWIG 4
description:
SWIG 4 is closed to final release and I trying to rebuild all its dependencies in Fedora. 

I tried to rebuild graphviz with prepared SWIG 4 and I found that Perl and PHP extension are not built. It is caused, because check in configure.ac failed. The reason is that the list of options in help changed:
* '-perl' was replaced by '-perl5', both are valid, but only the '-perl5' is listed in help
* '-php5' was removed, because PHP 5 is not supported now
* if language option is not valid, the error message will be 'No target language specified'

I have prepared patch for Fedora, which should work for SWIG 3.0.12 and also 4.0, you can found it [here](https://jplesnik.fedorapeople.org/swig-4/graphviz/graphviz-2.40.1-swig4-updated-language-options.patch)

summary: Can't create PNG with 36000 nodes
Heap Out-Of-Bounds Memory Access (128166469)
description:
Hello graphviz team,

As part of our fuzzing efforts at Google, we have identified an issue affecting
graphviz (tested with revision * master fb96c550b1db58ae5ae7610026dae1e7ac8afe87).

To reproduce, we are attaching a Dockerfile which compiles the project with
LLVM, taking advantage of the sanitizers that it offers. More information about
how to use the attached Dockerfile can be found here:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/

Instructions:
`unzip artifacts_128166469.zip`
`docker build --build-arg SANITIZER=address --tag=autofuzz-graphviz-128166469 autofuzz_128166469`
`docker run --entrypoint /fuzzing/repro.sh --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_128166469/poc-5887f6787709f8b5dc5e2721a136f2ec3333d7b49f065febd49bfd1bf6678937_min:/tmp/poc autofuzz-graphviz-128166469 "" /tmp/poc`
`docker run --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_128166469/poc-5887f6787709f8b5dc5e2721a136f2ec3333d7b49f065febd49bfd1bf6678937_min:/tmp/poc -it autofuzz-graphviz-128166469`

Alternatively, and depending on the bug, you could use gcc, valgrind or other
instrumentation tools to aid in the investigation. The sanitizer error that we
encountered is here:

summary: Null pointer dereference while calling gvLayout (gvc->textfont_dt in labels.c, line 35)
iffe "lib" check always succeeds when compiler optimises
description:
For various reasons, my compiler always performs optimisations, even without -O.

iffe's "lib" check is written in such a way that it gets optimised away entirely, thus causing all such checks to succeed, even when the function is actually not available.

Simply removing the "static" keyword from the global `i` variable works.

summary: cgraph library out-edge ordering doesn't conform to the documentation
description:
My Graphviz application generates a visualization of an attributed parse tree produced from an **Attribute Grammar Evaluator**, implemented on top of a bottom-up **LR(k) Parser**. The attributed parse tree visualization generation is implemented using the ***cgraph*** library as a strict directed graph where all nodes, save for the tree's root node, have exactly one **in-edge**. I use ***agwrite()*** to write the DOT-language representation of the attributed parse tree visualization into a file for off-line layout and rendering.

For this application, the left-to-right ordering of **out-edges** from an **interior node** is important. The Cgraph library tutorial ([cgraph.pdf](https://graphviz.gitlab.io/_pages/pdf/cgraph.pdf)) contains the following statements that led me to believe this would be trivial:
* At the end of **Section 6, Traversals**: "Traversals are guaranteed to visit the nodes of a graph, or edges of a node, in their order of creation in the root graph ..."
* At the start of **Section 16, Open Issues**: "**Node and Edge Ordering**. The intent in Cgraph’s design was to eventually support user-defined node and edge set ordering, overriding the default (which is object creation timestamp order)."

In my initial implementation, the ***agwrite()*** function did not traverse the **out-edges** of my application's parse trees in edge-creation order in some cases, so the visualization did not always correspond to the left-to-right parse of the input sentence.

Inspecting the ***cgraph*** implementation, I found that the code for the edge compare function ***agedgeseqcmpf()*** in ***edge.c***, used when adding a new **out-edge**, orders the edges by creation timestamp of the **out-edge head node** and not the **out-edge** itself (if both **out-edges** have the same **head node**, the **out-edges** are ordered by edge-creation order).

I was able to work-around this in my application by replacing the built-in edge compare function. Attached [cgraph_edge_order.c](/uploads/7616f94ce2e48bb77d900e251fb029eb/cgraph_edge_order.c) is a trivial sample application that demonstrates the before and after result.

While it isn't clear to me why ***agedgeseqcmpf()*** is written as it is, it has been that way since ***edge.c*** was first added to the [repository](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/), so it must have some design rationale.

summary: No Windows Registry Entry
description: Graphviz2.38 on Windows 7 does not make an entry to the registry on install.  This makes other software, such as Python scripts, unable to find the graphviz executable on the system.

summary: Crash in colorList parsing
description:
graphviz 2.40.1-15 (Arch linux)

dot file `min-color-crash.dot`:
```dot
digraph {
  layout=dot

  A [fillcolor="yellow;blue" style="filled"]
}
```

```bash
$ dot min-color-crash.dot
Error: Illegal length value in "yellow;blue" color attribute Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#k:colorList

The above dot file is invalid (`fillcolor` should be `yellow:blue`), but it took considerable time to find:
- the difference between `:` and `;` is subtle, both characters can be present in the colorList
- the error message is unhelpful for users first specifying colorList (`invalid length: "blue"` would have helped more)
- the crash is still unexpected (it made the process longer to find the problem with the dot file)

Hey. I am trying to plot decision tree from an XGB Model on Databricks. I have installed and imported the Graphviz library on Databricks. However, I am not sure how to implement the path executables on Spark. Is there any work around for this ? 

PS : I have the same code running on my local machine where it works just fine since I have the standalone Graphiz installed and path has been provided.

summary: Question: how to draw edges between rectangles of a record-styled shape
description:
I would appreciate it if someone could explain how to draw edges between rectangles of nodes of record shape using graphviz as a library. What I want to do would look like this. ![Screenshot_2019-05-15-02-54-30-719_com.google.android.apps.docs](/uploads/881bff3188df0baa6e36d4378e7ece3a/Screenshot_2019-05-15-02-54-30-719_com.google.android.apps.docs.png)

EDIT:
Figured this out, sorry for opening an issue. Set attribute **shape** of a node to **record**, then give it a layout with syntax described here https://graphviz.gitlab.io/_pages/doc/info/shapes.html#record, create an edge between nodes with **agedge** function and set its **headport** / **tailport** to be the ids of rectangles you want to link.

summary: Putting <> in label of an HTML table
description:
I'm using tablels in GraphViz, and need to include `<>` symbols in the label. A regular table is fine: a_node [ shape=plaintext; label=<
/user1
/user2
/...
/userN
> ]; But when I try changing the last cell to contain the `<>` as part of its HTML label, GV doesn't like it: a_node [ shape=plaintext; label=<
/user1
/user2
/...
/user
> ]; "Error: Unknown HTML element on line 6. Not really a surprise, the parser is trying to interpret the `` as a HTML. Double quotes don't help. Single quotes don't help. Back quotes don't help. Escaping the <> with a backslash gives the same error as ASCII or HTML codes below. OK... ASCII Codes it is. a_node [ shape=plaintext; label=<
/user1
/user2
/...
/user<N>
> ]; Error: not well-formed (invalid token) in line 6 I tried various combinations here... adding spaces, pruning the leading 0, as I expected they failed consistently. OK... HTML codes then. a_node [ shape=plaintext; label=<
/user1
/user2
/...
/user< N >
> ]; Error: not well-formed (invalid token) in line 6 My search in the documentation didn't turn anything up, but I'd not bet that the search string didn't get munged. My search on stackoverflow didn't turn up anything -probably the closest was general string formatting https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24859937/format-string-in-graphviz A wider web search didn't find what I was after. I'm using Graphviz 3.28 on Windows. Anyone have a suggestion?

summary: difficulties accessing GraphViz.app on MacOS
description:
Let me start by saying - thanks for your efforts in maintaining this great piece of software.

It appears that the option homebrew option --with-app has been erased.  i.e. brew install graphviz --with-app now does not work, as per [this homebrew issue](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/issues/31510)

This makes it very difficult for the majority of MacOS users to access the GraphViz.app (relatively few people have MacPorts comparatively, nor I could not find a location to download an installer.)  

I guess some of the possible resolutions would be:

1) include GraphViz.app in the default homebrew install;

2) create an additional graphviz-app homebrew either package or cask, which contains GraphViz.App;

3) allow people to download a build of the application from somewhere.

The only way it seems one can now access it is to install macports, or perhaps build it from source.  

I had a look and I do see other issues also somewhat related to this, #1469 and !1309

summary: Warning: darkred is not a known color?
description:
I am generating DOT files from graph data pulled from a database. At runtime, the user can choose different colors from a drop-down list for different graph elements. For example, articulation nodes can be represented differently than normal nodes, or bridge edges can be shown in a special color.

Since I am developing the GUI application with Qt, I have a list containing the built-in global color names which Qt supports, such as "darkRed". Additionally, the user can choose a custom color from the entire RGB gamut which returns a coded RGB name like "#ffe0e0" for light red, for example. When I use the coded RGB value directly in the DOT file, it works as expected (it has to be quoted, though).

But GraphViz also supports some named colors. Unfortunately, there is no obvious 1-to-1 correlation except for the primary colors (red, green, blue) and complements. I saw that there is a source file called "color_names" in graphviz/lib/common with several hundred named colors, some of which appear to be quite exotic ("chocolate" or "midnightblue", for example). The color "darkred" appears there, but when I use this (e.g.) "fillcolor=darkred", the above warning appears.

How can I determine at runtime which named colors are supported by the user's GraphViz installation? (I realize there is also the "colorscheme" parameter, but the user might not have a particular colorscheme installed). I can play it safe by always using an RGB name, but it would be nice not to have to do that.

Looks like cgraph is documented [here](https://graphviz.gitlab.io/_pages/pdf/cgraph.pdf) (there are many types defined there that start with `ag` though).

summary: Help understanding the parsing rules
description:
I'm currently working on implementing a parser for Dot in Rust.
I got most of the parser working using a [PEG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing_expression_grammar) based parser-combinator set-up. I've been consulting your language specification [here](https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/lang.html)

I ran into one issue that I need some help with.  
Given a graph like this:

```dot
graph {
    { rank=same; a, b, c }
}
```

What are the tokens `a`, `b`, `c`?  
Initially, I thought they were part of a `node_stmt` and they are individual `node_id`s.  
But, as per the specification, each `stmt` has to be separated by a `;` and not `,`.

Can someone help me demystify this?

Thanks in advance!

The question would be, how to section the subgraphs off while preserving (some) of the structure?

summary: [Dotty] Cannot move a node more than once
description:
I have a dot file that was generated by a script, so the layout of the nodes is disorganized, all nodes left to right with edges drawn over top of several nodes. It's virtually unreadable. I want to rearrange the nodes but this is where I'm having difficulties.

When I move a node, it works fine and all of the edges from other nodes are snapped to it properly, but if I "put the node down" in a particular place on the "canvas", it doesn't actually pick up and move so it seems to be stuck in the new location forever and cannot be moved a second time. This makes rearranging my graph next to impossible.

Steps to reproduce:
* Open a dot file using dotty with several nodes and interconnected edges.
* Left-click and hold on a node, move it, let go of left-button. Node is now located where dropped.
* Left-click and hold on the same node and attempt to move it. What is drawn instead is an oval where the cursor is when the button is released.
* Node moved in step 2 is permanently stuck in place.

Version information:

`[localhost]$ dotty -V`

`dotty version 96c (09-24-96)`

`lefty version 10 Mar 2005`

`graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)`

summary: Styles for GraphViz
Suggestion: support a "fontweight" attribute
description:
It seems to be impossible to specify font weights and styles in the DOT language except by mangling the **fontname** attribute value. If the renderer can grok the fontname, e.g. fontname="Times-Bold", it will export **font-family="Times,serif" font-weight=600"** in SVG files, for example, and it will be correctly rendered. But there is no way to know for which fonts this will actually work. And if you write the font family name out entirely, e.g. fontname="Times New Roman-Bold", it doesn't work (and the font family is not correctly rendered, either). One could say that this is somewhat less than orthogonal.

Why can't we simply write fontname="Times New Roman" (or any other name with spaces, of which there are quite a few) and fontweight="bold" (or alternatively fontweight=700)?

How much effort would it take to implement this?

summary: Command line to build gv_perl is missing PERL_INCLUDES
description:
gv_perl.cpp includes "EXTERN.h" and therefore the compiler must be able to find the location of files installed with perl.  Although PERL_INCLUDES is defined during configuration to point to the correct place, it is not included in the set of CPPFLAGS used to compile gv_perl.  Consequently, the compilation fails with a 'file not found' error.  The attached patch simply adds PERL_INCLUDES to the correct CPPFLAGS and fixes the problem.

[patch-tclpkg_gv_Makefile.in.patch](/uploads/6b98c37d03a9d40561e772f86172af93/patch-tclpkg_gv_Makefile.in.patch)

summary: Get Graph from One Node Downward
Heap Out-Of-Bounds Memory Access (129244780)
description:
Hello graphviz team,

As part of our fuzzing efforts at Google, we have identified an issue affecting
graphviz (tested with revision * master 372085ccbc1b170c8efb5665ee09be41e9eaa0b3).

To reproduce, we are attaching a Dockerfile which compiles the project with
LLVM, taking advantage of the sanitizers that it offers. More information about
how to use the attached Dockerfile can be found here:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/

Instructions:
[artifacts_129244780.zip](/uploads/5e56d78e9ca6817899af95483cc6e22d/artifacts_129244780.zip)
```
unzip artifacts_129244780.zip

summary: TypeError if charset is in handle of dot file

Error appears If charset is in dot file. \
C-function agget (from line176 from agraph.py) returns bytes, but it must be string. \
And C-func agattrdefval (from line 1833) returns bytes too. \
And I think the same returning is of C-func agattrdefval from line 1741. \
![Снимок_экрана_от_2019-08-23_22-29-29](/uploads/291baaddddc5ae5d6677512d721a6860/Снимок_экрана_от_2019-08-23_22-29-29.png)

summary: Patch to add hyperlinks / table of contents in Agraph.tex and libguide.tex
description:
The Cgraph Tutorial and the library guide have no hyperlinks or table of content.  The attached patch adds those, but requires some extra latex packages.

[documentation-hyperlinks.patch](/uploads/d7b51fe618af6df6bbaeac48b435dbf8/documentation-hyperlinks.patch)

summary: ttdot – a tree-specific preprocessor for graphviz
description:
Do you use graphviz for diagramming rooted trees? Or perhaps specifically binary trees?

I'd like to announce that I have created a simple preprocessor for graphviz, accompanied by a command script for Linux and its equivalent for MS Windows, to let me input and visualize rooted trees more conveniently and diversely. I imagine that it can be of help to other users of graphviz, so I post here.

For details please see this page: http://www.math.bas.bg/bantchev/ttdot/ttdot.html .

The program is in source code (C++), so you will need to compile it in order to run it.

If you do use the program, please let me know if you find errors or serious flows in it (or the script), or if you have any suggestions regarding the program and its use.

summary: Children order gets reversed with subgraph
Cannot install onto Mac OSX (really!)
description:
Following *all* installation instructions from graphviz.org and then attempting to run 'dot', I get the following error: 

pyenv: dot: command not found

The `dot' command exists in these Python versions:
  anaconda3-5.1.0

Yes I use 'pyenv' for version management, but this should not matter. I want to be able to use graphviz in *any* version of Python that I'm using. Currently, I'm using 3.6.4. 

In addition, I have:

- upgraded brew
- upgraded pip
- uninstall/reinstall graphviz
- unlink/relink graphviz
- removing dot* files out of ~/.pyenv/shims/
- Hand/hardcoded dot files in ~/.pyenv/shims/

The next thing will be to remove 'pyenv' entirely?

summary: tailport=c is not working
arrowtail=dot is not working
Can attributes be removed with GVPR
description:
Using **gvpr** I can add new attributes and change attribute values (including to an empty string), but is there a way to remove an object's attribute?  
Why?  This would allow me to create temporary attributes and then delete them when I was finished.

summary: Broken symlinks for _gv.so with PYTHON2/PYTHON3
description:
Hi, I'm using Arch Linux and I noticed two broken symlinks after upgrading graphviz to 2.42.1-1:
- /usr/lib/graphviz/python2/_gv.so is symlinked to libgv_python.so;
- /usr/lib/graphviz/python3/_gv.so is symlinked to libgv_python.so.

If I'm reading the code correctly I think this is due to incorrect linking in [Makefile.am](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/blob/master/tclpkg/gv/Makefile.am). I've attached a patch to correct this.

Please note that I'm not a developer, and my patch might be incomplete (although I've tested it on Arch Linux against 2.42-1).

Regards

[gv-python.patch](/uploads/48cce26eccf0c496dcec53dbadc8e3cd/gv-python.patch)

summary: Graph flips ordering
Build from git has a dependency to libltdl-dev
description: Just ran across this: On Ubuntu, building graphviz from sources obtained using git also requires the package 'libltdl-dev', not just 'libtool'. Should be added to dependencies, as it would save others quite some time to figure it out.

summary: gvpr: line numbers in gvpr errors/warnings are incorrect
description:
line numbers in **gvpr** errors/warnings are inflated (greater then the actual line number).   
My guess is that some of the program lines are parsed more than once.  In **lib/gvpr/parse.c**, i believe **readc** is called either with "new" input (from the input program file) or with "previously parsed" input (from a buffer), causing lineno to be inflated.  
I believe this happens in **parseBracket** and maybe in **endString**.

(Debugging my buggy programs is hard enough, but an incorrect line number makes this gruesome:
```
gvpr: "./SwimLane6.gvpr", line 392: 
 -- syntax error
```
)

summary: Expired SSL certificate
description: Heads up that your LetsEncrypt SSL certificate for https://graphviz.org expired about 30 minutes prior to this bug report

summary: Out-of-source build with LIBGD doesn't work
description:
Currently out-of-source build with LIBGD fails due to incorrectly set path to libgdtclft_C.la. I was able to fix this simply by replacing *$(top_srcdir)* with *$(top_builddir)* on the appropriate place in the *tclpkg/tcldot/Makefile.am* file.

I wanted to create a Pull/Merge request, however I have no idea how to do that here (my guess is that its disabled?) so patch is attached instead.

[tcldot-build.patch](/uploads/581904ab30a1fcff46aa00818dac4104/tcldot-build.patch)

thanks

I get the following error: "Format: "json" not recognized. Use one of: bmp canon cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot emf emfplus eps fig gd gd2 gif gv imap imap_np ismap jpe jpeg jpg metafile pdf pic plain plain-ext png pov ps ps2 svg svgz tif tiff tk vml vmlz vrml wbmp xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4"

Using the same file and command on my friends Macbook, I was able to produce the according JSON file.
Is JSON output not supported for windows 10 graphviz?

Thank you for your time

summary: Alignment Problem with german umlauts
description:
I encountered a edge case problem with german umlauts. When using html tag notation for label styling, a line containing an umlaut is not centered correctly. Escaping it with e.g. ü is not working either. The text is aligned correctly when using double-quote notation.

```dot 
digraph {
    node [shape=box]
    rankdir=LR
    //works without umlauts
    1 [label=<Test>]
    //does not work with html tag notation
    2 [label=<Prüfung>]
    3 [label=<Trübsal>]
    //works with double quotes
    4 [label="Lümmel"]

    1->2->3->4
}
```

![test.gv.svg](/uploads/c3ca5430eab612623876ac68c27348ea/test.gv.svg)

Is rendered not correctly.
graphviz version 2.38.0 (20140413.2041)

summary: Graphviz requires sbrk on FreeBSD
description: On FreeBSD sbrk is required, however arm64 and RISC-V don't implement this. Previously I was able to work around this by defining `_std_malloc`, however since 7beb94c8a2 This has been removed.

summary: SVG error for "g.transform.scale " in graphviz version 2.43
description:
Hello,

With such a dot file (and a graphsize ="1")
```
digraph "A->B" {
  "A" -> "B";
}
```

I noticed changes in the SVG created by graphviz between version 2.43 and 2.38 :

![image](/uploads/230b88ff51b2f7c98d87cbd14ca284e2/image.png)

This changes (in scale values apparently) unfortunately lead to error when vizualized in a jupyter notebook :

![image](/uploads/7653b9779696987b92a0c2be7309cf3f/image.png)

`s1` is generated by 2.43 and `s2` is generated by 2.38. As you understand, I would really prefer the version 2.38 :-) Apparently, the scale values have been inversed (1.61*0.62069 ~ 1)...

Because it worked before 2.43, I ask you first if the modification in the graphviz's SVG generator is not a bug (before asking to the other involved softs like `jupyter`)

Thanks!

summary: InvocationException: GraphViz's executables not found
description:
I cannot use graphviz, the same error always happens when I try to 

`graph.write_png('tree.png')`
All lines work just fine, until this one, which is the last, observe below.

Working in Windows 10.
Virtual Environment: 
Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 17:13:21) [MSC v.1915 64 bit (AMD64)] :: Anaconda custom (64-bit) on win32

I installed graphviz into this virtual env:
Successfully installed graphviz-0.13


I tried using MANY different examples from online, here is one:
```
# by vrutti-tanna import pydotplus from sklearn.datasets import load_iris from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43535863/invocationexception-graphvizs-executables-not-found
import pydotplus
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn import tree
import collections

# Data Collection
X = [ [180, 15,0],     
      [177, 42,0],
      [136, 35,1],
      [174, 65,0],
      [141, 28,1]]

Y = ['man', 'woman', 'woman', 'man', 'woman']    

data_feature_names = [ 'height', 'hair length', 'voice pitch' ]

# Training
clf = tree.DecisionTreeClassifier()
clf = clf.fit(X,Y)
# Visualize data
dot_data = tree.export_graphviz(clf,
                                feature_names=data_feature_names,
                                out_file=None,
                                filled=True,
                                rounded=True)
graph = pydotplus.graph_from_dot_data(dot_data)

colors = ('turquoise', 'orange')
edges = collections.defaultdict(list)

for edge in graph.get_edge_list():
    edges[edge.get_source()].append(int(edge.get_destination()))

for edge in edges:
    edges[edge].sort()    
    for i in range(2):
        dest = graph.get_node(str(edges[edge][i]))[0]
        dest.set_fillcolor(colors[i])

graph.write_png('tree.png')
```
InvocationException: GraphViz's executables not found

Not solved by restarting Spyder, not solved by restarting PC.
Not solved by this https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44351889/invocationexception-graphvizs-executables-not-found-python

summary: Alignment of record nodes
description:
Why does `dot` not align horisontally the two record nodes
in the following simple graph:

    digraph G {
    node[shape=record]
    dpi = 160
    rankdir = LR

    BT[label="<a>A|<b>B|C"]

    TR[label="<a>A|<b>B"]

    BT:a -> TR:a
    BT:b -> TR:b

    }

I expected the cells `A` and `B` in `BT` and `TR` to be perfeclty
aligned and both the edges to be perfectly horisontal, but
`dot` has decided otherwise.  Why?

![test](/uploads/f44ef9076cd57232561b12dd5bc4fef9/test.png)

As you see, the edge between the `B` cells is slightly skewed, and the top of the right record is slighly lower than the top of the left one.

summary: CMake build does not work on MacOS
description:
This is a duplicate of issue #1456 which was closed without resolving the underlying issue.

When doing a CMake build on MacOS, the linking stage for gvc produces a lot of linking errors:

~~~
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
  "_CL_type", referenced from:
      _graph_init in libcommon.a(input.c.o)
  "_CmdName", referenced from:
      _dotneato_usage in libcommon.a(input.c.o)
      _dotneato_args_initialize in libcommon.a(input.c.o)
  "_Concentrate", referenced from:
      _graph_init in libcommon.a(input.c.o)
  "_E_activefillcolor", referenced from:
      _emit_edge_graphics in libcommon.a(emit.c.o)
  "_E_activepencolor", referenced from:
      _emit_edge_graphics in libcommon.a(emit.c.o)
  "_E_arrowhead", referenced from:
      _graph_init in libcommon.a(input.c.o)
      _arrow_flags in libcommon.a(arrows.c.o)
~~~

etc etc…   (a complete list of failures can be found in https://pastebin.com/EZnckWYi)

summary: Dot is not producing deterministic output for SVG files
make subgraph areas not overlap
description:
Hi,

I want to display a network consisting of data centers and carrier links in between. Unfortunately, instead of laying out the nodes within the cluster subgraphs and afterwards layouting the subgraphs and the inter-subgraph links, neato layouts the whole graph first and then afterwards draws the areas around the sugraphs.

This results in overlapping subgraphs.

How can I make the subgraphs not overlap.

Also, it would be nice if I could roughly position the subgraphs.

Any help or pointer is appreciated.

H.

summary: regression: dot pack/packmode removes edge labels when there are disconnected subgraphs

graphviz commands should accept usual --help and --version program arguments.
description:
See also [this](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/a/307472/40065) for a detailed argumentation.

On my Linux Debian/Sid with its `graphviz 2.42.2-3` package, I am getting

% `dot --help` giving `Error: dot: option -- unrecognized`

and

% `dot --version` giving `Error: dot: option -- unrecognized`

and this is a bit annoying. I would be happy to be able to code shell scripts testing that the installed `dot` executable is recent enough (or think of [autoconf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoconf) -generated `configure` scripts).

summary: Number of URLs in man pages are dead
description:
All manual pages (like dot(1)), refer to few URLs that doesn't exist anymore
(graphviz homepage was restructured some time ago).

```
http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs
http://www.graphviz.org/content/output-formats
http://www.graphviz.org/content/dot-language
http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs#kcolor
http://www.graphviz.org/con‐tent/color-names
http://www.graphviz.org/content/node-shapes#html
http://www.graphviz.org/content/node-shapes.
https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/command.html  (this one works)
http://www.graphviz.org/Documentation.php
http://www.graphviz.org/pdf/dotguide.pdf
http://www.graphviz.org/pdf/neatogu‐ide.pdf
```

Also all of these links should be https, not http.


I personally think that the graphviz.org server should install proper routes / redirects, so old manuals keep pointing correctly.

But Documentation.php link can be probably improved, and http -> https should be fixed in the manual page itself.

summary: htmltable.c:1761: pos_html_tbl: assertion delx >= 0, when using nested fixedsize table
description:
Reported originally at https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=944297 , reporting here for extra visibility. Attached `dot` graphs lead to html table layout assertion failure. They are pretty minimized already. ``` $ dot -Tpng:cairo:cairo crashes_graphviz.dot Warning: cell size too small for content dot: htmltable.c:1761: pos_html_tbl: Assertion `delx >= 0' failed. Aborted $ ``` Input: ```dot // dot -Tpng:cairo:cairo crashes_graphviz.dot digraph stuff { green [shape=plaintext, label=<
1
>]; } ``` [crashes_graphviz.dot](/uploads/d3c0fdf46ace29142bd366ad3e19bf71/crashes_graphviz.dot) It does happen for all output types essentially (like `-Tdot`, `-Tplain` and `-Tpng`). This is using Debian/GNU Linux testing and unstable, on amd64, graphviz package version 2.42.2-3 (but `dot -v` says to me `graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)`). Similar more complex example with a bit different error message related to `dely >= 0` assertion failure. ``` $ dot -Tdot ./gen-acc-graphviz-crash-min.dot Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content Warning: cell size too small for content dot: htmltable.c:1764: pos_html_tbl: Assertion `dely >= 0' failed. Aborted $ ``` [gen-acc-graphviz-crash-min.dot](/uploads/3a714c6bb270372d6d7e00f622fc97d8/gen-acc-graphviz-crash-min.dot)

summary: Poor edge routing and avoidable intersections of common source edges in dot
description:
Don't get me wrong, graphviz and `dot` are amazing, and I have been using them for more than 15 years now. So thank you a lot for this!

dot usually produces perfect or close to perfect results, but sometimes it does really bizarre things that are known to be an issue, and even mentioned in the man page.

```
CAVEATS
       Edge splines can overlap unintentionally.
```


This happens to polylines too (I assume polylines are just quantized splines internally).

This happens even for reasonably small non-planar DAGs and sometimes for fully upward planar graphs too.

Apologizes for the big size of the original: 6376 x 2508

![output-space-science-pack-optimized-annotated](/uploads/419946c03e65a9869db61a3076b046da/output-space-science-pack-optimized-annotated.png)

I think fixing this would significantly improve the quality of graphviz graphs. The same happens for much simpler graph (i.e. without ports or custom styles).

My current workaround is to do `dot -Tplain-ext` layout with `polylines` and do postprocessing on all the edges manually to find unnecessary intersection of common source edges, and collapse into multi edges sometimes. It adds a lot of the extra complexity to my program tho of course.

I feel that maybe it could be fixed reasonably easy with some constrains on tangents of splines as they exit/enter the node? But I do not want necessarily constrain them to be to be constant 90 degree. Fanning them out gently would be preferable, just like it is doing it now, just in well ... correct order.

Graphviz 2.42.2-3 on Debian GNU/Linux testing, amd64.

summary: "Lost edge" error
Unstable dot node layout quality
description: I do have a digraph layouted down automatically by dot, with a bit of help from my generation program to try to find optimal arrangement of ports to minimise edge crossings. The best I could achieve is this, with 27 crossings: ![output-white-27-polylines-annotated](/uploads/a6108c90d247f1436145aaf774dde25e/output-white-27-polylines-annotated.png) [output-white-27.dot](/uploads/e1126732a84a88edd76b6b4472a99927/output-white-27.dot) If you look closely at the nodes at the right, most specifically a big node with 6 inputs, a "Satellite", and smaller one with 3 inputs, a "Rocket part" , you would probably say, to just flip two obviously suboptimal inputs to it: Flip (reorder ports) radar and solar_panel inputs to Satellite, and flip rocket_fuel and rocket_control_unit inputs to rocket_part and you will instantly go down to 25 crossings. Well, unfortunately it doesn't work. It actually produces completely different layout, and with way more crossings, 49 actually, not less! ![output-white-27-fix-atempt-annotated](/uploads/07e41001d13b29c9274aa4f6e1ce6442/output-white-27-fix-atempt-annotated.png) [output-white-27-fix-atempt.dot](/uploads/9d16695cf457285e60662990ee492b56/output-white-27-fix-atempt.dot) (This is exactly same input with just the above mentioned two changes to two nodes fixed. I didn't cound the edge crossings, just used what mincross is reporting in `dot -v`). ```diff --- output-white-27.dot 2019-11-11 02:57:37.000000000 +0000 +++ output-white-27-fix-atempt.dot 2019-11-11 02:51:39.000000000 +0000 @@ -44,10 +44,10 @@ processing_unit - radar - solar_panel + radar + accumulator rocket_fuel @@ -720,9 +720,9 @@ low_density_structure - rocket_fuel - rocket_control_unit + + rocket_fuel ``` So, I am not sure what to do. I understand `dot` doesn't provide strong guarantees on edge crossings, but it was disappointing dot can't do it better, when it seems if could do it. My workaround if I don't find another way is probably to do a 2 pass layout, with first finding a layout (and order of ports) that minimizes numbers of crossings, then read the full layout back, fix the position of nodes, change order of ports, and the do layout again, but with positions of nodes constrained fully, so only edges are routed and splines / polylines drawn. Not a fun thing to do tho. PS. It is possible possible to improve number of crossings even below 25 in the initial graph, by introducing more ranks. Anytime an edge crosses over all inputs of a node, and there is less outputs than inputs (which is almost always the case for the graphs I work with here), it is sufficient to simply route edge behind the node, instead in front of a node to reduce number of edge crossings. The graph will be wider (less square), but it does in fact improve legibility a bit in some cases. With various tricks I can do 17 edge crossings, if I do layout manually, and still keep all edges direction left to right, at the expanse of some minor detours or widening the layout. And down to 16 with edge concentrators. (Using edge concentrators in the initial layout only removes one intersection, from 27 down to 26, by merging `electric_circuit -> {speed_module, processing_unit}` edges ). PS2. I do not want to manually lay out all these graphs because I have about 800 of these graphs.

summary: Representing a port channel for a network diagram
description:
I'm getting into making network diagrams using graphviz. I'm stumped on how to create a port channel (sometimes called etherchannel or lacp) where several network links are bonded together. Here's an [example](https://ipwithease.com/etherchannel-modes-pagp-lacp-and-on/160-etherchannel-modes-pagp-lacp-and-on-01/) of how it's drawn. 

Is there a way to create a circle or oval over multiple lines?

summary: Can't apply edge attributes to a single edge when using multiple edge syntax
description:
I'm using multiple edge syntax in order to simplify my graph specification. I would like to be able to make a specific edge red, but when I apply a color attribute it colors the node outline, not the edge:
```
digraph Test {
    A -> {
        B [color=red]
        C
    }
    B -> {
        C
        D
    }
}
```
![test](/uploads/d4470cc12509b2b0af57e1639006b42a/test.png)

I can color all the edges in a group red, like this:
```
    A -> {
        B
        C
    } [color=red]
```

Or I can color a single edge red by avoiding the use of multiple edge syntax:
```
    A -> B [color=red]
    A -> C
```

Is there a way to apply a color attribute to a single edge within a set of multiple edges?

summary: Rendered output differs between OS-platforms
description:
We are trying to figure out why the following dot file:
[jc.dot](/uploads/979cf2537469eea5f4ddeee314d14502/jc.dot)
Results in different outputs depending on the platform, that is used.

The dotfile is added as attachment, because I have found the code-formatting inappropriate.

Expected (Linux):
![expected](/uploads/3f24130aae96842ffe7638c09c4a329d/expected.png)

Unexpected (OSX High Sierra):
![unexpected](/uploads/3b1d88d1bad69b4f988a93d191437468/unexpected.png)

Specifically the **bold** and underline formatting is gone, in spite the dot-file declares it.

Version of **dot**s seem to match up between the systems:
- osx: *dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304)*
- linux: *dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (0)*

The font may be system specific based on something, but could this be system dependent how the formatting gets rendered? The same experience is reported when creating SVG instead of png.

Any of your inputs would be appreciated!

[Just a cross reference](https://github.com/BurntSushi/erd/issues/62)

summary: Dot-generated SVG is blank (or cropped) when "size" is small
description:
Hi,

I'm not sure if this is a bug of `dot` program. We have a large generated dot file, but historically its "size" was set to `(16,16)` (I believe the unit is inch) and it worked for many years to generate a clickable SVG picture (then embedded into a HTML).

A month ago, maybe after the number of nodes go beyond a certain number, suddenly the HTML became blank, so was the SVG picture. I tried to increase the "size", and it only shows the full picture at `(100,100)` (or larger), then it's too big in the HTML, until I put `style="width: 100%;"` to further scale it down.

Could you please take a look at the related files and confirm if it's a misuse of parameters or a bug of `dot` itself?

Regards,

Chun Tian

summary: Graphviz libraries with windows
Add label rotate for edgelabel, headlabel and taillabel
description:
Can we add support for rotating the labels to be parallel to the edges. Currently all labels are horizontal. The `labelangle` only considers where to place the label. Not the angle of the text. While creating network diagrams, I am trying to add both ends of the interface as head/tail label. Since a node can have multiple interfaces, the labels overlap sometimes.

Comparing to `dot2tex` (to explain this better), the dot2tex supports `lblstyle="above, slopped"` option which can rotate the edgelabel. This still does not rotate the head/tail label.

summary: Neato output is non-deterministic
[feature suggestion] Allow edge ordering performed by both "in" and "out" directions: add "both" to the "ordering" attribute
description:
I use graphviz to draw a computation graph. There are functions that generally accept several inputs and produce several outputs. When shown visually, order of both outputs and inputs is important because showing the edges comimg in and out of nodes in a wrong order is confusing and doesn't match the entity being represented.

Documentation (https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#d:ordering) implies that the "outgoing" attribute can be ether "in" or "out". I suggest to add "both" such that a computation graph described above can be naturally represented.

There is a corner case when Node1 produces Edge1 and Edge2, but Node2 consumes Edge2 and Edge1, in that order. A case like this would be impossible to represent with "Node1 -> Node2" syntax. This needs to be dealt with somehow, but this problem is the problem of the DOT syntax, not of the underlying directed graph that it describes.

summary: Using layerselect to produce a single layer fails for many output formats
description:
The FAQ says:  
> The graph can have a layerselect attribute, which specifies which layers should be emitted. The value uses the same concrete syntax as the layer attribute.
> 
> At present, the output of multiple layers into a single output file is only available in PostScript. However, the layerselect attribute can be used to select a single layer for output in any format.

For most output formats, **layerselect=1** succeeds, but results in a *Segmentation fault* for subsequent layers.  For example:  
```
z=png;for x in 1 2 3 4 5 ;do echo $x; /bin/dot -Glayerselect=$x -T$z layer.gv >/tmp/$x.$z;done
1
2
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
3
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
4
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
5
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Interestingly, things succeed for **svg** and **xdot**, but not **gif** or **dot**

summary: GraphViz ignores dpi set in the graph, and uses a hard-coded value of 72 dpi
description:
I am looking into sizing issues. I first compute node boxes based on the sizes of texts that I intend to draw there based on actually used fonts and screen's real DPI. I set this DPI as a "dpi" attribute of the graph, but GraphViz seems to ignore this DPI, and returns values in inches computed based on the 72 dpi. This causes size mismatches.

GraphViz should use the DPI value supplied as a graph attribute.

The documentation here also mentions this hard-coded DPI value: https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html

summary: GraphViz loses memory when called through the CGraph API
description:
In my code I construct the graph with ```agopen``` https://github.com/yurivict/nn-insight/blob/master/graphviz-cgraph.cpp#L52, then render it with ```gvLayout``` https://github.com/yurivict/nn-insight/blob/master/graphviz-cgraph.cpp#L119, then destroy it with ```agclose``` https://github.com/yurivict/nn-insight/blob/master/graphviz-cgraph.cpp#L57.

Memory profile at program exit shows that the ```render``` function lost memory: https://people.freebsd.org/~yuri/profile-graphviz-loses-memory.pdf With every new graph the amount of lost memory goes up.


You don't deallocate something.

summary: Error, r: C stack usage is too close to the limit, Rgraphviz, neato
description:
I am trying to do an analysis of a three-way contingency table, and create a graphical representation of a model, showing nodes and edges, as depicted in the picture.

The problems stems from a paper on Graphical Models, by David Edwards (2011)

R produce the error: "Error: C stack usage 15924320 is too close to the limit"

I've tried updating the packages and running R as administrator.

library("gRbase")
library("gRim")
library("Rgraphviz")

liz.sat <- dmod(~.^., data = lizard)
liz.1 <- backward(liz.sat, details = 3, step = 1)
liz.1
liz.2 <- backward(liz.1, details = 3, step = 1)
liz.2
plot(liz.2, "neato", sep=0.1 )
plot(liz.2, "neato", sep=0.1 ) Error: C stack usage 15924320 is too close to the limit

plot(liz.2, "neato")

I hope someone has a neat solution to my problem. Thanks

It seems the problem is well known. A guide has been made containing possible solutions to how to solve the problem, however not being skilled enough I will appreciate if someone can make it clearer how to perform the steps in the solution. https://www.graphviz.org/pdf/neatoguide.pdf

i want to draw graphs with dot language as in the joined file ![graphs](/uploads/7beabdc9614cadb13a869794a5b6e89d/graphs.png)

summary: Is it safe to have the bin folder from graphviz 3.28 in company environment? Do we see any possible conflict here?

summary: Graphviz library symmetry in undirected graphs
urls for image
description:
Feature request:

```
digraph tools  {
  graphviz [  label="" tooltip="graphviz" image="http://wiki.bitplan.com/images/b/b1/GraphVizLogo.png" ]
}
```

should work out of the box to avoid code like https://github.com/wikimedia/mediawiki-extensions-GraphViz/blob/master/includes/GraphViz.php#L860

summary: Missing TAG for v2.43.3?
description: The changelog says the latest stable is 2.43.3, but there is no corresponding tag?

summary: xdot draw commands
description:
Are there any batch (non-interactive) programs in the Graphviz package that use the **xdot** **draw** commands as input to produce a graph drawing?  
Stated another way: is there anyway to tweak the **draw** commands in an **xdot** file to modify the result drawing?

summary: orientation attribute question/suggestion
description:
The documentation says: *Angle, in degrees, used to rotate polygon node shapes.*   
I assumed it would be rotated around the center of the node.  It is not.  Non-square rectangles become parallelograms. [My guess is that it is rotated around the origin (0,0) of the graph.]  
I think the documentation should be enhanced to make cleat that rotation is not around the center of the node.
![orientation5](/uploads/9ae2f0473096a3ad66e8f21fb18b074a/orientation5.png)

summary: documentation for skew attribute is incomplete
description:
The documentation for the **skew** attribute is correct, but doesn't seem complete.  [The **Drawing graphs with dot** document seems to have the most information.]  But e.g. how does .2 differ from 2.?  What are the units or what is the algorithm?  Some skew values seem to stay with the **width** while others cause the node to exceed the **width**.  
![skew2](/uploads/16a47b8f3ef8cb759cefc0f49809f2eb/skew2.png)

is this temporary? is there a way to help to resurect such an helpful and welcoming community ?

summary: color and background-color  of the website
description: as you defined the color of the font of the graphviz.org to #262626, you might define a font color as well so people who set dark backgrounds by default would be able to read the text. a better solution would be to remove the color of the font.

summary: make the label more readable when image overlap
description:
hello,

http://mc.aude.re/help/example.svg was generated with http://mc.aude.re/help/example.dot. the firewall looks perfect but the mail server has its label over the image.

i would like to move the label to the bottom of the image or add a background to it so it will be read easily again. i failed on the two strategies. any help would be appreciated.

thanks

graphviz (tested with revision * master e55af3cce23ddcdeefb42b75d115ee23e86e456b).

To reproduce, we are attaching a Dockerfile which compiles the project with
LLVM, taking advantage of the sanitizers that it offers. More information about
how to use the attached Dockerfile can be found here:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/

Instructions:
* `unzip artifacts_122575825.zip`
* `docker build --build-arg SANITIZER=address --tag=autofuzz-graphviz-122575825 autofuzz_122575825`
* `docker run --entrypoint /fuzzing/repro.sh --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_122575825/8394a7f7-741a-4863-b1a4-deb2c4ab1620:/tmp/poc autofuzz-graphviz-122575825 "" /tmp/poc`
