summary: Nested/Indirect Elements Result in Direct Linkages?
How to copy node's tooltip to clipboard
description:
Hi,
I am constructing some huge graphs like below.

![node_example](/uploads/cd141bfe655c8fe99f3c1613890d358c/node_example.png)

Each node has some information and I cannot represent them in the node explicitly because of readability.
So, I just decided to let them in nodes' tooltip. ( mouseover, then text appears )
However, I cannot find the way to copy that tooltip to clipboard.
I Want to copy it to clipboard by clicking node.
Can you tell me how to make it please?
Is there any attributes that make this thing happen?

I am using this kind of function to make nodes in python.
```python
G.add_node(node_name, tooltip='something important')
```

summary: SUBSTRING(),CHARINDEX() help
description:
Nous avons la chaine suivante de caracteres dans une cellule excel : OUI,NON 
je veux extraire OUI et extraire NON . J'ai testé avec le code suivant dans une requete SQL: 
SELECT [NODE_ID]   as [Item],[TO_NAME] as [Label], SUBSTR([TO_NAME],CHARINDEX(',', [TO_NAME]) - 1) as [Outside Label]  
FROM [OCAP$]
WHERE [ECAP_NAME] = 'TT_TH_SINGLE_R2R'  AND [TO_NAME] LIKE '%,%'

Dans l'excel Item, Label et OutsideLabel sont des colonnes differentes.

summary: XML errors in generated SVG when URL attribute contains ampersand (&)
description:
The following DOT source renders an incorrect SVG:
```
graph {
    "Google Graphviz" [URL="https://www.google.com/search?q=graphviz&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8"]
}
```
If the SVG is viewed with e.g. Firefox, the following error message is generated:
```
XML Parsing Error: not well-formed
Location: file:///home/magjac/graphviz-web-static/Gallery/undirected/tmp0.svg
Line Number 15, Column 57:
<g id="a_node1"><a xlink:href="index.php?sec=estado&sec2=operation/agentes/ver_agente&id_agente=300" xlink:title="ajax.php?page=operation/agentes/ver_agente&get_agent_status_tooltip=1&id_agent=300">
--------------------------------------------------------^
```
The reason is that `&` characters in the `xlink:href` attribute are not escaped as `&`.

The fdp engine sporadically generates edges overlapping node without changed DOT source
How to minimize the layout area when rank is used? [help wanted]
description:
I am working on visualization of a COVID-19 infection route tree in my resident region.![Digraph.gv](/uploads/27f8efe58a1a782ba406d6894370c83a/Digraph.gv.png)

To align daily new reported cases vertically, I use `rank`. For example, cases 218 to 221, shown at the top-right corner of the graph, are placed at the same X position with "4/4" (April the 4th).

But the number of cases is increasing everyday unfortunately, and the graph is growing vertically everyday accordingly.

I would like to keep graph height as small as possible and I would like to know how to relocate new cases at the bottom. Could anyone please tell me how to do it?

I made this graph by using the `graphvis` module for Python. The generated DOT code is here.
```

	graph [newrank=1 rankdir=LR]
	node [fontname="Hiragino UD Sans F StdN" fontsize=18]
	edge [arrowhead=vee arrowsize=0.5]

summary: (GVEdit) Saving output requires accepting settings
description: GVEdit 1.0.2 for Graphviz 2.38.0 on Windows 10 doesn't save the output graphic in a file unless the user has accepted the settings before in that session.

summary: fatal error: 'Python.h' file not found compiling source on macos
description:
I tried to compile graphviz 2.42.4 from source using directions from this article:

https://medium.com/@scrossoracle/building-graphviz-from-source-on-macos-b6a846d73949

Code was taken from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/releases/2.42.4

I'm using macOS Catalina 10.14.4

Everything worked fine until running make, when I got this error:

```
CXX libgv_python3_la-gv_python3.lo
gv_python3.cpp:178:11: fatal error: 'Python.h' file not found
# include <Python.h>
 ^~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
make[4]: *** [libgv_python3_la-gv_python3.lo] Error 1
```

it looks like python3 headers are missing, but actually Python3 is already installed (using brew install python3) and headers are located right where the Makefile has it configured:

```
/usr/local/Frameworks/Python.framework/Headers
```

I've also verified that Python3.h file is there (just in case). Changing the python include options in Makefile has not been successfull:

```
PYTHON3_INCLUDES = /usr/local/Frameworks/Python.framework/Headers

PYTHON_INCLUDES = /usr/local/Frameworks/Python.framework/Headers
```

It simply seems to be overlooking such settings …
Any help ???

summary: ClusterFsck: Core Dump in dot's cluster code
Problem to install RPM’s on Centos 6
description:
This issue is spawned from https://graphviz.discourse.group/t/problem-to-install-rpms-and-or-run-dot-on-centos-6/36

When doing `rpm --install --force /repo/Packages/development/centos/6/os/x86_64/graphviz-*.rpm`, error messages like t `/var/tmp/rpm-tmp.q2JL8v: line 1: /bin/dot: No such file or directory` are produced.

summary: 2.44.0 does not compile on macOS
description:
Since !1332, Graphviz no longer compiles on macOS.

```
PriorityQueue.c:14:10: fatal error: 'malloc.h' file not found
#include <malloc.h>
         ^~~~~~~~~~
```

The malloc.h header is non-standard and is deprecated. The standard header for malloc is stdlib.h.

I have verified the issue exists on macOS 10.13 with Xcode 10.1, 10.14 with Xcode 11.3.1 and 10.15 with Xcode 11.4.

summary: Graphviz version 64 bits for windows
description:
Dear Graphviz community,

First of all, many thanks for this wonderfull tool. I am using it for many purposes and it is very easy to use, fast and efficient.
I have currently linked graphviz to a C++ program to generate graphs.
My question is the following:
The program I am writing works perfectly fine with 32 bits version. However I would also like to create a 64 bits version.

**Is there a graphviz version for windows that is 64 bits?**

Many thanks for your answers.

Regards

summary: dot crashes in tight_subtree_search() with stack overflow
description:
Attach input file is fairly large. It causes a crash on dot.exe windows with the command line:
dot.exe -Tpdf -O cpa4

Running with debugger points to recursion stack overflow in function tight_subtree_search()
It should be possible to implement this function with a queue instead of recursive calls to resolve the issue.

summary: libgvc not safe to build with NDEBUG defined
Warning: Arrow type "8" unknown - ignoring in GVEdit
description:
## Steps to reproduce the error: I present a subset of code that reproduces the error: ``` digraph "ERD![notgood](/uploads/303c16ba21a66862850a4b24b92f724c/notgood.png)" { graph [rankdir = "LR"]; node [fontname="Tahoma", fontsize = "8", shape = "none"]; edge [fontname="Tahoma", fontsize = "8", arrowhead="crow", minlen=2]; #force tables to appear in a certain order as dot.exe can't figure out how to create a planar graph (when there's more than just these tables). {rank=same; tblAlbum} {rank=same; tblImage, trelRelated} #show the tables tblAlbum [label=<
tblAlbum
albumID
>]; tblImage [label=<
tblImage
imageID
albumID
>]; trelRelated [label=<
trelRelated
relID
imageID
albumID
relatedID
>]; #Show relationship between primary and foreign keys tblAlbum:pk_tblAlbum -> tblImage:fk_tblImage_tblAlbum; tblAlbum:pk_tblAlbum -> trelRelated:fk_trelRelated_tblAlbum; tblImage:pk_tblImage -> trelRelated:fk_trelRelated_tblImage; } #end ``` I ran the code in GVEdit version 1.02, Graphviz version: 2.38.0 ## Expected result 1. A graph that shows a crow arrowtype instead of no arrowtype next to imageID in trelRelated ## Actual result: 1. The following appears in the output console ``` Warning: Arrow type "8" unknown - ignoring Warning: Arrow type "8" unknown - ignoring ``` 2. A graph that shows no arrowType in one instance instead of a crow arrowType: ![notgood](/uploads/2e8ffbc4cd9afe2877221281394fb648/notgood.png) ## Other 1. More testing shows that removing the ranks or changing the font and font size changes the output to be correct. For example, change ``` edge [fontname="Tahoma", fontsize = "8", arrowhead="crow", minlen=2]; ``` to ``` edge [arrowhead="crow", minlen=2]; ``` ![better](/uploads/2c0590654eea3f39363f49ec9d3ef605/better.png) It seems to me that whether or not a font and size is specified for an edge, Graphviz should produce the same graph with respect to the arrowType. 2. Ideally, I would run the code with the latest version of Graphviz, but I am not clever enough to compile GVEdit.

summary: Investigate moving windows builds from AppVeyor to GitLab Windows
description:
This was announced recently:

https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2020/01/21/windows-shared-runner-beta/

AppVeyor is pretty slow, limiting free plans to one parallel job running at once - in practice this means it can take over half an hour for builds and tests to run on Windows.

But GitLab CI is free for Open Source projects like Graphviz, so we could run the jobs in parallel.

Today, the windows jobs don't run at pull-request time, only after merging (probably because they're so slow). It would be good to make them fast so they can run at pull-request time.

@magjac mentions at https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1345#note_338086371: 

> It's a pity that we currently don't run the Windows builds in the test stage before deploy because then it doesn't get run for merge requests. @ellson Can we can change this? Or don't you want to delay the deploy with the long Windows builds?

summary: Remove link to obsolete Windows version from docs and replace with permalink to latest official release
description:
https://graphviz.org/download/#windows says `Stable 2.38 Windows install packages` and leads to https://graphviz.gitlab.io/_pages/Download/Download_windows.html which also refers to version 2.38. While it's true that this is a version that *can* be downloaded and installed, the reader may be led to believe that it's latest version which it is not. It's actually [more than 6 years old](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/ChangeLog).

If possible, this should be replaced with a permalink to the latest "official" release. This is currently 2.44 and can be found through [this link](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ellson/graphviz-pl238/builds/32032002). This is however not a permalink.

If it's not possible to generate such a permalink, we should just remove the link and replace it with a description on how to find the latest official Windows releases or copy the releases to a place to which we *can* create such a permalink.

Info that might help:

* https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/1007
* https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/403

Reference:
* https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1704#note_338302112

description:

summary: MEMCPY bug?
description:
One of the things I came across in my recent changes was a `MEMCPY` macro, lib/sfio/sfhdr.h:736-747:

```c
/* note that MEMCPY advances the associated pointers */
#define MEMCPY(to,fr,n) \
	switch(n) \
	{ default : memcpy((void*)to,(void*)fr,n); to += n; fr += n; break; \
	  case  7 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  6 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  5 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  4 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  3 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  2 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	  case  1 : *to++ = *fr++; \
	}
```

Newer GCC has `-Wimplicit-fallthrough` enabled by default which causes all expansions of this macro to spray quite a lot of warning text. It seemed like a nice simple change to add `/* fallthrough */` comments to suppress this. However, modern compilers and libcs are capable of doing the micro-optimization in this macro by themselves, so why not simplify the whole macro I thought:

```diff
diff --git lib/sfio/sfhdr.h lib/sfio/sfhdr.h
index 7ebb4acce..265b69526 100644
--- lib/sfio/sfhdr.h
+++ lib/sfio/sfhdr.h
@@ -735,16 +735,7 @@ extern "C" {

 /* note that MEMCPY advances the associated pointers */
 #define MEMCPY(to,fr,n) \
-       switch(n) \
-       { default : memcpy((void*)to,(void*)fr,n); to += n; fr += n; break; \
-         case  7 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  6 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  5 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  4 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  3 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  2 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-         case  1 : *to++ = *fr++; \
-       }
+       do { memcpy((void*)to,(void*)fr,n); to += n; fr += n; } while (0)

     extern Sfextern_t _Sfextern;
     extern Sftab_t _Sftable;
```

However while doing this I noticed what I think is a subtle bug. This macro implicitly assumes its inputs are char pointers. Looking at the first call site I came across, this is not true, lib/gvmap/make_map.c:1895-1899:

```c
      int *grouping2;
      nzok0 = nzok = *nrandom - 1;/* points that are within tolerance of real or artificial points */
      grouping2 = MALLOC(sizeof(int)*(n + *nrandom));
      MEMCPY(grouping2, grouping, sizeof(int)*n);
      grouping = grouping2;
```

The inputs are int pointers here. So, e.g. on x86-64, the `MEMCPY` invocation steps the two pointers forwards by 4 times the numbers of bytes copied. This seems clearly incorrect. Am I misreading something?

summary: Neato's hier mode is broken since v2.44.0
description:
One of the regression tests trigger this bug, but since they don't run in CI yet because the reference data is not up-to-date, we haven't noticed. It is however possible to see if you eyeball the 135 generated output files and compare with the reference files (:cold_sweat:).

To reproduce:

```
neato -Tps -Gmode=hier -o tmp2.45-bug.ps rtest/graphs/mode.gv
```

Compare by:

```
evince tmp.ps rtest/linux.x86/mode_neato1.ps
```

The test uses postscript, but it's the same problem for e.g. SVG.

With v2.44.0:

![tmp2.45-bug.svg](/uploads/83c18150b0ca7c1a6be0221f311f2edb/tmp2.45-bug.svg)

With v2.42.4:

![tmp2.42.4.svg](/uploads/d0f7b448d3aaa76de0acf1964f2c517e/tmp2.42.4.svg)

The bug was introduced with the new `SGD`mode [here](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/443592f1e8950df88f6df9c71b60667c9ad98006#513a75c5e377cbcb0e6d26c26483b84e53ae93c8) and is fixed by:

```
diff --git a/lib/neatogen/neatoinit.c b/lib/neatogen/neatoinit.c
index 7d9e3c464..c2c36914e 100644
--- a/lib/neatogen/neatoinit.c
+++ b/lib/neatogen/neatoinit.c
@@ -1351,10 +1351,10 @@ neatoLayout(Agraph_t * mg, Agraph_t * g, int layoutMode, int layoutModel,
        MaxIter = atoi(str);
     else if (layoutMode == MODE_MAJOR)
        MaxIter = DFLT_ITERATIONS;
-    else if (layoutMode == MODE_KK)
-       MaxIter = 100 * agnnodes(g);
     else if (layoutMode == MODE_SGD)
        MaxIter = 30;
+    else
+       MaxIter = 100 * agnnodes(g);
 
     nG = scan_graph_mode(g, layoutMode);
     if ((nG < 2) || (MaxIter < 0))
```

summary: Support style="rounded,striped"
description:
When `shape=box`, `style=rounded` and `style=striped` work as expected, but `style="rounded,striped"` doesn't round corners.

Quick example:

```
digraph G {
eg[label=example shape=box style="rounded,striped" fillcolor="#00a803:#ffc905" fontcolor="#000000"]
}
```

summary: dot Makefile builds blank PDFs of man pages
description:
While testing something unrelated I noticed an incongruous "groff-Tps not found" in my build output. It seems 67a4546f95ae463db7cc3e6270d7fb32a848de7c accidentally removed some spaces in cmd/dot/Makefile.am making the groff commands there fail. This goes unnoticed because the command is piped into ps2pdf, which happily takes its empty stdin and generates a blank PDF.

Beyond simply restoring the spaces, I think we should restructure this so typos like this in future fail noisily instead of silently. We could do some Bash `PIPESTATUS` tricks, but what do people think about simply introducing intermediate .ps targets and dropping the piping altogether? Something like the following (untested) change:

```diff
diff --git cmd/dot/Makefile.am cmd/dot/Makefile.am
index 480c45730..c5ae861ec 100644
--- cmd/dot/Makefile.am
+++ cmd/dot/Makefile.am
@@ -66,8 +66,11 @@ uninstall-hook:
        (cd $(DESTDIR)$(bindir); for i in $(linkedprogram); do rm -f $$i; done;)
        (cd $(DESTDIR)$(libdir); rm -f config;)

-dot.1.pdf: $(srcdir)/dot.1
-       @GROFF@-Tps -man $(srcdir)/dot.1 | @PS2PDF@ - - >dot.1.pdf
+dot.1.pdf: dot.1.ps
+       @PS2PDF@ $< $@
+
+dot.1.ps: $(srcdir)/dot.1
+       @GROFF@ -Tps -man $< >$@

 osage.1.pdf: $(srcdir)/osage.1
        @GROFF@-Tps -man $(srcdir)/osage.1 | @PS2PDF@ - - >osage.1.pdf
```

It's perhaps worth noting that the only reason I noticed this was because I was looking at a diff of build output between two commits. Without this, I doubt I would ever have picked it up amidst the current volume of build warnings.

Related to https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz.gitlab.io/-/issues/39.

summary: "Auto-Size" fonts depending on number of incoming edges
description:
In many circumstances I've encountered, it would be really helpful to visualize large datasets when you could automatically adjust the sizes of the nodes depending on the number of incoming (or outgoing) edges. Like, in

    x -> a
    y -> a
    z -> a

the text and therefore also the node "a" would be 3 times larger than any x, y or z node. When you have like 10000 of incoming connections into a, then every other one may be only a little, nearly invisible bubble. 

As I've said, this would be of great help and I believe this is technically easy to realize for somebody who knows about the GraphViz code. 

Thanks!

summary: [feature request]I would like to have a replace function to replace a text-placeholder in html node
description:
Backgound: I'm not a developer, I'm an analyst I'm using a plantuml to generate my diagrams. One of the diagrams not supported by plantuml is the dfd (dataflow diagram) But since plantuml uses graphiz and support native graphiz notation, I created a template for me to generate dfd diagrams. One of the elements in a dfd diagram is a 'data store' drawn as a tekst (the name of the data) with a solid line drawn above it and a solid line drawn below it (think of some text in a rectangle with the left and right sides of the rectangle missing. So.. graphiz doesn't support this shape out of the box so I created it using html node notation. ``` 'create here all data stores node[shape=plaintext, width=label, fixedsize=false, label=<
my text comes here
> ] datastore1 datastore2 ``` and this works but I now have two times the same shape, which is ok, but also the same text in my shape which isn't ok. I know I can overwrite my node label data, but that would mean that for every element I have on my diagram of this type, I need to copy the whole html and fiddle with the html code every time. This is not very practical and certainly not clear. what I would like is some feature that option1: uses the html as 'background' image and allows me to add text independent of the html (like we have on other shapes already) like this: ``` node[shape=plaintext, width=50, height=20, fixedsize=true, **HTML**=<
> ] datastore1 **[label="my 1st text"]** datastore2 **[label="my 2nd text"]** ``` or option2: allows me to put some special html tag (a text-placeholder) in my html that can afterwards be replaced by the real text like this: ``` 'create here all data stores node[shape=plaintext, width=label, fixedsize=false, label=<
**<\textplaceholder>**
> ] datastore1 **[textplaceholder="my 1st text"]** datastore2 **[textplaceholder="my 2nd text"]** ``` where option2 has my preference as it is more flexible kr, Nir

summary: lib/gvpr/mkdefs.c leaks memory
description:
The program lib/gvpr/mkdefs.c allocates memory that it never deallocates. "So what?" you say, "it runs quickly and then exits which automatically cleans up." However, this program is compiled and run during the Graphviz build process. A side effect of this is that whatever is in your `CFLAGS` is applied when compiling it. This includes things like when you've enabled Address Sanitizer and told it to fail on leak detection. This then causes a build failure. To compound the situation, this is dependent on what level of compiler optimization (`-O0`, `-O1`, ...) you're using, which affects how the compiler can manipulate these heap allocations.

Rather than trying to track heap allocations and free everything before exiting, I think we should just rewrite this in a scripting language where we don't need to deal with manual memory management.

summary: indeterminate local variable reads in RBTreeCreate
Issues in the rendered graph
description:
I am using GraphViz to render neural networks.

Sometimes there are visual issues.

In the attached screenshot there are two problems:
1. Why some edges cross boxes? (sometimes GraphViz makes an effort to draw lines around boxes and sometimes it doesn't)
2. Some edges are rendered too close and this makes them confusing.

CORRECTION: The first issue is not crossing. The box has 2 ins and 2 outs. But GraphViz draws the second line as if it is crossing. It should attempt to place them more like this:

```
\     /
-------
|     |
-------
/     \
```

![image](/uploads/c1f2b84ddbaececcc2620018166530ff/image.png)

summary: Heap-double-free (159147107)
description:
Hello graphviz team,

As part of our fuzzing efforts at Google, we have identified an issue affecting
graphviz (tested with revision * master dbb3e130ef59eb9677c25f974c4d249f6382464a).

To reproduce, we are attaching a Dockerfile which compiles the project with
LLVM, taking advantage of the sanitizers that it offers. More information about
how to use the attached Dockerfile can be found here:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/

Instructions:
* `unzip artifacts_159147107.zip`
* `docker build --build-arg SANITIZER=address --tag=autofuzz-graphviz-159147107 autofuzz_159147107`
* `docker run --entrypoint /fuzzing/repro.sh --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_159147107/autofuzz_159147107:/tmp/poc autofuzz-graphviz-159147107 "" /tmp/poc`
* `docker run --cap-add=SYS_PTRACE -v $PWD/autofuzz_159147107/autofuzz_159147107:/tmp/poc -it autofuzz-graphviz-159147107`

Alternatively, and depending on the bug, you could use gcc, valgrind or other
instrumentation tools to aid in the investigation. The sanitizer error that we
encountered is here:

```

SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: double-free (/fuzzing/graphviz/render_fuzzer+0x4c9542) in free
==13==ABORTING

```

We will gladly work with you so you can successfully confirm and reproduce this
issue. Do let us know if you have any feedback surrounding the documentation.

Once you have reproduced the issue, we'd appreciate to learn your expected
timeline for an update to be released. With any fix, please attribute the report
to "Google Autofuzz project".

We are also pleased to inform you that your project is eligible for inclusion to

summary: edgepaint gives different results on Windows MSBuild Release and Debug builds
The Windows CMake installer does not remove previously installed Graphviz version
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Download `Graphviz-install.exe` from e.g. [here](https://ci.appveyor.com/api/buildjobs/kw9k9h7lt74he1j4/artifacts/build%2FGraphviz-install.exe)
2. Run it
3. Repeat using another build version

## Expected Behaviour

IMHO, the default should be to install Graphviz without using the version and build date in the path or name, thus overwriting a previously installed version. Alternatively the version should be kept, but the build version (or patch version if it's an official release) dropped.

## Actual Behaviour

The new version is installed alongside previously installed versions if the defaults are accepted.

The reason being that the Windows CMake installer by default installs Graphviz under a path and name containing the version and build date.

```
dir "C:\Program Files\Graphviz*"
...
 Directory of C:\Program Files

2020-06-23  10:29    <DIR>          Graphviz 2.45.20200615.0949
2020-06-22  21:33    <DIR>          Graphviz 2.45.20200621.0824
2020-06-23  10:03    <DIR>          Graphviz 2.45.20200622.0758
```

The start menu looks like this:

![image](/uploads/260a5c6f417b44ed3f9e62890d5374c2/image.png)

If `Add Graphviz to the system PATH for current user` is selected, the PATH will contain all previously installed versions.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

`dot - graphviz version 2.45.20200622.0758 (20200622.0758)`

## Additional info

I realize that this issue is somewhat opinionated. I'm open for arguments to keep it as it is.

summary: Ordering of ports in an html-like label causes edge of other node to render incorrectly
description: ## Steps to reproduce For a benchmark, the expected graph can be rendered using the following source: [gv_source_good.txt](/uploads/0fee603b9bd0261f3fc8fd59f5c4d4b1/gv_source_good.txt) Rendering the graph specified in [gv_source_bad.txt](/uploads/1561738f00b8fa96493a0c043884dcdf/gv_source_bad.txt) produces the following errors: ``` Warning: Arrow type "10" unknown - ignoring Warning: Arrow type "10" unknown - ignoring ``` and replaces an edge of the graph with an errant edge originating at the wrong port on the source node and terminating at the wrong port of the target node. The only difference between the two codes is that lines 87 and 88, which are port specifications for a node that is not a source or target of the edge in question, are swapped: line 87/88 of the bad config: ``` INPUT_CIM_oa_InputPort-0 INPUT_CIM_ob_InputPort-0 ``` and of the good config: ``` INPUT_CIM_ob_InputPort-0 INPUT_CIM_oa_InputPort-0 ``` [gv_source_bad.txt](/uploads/1561738f00b8fa96493a0c043884dcdf/gv_source_bad.txt) [gv_source_good.txt](/uploads/0fee603b9bd0261f3fc8fd59f5c4d4b1/gv_source_good.txt) ## Expected Behaviour ![graphviz_bug_correct_config](/uploads/4ca6d318b280abe069709f0db14ba7e8/graphviz_bug_correct_config.png) ## Actual Behaviour ![graphviz_bug_incorrect_config](/uploads/a4be6efed76350a010e3b2dc3754bcff/graphviz_bug_incorrect_config.png) ## OS Version Windows 10 Home build 19041.330 MacOS Catalina ## Graphviz Version version 2.38.0 (20140413.2041) on Windows version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304) on Mac ## Additional info I believe this may be related to the problems detailed in [this issue](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1444) and [this stackoverflow thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45082822/why-do-i-get-an-arrow-type-unkown-warning-with-this-dot-file), but the workarounds posted in the threads seem specific to their graphs. Help would be greatly appreciated! Thank you!

summary: Enhancement: Revise documentation packaging
description:
Currently CMake is set to put all man pages under `man3` (library functions). Most of the man pages are for applications (section 1), about 20% are libraries (section 3), and the main index page (section 7). It doesn't look as if the PDF documentation is installed, there are no PDF equivalents of the man pages, and the man pages are installed on Windows where there is no `*roff` reader for them.

I propose:
- installing man pages under the appropriate sections (`man1`, `man3`, `man7`)
- only installing man pages on non-Windows systems
- installing general application guides (existing PDFs) on all platforms
- generating PDFs from the existing man pages and installing those to Windows

I've taken a stab at implementing this in a forthcoming WIP MR. I wanted to write up the problem I was trying to solve before I posted any code so hopefully the MR makes some sense.

summary: Documentation for _background attribute needs improvement
description:
## The problem:  The documentation about **_background **includes this:
> A string in the xdot format specifying an arbitrary background.  

While arguably correct, I find this misleading.  The **xdot** format is a superset of the **dot** language.  This superset is not legal for the **_background** attribute.  Instead, only a concatenation of legal the values of the **\_xxx_** attributes are allowed. [sorry, this is not very clear either].  Here is an example of a legal **.gv** file that includes **_background**:  
```
digraph G {
  graph [_background="c 7 -#ff0000 p 4 4 4 36 4 36 36 4 36
            c 7 -#00ff00 p 4 0 0 0 26 26 26 26 0
            c 7 -#000099 b 4 59.5 94.7 59.5 86.98 59.5 77.71 59.5 69.11"]
    n1 [ xlabel="P1"]
    n2 [ xlabel="P2" ]
    n3 [ xlabel="P3" ]

    n1 -> n2
    n1 -> n3
    n2 -> n3
}
```
Note that only spaces and newlines are legal separators.

summary: xlabel attribute can't be overridden by command line setting
description:
Using the command line to set a new **xlabel** value (e.g. **-Nxlabel="xyz"**) works fine, but if the node or edge already has an **xlabel** value, the new command line value is ignored.

## Steps to reproduce
1. create a **.gv** file with some or all of the edges and node having **xlabel** values
2. run this command:  `dot -Nxlabel="" -Exlabel="new" -Tpng myfile.gv >myfile.png`


## Expected Behaviour

I expect all the edges/nodes to now have new **xlabel** values (possibly "" string, if that was on command line)

## Actual Behaviour

Existing **xlabels** are not changed

## OS Version

Linux  5.6.14-300.fc32.x86_64 
Fedora release 32 (Thirty Two)

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.42.4 (0)

## Additional info
Test case:  
```
digraph G {
    0  [xlabel="my X"];
    0 -> 1 [xlabel="my label"];
    1 -> 0 
}
```

summary: segfault on musl due to vmalloc
description:
## Steps to reproduce

simply run `gvpr` with musl-libc, segfault, 2.44.1

## Additional info

It seems that the stub vmalloc from lib/vmalloc/malloc.c overrides the musl-libc `malloc`(linker and loader things). So `malloc` in gvpr always return NULL.

And everything works if I add `-Dcray` to CFLAGS/CXXFLAGS to disable those stubs in lib/vmalloc/{malloc.c,vmbest.c}. You can check my working building sciprts [here](https://github.com/xhebox/noname-linux/blob/master/ports/graphviz/Pkgfile).

summary: Windows builds spuriously fails on choco install in GitLab CI/CD
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Trigger a GitLab pipeline run. If it doesn't fail; repeat. 

## Expected Behaviour

No failure.

## Actual Behaviour

```
$ choco install -y grep
Chocolatey v0.10.15
Installing the following packages:
grep
By installing you accept licenses for the packages.
Progress: Downloading grep 2.1032... 100%
grep v2.1032 [Approved] - Likely broken for FOSS users (due to download location changes)
grep package files install completed. Performing other installation steps.
Downloading grep 64 bit
  from 'https://sourceforge.net/projects/ezwinports/files/grep-2.10-w32-bin.zip/download'
ERROR: The remote file either doesn't exist, is unauthorized, or is forbidden for url 'https://sourceforge.net/projects/ezwinports/files/grep-2.10-w32-bin.zip/download'. Exception calling "GetResponse" with "0" argument(s): "Unable to connect to the remote server" 
This package is likely not broken for licensed users - see https://chocolatey.org/docs/features-private-cdn.
The install of grep was NOT successful.
Error while running 'C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib\grep\tools\chocolateyinstall.ps1'.
 See log for details.
Chocolatey installed 0/1 packages. 1 packages failed.
 See the log for details (C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\logs\chocolatey.log).
Failures
 - grep (exited 404) - Error while running 'C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib\grep\tools\chocolateyinstall.ps1'.
 See log for details.
Uploading artifacts for failed job
00:09
ERROR: Job failed: exit status 1
```

The full log is [here](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/jobs/609976790)

## OS Version

GitLab Windows runner, amd64.

## Graphviz Version

N/A, but most certainly still happens on the current tip: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/34348b822355fad9c6a027b071bc48913e255118

## Additional info
This probelm was mentioned in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1454#note_373714546

I've seen this maybe 5-10 times and every time that I have made a job retry, the job succeeded. Unfortunately, there seems to be no way to see the previous job log after a retry so I cannot link to more examples.

I suspect it might be a download bandwidth issue. If it is, we will avoid it once we start using Docker containers also for Windows builds since we then will have all dependencies already installed.

GitLab CI/CD has a [retry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ce/ci/yaml/#retry) that may be useful to work around this problem.

summary: de-duplicate gvc.def
description: The repository contains two copies of gvc.def, lib/gvc.def and lib/gvc/gvc.def. Each of these are needed by one of the Windows build systems, but they are intended to be identical. We should modify the build systems to point at the same gvc.def and delete the other copy.

summary: GVPR vim syntax
description:
Input programs to GVPR could be syntax highlighted if Vim had support for the format. Does a .vim file for the language exist already? If not, I would be open to working on such a thing. It would make sense to submit this to Vim itself rather than the Graphviz repo, as they're very accepting of new formats.

We could do this for other editors as well, but I'm just proposing this for Vim because it's my editor of choice and I'm tired of looking at unhighlighted text.

summary: make fails if ps2pdf is not installed (using autotools)
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Unpack the source then run:
```shell
./configure --prefix=/usr
make
```

## Expected Behaviour

build to completion

## Actual Behaviour

```shell
false cdt.3.ps cdt.3.pdf
make[3]: *** [Makefile:1112: cdt.3.pdf] Error 1
```

## OS Version

Linux LFS development: http://www.linuxfromscratch.org/blfs/view/svn/general/graphviz.html

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1

## Additional info

I think this is a long standing bug: setting `PS2PDF` to `false` if `ps2pdf` is not found will always return an error if trying to run it. But until recently, it was run inside a pipe, which somehow prevented the error to be caught.

summary: gvedit menu bar inactive or missing on Mac OSX Catalina
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Start gvedit, click File in menu bar.
## Expected Behaviour

Expect file open dialog to appear

## Actual Behaviour

It's dead

## OS Version

OSX Catalina 10.15.5

## Graphviz Version

2.43.20200330.1741

## Additional info

Curiously, the colorful Qt icon for opening a file is alive when gvedit starts. Then, after opening a graph, the Menu Bar changes from "gvedit File Edit Window Graph" to just "gvedit View". Weird.

At least once, I got a popup from the operating system asking to grant gvedit permission to access Documents. After I agreed, the menu bar started to work. I'm certain this happened, but I was not able to reproduce this. 

I tried System Preferences->Security & Privacy->Privacy and granting Full Disk Access to gvedit, and even tried, er, sudo gvedit (from a terminal), neither of which made any difference.

summary: inconsistent test suite run in CI
description:
I've been trying to debug the !1472 pipeline failure. So I dutifully checked out the source branch on my local Linux box and ran the CMake build instead of the Autotools build. But to my surprise, the test suite sprayed huge numbers of failures; not just failures related to the changes in that MR.

After some poking around, I realized the CI jobs are all running completely different test suites:
* the Linux jobs run `ci/test.sh`, which runs `python3 -m pytest --junitxml=report.xml tests rtest`
* the Windows Msbuild jobs run `tests/regression_tests/regression_tests.ps1`, which then runs a Python `unittest` test suite
* the Windows CMake jobs run:
  1. CMake-driven tests that call `python shapes.py` in tests/regression_tests/shapes; and
  2. `pytest -s rtest\test_examples.py`

To put it bluntly: this is a complete mess. We have little visibility into what is broken, coverage of the existing tests is difficult to determine, and it's very hard to even add a test and have confidence it will get run.

I don't mean this as an accusation of anyone (I know we're all doing our best), but we need to fix this situation. I spent a couple of hours debugging "why do my local failures disagree with CI?" which exhausted all the time I had available today to spend on addressing Graphviz user issues. The build system -- and now test suite -- diversity is gradually grinding progress to a standstill.

summary: Potential Trojan in Graphviz Binary Distribution - Win32/Uwasson.A!ml
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Download the win32 graphviz 2.44.1 binary distribution from https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/msbuild/Release/Win32/graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip
2. Extract the contents of the archive to a staging area
3. Scan the contents of the directory extracted in the staging area with Windwos Defender

## Expected Behaviour

No threats detected

## Actual Behaviour

Win32/Uwasson.A!ml threat detected

![gvpr-Uwasson](/uploads/040199b6b47ac99a888b52e9c286172e/gvpr-Uwasson.png)

## OS Version

Windows 10 Pro
Version	10.0.18363 Build 18363

Windows Defender Security Intelligence
Version: 1.319.2181.0

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1
https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/msbuild/Release/Win32/graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip

## Additional info

Threat detected in graphviz-2.44.1-win32\Graphviz\bin\gvpr.exe

**EDIT by @magjac:** The whole 2.44.1 release is being tracked at https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/76e79d0fe4fb18112f733e0fcad152c6a894efac2c07441ecaa1993b49c91487/detection

summary: Chrome downloading Graphviz: "graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip is dangerous, so Chrome has blocked it."
description:
## Steps to reproduce

- Open Chrome
- Navigate to https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/msbuild/Release/Win32/graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip

## Expected Behaviour

- Downloads Graphviz

## Actual Behaviour

![image](/uploads/979b01e55a2c082b3a22f28ad3017ff0/image.png)

Clicking the arrow, gives a link to "Learn more" which goes to https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/6261569?visit_id=637312304190232180-4009787860&p=ib_download_blocked&hl=en-GB&rd=1.

## OS Version

macOS Version 10.15.5 (Build 19F101)
Chrome 84.0.4147.89 (Official Build) (64-bit)

## Additional info

The Chrome Support page says:

> To help protect users, Google maintains a list of websites that are known to host malicious downloads and a list of trusted software publishers. If you're a software publisher and your binaries are flagged by Chrome, learn how to resolve malware or unwanted software issues related to your downloads.

Which links to https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/3258249:

> Google checks websites to see whether they host software or downloadable executables that negatively affect the user experience. You can see a list of any suspected files hosted on your site in the Security Issues report.

So I think we can take a look at the Google Search Console for www2.graphviz.org to find out what issue in particular Google thinks we have. We can verify ownership of www2.graphviz.org by adding a DNS TXT record or uploading an HTML file to the root directory of the website. Who has access to do this?

summary: remove open coded strcasecmp
description:
Graphviz contains three implementations of the function `strcasecmp` and two implementations of the function `strncasecmp`. It looks like these were added as there was no cross-platform alternative at the time.

At the time of writing, every major platform I'm aware of implements `strcasecmp` and `strncasecmp` except Windows. Windows also has this functionality, but under the names `_stricmp` and `_strnicmp`.

I propose we remove these implementations and replace them with a small compatibility header that provides `strcasecmp` and `strncasecmp` on Windows by redirecting to the alternatives. I'm creating this issue to see what others' opinions are. Maybe it would be better to hold off until we move to C99 in December 2020? I don't believe this will make a difference because these two functions are not standardized in C99 but rather in POSIX 2001, but maybe someone has a different opinion.

$ echo 'digraph { 1 -> 2; }' | dot -Tx11

```

## Actual Behaviour

Segfault.

## OS Version

Debian 10.2.0 with no desktop environment installed.

## Graphviz Version

Commit 31cb447e4cd0f2ce633998bc7d753474fd144c60

2. Run `git submodule update --init`.
3. In Visual Studio 2019 open *graphviz.sln*
4. Choose Release configuration and Win32 platform.
5. Compile solution. There are some errors, the first of them is:

Error	MSB3073	Command "bison -dy grammar.y -o grammar.c

summary: Port ksh script rtest.sh to a Python script
description: `ksh` doesn't exist on Windows. Porting the [rtest.sh](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/rtest.sh) script to Python would allow it to be run on all platforms.

summary: gvpr on Windows does not support absolute paths
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Unzip e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/msbuild/Release/Win32/graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip and run gvpr with an absolute path:

Run:

1. `echo BEGIN{} > test.gvpr`
2. `Graphviz\bin\gvpr.exe -f C:"\Users\magja\Downloads\graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release"\test.gvpr` (or whatever)

## Expected Behaviour

No error.

## Actual Behaviour

```
Graphviz\bin\gvpr.exe: Could not find file "C:\Users\magja\Downloads\graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release\test.gvpr" in GVPRPATH
Usage: Graphviz\bin\gvpr.exe  [-o <ofile>] [-a <args>] ([-f <prog>] | 'prog') [files]
   -c         - use source graph for output
   -f <pfile> - find program in file <pfile>
   -i         - create node induced subgraph
   -a <args>  - string arguments available as ARGV[0..]
   -o <ofile> - write output to <ofile>; stdout by default
   -n         - no read-ahead of input graphs
   -q         - turn off warning messages
   -V         - print version info
   -?         - print usage info
If no files are specified, stdin is used

The file does exist:
```
C:\Users\magja\Downloads\graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release>more C:"\Users\magja\Downloads\graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release"\test.gvpr
BEGIN{}
```

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

gvpr version 2.44.1 (20200629.0800)

## Additional info

Relative paths work:
```
C:\Users\magja\Downloads\graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release>Graphviz\bin\gvpr.exe -f test.gvpr

```
produces no error.

summary: typo in cmd/gvpr/lib/clustg?
description: While working on #1762, I noticed clustg seems to think `$tv_type` is a built-in variable. But according to the GVPR man page, the variable is `$tvtype`. AFAICT `$tv_type` is not known to GVPR. Is this a typo?

summary: Graphviz doesn't build on MacOS with the latest libc++
description:
[I'm the libc++ maintainer]

I was trying to build Graphviz using the latest version of libc++ (the C++ Standard Library shipped with the Clang compiler, and used on Apple platforms), and I noticed the following error:

```
In file included from <graphviz>/blocks.cpp:22:
In file included from <graphviz>/blocks.h:32:
In file included from <toolchain>/usr/bin/include/c++/v1/set:427:
In file included from <toolchain>/usr/bin/include/c++/v1/__tree:17:
In file included from <toolchain>/usr/bin/include/c++/v1/algorithm:644:
In file included from <toolchain>/usr/bin/include/c++/v1/functional:512:
In file included from <graphviz>/Block.h:26:
In file included from <toolchain>/usr/bin/include/c++/v1/vector:274:
<toolchain>/usr/include/c++/v1/__bit_reference:172:38: error: no member named 'min' in namespace 'std::__1'
```

The issue is that we `#include <Block.h>` from <functional>, however Graphviz contains a block.h header (which is the same as Block.h on a case insensitive FS), and they collide. This triggers some circular dependency issue in libc++, which causes the build to fail. The root cause of the issue is that by including `<Block.h>` in libc++, we're potentially conflicting with a user-provided `<Block.h>` header. It would be better if `<Block.h>` were somehow namespaced, so that we know for sure we're not including a user provided header, however that's not the reality we live in.

I suggest fixing Graphviz in one of two ways:

1. Rename your `block.h` header to something else, or
2. Avoid adding `<graphviz>/lib/vpsc` to the include paths of the compiler. Instead, add `<graphviz>/lib` and then include `<vpsc/block.h>` from your code. This will effectively namespace the block.h header from your side, making sure that we don't find it when we include `<Block.h>` from libc++.

I acknowledge this is an annoying issue and I wish we had a better way of solving it from our side in libc++, however I can't think of a good solution from our side.

summary: CMake builds do not support format png:gd
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Install a CMake build on Windows through e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/cmake/

Run `dot -Tpng:gd`

## Expected Behaviour

No error.

## Actual Behaviour

`Format: "png:gd" not recognized. Use one of: png:cairo:cairo png:cairo:gdiplus png:gdipiplus`

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

Homebuilt from commit 0c58634ebd81e01614eb54fe82026327b6dcc9af

dot - graphviz version 2.45.20200730.1411 (20200730.1411)

## Additional info

The problem exists for both 32-bit and 64-bit CMake builds and for both Debug and Release CMake builds, but not for MSbuild builds.

For 32-bit CMake builds the builds log says that CMake has found `GD`, but for 64-bit builds it says it hasn't:

```
-- The following OPTIONAL packages have not been found:
...
 * GD
```
but in neither case is the `png:gd` format supported.

This is also a problem for Linux CMake builds.

summary: Using shapefile with Windows MSBuild Debug builds silently fails
description:
## Steps to reproduce

* Download and unzip e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/msbuild/Debug/Win32/graphviz-2.44.1-win32.zip
* Clone the graphviz repository and `cd graphviz\rtest`
* Run `<unzip-location>\Graphviz\bin\dot -Kdot -Tps -o user_shapes_dot.ps user_shapes.gv`
  Where [user_shapes.gv](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/graphs/user_shapes.gv) is:
```
digraph G {
  n [label="", shapefile="graphs/jcr.gif"]
  x [width=3, height=3, label="", shapefile="graphs/jcr.gif"]
  m -> n -> x
}
```
* Run `echo %errorlevel%`
* Run `dir user_shapes_dot.ps`

## Expected Behaviour

Zero exit status and non-empty PostScript file as with the Release build:

```
C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest>echo %errorlevel%
0

C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest>dir user_shapes_dot.ps
 Volume in drive C is Win7Pro
 Volume Serial Number is 168D-7220

 Directory of C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest

2020-08-02  09:01           123 073 user_shapes_dot.ps
               1 File(s)        123 073 bytes
               0 Dir(s)  47 478 906 880 bytes free
```

## Actual Behaviour

Non-zero exit status and empty PostScript file.

```
C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest>echo %errorlevel%
-1073740791

C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest>dir user_shapes_dot.ps
 Volume in drive C is Win7Pro
 Volume Serial Number is 168D-7220

 Directory of C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest

2020-08-02  09:03                 0 user_shapes_dot.ps
               1 File(s)              0 bytes
               0 Dir(s)  47 477 399 552 bytes free
```

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.1 (20200629.0800)

## Additional info

When run under MinGW, the exit status is `127`:

```
~/graphviz/rtest$ ~/Downloads/graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-debug/Graphviz/bin/dot -Kdot -Tps -o user_shapes_dot.ps graphs/user_shapes.gv
~/graphviz/rtest$ echo $?
127
```

The problem can also be seen indirectly in [this pipeline](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/pipelines/173384126)

Download and install e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/graphviz-install-2.44.1-win64.exe

Run `diffimg`

operable program or batch file.
```
## OS Version

Windows 10

dot - graphviz version 2.44.1 (20200629.0846)

The Windows MSBuild builds do contain `diffimg`:

C:\Users\magja\Downloads>graphviz-2.44.1-msbuild-win32-release\Graphviz\bin\diffimg.exe
Usage: diffimg image1 image2 [outimage]
```

The diffimg utility is located [here](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/tree/master/contrib/diffimg).

summary: The order of clusters in gv or ps output is not stable on Windows
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Run once:
```
dot -Tps clusters.gv -o tmp0.ps
```
Run and repeat until diff:
```
dot -Tps clusters.gv -o tmp1.ps
diff --strip-trailing-cr tmp1.ps tmp0.ps
```


The input data is [rtest/graphs/clusters.gv](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/graphs/clusters.gv):
```
digraph G {

	subgraph cluster_0 {
		style=filled;
		color=lightgrey;
		node [style=filled,color=white];
		a0 -> a1 -> a2 -> a3;
		label = "process #1";
	}

	subgraph cluster_1 {
		node [style=filled];
		b0 -> b1 -> b2 -> b3;
		label = "process #2";
		color=blue
	}
	start -> a0;
	start -> b0;
	a1 -> b3;
	b2 -> a3;
	a3 -> a0;
	a3 -> end;
	b3 -> end;

	start [shape=Mdiamond];
	end [shape=Msquare];
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

Stable output. No diff.

## Actual Behaviour

After many iterations:
```
187,199d186
< % cluster_1
< gsave
< 1 setlinewidth
< 0.66667 1 1 graphcolor
< newpath 129 65 moveto
< 129 356 lineto
< 208 356 lineto
< 208 65 lineto
< closepath stroke
< 0 0 0 graphcolor
< 14 /Times-Roman set_font
< 137 340.8 moveto 63 (process #2) alignedtext
< grestore
218a206,218
> grestore
> % cluster_1
> gsave
> 1 setlinewidth
> 0.66667 1 1 graphcolor
> newpath 129 65 moveto
> 129 356 lineto
> 208 356 lineto
> 208 65 lineto
> closepath stroke
> 0 0 0 graphcolor
> 14 /Times-Roman set_font
> 137 340.8 moveto 63 (process #2) alignedtext
```

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

Homebuilt from commit 15379daf5273c8bcf3ffc09f75b8e29d003f262c

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200803.0611 (20200803.0611)

## Additional info

This may be related to https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1767.

This may not be a bug, but is impractical for regression testing.

The same happens for [rtest/graphs/compound.gv](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/graphs/compound.gv) and [rtest/graphs/rootlabel.gv](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/graphs/rootlabel.gv).

The issue can be triggered by running this bash script from `rtest/graphs` in the repository:

```
#!/bin/bash -ex

dot -Tps clusters.gv -o tmp0.ps while true; do dot -Tps clusters.gv -o
tmp1.ps diff --strip-trailing-cr tmp1.ps tmp0.ps done
```

summary: Using PostScript shapefile on Windows produces incorrect output
description:
## Steps to reproduce

* Clone the repository and `cd rtest`
* Run `dot -Tps -Nshapefile=graphs/dice.ps -o ps_user_shapes_dot.ps graphs\ps_user_shapes.gv`

summary: Regression: The CMake Windows development builds have (partly) the wrong version
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Look in [this Windows CMake CI build log](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/jobs/678123414).

## Expected Behaviour

CPack should produce a file whose name contains the current VERSION, i.e. I expect to find a log entry saying:

`CPack: - package: C:/GitLab-Runner/builds/magjac/graphviz/build/Graphviz-2.44.2~dev.20200810.0719-win64.exe generated.`

## Actual Behaviour

The version part of the filename is 0.1.1:

`CPack: - package: C:/GitLab-Runner/builds/magjac/graphviz/build/Graphviz-0.1.1-win64.exe generated.`

## OS Version

Windows 10.

## Graphviz Version

* Expected: 2.44.2~dev.20200810.0719
* Actual: 0.0.1

## Additional info

If installing using e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/development/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/graphviz-install--win64.exe, Graphviz is installed under /c/Program Files/Graphviz 0.1.1, but the built-in version is still correct:
```
$ which dot
/c/Program Files/Graphviz 0.1.1/bin/dot

magja@DESKTOP-GSDBC95 MINGW64 ~
$ dot -V

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200811.0113 (20200811.0113)
```

This bug was introduced in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1476/diffs?commit_id=51a96c5e182f509eef2e7fe2c550109816c4bed9.

It turns out that the version used by CPack comes from `GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MAJOR`, `GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MINOR` & `GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_PATCH`. This can be seen [here](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/blob/master/cmake/package_info.cmake#L2). These variables were incorrectly removed by this commit.

summary: The Windows artifacts produced in CI does not contain the version in the filename
description:
## Steps to reproduce

See e.g. https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/development/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/

## Expected Behaviour

The name should be `graphviz-install-2.44.2~dev.20200810.0719-win64.exe`.

## Actual Behaviour

The name is `graphviz-install--win64.exe`.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

2.44.2~dev.20200810.0719

## Additional info

It's the same problem for the zip archive produced by the `MSBuild` builds.

~~The reason is that in CI the version used in the filename is set with `$Env:GV_VERSION=$( cat VERSION )` [here](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml#L91). This does not work in PowerShell.~~

**EDIT:** This problem was introduced in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/ffc2e8d391a67b1d56459dd7278aa7b96c89e828 which changed from setting `$GV_VERSION` to setting `$Env:GV_VERSION` which are different variables.

See also https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1791.

summary: unify stack implementations
description:
Graphviz contains a number of inline implementations of a stack data structure:
* `initStk` implementation duplicated in at least five places
* SFIO's `sfstack`
* cgraph's `gstack_t`
* cgraph's `save_stack_t`
* rbtree's `stk_stack`
* ortho's `stack`
* sparse's `IntStack`
* circogen's `nstack_t`
* cricogen's `estack`
* tred's `estack`
* sccmap's `stack`
* gxl2gv's ad hoc `Gstack`

I have not analyzed how much these overlap, but I hope we can all agree this is more stack implementations than we would like to maintain. As a first step, de-duplicating all the `initStk` copies would be progress. I have not yet investigated which is the best target library to merge them into.

summary: test_1767 fails on agread() on Windows
description:
## Steps to reproduce

This issue was discovered by @smattr, see https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1489#note_392218027.

* Remove the skipping of test_1767 on Windows in [rtest/test_regression.py](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/rtest/test_regression.py#L231) as in https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/commit/f1571dd7ee2583a352bdb71224be5039c48a2bbb
* Run `pytest -vv -k test_1767 rtest/test_regression.py` on Windows

## Expected Behaviour

Passing test.

## Actual Behaviour

The test fails with exit status 3221226505, but no other error messages.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200812.0541 (20200812.0541)

## Additional info

* printf-debugging shows that the problem occurs when `g = agread(file, 0);` is executed the first time.
* If the program is changed to read the same DOT source from stdin instead, it runs the first pass without problems and prints out the clusters, but since stdin is drained it cannot run a second pass.
* Modifying the program to just read the original file with fgets() and print the contents works without problems.

I'm puzzled; why can't agread read an already opened file from the file system, but has no problem to read the same contents from `stdin` when `fgets()` has no problem reading the same file?

Full test log from unmodified test program:
```
============================= test session starts =============================
platform win32 -- Python 3.8.5, pytest-6.0.1, py-1.9.0, pluggy-0.13.1 -- c:\users\magja\graphviz-build-utilities\python38-32\python.exe
cachedir: .pytest_cache
rootdir: C:\Users\magja\graphviz\rtest
collecting ... collected 12 items / 11 deselected / 1 selected

test_regression.py::test_1767 FAILED                                     [100%]

================================== FAILURES ===================================
__________________________________ test_1767 __________________________________

    def test_1767():
        '''
        using the Pango plugin multiple times should produce consistent results
        https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1767
        '''
    
        # FIXME: some of the Windows CI builds don't install libcgraph that this
        # test depends on. Others fail the execution of the compiled binary for
        # unknown reasons.
    #    if platform.system() == 'Windows':
    #      pytest.skip('test disabled on Windows')
    
        # find co-located test source
        c_src = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '1767.c'))
        assert os.path.exists(c_src), 'missing test case'
    
        # create some scratch space to work in
        tmp = tempfile.mkdtemp()
        atexit.register(shutil.rmtree, tmp)
    
        # compile our test code
        exe = os.path.join(tmp, 'a.exe')
        if platform.system() == 'Windows':
            subprocess.check_call(['cl', c_src, '-Fe:', exe, '-nologo', '-link',
              'cgraph.lib', 'gvc.lib'])
        else:
            cc = os.environ.get('CC', 'cc')
            subprocess.check_call([cc, c_src, '-o', exe, '-lcgraph', '-lgvc'])
    
        # find our co-located dot input
        dot = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '1767.dot'))
        assert os.path.exists(dot), 'missing test case'
    
        # run the test
>       stdout = subprocess.check_output([exe, dot], universal_newlines=True)

test_regression.py:256: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
..\..\graphviz-build-utilities\python38-32\lib\subprocess.py:411: in check_output
    return run(*popenargs, stdout=PIPE, timeout=timeout, check=True,
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

input = None, capture_output = False, timeout = None, check = True
popenargs = (['C:\\Users\\magja\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\tmpp04jgrmj\\a.exe', 'C:\\Users\\magja\\graphviz\\rtest\\1767.dot'],)
kwargs = {'stdout': -1, 'universal_newlines': True}
process = <subprocess.Popen object at 0x03D725B0>, stdout = '', stderr = None
retcode = 3221226505

    def run(*popenargs,
            input=None, capture_output=False, timeout=None, check=False, **kwargs):
        """Run command with arguments and return a CompletedProcess instance.
    
        The returned instance will have attributes args, returncode, stdout and
        stderr. By default, stdout and stderr are not captured, and those attributes
        will be None. Pass stdout=PIPE and/or stderr=PIPE in order to capture them.
    
        If check is True and the exit code was non-zero, it raises a
        CalledProcessError. The CalledProcessError object will have the return code
        in the returncode attribute, and output & stderr attributes if those streams
        were captured.
    
        If timeout is given, and the process takes too long, a TimeoutExpired
        exception will be raised.
    
        There is an optional argument "input", allowing you to
        pass bytes or a string to the subprocess's stdin.  If you use this argument
        you may not also use the Popen constructor's "stdin" argument, as
        it will be used internally.
    
        By default, all communication is in bytes, and therefore any "input" should
        be bytes, and the stdout and stderr will be bytes. If in text mode, any
        "input" should be a string, and stdout and stderr will be strings decoded
        according to locale encoding, or by "encoding" if set. Text mode is
        triggered by setting any of text, encoding, errors or universal_newlines.
    
        The other arguments are the same as for the Popen constructor.
        """
        if input is not None:
            if kwargs.get('stdin') is not None:
                raise ValueError('stdin and input arguments may not both be used.')
            kwargs['stdin'] = PIPE
    
        if capture_output:
            if kwargs.get('stdout') is not None or kwargs.get('stderr') is not None:
                raise ValueError('stdout and stderr arguments may not be used '
                                 'with capture_output.')
            kwargs['stdout'] = PIPE
            kwargs['stderr'] = PIPE
    
        with Popen(*popenargs, **kwargs) as process:
            try:
                stdout, stderr = process.communicate(input, timeout=timeout)
            except TimeoutExpired as exc:
                process.kill()
                if _mswindows:
                    # Windows accumulates the output in a single blocking
                    # read() call run on child threads, with the timeout
                    # being done in a join() on those threads.  communicate()
                    # _after_ kill() is required to collect that and add it
                    # to the exception.
                    exc.stdout, exc.stderr = process.communicate()
                else:
                    # POSIX _communicate already populated the output so
                    # far into the TimeoutExpired exception.
                    process.wait()
                raise
            except:  # Including KeyboardInterrupt, communicate handled that.
                process.kill()
                # We don't call process.wait() as .__exit__ does that for us.
                raise
            retcode = process.poll()
            if check and retcode:
>               raise CalledProcessError(retcode, process.args,
                                         output=stdout, stderr=stderr)
E               subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['C:\\Users\\magja\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\tmpp04jgrmj\\a.exe', 'C:\\Users\\magja\\graphviz\\rtest\\1767.dot']' returned non-zero exit status 3221226505.

summary: Add cmake option to disable testing
description:
When using graphviz as a subdirectory in cmake it would be nice to disable testing, so I can avoid building and testing graphviz along with my project. This patch provides a cmake option to do this, with the default value to enabling testing.

I tried submitting a merge request, but got bounced by the mail system.

[0001-Add-CMake-option-to-enable-disable-unit-testing.patch](/uploads/dddba72ee56ab5454b2bb79542338a70/0001-Add-CMake-option-to-enable-disable-unit-testing.patch)

summary: error C2065: 'uint_64_t': undeclared identifier when building with bison --debug using CMake on Windows
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Apply the following patch and build an x64 Debug build on Windows using CMake:

```
diff --git a/lib/cgraph/CMakeLists.txt b/lib/cgraph/CMakeLists.txt
index 6182bf37a..37e1acc1b 100644
--- a/lib/cgraph/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/lib/cgraph/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-BISON_TARGET(Grammar grammar.y ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/grammar.c)
+BISON_TARGET(Grammar grammar.y ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/grammar.c COMPILE_FLAGS --debug)
 FLEX_TARGET(Scan scan.l  ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/scan.c)
 ADD_FLEX_BISON_DEPENDENCY(Scan Grammar)
```


## Expected Behaviour

No error.

## Actual Behaviour

`C:/Users/magja/graphviz/build/lib/cgraph/grammar.c(885,13): error C2065: 'uint_64_t': undeclared identifier [C:\Users\magja\graphviz\build\lib\cgraph\cgraph.vcxproj]`

and subsequent errors.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

Home-built 2.44.2~dev.20200813.1227 based on commit https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/ce10e7e1c3c155c1c077c756511dac5ebe90140d

## Additional info

Presumably this happens for all Windows CMake builds and possibly for CMake builds on other OSs as well.

I have no idea why this happens only when using `bison --debug`. Why not always?

[This commit](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/commit/02a98f5ebc74d4fd1535ec8d237d0a51b9820876) solves the problem:
```
commit 02a98f5ebc74d4fd1535ec8d237d0a51b9820876
Author: Magnus Jacobsson <magnus.jacobsson@berotec.se>
Date:   Thu Aug 13 13:11:06 2020 +0200

    Correct uint_64_t typo to uint64_t in CMake files
    
    The commit message of
    https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/25fc2bcef8cb565f04081660fc60697d1f863b98
    includes:
    
    - Replace "unsigned long int" with "uint64_t" in grammar.h and grammar.c
    - Replace "unsigned long" with "uint64_t" in grammar.h and grammar.c
    
    but the added code is:

summary: remove comment references to CVS
description: A nice easy issue for anyone to tackle if they get to it before me: a lot of code comments tell the reader to refer to CVS, but the code is now hosted using Git at Gitlab. I think we should just remove any comments referencing CVS.

summary: failed Exshort_t type discrimination
description:
One of the many warnings that flies by in an autotools build is:

```
expr.h:117:5: warning: "LONG_MAX" is not defined, evaluates to 0 [-Wundef]
```

The offending code looks like this:

```
#if LONG_MAX > INT_MAX
typedef int Exshort_t;
#else
typedef short Exshort_t;
#endif
```

Perhaps reasonable except this header does not include limits.h, so neither `LONG_MAX` nor `INT_MAX` are in scope. As a result, the wrong path of this conditional is selected on e.g. x86-64. Compounding the issue, the correct path is chosen if someone including this header happened to include limits.h prior. This can cause different translation units to see a different underlying type for `Exshort_t`, something that will be caught by neither the compiler nor the linker.

I haven't yet evaluated the impact of this.

summary: indeterminate local variable reads
description:
Related to #1742 and as discussed on #1800, there are further uses of `setjmp` errors paths that access non-volatile local variables with the expectation that they are preserved across a call to `longjmp`. Unfortunately this property is not true.

Rather than trying to audit this and annotate every accessed variable with `volatile`, I propose we simply remove this exception-style control flow. I have not yet assessed how hard this is to do.

summary: The windows 32-bit development release directory is named x86 while the stable release directory is Win32
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Visit:
* https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/cmake/Release/ and
* https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/development/windows/10/cmake/Release/

## Expected Behaviour

Same name for 32-bit releases.

## Actual Behaviour

The stable 32-bit release directory is named `Win32` while the development release directory is named `x86`

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

* The stable build is `graphviz-install-2.44.1-win32.exe`
* The development build is `graphviz-install-2.44.2~dev.20200821.1434-win32.exe`

## Additional info

This was noted by @smattr in https://forum.graphviz.org/t/windows-x86-x86-64-builds/305.

The reason is that [Set up VCTools variables and import into PowerShell environment](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml#L117) changes the `$Env:platform` environment variable to `x86`. This setup was introduced after the latest stable release in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/9afa76f20d3627d90126c30c9924c357d0c3d4a9, hence the difference.

summary: gvpr typedefs ssize_t as int
description:
From lib/gvpr/gvpr.h:

```c
#ifdef _MSC_VER
typedef int ssize_t;
#endif
```

While it is true Windows does not provide `ssize_t`, using `int` for this purpose is not the right solution. On, e.g. x86-64, `int` is not the same size as `size_t` so surprising overflows can occur. Some internet searching suggests to me that the correct solution is something like:

```c
#if defined(_MSC_VER)
#include <BaseTsd.h>
typedef SSIZE_T ssize_t;
#endif
```

summary: replace sed steps on generated parsers with api.prefix
description:
Creating an issue to more accurately track a discussion stemming out of !1523...

Several of the steps that generate lexers/parsers using Flex/Bison run a subsequent `sed` step to find-and-replace "yy" with a custom prefix. The purpose of this is to avoid symbol clashes between different generated parsers.

These `sed` steps are both fragile and over-eager (they end up replacing "yy" in comments etc), but they are also not necessary. At the time this code was written there was probably no other convenient way of accomplishing this. But today Flex provides [`%option prefix`](https://www.cs.virginia.edu/~cr4bd/flex-manual/Code_002dLevel-And-API-Options.html) and Bison provides [`%define api.prefix`](https://www.gnu.org/software/bison/manual/html_node/Multiple-Parsers.html) for this purpose. Moving to these would make the build more robust, remove some unnecessary intermediate files, and take us one step towards dropping `sed` as a build dependency.

Quoting my last comment from !1523:

> I attempted this and it results in quite a nice clean up: https://gitlab.com/smattr/graphviz/-/commits/064bf64e-752b-45fc-8da7-e66050fbe8b5. However, [the Windows builds fail CI](https://storage.googleapis.com/gitlab-gprd-artifacts/a4/90/a490598b42559b4746fbf724494aea3ddbf245afc71b53f49640ff8d9d53116f/2020_08_25/701692276/770923734/job.log?response-content-type=text%2Fplain%3B%20charset%3Dutf-8&response-content-disposition=inline&GoogleAccessId=gitlab-object-storage-prd@gitlab-production.iam.gserviceaccount.com&Signature=qHFyA2rslJZA63P%2FR6G34aKlFGDhqtPK24qXkOWI1fgI21RHVEz7%2FNNdg7WP%0AyXiflBcqQWrdMj80i%2FWa07RzrBxQhoSZOCBRRSAPYNn8IS8VMz7rZ4RJc3NN%0AJ34PtmsfQyNGo6YiHLz3S4EK3nf1hBV%2Fcd1zRg%2BQOwtS1GjbXJQsMuVl%2FllN%0AQYLhH6LwsI%2F28b0KREOPDLW1gPlkDImDQAQoUjmnUqsRX%2BUxYBs%2F6SqYxHgK%0AOeig%2Fhx853uR4LJEBXpTPThSTHTlyq%2FdMjPkBwokwivAT2dXqqLSpAEqbGMu%0AGYsiHF5PXnjNuGu%2FF%2B1jgQ7xk%2BvxAWQpDVK%2B0E4GRw%3D%3D&Expires=1598324058):
>
> ```
> Generating Code...
>      Creating library C:/GitLab-Runner/builds/smattr/graphviz/build/lib/cdt/Debug/cdt.lib and object C:/GitLab-Runner/builds/smattr/graphviz/build/lib/cdt/Debug/cdt.exp
>   cdt.vcxproj -> C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\smattr\graphviz\build\lib\cdt\Debug\cdt.dll
>   [BISON][Grammar] Building parser with bison 2.7
>   grammar.y:14.20-24: error: syntax error, unexpected {...}
> C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\BuildTools\MSBuild\Microsoft\VC\v160\Microsoft.CppCommon.targets(231,5): error MSB6006: "cmd.exe" exited with code 1. [C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\smattr\graphviz\build\lib\cgraph\cgraph.vcxproj]
> ```
>
> This confuses me because this feature was introduced in Bison 2.6 and the version of Bison we're using there claims to be 2.7. The [Bison docs](https://www.gnu.org/software/bison/manual/bison.html) indicate there have been no relevant changes to this feature since its introduction. @magjac do you have any guesses at what's going on here?

summary: Build GraphViz in Windows for CI
description: I've recently been trying to setup CI for downstream projects (mainly [pygraphviz](https://github.com/pygraphviz/pygraphviz/) and, by extension, NetworkX) to run the respective test suites on Windows. One of the biggest hurdles I've experienced is trying to build graphviz from source on a cloud-hosted Windows instance. It looks like there have been some recent developments e.g. in #1438 that could also be relevant for downstream projects. Is there an easy way to extract/package a subset of that procedure for use downstream? Is that a reasonable thing to do, or perhaps you have alternative approaches that are being explored? If you have any thoughts/tips in this arena please LMK - I know that the NetworkX developers would be very happy to collaborate on a solution to improve both our workflow and support for NX/pygraphviz users on windows (CC: @dschult @jarrodmillman)

summary: remove gdiplus patches
description: The latest quirk I discovered is that plugin/gdiplus/Makefile.am patches source files during compilation. It's not obvious to me why this kind of platform-dependent behavior is not managed with ifdefs or `configure`. I think we should undo these gymnastics and either (1) rephrase the source to be platform-independent or (2) manage this with ifdefs, with that being my order of preference as well.

summary: Not Get Minimum length of edge in the Graph
GRAPHVIZ_PLUGIN_VERSION arithmetic
description:
While reviewing !1521, I noticed some mysterious arithmetic on `GRAPHVIZ_PLUGIN_VERSION`, CMakeLists:196:

```cmake
MATH(EXPR GRAPHVIZ_PLUGIN_VERSION "${GRAPHVIZ_PLUGIN_VERSION}+1")
```

This made very little sense to me, so I asked `git blame` where it originated:

```
commit 1677db46200d18fda641426c08c6dec1fa0e43f6
Author: Nathan Owens <ndowens04@gmail.com>
Date:   Sun Jan 12 23:32:18 2020 -0600

    Add pkg-config files
```

This tells me nothing further useful either, but cross-referencing with the autotools build system I think it was copied from configure.ac:89-97:

```sh
# This nonsense drives me crazy!!
case "${host_os}" in
  *irix* | *nonstopux* )
    GVPLUGIN_VERSION=`expr $GVPLUGIN_CURRENT + 1`
    ;;
  * )
    GVPLUGIN_VERSION=$GVPLUGIN_CURRENT
    ;;
esac
```

I have no idea what "this nonsense" refers to, but I can certainly empathize. This seems to have originated from the following commit:

```
commit c8425c50df1dd27e083dffdc1a8dfc30dfd6ddb6
Author: ellson <devnull@localhost>
Date:   Tue Oct 18 19:14:53 2005 +0000

    work around "if IRIX +1" weirdness in libtool LT_CURRENT versioning
```

I don't know what this refers to either. Does/did libtool somehow behave weirdly on IRIX? Can anyone shed light on this?

Maybe more simply, do we still support IRIX? Wikipedia tells me the last and final release of IRIX was in 2006. The other case in that expression looks like it's trying to match HP-UX on an HP NonStop machine, but is this correct? I would have thought `host_os` would return something like `hpux*` in that scenario.

diff --git a/cmd/gvedit/main.cpp b/cmd/gvedit/main.cpp

--- a/cmd/gvedit/main.cpp
+++ b/cmd/gvedit/main.cpp
@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ static char **parseArgs(int argc, char *argv[])
            Verbose = 1;
            break;
        case '?':
-           if (optopt == '?')
+           if (optopt == '\0')
                usage(0);
            else
                errout << cmd << " : option -" << ((char) optopt) <<
```

Fill in with anything else that might be important.

summary: agxbputc macro does not bracket its arguments
description:
The `agxbputc` macro looks like this:

```c
#define agxbputc(X,C) ((((X)->ptr >= (X)->eptr) ? agxbmore(X,1) : 0), (void)(*(X)->ptr++ = ((unsigned char)C))
```

Note that the expansion of neither `X` nor `C` is bracketed. This can result in surprising behavior. For example, lib/common/utils.c contains code like the following:

```c
agxbputc(&xb, (v >> 12) | 0xE0);
```

The lack of bracketing around `C` in `agxbputc` results in the final term appearing as `((unsigned char)(v >> 12) | 0xE0)`. I suspect what the caller of `agxbputc` is really intending in this case is `((unsigned char)((v >> 12) | 0xE0))`. I.e. for the `unsigned char` cast to apply to the whole expression after computation, rather than eagerly to the first part of it.

summary: Outdated getopt in windows/getopt. Used also for Linux/macOS CMake builds
description:
The version of `getopt` in [windows/getopt](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/tree/master/windows/getopt) is outdated. It's incompatible with the version that the Linux autotools builds use. The fix for https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1561 in commit https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1561/diffs?commit_id=997e12cf45ddfb44d1019c05f05bf12b53bd7322 shows this incompatibility.

Also, this outdated version is used by the CMake builds, regardless of which operating system you're on. I discovered this the hard way by an accidental (details provided on a need-to-know basis :flushed: ) removal of `windows/getopt` in [this Ubuntu CMake job](https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/jobs/729861596).

My plan right now is to:

1. Remove `windows/getopt`
1. Add `getopt` using `vcpkg` to the [windows/dependencies/libraries](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz-windows-dependencies) submodule
1. Adapt the CMake builds to:
    1. Use the vcpkg version on Windows
    1. Use the native/Docker image version on Linux and hope that this also works on macOS
1. Adapt the MSBuild builds to use the vcpkg version

The current libraries in [windows/dependencies/libraries](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz-windows-dependencies) has unclear origins, but I read in [this issue](https://github.com/ellson/MOTHBALLED-graphviz/issues/1218#issuecomment-323947968) that many probably comes from https://windows.php.net/downloads/.

My plan is to add a new `vcpkg` top level directory to [windows/dependencies/libraries](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz-windows-dependencies) so that libraries can be installed there directly without the need to figure out which file to put where in the old structure. In future, we can replace other outdated packages in the old structure with new ones installed with `vcpkg`.

**I would very much like to hear your comments on this and the above.**

As a reference, these are the `getopt` files that are installed with vcpkg:

```
~/vcpkg/vcpkg-export-20200910-082739$ find . -type f
./.vcpkg-root
./installed/vcpkg/info/getopt-win32_0.1_x86-windows.list
./installed/vcpkg/info/getopt_0_x86-windows.list
./installed/x86-windows/bin/getopt.dll
./installed/x86-windows/bin/getopt.pdb
./installed/x86-windows/debug/bin/getopt.dll
./installed/x86-windows/debug/bin/getopt.pdb
./installed/x86-windows/debug/lib/getopt.lib
./installed/x86-windows/include/getopt.h
./installed/x86-windows/lib/getopt.lib
./installed/x86-windows/share/getopt/vcpkg_abi_info.txt
./installed/x86-windows/share/getopt-win32/copyright
./installed/x86-windows/share/getopt-win32/vcpkg_abi_info.txt
./scripts/buildsystems/msbuild/applocal.ps1
./scripts/buildsystems/msbuild/vcpkg-general.xml
./scripts/buildsystems/msbuild/vcpkg.props
./scripts/buildsystems/msbuild/vcpkg.targets
./scripts/buildsystems/vcpkg.cmake
./scripts/cmake/vcpkg_get_windows_sdk.cmake
```

summary: use of uninitialized pointers in gvmap
description:
While investigating some of the Coverity issues reported in #1464, I noticed cmd/gvmap/gvmap.c does some unwise looking pointer passing. `mapFromGraph` calls `makeMap` with uninitialized pointers `rgb_r`, `rgb_b`, and `rgb_g`. `mapFromGraph` then contains control flow that depends on whether these pointers are NULL. All of this logic looks non-deterministic. Command line flag `-O` can make this more reliable, but by default it is not.

Interestingly (maybe?) this is *not* the issues that Coverity finds with this code.
