summary: Build fails on macOS with Apple Clang 12.0.0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```console
$ git clone https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz.git
$ git checkout stable_release_2.44.1
$ ./autogen.sh NOCONFIG
$ ./configure '--disable-swig' '--without-expat' '--without-gts' '--without-ghostscript' '--without-libgd' '--without-pangocairo' '--without-poppler' '--without-qt' '--with-quartz' '--without-x' '--without-gtk'
$ make -j4
```

## Expected Behaviour

Successful compilation.

## Actual Behaviour

Several warnings about implicit conversions and then a build failure:
```
make[3]: *** [cdt.3.pdf] Error 1
make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [all] Error 2
```
Full build log attached:

* [build log](/uploads/3b4e8dbecf97a6c166f997f041f7eb2d/spack-build-out.txt)
* [build env](/uploads/618b608180113e5d07c03d864f3c1c28/spack-build-env.txt)

## OS Version

macOS 10.15.6, Apple Clang 12.0.0 (LLVM Clang 10.0.0)

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1

## Additional info

Graphviz 2.42.2 built just fine on macOS 10.15.6 with Apple Clang 11.0.3 (LLVM Clang 9.0.0). When I updated to XCode 12, which comes with Apple Clang 12.0.0 (LLVM Clang 10.0.0), the 2.42.2 build failed:
```
5 errors found in build log:
     20599    gvgen.c:397:11: warning: implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'int' to 'char' [-Wimplicit-int-conversion]
     20600                    errexit(c);
     20601                    ~~~~~~~ ^
     20602    gvgen.c:405:11: warning: implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'int' to 'char' [-Wimplicit-int-conversion]
     20603                    errexit(c);
     20604                    ~~~~~~~ ^
  >> 20605    gvgen.c:513:6: error: implicit declaration of function 'makeTetrix' is invalid in C99 [-Werror,-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
     20606                makeTetrix(opts.graphSize1, ef);
     20607                ^
     20608    20 warnings and 1 error generated.
  >> 20609    make[3]: *** [gvgen.o] Error 1
  >> 20610    make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
  >> 20611    make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
  >> 20612    make: *** [all] Error 2
```
I tried updating to 2.44.1 but that build also failed. I believe this is due to a change in Clang major version, but I'm no C expert. I'm using the Spack package manager to install this, so if we come up with a patch I can add it to Spack.

summary: remove Electric Fence support?
description:
The autotools build system contains support for building with [eFence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_Fence):

```
dnl -----------------------------------
dnl ElectricFence support for debugging

AC_ARG_WITH(efence,
   [AS_HELP_STRING([--with-efence=no],[use efence for debugging memory use])],
   [],[with_efence=no])
if test "x$with_efence" = "xyes"; then
        LIBS="$LIBS -lefence"
fi
```

Does anyone use this? I am under the impression eFence's functionality had been entirely subsumed by Valgrind and later Address Sanitizer. The only scenario in which I have found eFence preferable is free-standing environments (e.g. OS kernels) where there are fewer instrumentation options. I can't imagine anyone is running Graphviz in a free-standing environment though.

summary: smyrna fails to start because of missing DLLs in Windows MSBuild builds
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Install or build a Windows 32-bit MSBuild Release build.

Run `smyrna -?`

## Expected Behaviour

No errors.

## Actual Behaviour

Four pop-ups (in sequence) complaining about missing DLLs:

![image](/uploads/642b8920c1a0ce054854a0b2d6942293/image.png)
![image](/uploads/432d9b3a101104d4f546100566b7bb33/image.png)
![image](/uploads/3d5a0d1dd424ddfbebac9b3d7596ffb2/image.png)
![image](/uploads/1465b8a726be741eb5460178c657b138/image.png)

## OS Version

Windows 10.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200920.1253 (20200920.1253)

Home-built based on commit 37ee115a779092feabd61ac11f1faec80b955783

## Additional info

The DLLs are missing from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz-windows-dependencies. The corresponding `.lib` files exist, but they do not *seem* to be static libraries (containing object files), just import libraries (containing symbols to allow the linker to link to a DLL). See [this SO post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/913744/3122101) for more about `.lib` & `.dll`  files.

The `smyrna.vcxproj` contains commands to copy the (nonexistent) DLLs to the output directory, but they fail silently.

I guess it's the same problem in MSBuild Debug builds, but I haven't tried. `smyrna` is not built in CMake builds.

summary: smyrna is not built on Centos
description: The build logs shows that `configure` is run with `--without-smyrna`. The reason for this is yet unknown.

summary: mingle is not built on Ubuntu or Centos
description:
The reason is that the [ANN](http://www.cs.umd.edu/~mount/ANN/) library is not installed in the Docker images for Ubuntu or Centos.

At least for Ubuntu 18.04 `libann-dev` is available for install with `apt`, but I haven't found any lib for Centos.

summary: gvpack built with CMake in Linux cannot load shared library libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Build Graphviz with CMake on Linux.

Set up:
```
dir=`pwd`/`echo build/_CPack_Packages/Linux/DEB/Graphviz-*-Linux/usr`
export C_INCLUDE_PATH="$dir/include:$C_INCLUDE_PATH"
export LIBRARY_PATH="$dir/lib:$LIBRARY_PATH"
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:"$dir/lib"
export PATH="$dir/bin:$PATH"
dot -c
```

Run:
`gvpack -?`

## Expected Behaviour

Print usage. No error.

## Actual Behaviour

```
gvpack: error while loading shared libraries: libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

## OS Version

Ubuntu 18.04.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200925.1756 (20200925.1756)

Home-built based on master at 898c87cb.

## Additional info

Adding:
```
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:"$dir/lib/graphviz"
```
fixes the problem. I don't know if this is what you're supposed to do or if `gvpack` should be linked in a different way so that it looks for `libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6` in the `graphviz` subdirectory.

find:
```
magjac@t440:~/graphviz$ find $dir -name libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6
/home/magjac/graphviz/build/_CPack_Packages/Linux/DEB/Graphviz-2.44.2~dev.20200926.1525-Linux/usr/lib/graphviz/libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6
```

ldd:
```
magjac@t440:~/graphviz$ ldd $dir/bin/gvpack
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007fff47f38000)
	libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6 => not found
	libgvc.so.6 => /usr/lib/libgvc.so.6 (0x00007f84ef98d000)
	libcgraph.so.6 => /usr/lib/libcgraph.so.6 (0x00007f84ef772000)
	libcdt.so.5 => /usr/lib/libcdt.so.5 (0x00007f84ef56a000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f84ef1cc000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f84eeddb000)
	libpathplan.so.4 => /usr/lib/libpathplan.so.4 (0x00007f84eebcf000)
	libxdot.so.4 => /usr/lib/libxdot.so.4 (0x00007f84ee9c8000)
	libexpat.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libexpat.so.1 (0x00007f84ee796000)
	libltdl.so.7 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libltdl.so.7 (0x00007f84ee58c000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f84efe5b000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f84ee388000)
```
Might be related to the discussion in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1581#note_419129746.

summary: dot_builtins are not installed on Centos or Fedora systems
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Install Graphviz on a Centos or Fedora system.

Run `dot_builtins -V`

## Expected Behaviour

dot_builtins - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200926.1616 (20200926.1616)

## Actual Behaviourz on 

`dot_builtins: command not found`

## OS Version

Centos 6.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200926.1616 (20200926.1616)

Home-built based on master at 898c87cb.

## Additional info

It works fine on Ubuntu 18.04:

`dot_builtins - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200926.1616 (20200926.1616)`

The `dot_builtins` are built and installed during the build, but excluded from the RPM package trough https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/redhat/graphviz.spec.fedora.in#L205

The exclusion seems to be deliberately introduced in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/e5f514b283fa5fe8690f7d82fe7555e8ce74e371. Perhaps @ellson can comment?

summary: Graphviz.Graph/Graphviz.DiGraph is unusable after pydot.graph_from_dot_file()
description:
The ability to use DOT files is no longer supported by Graphviz 2.40.1 (Debian Buster), if using the latest PyDot (v1.4.1) approach to load its DOT file.

I suspect the problem to be at `graphviz.Graph`/`graphviz.DiGraph`.

What's really scary is that when using the Python debugger in PyCharm IDE (by JetBrain), Python exception error messages got written (OVER?) into the `Graphviz.source` string.

## Steps to reproduce

Run
```python
#!/usr/bin/python3

import graphviz
import pydot
print('PyDot version:', pydot.__version__)
print('Graphviz version:', graphviz.version())

DotG = pydot.graph_from_dot_file('Digraph.gv')
print('DotG:', DotG[0])  # prints out original file content

# Now, convert PyDot Graph into a Graphviz Graph type
GvDotG = graphviz.Digraph(DotG)
print('GvDotG.engine:', GvDotG.engine)
print('GvDotG.render:', GvDotG.render)
print('GvDotG.strict:', GvDotG.strict)
print('GvDotG.directed:', GvDotG.directed)
print('GvDotG.comment:', GvDotG.comment)
print('GvDotG.directory:', GvDotG.directory)
print('GvDotG.encoding:', GvDotG.encoding)
print('GvDotG.filename:', GvDotG.filename)
print('GvDotG.filepath:', GvDotG.filepath)
print('GvDotG.graph_attr:', GvDotG.graph_attr)
print('GvDotG.name:', GvDotG.name)
print('GvDotG.format:', GvDotG.format)
# so far, so good.

# But fails on next three lines
print('GvDotG.source:', GvDotG.source)  # BOOM!
print('GvDotG:', GvDotG)  # doesn't work here also (alias of GvDotG.source?)
GvDotG.edge('Hello', 'World')  # also fails here, graph is rendered unusable?
```

## Expected Behaviour

I expect the `graphviz.Digraph(DotG)` to provide a Graphviz-compliant `Graph` type variable so that this `Graph` can be used by other functions provided by Graphviz.

Following 3 lines should be working.

```python
print('GvDotG.source:', GvDotG.source)  # BOOM!
print('GvDotG:', GvDotG)  # doesn't work here also (alias of GvDotG.source?)
GvDotG.edge('Hello', 'World')  # also fails here, graph is rendered unusable?
```

## Actual Behaviour

Instead, it errors all similarly for 3 test lines here:
```python
print('GvDotG.source:', GvDotG.source)  # BOOM!
print('GvDotG:', GvDotG)  # doesn't work here also (alias of GvDotG.source?)
GvDotG.edge('Hello', 'World')  # also fails here, graph is rendered unusable?
```

Python3.7.3 reports:
```console
$ python3 bug-gv.py 
PyDot version: 1.4.1
Graphviz version: (2, 40, 1)
DotG: digraph G {
Hello -> World;
}

GvDotG.engine: dot
GvDotG.render: <bound method File.render of <graphviz.dot.Digraph object at 0x7f3a7f612208>>
GvDotG.strict: False
GvDotG.directed: True
GvDotG.comment: None
GvDotG.directory: 
GvDotG.encoding: utf-8
GvDotG.filename: [<pydot.Dot object at 0x7f3a7f629908>].gv
GvDotG.filepath: [<pydot.Dot object at 0x7f3a7f629908>].gv
GvDotG.graph_attr: {}
GvDotG.name: [<pydot.Dot object at 0x7f3a7f629908>]
GvDotG.format: pdf
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bug-gv.py", line 28, in <module>
    print('GvDotG.source:', GvDotG.source)  # BOOM!
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/graphviz/dot.py", line 118, in __str__
    return '\n'.join(self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/graphviz/dot.py", line 104, in __iter__
    yield head % (self._quote(self.name) + ' ' if self.name else '')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/graphviz/lang.py", line 72, in quote
    if is_html_string(identifier) and not isinstance(identifier, NoHtml):
TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object
```

ipython3 v5.8.0 reports similar error:
```console
$  ipython3 bug-gv.py 
PyDot version: 1.4.1
Graphviz version: (2, 40, 1)
DotG: digraph G {
Hello -> World;
}

GvDotG.engine: dot

```

## OS Version

## Graphviz Version

$ dot -v

autogen.sh, I didn't try cmake yet

In file included from main.cpp:20:

```

Despite CXXFLAGS='-Wall -g -O1 -Wc++11-extensions' at configure time.

I made some progress on other issues, like adding QT += widgets printsupport and not finding #include <gvc/gvc.h> but eventually got stuck with needing DGVEDIT_DATADIR to be defined through gvedit.pro  After running automake and qmake enough times I lost my changes and need to take a break.

Anyway, just letting others know it's broken.

summary: Many tools do not fail when supplied with an unsupported option
description:
## Steps to reproduce

E.g. `edgepaint -Q`

## Expected Behaviour

An error message and exit with non-zero status.

## Actual Behaviour

`option -Q unrecognized - ignored`

The edgepaint program still runs and waits for input from stdin. If some garbage is entered, it (correctly) prints an error message:

```
yada yada
Error: <stdin>: syntax error in line 1 near 'yada'
```
This was just to shown the program is still running.

## OS Version

All OSs, but this was tested on Ubuntu 18.04.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20200928.0851 (20200928.0851)

Built from master at 3dd185241646d10149c86899f3a99beb51fce5d9 with local modifications.

## Additional info

Similar behavior is shown by:
* bcomps
* ccomps
* cluster
* edgepaint
* gc
* gvcolor
* gvmap
* gvmap.sh
* gvpack
* nop
* sccmap
* tred

summary: splines="polyline" partially ignored
description:
## Steps to reproduce

This is the graph I'm trying to render. [loc.dot](/uploads/e816a060fbb9b5968b05951d2a2594b7/loc.dot)

```
digraph G {

  #rounded nodes
  {
    node[shape=box,style="rounded,filled",fillcolor=aliceblue,fontname=helvetica,fontsize=12,fontcolor=gray20,color=mediumpurple,margin="0,0",height=0.4]

    Start
    End
  }

  #box nodes
  {
    node[shape=box,style=filled,fillcolor=aliceblue,fontname=helvetica,fontsize=12,fontcolor=gray20,color=mediumpurple,margin="0.1,0.1",height=0.4,width=0.3]

    br[label="Bedroom"]
    lr[label="Living Room"]
    c[label="Cellar"]
    s1[label="Stairs"]
    s2[label="Stairs"]
    e[label="Exterior"]
    w[label="Window"]
  }

  edge[arrowsize=0.7,color=gray20,fontname=helvetica,fontsize=10,fontcolor=gray20]

  splines="polyline"
  nodesep=2
  ranksep=2

  Start->br->s1->lr->s2->c
  c->s2->lr->s1->br
  lr->e[label="Must have T-Shirt",style=dotted]
  br->w->e
  e->End

}
```

I set the splines="polyline" option in the source and I ran graphviz like this:

dot -Tsvg -O loc.dot

## Expected Behaviour

I did not expect to see curved lines.

## Actual Behaviour

There are curved lines.

![loc.dot.svg](/uploads/38d13515dd8f79434c035e9c8fb6eeea/loc.dot.svg)

## OS Version

Manjaro Linux - Kernel 5.8.6

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.1 (0)

summary: dot: multiple graphs to file output causes a segfault
description:
## Steps to reproduce

With input file yoda.gvz containing:
```
digraph {
    fear -> anger;
}

digraph {
    anger -> hate;
}
```

run `dot -Tps yoda.gvz -o yoda.ps`

## Expected Behaviour

Expect to get a 2-page postscript file, with the first containing the fear->anger graph, second containing anger->hate.

## Actual Behaviour

dot segfaults, on my machine the message is `[1]    1168930 segmentation fault (core dumped)  dot -Tps yoda.gvz -o yoda.ps`

## OS Version

Linux, Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS

## Graphviz Version

2.38.0 (20140413.2041) - works as expected, in an Ubuntu 16.04 Docker container

2.43.0 (0) - fails

2.44.2~dev.20200930.1503 (20200930.1503) - built from 4747e3ff2f fails

## Additional info

The segfault is due to the output file being closed after the first graph is written to it.  I think the offending change is 806b8a2f36 - have attached [a patch](/uploads/f75be31c9d2c68cddf3053f0dd23d71b/fix.patch), but would be happy to make a MR if that is easier to deal with.

summary: Most recent stable installer (stable/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/) leads to broken installation
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Downloaded GraphViz' stable release from https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/ and installed it.
Tried the following graph definition (actually one of your examples) as input (via "%temp%\example.txt" - see attached screens):

```
digraph D {

  A [shape=diamond]
  B [shape=box]
  C [shape=circle]

  A -> B [style=dashed, color=grey]
  A -> C [color="black:invis:black"]
  A -> D [penwidth=5, arrowhead=none]

}
```
Ran:

`dot -v -Tplain "-o%temp%\dotout.txt" "%temp%\example.txt"`

... in the bin-directory of the according installation.

## Expected Behaviour

The according txt-file appearing in %temp% and command-line output comparable to my tests with an ancient version of GraphViz, as well as with the most recent dev-version (see according screens).

## Actual Behaviour

```
C:\Program Files\Graphviz 2.44.1\bin>dot -v -Tplain "-o%temp%\dotout.txt" "%temp%\example.txt"
dot - graphviz version 2.44.1 (20200629.0846)
Format: "plain" not recognized. Use one of:
```

Please also see attached screens.

## OS Version

Windows: I tested on Win7 (x64) but I heared of other users of my software (I'm the author of ProcDOT, which uses GraphViz for graphing) that they are experiencing the same problem with various Windows versions.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.1 (20200629.0846)![graphviz-issue_ancient-build-okay](/uploads/4013ef2f1970e58d25ff4b1274c41deb/graphviz-issue_ancient-build-okay.png)

![graphviz-issue_dev-build-okay](/uploads/9c6a2ed95a0fc6de4355d8b88d86e511/graphviz-issue_dev-build-okay.png)

![graphviz-issue_stable-build-broken](/uploads/eb6092fca4f4e785f857d9788788d68e/graphviz-issue_stable-build-broken.png)

![graphviz-issue_stable-build-broken-plus-mitigation-steps](/uploads/88bcbc6fcdf1ec2ef95693bb2d7682ae/graphviz-issue_stable-build-broken-plus-mitigation-steps.png)

## Additional info

I managed to fix the problematic installation by copying the file "config6" from the dev-installation.

summary: Problem with the new version numbering on RPM systems
description:
According to @ellson in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1839#note_419178199:

>This is all because somebody decided to rename the rpms with a dev string that breaks the rpm version numbering syntax rules.
>
>Now it looks like the package names are graphviz-2.44.2\~dev with a version of 20200926.1616 which breaks all the "requires rules" and also broke yum updating.
>
> I suggest the change should be completely reverted. What problem was supposed to be solved by the change?

The new version numbering was introduced with https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1476.

The background was discussed in https://forum.graphviz.org/t/version-numbering-going-forward/237.

It is not clear to me why the new version numbering causes the above mentioned problems. There was a problem with using `-` that was the original idea, but changing it to `~` seemed to be ok, see https://forum.graphviz.org/t/version-numbering-going-forward/237/16.

It is also not clear to me where I can see the problems mentioned above or how I could test that another solution does not have these problems.

summary: separate CI tests and "user" tests
description:
Something I discussed with @magjac, is that it would be nice to separate the pytest test cases into ones only intended for CI and ones intended to be run by both CI and developers. We want to test for the existence of e.g. `mingle` in CI to avoid building a release that does not include it, but it is not an error for the test suite to fail to find this binary when running in a developer's local checkout.

I'd like to factor out all the tests under tests/ and rtest/ that are only relevant for CI, and put them in ci/tests. This way users won't accidentally think they need to run them and will not be confused by spurious failures.

summary: Regression: many tools does not recognize the -? option on macOS
description:
In https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1592 and https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1608 many tools were adapted to GNU getopt. See e.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1592/diffs?commit_id=2c6420be0dfc252b7db4207accf40af2170c50e8 or https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1608/diffs?commit_id=81852ca7b3eea614752c8d38230562a9027efe89.

macOS however, does not use GNU getopt, but BSD getopt where the `optopt` variable behaves slightly differently and the code prior the the changes mentioned above is the correct one. Therefore, the code needs to be different depending on which OS it it running on.

The tools that are currently failing the tools test on macOS are:
* bcomps
* ccomps
* cluster
* dijkstra
* edgepaint
* gc
* gvcolor
* gvmap
* gvpack
* mm2gv
* nop
* sccmap
* tred

All of them may not have been working on macOS before, but at least some of them did.

This problem should be fixed before the next stable release.

## Steps to reproduce

E.g. `bcomps -?`

## Expected Behaviour

Show usage and exit status zero.

## Actual Behaviour

Output:
```
bcomps: option -? unrecognized
Usage: bcomps [-stvx?] [-o<out template>] <files>
  -o - output file template
  -s - don't print components
  -t - emit block-cutpoint tree
  -v - verbose
  -x - external
  -? - print usage
If no files are specified, stdin is used
```
Exit status 1.

## OS Version

macOS Catalina Version 10.15.7

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20201016.1439 (20201016.1439)

Home-built from aa165722db3b556213622727d45bb08d95d3bac7.

summary: SVG layout doesn't always respect requested size
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Attached to this report are two matched sets of files. One set used versions 2.38, the other used version 2.44. For each version, the files consist of 1) the input dot file, 2) the output SVG file, 3) a screenshot of SVG file displayed in my Polymeter software (via the IWebBrowser interface which wraps Internet Explorer) and 4) a screenshot of the same SVG file displayed in Firefox. The 2.38 graph fits neatly within the specified window size, but the 2.44 graph is slightly too wide and is consequently partially clipped. This misbehavior is observed in both IWebBrowser and Firefox.

## Expected Behaviour

I expect the graph to respect the specified size. This was so in version 2.38, and is not so in 2.44. Comparing the two SVG files shows that they are significantly different. Based on this comparison, I surmise that the SVG layout engine has changed and that the change is causing the incorrect sizing.

## Actual Behaviour

The input file, correct and incorrect SVG files, and screenshots are attached to this report.

## OS Version

Windows 7 64-bit.

## Graphviz Version

I'm reporting this issue for version 2.44.1. I don't know exactly which version introduced the issue. All I can say for sure is that version 2.38 does NOT exhibit the issue. I can also confirm that the issue occurs with both the 32-bit and 64-bit versions of 2.44.1.

The command line was:

dot -Ksvg -o"xxx" "yyy"

where xxx is the output SVG file path and yyy is the input dot file path. All other options are specified in the dot file.

## Additional info

[graphviz_SVG_size_bug.zip](/uploads/3227ead139a3fa47e6a46ad13c4f56e4/graphviz_SVG_size_bug.zip)

summary: dot: failure to create cairo surface: out of memory
description:
I have a large graph, and I'm getting the error
	dot: failure to create cairo surface: out of memory
	
I experienced the problem with jpg and png output. I do not get the error with pdf, svg or dot. Converting the dot to jpg gave the same error.

I tried changing the DPI, but that didn't help.

The PDF version is 193.54 inches (16.13 feet) by 217.18 inches (16.13 feet by 18.10 feet). At 96 DPI, that would be 18,579 x 20,849 pixels. At 24 bits per pixel, that comes out to just over 1 GB uncompressed size.

The graph will work with jpg if I limit the size to 6 feet by 8 feet at 96 DPI. 
	size="72,96"
	
The input dot file wasn't created by hand. The file is actually created by a PowerShell script using an XML file for input. 

I'm using Graphviz 2.44.1-Win32.
[EnglishBibleVersions-20201030.dot](/uploads/f35d50cb69e07bf267e05f0e3f1948af/EnglishBibleVersions-20201030.dot)

summary: command line options documentation is incomplete
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Documentation of command line options is incomplete.  
Here:     https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/command.html   
And here: https://www.graphviz.org/pdf/dot.1.pdf


## Actual Behaviour

Some engine-specific options are not documented.

## OS Version

All versions

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)

## Additional info

Complete command line options are documented with **dot -?** command.
Specifically:
```
dot -?
Usage: dot [-Vv?] [-(GNE)name=val] [-(KTlso)<val>] <dot files>
(additional options for neato)    [-x] [-n<v>]
(additional options for fdp)      [-L(gO)] [-L(nUCT)<val>]
(additional options for memtest)  [-m<v>]
(additional options for config)  [-cv]
```
and
```
 -Lg         - Don't use grid
 -LO         - Use old attractive force
 -Ln<i>      - Set number of iterations to i
 -LU<i>      - Set unscaled factor to i
 -LC<v>      - Set overlap expansion factor to v
 -LT[*]<v>   - Set temperature (temperature factor) to v
```

summary: unify XML string escaping implementations
description:
The current code base (608aab7b989cf33b48145e1c78abdd73f598fe44) has four implementations (that I have found so far) of XML string escaping:
* `xml_string` and friends in cmd/tools/gv2gxl.c
* `xml_string` and friends in cmd/smyrna/smyrna_utils.c
* `xml_string` and friends in lib/common/labels.c
* `html_string` and friends in plugin/core/gvrender_core_vml.c

The identical comments surrounding these implementations make it clear they were once copy-pasted from the same source. The lib/common one looks like the original and a comment in Smyrna even explains why this situation exists:

```c
/* many of these functions are available in libcommon.
 * We cannot use those because dependencies cause a great
 * deal of libcommon to be brought in, which complicates
 * and makes possible conflicts as some parts of libcommon
 * rely on not using libcgraph.
 */
```

As far as I'm aware, this situation no longer exists. libcgraph is the only graph library supported and there is no sensible way to use libcommon without libcgraph. However, a naive attempt to undo the Smyrna code duplication fails because:
1. A number of libcommon headers rely on something else being #included prior to them. lib/common/utils.h that contains the libcommon prototype for `xml_string` cannot be #included without other libcommon headers being #included prior to it.
2. A number of libcommon typedefs/prototypes conflict with other ones in Smyrna headers.

The situation is pretty messy and may require diagnosing and undoing the conflicting definitions one-by-one. But I think it's worth doing in service of paring back the number of XML string escaping variants we're maintaining to 1.

summary: gml2gv doesn't handle some attributes correctly
require Python 3.6 for testing?
description:
[Python 3.5 was EOLed on September 5 2020](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3510/). Currently CentOS 6 only has Python 3.4.10 available, but we are planning to drop support for this in December 2020. At that point, the lowest requirements would be determined by CentOS 7, which has Python 3.6.8.

Is it feasible and desirable to drop support for running the test suite with anything below Python 3.6? The main advantage of setting a new base line of 3.6 would be [f-string](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/inputoutput.html#tut-f-strings) support, which leads to much more concise and readable code.

summary: gml2gv does not handle integer penwidth correctly
description:
## Steps to reproduce

`echo graph {a [penwidth=1]} | gv2gml | gml2gv`

## Expected Behaviour

```
graph "" {
	graph [version=2];
	0	[name=a,
		penwidth=1.0,
		pos="0,0"];
}
```

## Actual Behaviour

```
Warning:  syntax error in line 8 near '1'
```

## OS Version

Ubuntu 20.04.

## Graphviz Version

`dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20201109.0606 (20201109.0606)`

## Additional info

The file produced by `gv2gml` is:
```
graph [
  version 2
  directed 0
  node [
    id 0
    name "a"
    graphics [
      width 1
    ]
  ]
]
```

Either `gv2gml` is incorrectly producing an integer `width` or `gml2gv` is incorrect by not being able to parse it. The [GML spec](https://web.archive.org/web/20190303094704/http://www.fim.uni-passau.de:80/fileadmin/files/lehrstuhl/brandenburg/projekte/gml/gml-technical-report.pdf) does not seem to rule out using integers for foreign attributes, so I guess this means that `gml2gv` is incorrect.

Using a real number for penwidth works fine:

`echo graph {a [penwidth=1.0]} | gv2gml | gml2gv`

gives the expected result.

summary: dot fails with segmentation fault on SLES 12
replace sfstropen with agxbuf
description:
Graphviz contains two APIs for in-memory dynamically expanding string buffers:
1. `sfstropen` and friends in lib/ast/sfstr.h
2. `agxbuf` functions in lib/cgraph/agxbuf.h

These are both analogues of [`open_memstream`](https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/open_memstream.html).

(1) is implemented in terms of `sfnew` and encumbered by a lot of the SFIO implementation details, which are irrelevant for in-memory buffers. In contrast, (2) is about as clean and minimal as it's possible to get for something like this.

I think we should move towards deprecating `sfstropen` and migrate all existing uses to `agxbuf` functionality.

summary: private inheritance in IncVPSC
mm_typecode_to_str() does not return NULL when its argument is not a matrix
description:
As noted by @smattr in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/1663#note_447682225, a `return NULL` statement is missing at https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/master/cmd/tools/mmio.c#L469.

The consequences of this is currently unknown.

summary: Regression: fdp generates internal names in the output
Regression: fdp assertion error on cluster in edge
description:
This issue is spawned from point 4) of https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/592#note_447723339.

## Steps to reproduce

`echo "graph {subgraph cluster_a {}; cluster_a -- b}" | fdp`

## Expected Behaviour

Something like:

```
graph {
	graph [bb="0,0,89,36"];
	node [label="\N"];
	subgraph cluster_a {
		graph [bb="0.44664,18.432,16.447,34.432"];
	}
	b	[height=0.5,
		pos="61.822,18.457",
		width=0.75];
	cluster_a -- b	[pos="16.787,25.186 21.83,24.432 28.567,23.426 35.291,22.421"];
}
```

At least no assertion error.

## Actual Behaviour

```
fdp: utils.c:1248: mapN: Assertion `name' failed.
Aborted
```

## OS Version

Debian 10 buster amd64, Linux 4.19.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20201115.0109 (20201115.0109)

## Additional info

Version 2.44.1 works as expected.

Only happens with fdp. sfdp, neato, twopi, dot, circo, patchwork & osage do not raise an assertion, but some still show graphviz/graphviz#1876.

The assertion only seems to happen when the subgraph and the edge point have the same name AND that name starts with `cluster`. Changing either of the two occurrences of `cluster_a` to `cluster_c` prevents the assertion. Changing both occurrences of `cluster_a` to `a` also prevents the assertion.

Maybe caused by a hidden bug that only comes out in combination with the bug causing graphviz/graphviz#1876.

summary: enable Address Sanitizer in CI
description: I think we should eventually have at least one CI task that builds an ASan-instrumented version of Graphviz and runs the test suite with this. I had a brief attempt at this, but the toolchains we're using in CI do not seem to have ASan support (maybe we need to install something beyond build-essential?). Even if we can get the build working, I think an ASan instrumented Graphviz currently fails the test suite because of some memory leaks. So we should probably initially run it with leak detection disabled (`ASAN_OPTIONS=detect_leaks=0`) and then ratchet this on once leaks have been fixed.

summary: test_gvpr_clustg fails with 64-bit gvpr on Windows
description:
## Steps to reproduce

An upcoming MR will add CMake builds of gvpr. The 64-bit Windows versions fail `test_gvpr_clustg` in CI and locally the test is unstable, i.e. it sometimes fails and sometimes succeeds.

`python3 -m pytest -k test_gvpr_clustg rtest/test_examples.py`

## Expected Behaviour

No failure.

## Actual Behaviour

The 64-bit Debug build fails with this diff:
```
E         - 	N1 -> N2	[_cnt=1];
E         + 	N1 -> N2	[_cnt=-3689348818177884159];
```
(-3689348818177884159 = 0xcccccccc00000001)

The 64-bit Release build fails with this diff:
```
E         - 	N1 -> N2	[_cnt=1];
E         + 	N1;
```

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

`2.44.2~dev.20201122.1515`

## Additional info

Link to failing pipeline: https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/pipelines/219663764.

summary: gzip man pages
description:
While reviewing !1684, I noticed that the CMake build system installs plain man pages. Most Linux distros these dates mandate gzipped man pages, simply because there are no downsides to not gzipping. You end up with a smaller installed footprint and `man` has native support for reading gzipped docs.

To ease the life of downstream packagers, we should probably be doing this ourselves in CMake. You can achieve this with something like:

```cmake
# artificial target to force gzip rules to be run
add_custom_target(man-foo
  ALL
  DEPENDS foo.1.gz)

# compress man page
add_custom_command(
  OUTPUT foo.1.gz
  COMMAND gzip -9 --no-name --to-stdout foo.1 >"${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/foo.1.gz"
  MAIN_DEPENDENCY foo.1
  WORKING_DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR})

# install compressed man page
install(FILES
  ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/foo.1.gz
  DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_MANDIR}/man1)
```

summary: Where are the latest build instructions for windows?
description:
According to the documentation linked in the README these steps are supposed to be working:
https://graphviz.org/doc/winbuild.html

However, they seem to be very outdated/not working. Are there any other more recent instructions available? If yes, could we update the documentation on this?

summary: Support guile 2.2 and 3.0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

graphvis only supports guile 2.0 and older, and these releases are largely obsolete, guile 2.2 has been out since May 2017, guile 3.0 has been out since Jan 2020. It would be good to support the newer 2.2/3.0 releases of guile.

## Expected Behaviour

To be able to build with newer releases of guile.

## Actual Behaviour

Show any unexpected output

## OS Version

Fedora 33 and later

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1

## Additional info

Nothing to note.

summary: stop installing python-pytest in CI
description: I just noticed a couple of our CI jobs install both python-pytest and python3-pytest. The test suite has no compatibility with Python 2, so I assume the first of these is unused. We should be able to drop it.

summary: Default attribute not written by agwrite when it is the empty string
Dot crash with labelled flat edge
description:
## Steps to reproduce

If you use the following definition with dot, dot is crashing:

```
digraph crash {
subgraph cluster1 {
cl1;
cl2;
cl3;
cl1 -> cl2 [minlen=0]
cl3 -> cl2 [minlen=0]
cl3 -> cl2 [minlen=0, label="X"]
}
}
```
If you remove the label or change minlen, it works


## Expected Behaviour

Some diagram.

## Actual Behaviour

Crash

## OS Version

Tested under Windows and Linux.

## Graphviz Version

Tested with version 2.38.0 and 2.44.1

## Additional info

Not 100% sure, but it looks like it is crashing in `flat.c` / function `flat_limits()`.

Since the `ND_rank` of the node is equals to `0`, the variable `r` is set to `-1`. And then `GD_rank(g)[r]` is crashing.

The call stack looks like: `flat_limits()` called by `flat_node()` called by `flat_edges()` called by `dot_position()`.

`flat_node()` is called from `flat_edges()` because there is a label on the edge.
If you remove the label, it works.

summary: Unexpected order of rectangles in rects attribute for record shape nodes
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```dot
digraph "test graph 1" {
    A [label="1|{2|3}", shape=record];
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

The behaviour below, but the `rects` ordered to the corresponding fields in the label.

## Actual Behaviour

cat in.dot | dot.exe -Txdot

```dot
digraph "test graph 1" {
        graph [_draw_="c 9 -#fffffe00 C 7 -#ffffff P 4 0 0 0 59.93 54 59.93 54 0 ",
                bb="0,0,54,59.93",
                xdotversion=1.7
        ];
        node [label="\N"];
        A       [_draw_="c 7 -#000000 p 4 0 0.5 0 59.43 54 59.43 54 0.5 c 7 -#000000 L 2 26.33 0.5 26.33 59.43 c 7 -#000000 L 2 26.33 29.96 53.67 29.96 ",
                _ldraw_="F 14 11 -Times-Roman c 7 -#000000 T 13.17 26.7 0 9.33 1 -1 F 14 11 -Times-Roman c 7 -#000000 T 40 41.43 0 9.33 1 -2 F 14 11 -Times-Roman \
c 7 -#000000 T 40 11.96 0 9.33 1 -3 ",
                height=0.83236,
                label="1|{2|3}",
                pos="27,29.965",
                rects="0,0.5,26.333,59.43 26.333,29.965,53.667,59.43 26.333,0.5,53.667,29.965",
                shape=record,
                width=0.75];
}
```

As you can see, the returned order of the rectangles is 1, 3, 2.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

2.44.2~dev.20201112.1525

## Additional info

I'm reading out the layout attributes using the CGraph library, and I have the need to map the given `rects` onto the fields as I defined them in the label. I expected the order to be maintained, but this appears not to be the case.

- Are there other feasible ways to obtain this mapping?
- If not, is there a good reason the order of the rectangles is not maintained, i.e. would it be hard to make it so?

summary: unresolved external symbol for Graphviz plugin library
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I'm using MSVC v142 and install Graphviz Windows library from this page https://www2.graphviz.org/Packages/stable/windows/10/cmake/Release/x64/ , then copy all of the `include` and `lib` directory to my project and add it to my CMakeLists.txt.

[CMakeLists.txt](https://github.com/andraantariksa/cit310-visible-surface-rendering/blob/285bd91ccdae4b544cbef6df028f3f73789b4c31/CMakeLists.txt)

```
cmake_minimum_required (VERSION 3.8)

project ("VisibleSurfaceRendering")

set(EXECUTABLE_NAME "VisibleSurfaceRendering")

set(FILE_SOURCES
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/imgui-sfml/imgui-SFML.cpp" # Workaround for ImGui-SFML
	"Source/Main.cpp"
	# another stuff here
        )

set(GRAPHVIZ_LIB
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvc.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/cgraph.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/cdt.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/Pathplan.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/xdot.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvplugin_core.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvplugin_gdiplus.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvplugin_neato_layout.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvplugin_dot_layout.lib"
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/lib/gvplugin_pango.lib")

if(CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE STREQUAL "Debug")
	add_executable(${EXECUTABLE_NAME}
		${FILE_SOURCES})
	target_compile_definitions(${EXECUTABLE_NAME} PUBLIC _DEBUG_BUILD)
else()
	add_executable(${EXECUTABLE_NAME}
		WIN32
		${FILE_SOURCES})
endif()

target_link_libraries(${EXECUTABLE_NAME} PUBLIC
	${GRAPHVIZ_LIB}
	# another stuff here
        )

target_include_directories(${EXECUTABLE_NAME} PUBLIC
	# another stuff here
	"${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/Lib/graphviz/include"
        # another stuff here
        )
```

[PainterRenderSystem.hpp](https://github.com/andraantariksa/cit310-visible-surface-rendering/blob/285bd91ccdae4b544cbef6df028f3f73789b4c31/Source/System/PainterRenderSystem.hpp)

```
// ...

extern gvplugin_library_t gvplugin_dot_layout_LTX_library;

// ...
```

Full project is here https://github.com/andraantariksa/cit310-visible-surface-rendering/blob/285bd91ccdae4b544cbef6df028f3f73789b4c31/

## Expected Behaviour

I'm expecting no error on compilation process

## Actual Behaviour

Linking error

```
Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	LNK2001	unresolved external symbol "struct gvplugin_library_t gvplugin_dot_layout_LTX_library" (?gvplugin_dot_layout_LTX_library@@3Ugvplugin_library_t@@A)	C:\Users\andra\Projects\cit310-visible-surface-rendering\out\build\x64-Debug (default)\cit310-visible-surface-rendering	C:\Users\andra\Projects\cit310-visible-surface-rendering\out\build\x64-Debug (default)\PainterRenderSystem.cpp.obj	1	
```

## OS Version

Windows 10 20H2 x64

## Graphviz Version

Grapgviz 2.44.1

summary: Unwanted space around html font tags with svg output
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Any html label with font color specification. For example:

```graphviz
digraph {
   main [
       label=<<font color='red'>main</font>( _1: <font color='darkgreen'>impl Fn()</font>, _2: <font color='darkgreen'>usize</font> )>
   ]
}
```

## Expected output

This is what you get with

```
dot -Tpng my_file.dot
dot -Txlib my_file.dot
```

![image](/uploads/c76688b1d1d07f4bde5f3618d1bc5950/image.png)

## Actual behaviour

This is what you get with

```
dot -Tsvg my_file.dot
```

![image](/uploads/d6d44d16eace43e03b8f11db008d2878/image.png)

The difference is subtile, but there are extra spaces between main and the opening parenthesis, as well as between Fn() and the comma, and between usize and the closing parenthesis.

## OS Version

Archlinux, up-to-date

## Graphviz Version

```
$ dot -V
dot - graphviz version 2.44.1
```

## Additional info

I discussed it on the [forum](https://forum.graphviz.org/t/unwanted-space-around-html-font-tags/460/3) and the bug was reproducible.

summary: host releases on Gitlab
description:
As discussed on private email, the current deployment workflow is failing and we don't seem to have the requisite knowledge to fix it. I proposed moving release hosting away from www2.graphviz.org to the releases tab on Gitlab.

I got partway through scripting something using [python-gitlab](https://python-gitlab.readthedocs.io/en/0.21.2/index.html), before I discovered there is no option to attach a file when creating a new release; Gitlab expects you to attach URLs that point to an external host.

I then discovered in October 2020 Gitlab added the ability to script your entire release deployment to the releases tab from within CI: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#release. Their [`release-cli` script](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release-cli) completely automates the process of creating a release.

This looks much simpler and less error prone than our current release process and I think we should move to it ASAP.

summary: Intermittent crash with dot layout
description:
The attached dot file crashes about half the time with dot:
```
"C:\Program Files\Graphviz 2.44.1\bin\dot.exe" ClusterCallButterfly-_git_uploadpack.dot -Txdot1.2 -o tst2.dot & echo %errorLevel%
-1073741819
```
How can I get dot to work consistently?

Graphviz is version 2.44.1. The intermittent crashing is happening on both mac and windows and with other dot files. I've been debugging from a custom program (gvlayout.cpp) that calls graphviz, but the crash happens with the shipped version of dot too (as shown above).

It looks like crash depends on the dictionary order. In collapse_sets (graphviz/lib/dotgen/rank.c) if the rank_set_class returns 0 first, then collapse_sets is called recursively. In the second call, rank_set_class returns 7 and make_new_cluster is called with the same subgraph pointer that is stored in the ccs variable of doDot (graphviz/lib/dotgen/dotinit.c). The ccs variable is cleared in dot_cleanup_graph  at the end of doDot, so the subgraph data pointer is null in place_flip_graph_label (graphviz/lib/common/postproc.c) causing a crash with this stack trace:
```
	gvlayout.exe!place_flip_graph_label(Agraph_s * g) Line 706	C
 	gvlayout.exe!place_flip_graph_label(Agraph_s * g) Line 727	C
 	gvlayout.exe!gv_postprocess(Agraph_s * g, int allowTranslation) Line 613	C
 	gvlayout.exe!gvLayoutJobs(GVC_s * gvc, Agraph_s * g) Line 88	C
 	gvlayout.exe!main(int argc, char * * argv) Line 472	C++
```
	
And this exception:
Exception thrown at 0x00007FF74D727ED0 in gvlayout.exe: 0xC0000005: Access violation reading location 0x0000000000000018

If the first call to rank_set_class from collapse_sets returns 7, then make_new_cluster does not share a subgraph pointer with ccs and the program runs successfully. 

Here is output from visual studio debugger with some breakpoints printing out variable information. The first is from a crash and the second ran successfully (exact same input). In the crash output the pointer used by the second place_flip_graph_label call has already been cleared by set_data (graphviz/lib/cgraph/rec.c).

summary: node and subgraph not center-aligned when connected to subgraph with node breadth of two
Division by zero in RectArea
description:
## Steps to reproduce

This issue used to be possible if graphviz was built with a slightly broken config.h, but presently only applies if  built so that LLONG_MAX <= UINT_MAX (or editing rectangle.c to force the fallback path).

```
$ dot -Tsvg -O rectarea_bug.dot
caught SIGFPE 8
```
## Expected Behaviour

Graph should render to svg file.

## Actual Behaviour

`dot` crashes with a `SIGFPE` on stderr.
 
```
caught SIGFPE 8
```

## OS Version

Linux

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1

## Additional info

On closer inspection the LLONG_MAX > UINT_MAX version is also buggy as it's missing parentheses around the subtraction.

I have a fix, but filing an issue so that I can use the issue number for the rtest.

summary: delete "untagged-*" tags?
description:
There are a lot of Git tags in the repository like "untagged-d41a2ad534044c12cb35" that seem to have been programmatically created. AFAIK these do not serve any purpose and just clutter the tags list. Shall we remove them?

We should possibly also remove the "Nightly" tag which doesn't point at any nightly release.

summary: add Ubuntu 20.10 to CI
CI config is broken for builds of tagged commits
description:
While working on #1892, I was trying to figure out why I kept getting these duplicate spurious failures in CI. I finally realized what was going on: Many of the CI jobs are not marked `except: tags` (i.e. they run on regular commits as well as on seeing a new Git tag), but the root job, "portable-source" *is* marked `except: tags`. So CI of a tagged commit always fails because the enabled jobs depend on something that cannot run. The error that's presented is:

> Found errors in your .gitlab-ci.yml:
> 
> * ubuntu18-04-test: needs 'portable-source' ubuntu18-04-test: needs 'ubuntu18-04-build' ubuntu19-10-test: needs 'portable-source' ubuntu19-10-test: needs 'ubuntu19-10-build' ubuntu20-04-test: needs 'portable-source' ubuntu20-04-test: needs 'ubuntu20-04-build' centos6-test: needs 'portable-source' centos6-test: needs 'centos6-build' centos7-test: needs 'portable-source' centos7-test: needs 'centos7-build' centos8-test: needs 'portable-source' centos8-test: needs 'centos8-build' fedora31-test: needs 'portable-source' fedora31-test: needs 'fedora31-build' fedora32-test: needs 'portable-source' fedora32-test: needs 'fedora32-build' fedora33-test: needs 'portable-source' fedora33-test: needs 'fedora33-build' macos-autotools-test: needs 'portable-source' macos-autotools-test: needs 'macos-autotools-build' ubuntu18-04-cmake-test: needs 'portable-source' ubuntu18-04-cmake-test: needs 'ubuntu18-04-cmake-build' centos7-cmake-test: needs 'portable-source' centos7-cmake-test: needs 'centos7-cmake-build' fedora31-cmake-test: needs 'portable-source' fedora31-cmake-test: needs 'fedora31-cmake-build' macos-cmake-test: needs 'portable-source' macos-cmake-test: needs 'macos-cmake-build'
> 
> You can also test your .gitlab-ci.yml in CI Lint 

E.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/pipelines/225795224

I assume this has gone unnoticed before now because we rarely tag commits.

summary: assert failure with nslimit1=0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```
dot -v -T[testcase.dot](/uploads/c924123004d606d2b4b31c1a1502aa17/testcase.dot)testcase.dot 
dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)
libdir = "/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/graphviz"
Activated plugin library: libgvplugin_dot_layout.so.6
Using layout: dot:dot_layout
Activated plugin library: libgvplugin_core.so.6
Using render: dot:core
Using device: dot:dot:core
The plugin configuration file:
	/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/graphviz/config6a
		was successfully loaded.
    render	:  cairo dot dot_json fig gd json json0 map mp pic pov ps svg tk visio vml vrml xdot xdot_json
    layout	:  circo dot fdp neato nop nop1 nop2 osage patchwork sfdp twopi
    textlayout	:  textlayout
    device	:  canon cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot dot_json eps fig gd gd2 gif gv imap imap_np ismap jpe jpeg jpg json json0 mp pdf pic plain plain-ext png pov ps ps2 svg svgz tk vdx vml vmlz vrml wbmp webp x11 xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4 xdot_json xlib
    loadimage	:  (lib) eps gd gd2 gif jpe jpeg jpg png ps svg webp xbm
pack info:
  mode   undefined
  size   0
  flags  0
  margin 8
pack info:
  mode   node
  size   0
  flags  0
fontname: "Times-Roman" resolved to: (ps:pango  Times New Roman,  REGULAR) (PangoCairoFcFont) "Times New Roman, Regular" /usr/share/fonts/truetype/msttcorefonts/Times_New_Roman.ttf
network simplex:  3 nodes 3 edges maxiter=0 balance=1
network simplex:  6 nodes 6 edges maxiter=0 balance=0
dot: rank.c:238: cluster_leader: Assertion `leader != NULL' failed.
Aborted
```

## Expected Behaviour

Either a successful render or a meaningful error message.

## Actual Behaviour

```
dot: rank.c:238: cluster_leader: Assertion `leader != NULL' failed.
Aborted
```

## OS Version

Debian

## Graphviz Version

Tested on Graphviz 2.44.1

## Additional info

This dot file in this issue came from a fuzzer, but has been manually simplified. I don't fully understand what the expected behaviour is with nslimit1 = 0 as there's not much [documentation](https://graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#d:nslimit1) on it, but anything that asserts causes problems when used as a library, batch job, or rpc server.

Here's the backtrace

```
    #7 0x560418ca8c0c in cluster_leader graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/rank.c:281:5
    #8 0x560418ca7754 in collapse_cluster graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/rank.c:311:2
    #9 0x560418ca524f in collapse_sets graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/rank.c:330:3
    #10 0x560418ca4ac7 in dot1_rank graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/rank.c:589:5
    #11 0x560418ca44db in dot_rank graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/rank.c:623:2
    #12 0x560418c38be5 in dotLayout graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/dotinit.c:311:9
    #13 0x560418c384c1 in doDot graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/dotinit.c:463:2
    #14 0x560418c37eb8 in dot_layout graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/dotgen/dotinit.c:509:22
    #15 0x560418bec06d in gvLayoutJobs graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/gvc/gvlayout.c:85:2
    #16 0x560418be19fc in gvLayout graphviz/v2_44_1/lib/gvc/gvc.c:65:9
```

The assert failure can be trivially avoided by changing  nslimit1 to any value greater than 0 in the testfile.

If nslimit1 <= 0 then `rank2` is called with `maxiter=0` causing it to bail early, meaning that there are no suitable nodes for `cluster_leader` to assign as leader.

Ideas:
 * modify `cluster_leader` to pick lowest rank node rather than rank 0.
 * modify `dot2_rank` to force maxiter = 1 if nslimit1 <=0.
 * somehow propagate an error up from `cluster_leader`
 * silently do nothing in `cluster_leader` etc.

summary: Multiple compile errors when compiling with PHP 8.0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Attempt to compile on a system with only PHP 8.0.

## Expected Behaviour

Successful compilation.

## Actual Behaviour

Failed compilation. Complains that PHP 7 not found, and suggests what to do if PHP 5 is wanted. I want neither; I want PHP 8.0. Further, failed compilation with multiple errors related to ZEND macros being deprecated.

## OS Version

Linux 5.9.12; GCC 10.2

## Graphviz Version

Latest release ?2.40.1? and also a just-cloned copy of the git repository.

## Additional info

Nope. I didn't include a ton of output because this will be obvious to anyone compiling it with PHP 8.0.

broken overflow checks in RectArea

$ # Also run the above on a stable build of 2.44.1
$ diff -u /tmp/simple-twopi-stable.svg /tmp/simple-twopi-git.svg 
--- /tmp/simple-twopi-stable.svg	2020-12-14 01:58:42.310517803 -0800
+++ /tmp/simple-twopi-git.svg	2020-12-14 01:58:56.498488850 -0800

[simple.dot](/uploads/5d604bf588a1ea296289eee984a7015d/simple.dot)

![simple-twopi-git.svg](/uploads/1079455cbb8bde5b9ced3854a033be33/simple-twopi-git.svg)

![simple-twopi-stable.svg](/uploads/32c0837aa134dbfb2b2fd1bd198fc0a2/simple-twopi-stable.svg)

## Expected Behaviour

Title elements should not have changed between versions. In viewers like chrome, the title is used as a tooltip, and provides accessibility (e.g. when rendered with small fonts).

## Actual Behaviour

Title elements have been replaced with anonymous ids. This likely relates to the fix for #1767

## OS Version

Debian linux.

## Additional info

It's worth noting that running this in plain dot doesn't suffer the same problem, which might indicate why this change hasn't been picked up in regression tests. Under plain, there are still additional : in edge titles. Possibly related to !1527 ?

@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@

summary: Segfault with multiple segfaults containing same node and newrank=true
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Running `dot` on the following file causes a segfault.

```
digraph G
{
        rankdir=TB
        newrank=true

        subgraph Cluster_1 {
                label = L1
                node1 [label = "1"];
        }

        subgraph Cluster_2 {
                label = L2
                node1 [label = "11"];
        }
}
```

Removing either subgraph, or removing `newrank=true` avoids the segfault.

```
$ dot -v minimal.txt

summary: recent GVPR (from git) loses node names
Regression in agmemread caused by change in scan.l
Support for hypergraphs
description:
Graphviz sadly doesn't currently support hypergraphs. It would be great if it did. I propose two new graph-types, `hypergraph` and `dihypergraph`.

Layout: using the algorithm given in https://bioconductor.riken.jp/packages/3.3/bioc/vignettes/hyperdraw/inst/doc/hyperdraw.pdf, using dummy nodes to represent the hyperedges, and some Bezier-splines magic.

Notation: single nodes on either end of a hyperedge represented as now. For `dihypergraph`, tails and heads would be grouped with `()`, which are currently a syntax error. For `hypergraph`, all the nodes would simply be in a `()`.

For undirected, a single one would be a self-loop, since undirected hyperedges are conceptually a set, and that's the only meaningful mapping to a self-loop.

Is there appetite for this?

summary: Bison version for macOS
description:
## Steps to reproduce

First time I tried to use CMake with output to Xcode. I prepared a small script:
```
INSTALLER_ROOT="~/xcode/"
GVROOT="~/Downloads/graphviz-master/"
GVTARGET="${GVROOT}/_build"
PLATFORM_DEVELOPER_BIN_DIR="/usr/bin"

export CC="/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/clang"
 #  CPP="${PLATFORM_DEVELOPER_BIN_DIR}/clang -E"
export CXX="${PLATFORM_DEVELOPER_BIN_DIR}/clang++ "
#   OBJC="${PLATFORM_DEVELOPER_BIN_DIR}/clang"
#   LD="${PLATFORM_DEVELOPER_BIN_DIR}/ld"

cmake -G Xcode -H${GVROOT} -B${GVTARGET} -D CMAKE_C_COMPILER=${CC} -D CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=${CXX}
```
I run the script the open the result Xcode project file in Xcode. I press run. 

## Expected Behaviour

Project will compile. 

## Actual Behaviour

Resulting project doesn't compile do to wrong Bison version. macOS comes with an inbuilt 2.3 version and according to internet research is dependent on it. But common_obj needs bison 3.0 or later. 

![image](/uploads/ec88dbde191b12fc9b5b01f72542432a/image.png)

## OS Version

macOS 11.1 (Big Sur, M1 Chip), Xcode Version 12.3 (12C33)

## Graphviz Version

snapshot of today (31/12/2020)

## Additional info

I assume we should make it possible to specify the right bison version. (in my case /opt/homebrew/opt/bison/bin)
First attempt was to add it to script like this: 

```
# ============================= Build dependencies =============================
if(PLATFORM STREQUAL "Darwin")
    set(BISON_EXECUTABLE "/opt/homebrew/opt/bison/bin" CACHE PATH "Bison executable")
endif()
find_package(AWK REQUIRED)
find_package(BISON REQUIRED)
find_package(FLEX REQUIRED)
find_package(Git REQUIRED)
find_package(Perl REQUIRED)
```

which fixed one instance but common_obj problem but this problem remained: 
`htmlparse.y:14.10-14: require bison 3.0, but have 2.3`

Maybe we should do something like: 
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53877344/cannot-configure-cmake-to-look-for-homebrew-installed-version-of-bison

Unfortunately, this is day one of my experience with CMake, so I rather seek guidance then just doing stuff.

summary: Impossible to render a 300 nodes + 900 edges dot
description:
## Steps to reproduce

When trying to render the following dot file (a representation of a densenet121 network, composed of 300 nodes and 900 edges) the renderer freezes.
[densenet121.dot](/uploads/be8a8aacfaf83ea34d6b522cb67d779e/densenet121.dot)

It freezes when using the dot command line tool, and when using it as a C++ library when the gvLayout() function is called.
Other dot graph have no issues rendering, even with a larger number of nodes and edges.

## Expected Behaviour

No freezing, rendering in less than 5 seconds.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

graphviz 2.44.1 (20200629.0846)

summary: Feature request: subgraph as a node
description:
## Steps to reproduce

<!-- List what commands you ran, any errors you see. If you run commands over some input, attaching the input to the issue will help us track down the bug. -->

```graphviz
digraph G {
   subgraph cluster_0 {
      a;
      b;
   }
   cluster_0 -> abc;
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

<!-- Fill in with what you expected to see. -->

I hope there will be an edge starting from `cluster_0` to `abc`.

## Actual Behaviour

<!-- Show any unexpected output -->

The syntax above is not supported.

## OS Version

<!-- Windows/macOS/Linux/BSD? What version? -->

General syntax.

## Graphviz Version

<!-- run $ dot -V -->

This is a feature request.

## Additional info

<!-- Fill in with anything else that might be important. -->

Graphviz is the de facto standard on dot language. If a subgraph can inherit all the features of a node, the graph can scale a lot. Please consider this feature request! Great thanks!

summary: remove regex usage
description:
This is a bit of an open question, wherein I want to see if others think this is a good idea.

The Graphviz tree contains exactly three usages of the POSIX regular expression API (regex.h): ./lib/gvc/gvconfig.c, ./lib/gvc/gvusershape.c, and ./cmd/smyrna/btree.c. The first two look trivial and the last one looks like it's not even used as a regex. To support these three uses, we take a dependency on RxSpencer because Windows does not support this API.

Would it be an improvement to refactor these to not use regexes at all and then drop the RxSpencer dependency?

summary: Graphviz doesn't compile on macOS with cmake/Xcode combination
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Download a clean graphviz on a macOS system. 
Use `cmake -G Xcode ..` and `cmake --build build` (in correct folders)

## Expected Behaviour

Full build :-)

## Actual Behaviour

It doesn't compile. I have identified so far several reasons: 
- wrong bison version (see https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1916#additional-info)
- Xcode not able to handle OBJECT libraries (see [here](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/add_library.html), where under Object Libraries is says: Some native build systems (such as Xcode) may not like targets that have only object files, so consider adding at least one real source file to any target that references $<TARGET_OBJECTS:objlib>.) 

The cmake/Xcode problem manifests itself in two ways: 
1. Wrong compile order (first compile complains some object files missing), see here: 
```
Ld /Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/gvc/Debug/libgvc.6.0.0.dylib normal (in target 'gvc' from project 'Graphviz')
 [..]
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/args.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/arrows.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/colxlate.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/ellipse.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/emit.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/geom.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/globals.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/htmllex.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/htmltable.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/input.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/intset.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/ns.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/shapes.o'
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/Objects-normal/arm64/htmlparse.o'
Command Ld failed with a nonzero exit code
```
2. The first problem can be fixed just by executing the build a few times until all object files are created! Then compilation fails because of the missing 'libcommon.a' during compilation of `tred`. Indeed, the library isn't produced. Instead of `build/lib/common/Debug/libcommon.a` the build process produces `build/lib/common/Graphviz.build/Debug/common_obj.build/libcommon_obj.a`. See error message here: 
```
Ld /Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/cmd/tools/Debug/tred normal (in target 'tred' from project 'Graphviz')
[..]   
clang: error: no such file or directory: '/Users/klaus/Downloads/graphviz-master/build/lib/common/Debug/libcommon.a'
Command Ld failed with a nonzero exit code
```

## OS Version

macOS 11.1 Big Sur (on "Apple Silicon")

## Graphviz Version

current developer snapshot 

## Additional info

To compile common as object codes seems to be at least for the current cmake build superfluous: https://forum.graphviz.org/t/cmake-creates-common-library-as-object-library/500/10?u=vithanco 

My straightforward suggestion would be to merge common and gvc - at least for the cmake branch. But I expect this to be controversial. 

The alternative is to move at least one `.c` file to the static build. I created an empty `dummy.c` file and added it to the CMakeLists.txt:
add_library(common STATIC
    $<TARGET_OBJECTS:common_obj>
    dummy.c # new addition in order to avoid Xcode problem
)

That works fine. 

I would expect that if the cmake branch will be further developed that we will run into the sam issues with the other OBJECT library pack.

## Next Steps

I will present a MR for these two issues soon, which will add the script needed for BISON and a dummy file for Xcode in common and pack. Any comments on this?

summary: Potential Memory Issue
description:
## Steps to reproduce

- Compile graphviz for mac on x86_64 architecture as static libraries
- use this function to load 
```
GVC_t * loadGraphvizLibraries() {
    GVC_t * gvc =  gvNEWcontext(&lt_preloaded_symbols[0], 4);
    gvAddLibrary(gvc, &gvplugin_dot_layout_LTX_library);
    gvAddLibrary(gvc, &gvplugin_neato_layout_LTX_library);
    gvAddLibrary(gvc, &gvplugin_core_LTX_library);
    textfont_dict_open(gvc);  // this is a workaround due to https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/issues/1520
    return gvc;
}
```
- run the app with all kind of sanitisers and checks. 

## Expected Behaviour

Graphviz ready to layout. 

## Actual Behaviour

The loading fails. It claims an stack-use-after-return error. If I understand the message correctly, then the problem steams from `gvplugin_install`. However, I cannot see the issue.

macOS 11.2 Big Sur. Interestingly, it works nicely on the arm64 architecture but fails on x86_64, both on Intel chips or with Rosetta2. 

## Graphviz Version

current developer snapshot 1

description:
Hello
I'm using large DOT graph to check the consistency of large genealogical trees. Most of times I don't need to print the tree, so that I don't use the SIZE command, with the purpose of obtaining a "natural size" graph.
Actually the graph seems to be in "natural size" horizontally, I mean it grows without constraints horizontally. In vertical direction, instead, the graph appears to be limited in a way I can't explain. 
Usually I select the .pdf output format, but the problem is the same with the .jpg format.
Thank you[pp.pdf](/uploads/2508b8991b065420476c06c82052e7ed/pp.pdf)

summary: Subtree ordering gets messed up by constraint=false edges even when ordering=out is present
description:
Attached is a file (which is a representation of an AST) that contains cross-references between nodes. Even though the graph is specified with ordering=out and the cross-references have constraint=false, their presence still changes the ordering of the subgraph of specific nodes.

[thefile.dot](/uploads/ed434f6e7c24f198b4368a7cfa586214/usefulexample.c.typed.dot)


## Steps to reproduce

render the attached file.
Then run `grep -vwE "(constraint)" thefile.dot > newfile.dot` and render `newfile.dot`

## Expected Behaviour

The graphs should look the same (ignoring the removed edges)

## Actual Behaviour

The graphs do not look the same, more specifically the ordering of the nodes under the top-level node is wrong.

## OS Version
Linux, but that should not matter

## Graphviz Version

2.44.1 (0)

summary: Question about userout() function in agerror.c
description:
I am using GraphViz as a library and calling the graph functions in my application to generate an SVG rendering of DOT data which is passed to `agmemread()` as described in the PDF documentation `libguide.pdf` and `Agraph.pdf`. I would like to capture the errors or warnings in my application instead of having them written to `stderr`. To do this, I can set a custom callback function `agseterrfunc()` as described on p. 12 of the latter PDF file. The function is typedef'd like this:
```
typedef int (*agusererrf) (char*);
agusererrf agseterrf(agusererrf);
```

Two questions arise:

(1) There is a dynamically allocated buffer which is passed as a `char*` to the user's custom error function, if set. If the text to be written is larger than the buffer, it is grown. However, it appears that this buffer is never freed unless the call to `realloc()` failed. Does this happen automatically when the library is unloaded or the application quits?

(2) What value(s) should my function return (an `int` is required)?

Thank you.

summary: [GVPR] hasAttr sometimes returns false positive
typo in pathcross
description:
Switching to C99 compilation results in a new compiler warning:

```
dotsplines.c: In function ‘pathscross’:
dotsplines.c:2498:32: warning: logical ‘and’ of equal expressions [-Wlogical-op]
     if ((ND_out(n0).size != 1) && (ND_out(n0).size != 1))
                                ^~
```

This is pretty obviously a typo, but I'm not sure what this code is supposed to be.

summary: typos in gpcanvas.c
description:
Switching to C99 compilation exposes the following new warnings:

```
gpcanvas.c:703:44: warning: logical ‘and’ applied to non-boolean constant [-Wlogical-op]
             hi = (*s >> 4) & 15, lo = *s++ && 15;
                                            ^~
gpcanvas.c:705:44: warning: logical ‘and’ applied to non-boolean constant [-Wlogical-op]
             hi = (*s >> 4) & 15, lo = *s++ && 15;
                                            ^~
gpcanvas.c:707:44: warning: logical ‘and’ applied to non-boolean constant [-Wlogical-op]
             hi = (*s >> 4) & 15, lo = *s++ && 15;
                                            ^~
```

It looks clear these are meant to be bitwise operators.

summary: Out-of-bounds write caused by incorrect error handling of malloc in genUserdata (gxl2gv.c:152)
description:
gxl2gv is vulnerable to OOB write when opening GXL file after exhausting the memory pool.

Incorrect handling of the value returned by malloc in genUserdata may lead to:
- out-of-bound write attempt and segmentation fault error in case of restrictive memory protection,
- near NULL pointer overwrite in case of limited memory restrictions (e.g. in embedded environments).

Memory allocations are triggered during opening GXL files, so the allocation error can be caused locally or remotely depending on the way of obtaining files.
In some embedded environments near zero memory areas are used to store device configuration, so in this case such configuration can be overwritten using this vulnerability.

Vulnerable code (gxl2gv.c):

	 51: #define NEW(t)      malloc(sizeof(t))

	150: static userdata_t *genUserdata(void)
	151: {
	152:     userdata_t *user = NEW(userdata_t);
	153:     agxbinit(&(user->xml_attr_name), NAMEBUF, 0);
	154:     agxbinit(&(user->xml_attr_value), SMALLBUF, 0);
	155:     agxbinit(&(user->composite_buffer), SMALLBUF, 0);

## Steps to reproduce

The issue can be reproduced and tested using ErrorSanitizer (https://gitlab.com/ErrorSanitizer/ErrorSanitizer).

0. Install gdb

1. Download and unpack code of ErrorSanitizer (https://gitlab.com/ErrorSanitizer/ErrorSanitizer)

2. Perform compilation of ErrorSanitizer according to the manual (https://gitlab.com/ErrorSanitizer/ErrorSanitizer#compilation)

	cd ErrorSanitizer; make

3. Set ESAN to the path of ErrorSanitizer directory

	export ESAN=/opt/...

4. Download attached map temp_1.cur_input
[temp_1.cur_input](/uploads/12f4afe6b485dc12ec2063fb9da946ae/temp_1.cur_input)

5. Download and compile graphviz (after compilation with symbols gdb results will be more readable)

6. Run gxl2gv test program example with ErrorSanitizer in gdb using:

	gdb -batch -ex='run' -ex='backtrace' -ex='backtrace full' --args env LD_PRELOAD=$ESAN/error_sanitizer_preload.so ./gxl2gv temp_1.cur_input

You should receive similar output:

	process 16938 is executing new program: gxl2gv

	Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
	0x00007ffff799a697 in agxbinit () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcgraph.so.6
	#0  0x00007ffff799a697 in agxbinit () from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcgraph.so.6
	No symbol table info available.
	#1  0x0000555555559d2d in ?? ()
	No symbol table info available.
	#2  0x000055555555617b in ?? ()
	No symbol table info available.
	#3  0x00007ffff718db97 in __libc_start_main (main=0x555555555ef0, argc=2, argv=0x7fffffffde88, init=<optimized out>, fini=<optimized out>, rtld_fini=<optimized out>, stack_end=0x7fffffffde78) at ../csu/libc-start.c:310
		self = <optimized out>
		__self = <optimized out>
		result = <optimized out>
		unwind_buf = {cancel_jmp_buf = {{jmp_buf = {0, 8341880585942211103, 93824992240464, 140737488346752, 0, 0, 2779008384571021855, 2779025160807520799}, mask_was_saved = 0}}, priv = {pad = {0x0, 0x0, 0x7ffff7de5783 <_dl_init+259>, 0x7ffff7db2d10}, data = {prev = 0x0, cleanup = 0x0, canceltype = -136423549}}}
		not_first_call = <optimized out>
	#4  0x000055555555637a in ?? ()
	No symbol table info available.


With symbols this output will look like this:

	process 19071 is executing new program: gxl2gv

	Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
	agxbinit (xb=xb@entry=0x0, hint=hint@entry=100, init=init@entry=0x0) at agxbuf.c:34
	34		xb->dyna = 1;
	#0  agxbinit (xb=xb@entry=0x0, hint=hint@entry=100, init=init@entry=0x0) at agxbuf.c:34
	No locals.
	#1  0x0000555555559d1d in genUserdata () at gxl2gv.c:153
		user = 0x0
		user = <optimized out>
	#2  gxl_to_gv (gxlFile=0x55555575f880) at gxl2gv.c:667
		buf = '\000' <repeats 6152 times>...
		done = <optimized out>
		udata = <optimized out>
		parser = <optimized out>
	#3  0x00005555555561c3 in main (argc=<optimized out>, argv=<optimized out>) at cvtgxl.c:208
		inFile = <optimized out>
		G = <optimized out>
		prev = 0x0

## Expected Behaviour

See following recommendations for details (especially the calloc example):
https://wiki.sei.cmu.edu/confluence/display/c/ERR33-C.+Detect+and+handle+standard+library+errors

## Actual Behaviour

Memory allocation error is not handled correctly leading to segmentation fault.

## OS Version

Not dependent on OS

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.44.2~dev.20201210.0457 (20201210.0457)

## Additional info

summary: Header file graphviz_version.h has no include guards
description:
I can #include this header since it is installed along with the other headers in `/usr/local/include` (on Linux Ubuntu 18.04 built from GraphViz sources). It consists only of various #defines, but is the only place I can find where the current GraphViz version is available in the code. Apparently, it is not included by other headers drawn in when I #include <gvc.h> in my own code.

Shouldn't there be include guards present to prevent multiple definitions of the symbols?

summary: i want to  set width and heigth for subgraph cluster,but it does not work.
regression: newlines embedded in quoted labels / node names are not preserved in 2.46.0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

The following graph produces different output on 2.46.0 than 2.44.1

```
graph { 
  node1 [label="line 1
line 2
"];
  node2 [label="line 3
line4"];
  node1 -- node2
  node2 -- "line 5
line 6"
}
```

I don't see anything in the changelog that would lead me to expect this (although https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/165 might be related) 

## Expected Behaviour

I would expect these labels to continue to have multiple lines, although http://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#k:escString isn't clear on the behaviour.

If this was an intentional change in behaviour, then an update to documentation and mention in the changelog would be warranted.

## Actual Behaviour

The lines have been concatenated.

summary: Missing vcruntime140.dll in stable_windows_10_msbuild_Release_Win32_graphviz-2.46.0-win32.zip
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Download  stable_windows_10_msbuild_Release_Win32_graphviz-2.46.0-win32.zip, unzip it and run dot.exe on a clean, fresh Windows 10.

## Expected Behaviour

Should work.

## Actual Behaviour

Doesn't work due to the missing library vcruntime140.dll, which should be included in the zip.

## OS Version

Windows, win32 ".zip" version

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.46.0 (20210118.1747)

## Additional info

- The library vcruntime140.dll is usually already available on developer machines, as it is part of the Visual Studio installation (of course) and then already installed in the C:\Windows\System32 folder. That's the reason why a developer can't reproduce / won't notice that problem.
- looking from dot.exe, the dependency to that file is through all dependend .dll to that .dll, including dot.exe itself.
- The missing file is distributed in the installer package stable_windows_10_cmake_Release_x64_graphviz-install-2.46.0-win64.exe. So you don't have any problem if you install graphviz with that.
- Since it is already included in the x64 installer, I guess that's not a licensing problem to include that in the .zip distribution too. If it is, I would rather guess to remove the dependency from the build generally, also from the x64 build.

```bash
$ man -M /cygdrive/c/opt/graphviz/share/man dot
man: warning: /cygdrive/c/opt/graphviz/share/man/man3/dot.1: ignoring bogus filename
No manual entry for dot
```

> manpage for dot should open

Show any unexpected output

> shown above

## OS Version

Windows/macOS/Linux/BSD? What version?

> Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

run $ dot -V

```bash
$ dot -V
dot - graphviz version 2.46.0 (20210118.1747)
```

## Additional info

Fill in with anything else that might be important.

> caused by section 1 manpages placed in man3 directory instead of man1 - fix is to set two install directory paths for man1 and man3 in CMakeLists.txt - then have each command like cmd/dot/CMakeLists.txt use the correct man section directory

summary: Class in SVG on Windows
description:
Hi, the class attribute is not render the same way on Windows and Ubuntu

## Steps to reproduce

dot file :
```
digraph simple {
    c [class="bar"]

    a -> b [class="foo"]
    c -> b

    subgraph cluster_0 {
        class="sub-foobar";
            d
            e        
    }
}
```

Command line on both Ubuntu (WSL) and Windows

`dot -Tsvg a.dot -o a.svg`

## Expected Behaviour

The class attribute should be translated into css class in the html document

## Actual Behaviour

With the Ubuntu version, everything ok, but with windows, the classes doesnt appears. On the same browser, same system, same document and same source.

## OS Version

Windows 10
Ubuntu 20 (WSL)

## Graphviz Version

Ubuntu : 2.40.1 (latest using apt)
Windows : 2.38.0 (latest using winget)

summary: broken sorting in nearest_neighbor_graph_ann.cpp
description:
The two functions `sortPtsX` and `sortPtsY` in nearest_neighbor_graph_ann.cpp contain nested loops whose inner loop is useless. The loop counter is never used, so the body of the loop is a no-op after the first iteration.

It's not obvious to me what this code is attempting to accomplish. It uses the global `dim` that is not declared `const` but whose value is always `4`. However, the functions are called from `nearest_neighbor_graph_ann` that takes a custom `dim` value from its caller. It looks to me as if the bodies of the nested loops were coded to assume `dim` is always `4` but also ignore their containing loop.

What is the right fix here? It looks like the functions to reach this are not in any shipped header and Graphviz itself only calls into this code with `dim == 4`. So maybe we should just remove `dim` as a parameter and remove the inner loops?

summary: Versions 2.44.1 and 2.46 have no stable_release_ tag
description:
Distro version trackers like Fedora's release-monitoring detect new releases by tracking the `stable_release_` tags by GraphViz. However, version 2.46 seems to not have this tag (maybe a push was forgotten?).

Apologies if this was an intentional change, but I couldn't find anything on it online.
