summary: remove sprintf usage
description: I think we should start proactively looking at replacing the use of `sprintf` with `snprintf` in the code base. `sprintf` is a common source of memory safety issues and, while I don't think it's the root cause of any of our known ones, it will likely help us avoid some pain in the future.

description:
## Steps to reproduce

Submit a merge request to graphviz

## Expected Behaviour

CI passes on my markhnsn/graphviz repo.
Perhaps CI doesn't run the macOS tests, because I don't have access.

## Actual Behaviour

CI hangs forever because I don't have a macOS runner. Example: https://gitlab.com/markhnsn/graphviz/-/pipelines/259086923

## Additional info

I wonder if we could restrict the macOS CI job to only run for `graphviz/graphviz` GitLab repo. There's examples of using `only:refs: master@graphviz/graphviz` to restrict to only one repo. I'm not sure how to allow it for `master`, merge requests, tags, etc etc though.

summary: setting rankdir causes odd node ordering
description:
## Steps to reproduce
  (rankdirBug.gv is attached)
- run **dot -Tpng rankdirBug.gv >rankdirBug.png**   ##   rankdir=LR
- then **dot -Grankdir="" -Tpng rankdirBug.gv >rankdirBugOK.png**
- compare the two output files, note that the node order within the subgraphs is different

## Expected Behaviour

the order of the nodes within the subgraphs should be as directed by the input (controlled by edge weights)

## Actual Behaviour

When **rankdir=LR**, the node order is not the desired order

## OS Version

Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS on Windows 10 WSL

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304)  
and  
dot - graphviz version 2.46.2~dev.20210215.0502 (20210215.0502)  

## Additional info

rankdirBug.gv:  
```
digraph video {
    graph[rankdir="LR"]  // here lies the issue

    subgraph cluster_main{
      MAIN 
    }

    subgraph cluster_ingest {
        {rank=same
	edge  [ weight=999  style=invis ]
	A->B->C->D->E->F->G->H->I->J
      }
    }

    subgraph cluster_onprem {
	{rank=same
	edge  [weight=999  style=invis]  
        M1 -> M2 -> M3 -> M4 -> M5;
	}
    }

    edge [weight=1]

    D -> M1
    E -> M2
    F -> M3
    G -> M3
    H -> M3  
    I -> M4
    J -> M5
    A -> MAIN
    B -> MAIN
    C -> MAIN
    D -> MAIN
    M1 -> MAIN
    M2 -> MAIN
}
```
![rankdirBugOK](/uploads/ec640a68e2338a3178b784e723a6eab3/rankdirBugOK.png)

summary: Windows build thinks xdg-open can be used to open a web browser
description:
For some reason windows/include/config.h has the following:

```c
/* Command to open a browser on a URL */
#define BROWSER "xdg-open"
```

xdg-open is a Linux thing and it seems clear this is intended to read `start`, like in cmake/config_checks.cmake. I haven't seen any users reporting this, so maybe this is currently unused.

summary: GVPR incorrectly understands color schemes
description:
lib/gvpr/actions.c contains the following code:

```c
/* resolveColor:
 * Resolve input color str allowing color scheme namespaces.
 *  0) "black" => "black"
 *     "white" => "white"
 *     "lightgrey" => "lightgrey"
 *    NB: This is something of a hack due to the remaining codegen.
 *        Once these are gone, this case could be removed and all references
 *        to "black" could be replaced by "/X11/black".
...
    if ((*str == 'b') || !strncmp(str+1,"lack",4)) return str;
    if ((*str == 'w') || !strncmp(str+1,"hite",4)) return str;
    if ((*str == 'l') || !strncmp(str+1,"ightgrey",8)) return str;
```

The logical operators here are pretty clearly meant to be `&&`, not `||`.

summary: xdot man page does not document some functions
xdot JSON output is not valid JSON
CI Graphviz builds are delayed by unrelated Docker image builds
description:
Now that we've introduced an initial CI stage that conditionally rebuilds all the Docker images, all build tasks implicitly depend on all tasks in this stage. In a typical CI run, this is not noticeable because the Docker images are not rebuilt and the time of the portable source task dominates them all. I.e. the Docker image rebuild tasks all finish before the portable source task is done.

However, when the Docker images *are* rebuilt you end up in a situation where the Ubuntu 18.04 image rebuild has completed, the portable source task has completed, but the Ubuntu 18.04 build task won't start because it's waiting for the other Docker rebuild tasks to finish. I think we should introduce depends clauses for all these tasks.

summary: Edge tooltips not behaving correctly, nor matching the documentation
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Given the following graph:

[tooltip_example.gv](/uploads/8952566996018d6f9063f82689642827/tooltip_example.gv)

```
digraph  {
  node1 -> node2 [label="via tooltip, no URL", tooltip="this is a tooltip, via tooltip!"]
  node1 -> node2 [label="via tooltip, with URL", URL="https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz", tooltip="this is a tooltip, via tooltip!"]
  node1 -> node2 [label="via edgetooltip", edgetooltip="this is a tooltip, via edgetooltip!"]
  node1 -> node2 [label="via labeltooltip", labeltooltip="this is a tooltip, via labeltooltip!"]
}
```

2. Convert it to an SVG: `dot -Tsvg tooltip_example.gv -o tooltip_example.svg`

3. Load the SVG into a web browser to hover with the mouse above each edge and each of their labels, to view their tooltips.

![tooltip_example.svg](/uploads/84a62fe7e463bc06f08875e7ccaff9ae/tooltip_example.svg)

## Expected Behaviour

The edges with an `edgetooltip` and `labeltooltip` should show tooltips only on their edge or label, respectively. The two edges defined with a `tooltip` should show tooltips on both their edges and labels, because the label is part of the edge.

## Actual Behaviour

- Good: The edges with an `edgetooltip` or `labeltooltip` behave as expected. Note that this is in constrast to the documentation (https://graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#d:edgetooltip and https://graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#d:labeltooltip), because supposedly these tooltips should only appear if there's a `URL` defined. Please don't change this behavior! Why should it even matter whether there's a URL? For my use cases, sometimes I don't have a URL but I still want to show a tooltip..

- Good: The contents of `tooltip` is indeed always applied to the edge itself (best checked by hovering above the arrows).

- **Bad**: The contents of `tooltip` is never applied to the edge's label, however the label _does_ receive a tooltip containing the contents of the label, if there's a `URL` defined for that edge. Not only is this redundant (why show the same thing twice?), but also a bit confusing because it's not showing the standard contents.

Long story short, the only way to show a tooltip also on the label for an edge is to define both the `tooltip` (or `edgetooltip`) as well as its `labeltooltip`. It's not a critical bug, but very annoying for maintenance/development.

## Documentation Fix

From the `attrs.html` page, remove both of the following sentences, because they aren't true (nor should they be):

1. For `edgetooltip` remove the sentence `Used only if the edge has a URL or edgeURL attribute.`

2. For `labeltooltip` remove the sentence `Used only if the edge has a URL or labelURL attribute.`

## OS Version

Linux

## Graphviz Version

```
$ dot -V
dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)
```

## Related Issues

On first glance, one might see https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1425 as a duplicate _but it's not_, because that ticket is only about adding support for tooltips embedded within HTML labels.

I have multiple custom-built packages in /usr/sup.  I have a new Python build in /usr/sup/Python-3.9.2.  Based on https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1693, I built a new version of swig, as my existing one is quite old; it's in /usr/sup/swig-4.0.2.  There is nothing in /usr/local.

summary: lab_gamut_data misses a value
description:
If you peer very closely at the lookup table in lib/edgepaint/lab_gamut.c you will notice all the ranges are continuous except for L=5,a=22 which has a hole at b=7:

```c
5,22,5,
5,22,6,
5,22,8,
5,23,-37,
```

I'm pretty sure this is a typo and `5,22,7` is also meant to be present in this list.

----

In case you're wondering why I was idly reading the contents of a lookup table, I was not. I was back on the "let's optimize this large artifact" train, as [previously discussed on the forum](https://forum.graphviz.org/t/fatal-error-c1060-compiler-is-out-of-heap-space-for-lib-edgepaint-lab-gamut-c/187). I have a pretty impactful compression (MR forthcoming), but my script to validate that my compression was a functional no-op detected a mismatch on `5,22,7` as I'd assumed all ranges were continuous.

the last `@param` should not be present.

summary: pylint CI job runs on tags
description:
383ec8753b8007d26fc4f6eb51c61b6d8b71d12e added a pylint task in CI. This task is unrestricted, so Gitlab thinks it is meant to run on tags as well as on master. Every other task is restricted to only run on master (including the dependencies of the pylint job) so CI now fails on tags. E.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/pipelines/270947501.

This task should be restricted to only run on master.

summary: updating the website download links is too error prone
description: The combination of (a) Gitlab's generic package UI mis-aligning table cells and suppressing copy-paste, (b) the opaque download URLs, and (c) the sheer volume of release artifacts we offer makes it almost impossible to submit a correct Graphviz website update. I think we should alter the deploy script to print a suitable diff for the website, so we can then copy-paste this from the CI log to avoid typos.

The following linux command will list all the undocumented calls to **agget** (the attribute fetching routine) in any .c or .h file in the **lib** directory tree (according to **doc/infosrc/attrs**)  
`grep 'agget('  $(find . -type f |grep '\.[ch]$')|grep './lib/'|gawk -F'"' '{print $2}'|sort -u|gawk 'NR==1{next}{print}'|while read X;do Z=`grep "^:$X:" doc/infosrc/attrs`;echo "$X  +++  $Z";done |grep -v ':'`

No undocumented attributes (naively)

## Actual Behaviour

Several useful attributes discovered

```
_draw_  +++  required for _background, in lib/common/emit.c
TBbalance +++ see here https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1339, in lib/common/ns.c
beautify  +++  sfdp attribute, in lib/sfdpgen/sfdpinit.c
cluster  +++ alternate to naming a graph "cluster...", in lib/common/utils.c
clustercolor  +++  in lib/sparse/DotIO.c
compact  +++  for edges into/out of a cluster, used to determine "is_a_strong_cluster", in lib/dotgen/rank.c
labelaligned  +++  part of emit_begin_edge, in lib/common/emit.c
linelength  +++  used to determine max length of printed text output, in lib/cgraph/write.c
odb  +++  used to help debug ortho lines (if #DEBUG is defined), in lib/ortho/ortho.c
oneblock  +++  circo only, in lib/circogen/circular.c
postaction  +++  allows "reparseable input", in lib/common/input.c
```

summary: reference counted strings put the HTML bit in the middle of the reference count
description:
This is something I noticed a long time ago and has been on my list of things to fix, but I thought I should actually document the situation.

lib/cgraph/refstr.c implements reference-counted strings with the structure `refstr_t`. Since the initial commit of cgraph, d7767d4b5c511afa89b46798eea4e2f915930844, `HTML_BIT` has been (IMHO incorrectly) set based on `unsigned int` instead of `unsigned long`. Presumably this was not an issue because most machines were 32-bit x86 at the time, where `sizeof(unsigned int) == sizeof(unsigned long)`.

In the transition to x86-64 machines, this setup became awkward. The reference count is 8 bytes wide, but `HTML_BIT` is set to be bit 31. I.e. the bit indicating that a string is HTML is now in the middle of the reference count. A string with ≥ 2³¹ references, something that is possible on an x86-64 machine, now accidentally sets the HTML bit. Note that this ecosystem transition also made the comment about `HTML_BIT` incorrect, `/* msbit of unsigned long */`.

d1244c8001e8c681def4c0ff25a91136845c2a75 did a tree-wide replacement of `unsigned long` with `uint64_t`, which further compounded the situation. Now the HTML bit is in the incorrect position on *both* 32-bit and 64-bit x86.

It's debatable whether this bug has any effect or is latent, because it's effectively masked by another bug, !1857. Nevertheless I think we should fix it.

The cleanest solution is to stop storing two things in one field. We can use a bitfield to implement the correct semantics in a safer way, making the compiler do the shifting and masking for us:

```c
  uint64_t refcnt: sizeof(uint64_t) * 8 - 1;
  uint64_t is_html: 1;
```

It is questionable whether this even needs to be a bitfield, and not simply a `uint64_t` and a `bool`, but I think we should leave this space optimization in place for now.

summary: CI docker push tasks wait for all docker build tasks
description:
The next CI bottleneck...

Commit 51fa5d8c5217d4e298e682c92e0fc6aced571ed3 allowed the portable source CI task to run as soon as its Docker image is ready. However, the docker_push_* tasks all have no `needs` clauses, resulting in them blocking until *all* the docker_build_* tasks are complete. So the Ubuntu 18.04 image can be built and ready to be pushed, but its push task won't run until other Docker images have finished building.

More precise `needs` clauses could break this dependency and increase our build parallelism.

        "2⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "3⋯7 ❰A❱"
        "3⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "3⋯4 'a'"
        "3⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "4⋯7 ❰A❱"
        "4⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "4⋯5 'a'"
        "4⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "5⋯7 ❰A❱"
        "5⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "5⋯6 'a'"
        "5⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "6⋯7 ❰A❱"
        "6⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "6⋯7 'a'"
        "6⋯7 ❰A❱" -> "7⋯7 ❰A❱"
    }

## Expected Behaviour

SVG to stdout

## Actual Behaviour

crash

summary: translate URLs into something in PS files that is recognized by LaTeX as a hyperref
description:
From [a sprawling discussion on the forum](https://forum.graphviz.org/t/tikz-and-latex-driver-for-graphviz/577):

> LaTeX proves that it is possible to include hyperlinks in PostScript. They are disregarded by PS viewers, but ps2pdf makes use of them & produces a PDF with active hyperlinks. I don’t know how it works, but I believe GV could produce PostScript that’s enhanced in that way. This would ultimately enable LaTeX docs to have interactive graphs that are GV-generated. It’s potentially a trivial fix, but OTOH the document could not at the same time embed files using the attachfile pkg (but pdftk could be used as a hack to embed files as a separate step).

summary: remove Python 2 bindings
description:
This was discussed on !1801, but we should have an actual issue for it.

Python 2 was EOLed some time ago, so we should remove the Python 2 bindings for Graphviz. Currently we generate both Python 2 and Python 3 bindings, so removing one of these options should simplify the build a little. We should also be able to remove some dependencies from the CI Docker images.

summary: feature request: wrap text inside box label
description:
Graphviz does not allow me to wrap text in a box label. I have to put in the line breaks by hand, which is a big problem when I generate .dot-files (instead of writing them by hand). The HTML-style labels give some formatting possibilities, but word wrap is not one of them.

## OS Version

I am using macOS Catalina vs. 10.15.7 (19H15)

## Graphviz Version

I am running graphviz version 2.43.0

summary: Omit DOCTYPE declaration
description:
From https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#sec-prolog-dtd :

> XML documents _should_ begin with an XML declaration

From https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-SVG2-20150709/intro.html#Namespace :

> It is recommended that authors _do not include_ a DOCTYPE declaration in SVG documents.

What do you think of omitting the DOCTYPE and XML declarations? (At the very least, the DOCTYPE should probably not be included by default.)

summary: Feature Request: Markdown in Node Labels
description:
Forked from: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1993, filed @StefJoosten, the context was automatic word wrap.

In general, I would like to see a proper markup possibility (e.g. markdown), which would solve all markup desires. An easy way might be to build in Pandoc, but that is not up to me as a user.

summary: CI Python OSErrors from Windows tasks
description:
I'm seeing some variant of the following error very often in CI. ~50% of my CI runs are failing due to one of the Windows tasks failing in this way. We have six Windows tasks, so this is occurring in ~8% of Windows CI tasks. This may not sound like a lot, but the effect is that I am having to retry every second CI run, some multiple times.

My analysis of the error (please correct me if I've misinterpreted it): the assertion is not failing. The condition is true, but that line is being blamed as where the temporary file destruction is triggered from (exiting the `with` block). Somehow deletion of the temporary directory fails. It looks to me like something else is either (a) racing with the temporary directory deletion or (b) holding an open file handle while the temporary directory deletion is running.

Commence wild speculation:
* This is not Graphviz' fault. This appears to be a fault of Python or the OS.
* I don't want to jump to conclusions, but my suspicion is that this is more Windows nonsense: Windows Defender or some other background scanner operating on the temporary directory/files while Python believes it has exclusive control of them.
* This is not worth our time to debug.

My suggestion: I would like to upgrade the version of Python we're using (3.8) in the hope that smarter people than us have solved/worked-around this in Python itself. @magjac can we drop the Python version from dependencies repo and install Python ≥3.9 from a Gitlab-supported package manager?

              + [f'-l{l}' for l in libs])

          # https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1800 has been fixed

summary: Add C++ API
description:
In order to be able to take advantage of many modern C++ features such as automatic memory managment, it would be useful if Graphviz had a high-level C++ API.

This is spawned from a [discussion at the forum](https://forum.graphviz.org/t/work-going-forward/165/28?u=magjac). I though it might be better to collect discussion about it in one place.

I realize that this is not a priority for the Graphviz project right now, but since I'm working on creating a new test suite written in C++, I will implement parts of such an API anyway.

summary: Add a new C++-based test suite
description:
This is what I'm currently working on and what we discussed [at the forum](https://forum.graphviz.org/t/work-going-forward/165/18?u=magjac).

I realize that there's some skepticism about the choice of language. I hope to prove the skeptics wrong, but I'm not sure I will succeed. This purpose of this issue is to be able to discuss aspects of the new C++ test suite, not to debate the choice of language. If my effort turns out badly, we will just not merge it.

Based on initial experiments, I plan to include the following in my work:
* A new C++ API #2001 
* [AddresSanitizer](https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizer)
* Code coverage using [gcov](https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Gcov.html) and [lcov](http://ltp.sourceforge.net/coverage/lcov.php)
* Unit tests based on [Catch2](https://github.com/catchorg/Catch2)
* Test run with [CTest](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/ctest.1.html), although perhaps `ctest` will be run through `pytest` in CI.
* SVG parsing using [SVG++](http://svgpp.org/) which is based on [Boost](https://www.boost.org/)
* At a later stage, add support for fuzzing using [libFuzzer](https://llvm.org/docs/LibFuzzer.html])

Feel free to comment on these choices.

summary: dot: error message libpath/shortest.c:324: triangulation failed
description:
graphviz version: dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)
OS: Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS running on oracle virtual box 6.1 (host system windows 10)
dot -T jpg triangulation-failed.gv 1>triangulation-failed.jpg
libpath/shortest.c:324: triangulation failed
libpath/shortest.c:207: cannot find triangle path
Warning: Unable to reclaim box space in spline routing for edge "Melvin" -> "Howard". Something is probably seriously wrong.

This is *not* causing me any problem as it was due to a missing statement in my .gv input file (which I fixed immediately). However, I thought I should report it in case it indicated a more serious problem.

Expected behavior is a more meaningful error message or a fix to the internal error.

In the initial bug report I used the error text from an earlier run by accident. The current error message text is from downloading the attached .gv.txt file and running dot on it in the linux virtual machine (as described above). I apologize for this mistake and my delay in attaching the .gv file. I've added markdown so the text is no longer run together: I did not realize initially that the default was markdown.

summary: Feature request: Extend the allowed edge styles.
description:
This issues is migrated from the wishlist HTML page at https://graphviz.org/doc/todo.html.

Git blame shows this is from 2014:

```
620a8b3427 (Emden R. Gansner 2014-01-30 15:21:11 -0500  19) Extend the allowed edge styles.
```

Arrow shapes we already support are documented at https://graphviz.org/doc/info/arrows.html.

Questions:

- What edge styles would we like that we don't support today? I suppose we could look at other graphing software for feature gaps?
- Is this about shapes? Edge colors? Line patterns?

description:

<g id="CFC72F05-6E77-4772-93C9-0BE9485815E8-02700" class="node" **time="2021/4/15"** >

summary: ortho's eqEndSeg incorrectly modifies its arguments
Feature request: Warn when declaring duplicate nodes
description:
Filing this bug, not as high priority, but to track this piece of feedback I saw the other day.

I read https://swagitda.com/blog/posts/security-decision-trees-with-graphviz/ -- a great post about how to use Graphviz, and they say:

> Also note that Graphviz does not warn you if there are duplicate nodes, so choose whichever organization option will minimize the probability of you creating duplicates.

I also found this question: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32422592/force-graphviz-to-complain-for-duplicate-nodes

This seems like something we could potentially bake into the core of graphviz?

summary: remove the need for python3 symlink/copy on Windows
description:
Just notifying of something I'm planning to do in the near future...

Installing Python 3 on Windows only installs a python.exe, not python3.exe. To work around some Graphviz infrastructure assuming python3 (e.g. rtest/test_regression.py) we copy python.exe to python3.exe in Windows CI jobs. It should be possible to remove this assumption, which will also simplify life for users trying to run the test suite on Windows.

summary: remove md5 functionality in Smyrna
description:
cmd/smyrna contains a full MD5 implementation, which is largely unused. Check sums are calculated in a couple of places but never read. There are also check sum fields that are never read or written.

This should all be removed, both the computation of these check sums, as well as the MD5 implementation itself.

summary: deduplicate pic_string, fig_string, mp_string
description: This functions are essentially three copies of the same thing.

summary: Consider specifying what whitespace means in the format specification
description:
The [format specification document](https://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/lang.html) indicates that “any amount of whitespace may be inserted between terminals”. Please consider specifying which whitespace characters are allowed exactly (or permitted / tolerated / works but is highly discouraged…). 

From the [examples](https://www.graphviz.org/resources/#simple-examples-and-tutorials) section I understand that new line characters seem permitted, for example, not just U+0020 SPACE. 

As a more specific question: is there a recommended encoding for newlines (Windows / Mac / Linux)? Are all three spec compliant?

summary: symbol visibility via defs or attributes?
description:
I thought I'd split off a new issue from #2057 to have a longer term discussion of what is the right way to handle symbol visibility. The remainder of this description is going to assume you have read the following:
* #205
* !1760
* #1940
* https://forum.graphviz.org/t/use-dllimport-dllexport-and-or-a-def-file-on-windows/620
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/cpp/declspec?view=msvc-160
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/exporting-from-a-dll-using-declspec-dllexport?view=msvc-160
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/exporting-from-a-dll-using-def-files?view=msvc-160
* https://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility

So Graphviz (or really any C/C++ app+lib project) needs to manage visibility wrt linkage that is *outside* the C and C++ standards. To reiterate and stress that last part, there is currently no way to control this kind of symbol visibility with ISO standardized mechanisms.¹ Here is the ideal state for the end user, using the GCC visibility terms:

| context | symbol | visibility |
|----|----|----|
| compiling libfoo | `bar`, a symbol only used internally in libfoo | internal |
| compiling libfoo | `baz`, a symbol that is part of libfoo’s API | default | 
| compiling foo, an app that links against libfoo | `baz` | hidden |
| compiling foo | a symbol from foo itself | hidden |

There are a number of ways to control symbol visibility:
1. Command line options, e.g. `-fvisibility…`
2. GNU attributes, `__attribute((visibility(…)))`
3. MSVC `__declspec`
4. MSVC defs file

(1) is not useful for controlling symbol-by-symbol visibility. (2) is understood by GCC and Clang, but not MSVC. (3) is understood by GCC and MSVC, but not Clang.² (4) is hard to keep in sync with the source.

So essentially I think what we want to aim for is something like the following in a library’s API header:

```c
#ifdef FOO_EXPORT
#ifdef _WIN32
#define FOO_API __declspec(dllexport)
#elif defined(__GNUC__)
#define FOO_API __attibute__((visibility("default")))
#else
#define FOO_API /* nothing; suboptimal build with everything visible */
#endif
#else
#ifdef _WIN32
#define FOO_API __declspec(dllimport)
#elif defined(__GNUC__)
#define FOO_API __attribute__((visibility("hidden")))
#else
#define FOO_API /* nothing; suboptimal build with everything visible */
#endif
#endif
```

where `FOO_EXPORT` is only defined when compiling the library itself. There are some additional complications for C++,³ but for the most part I think this is it. Please comment if you think we should be moving towards something different.

CC @magjac, @compnerd_

¹ Neither `extern` nor `static` is the droid we are looking for.

² However, in practice the GCC interpretation of this is not so useful as e.g. `__declspec(dllimport)` does *not* imply `extern` as it does under MSVC.

³ As https://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility discusses, things that need RTTI typically need to be visible across SOs.

summary: libtool: compile: unable to infer tagged configuration
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Configure and compile graphviz on macOS with the quartz plugin enabled.

## Expected Behaviour

Successful build

## Actual Behaviour

```
libtool: compile: unable to infer tagged configuration
libtool:   error: specify a tag with '--tag'
```

## OS Version

The problem has been observed by two MacPorts users running OS X 10.9.5 (https://trac.macports.org/ticket/62423, https://trac.macports.org/ticket/62679) and by a MacPorts automated build machine running Mac OS X 10.5.8 (https://build.macports.org/builders/ports-10.5_ppc_legacy-builder/builds/95567).

## Graphviz Version

2.40.1

## Additional info

I'm the maintainer of graphviz in MacPorts. I have not been able to reproduce the build failure on my macOS 10.13.6 machine, however I am able to confirm that `--tag=CC` is missing when invoking libtool to compile GVTextLayout.m, and all libtool invocations should specify the tag.

I'm not sure because the commit message does not indicate but I think this is the issue that 79aa7d77ef433d66c0142168d2817b4c7014d263 was trying to solve. However there were two problems: the fix was added inside a conditional so that it only takes effect on Darwin 9 (Mac OS X 10.5) when in fact the fix is needed regardless of OS version, and there was a typo in the variable name in the fix so that it does not work even on Darwin 9 (Mac OS X 10.5). I'll submit a PR to fix this shortly.

I'm aware that version 2.40.1 is old, but since the code in question has not changed in your repository, I believe the problem probably affects the current version too and that the fix is still appropriate.

summary: Autotools enables -Wtrampolines and -Wlogical-op for Clang
description:
The Autotools build system enables extra compiler warnings -- which is a good thing -- but it tries to only enable extra flags like `-Wtrampolines` and `-Wlogical-op` for GCC, which is the only compiler that supports these. Unfortunately `$GCC` in Autotools just checks for `__GNUC__` which is true for Clang as well.

The result of this is that building with Clang emits repeated warnings about not understanding these two flags. You can see this in the CI macOS Autotools build.

summary: remove Perl build dependency
description:
As best I can tell, building Graphviz currently requires Perl for a single thing: running lib/common/mksvgfonts.pl. Looking at this script and how it is run, I have the impression Perl is not necessary. Going further, I would say a script is not necessary. This can probably be accomplished with a regular header or, if not that simple, an [X macro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X_Macro).

Making this change would allow us to drop Perl as a build dependency, delete Perl from the Windows build dependency repo, and generally exit the Perl game altogether.

Interestingly the MSBuild system does not run this script, suggesting it is not necessary on Windows. Though the CMake build system on Windows *does* run the script.

summary: inconsistent error handling strategy in windows/bin/setup-build-utilities.ps1
artificial Windows diff, grep dependency
description:
The Windows builds claims to need diff and grep, windows/bin/setup-build-utilities.ps1:

```
…
find_or_fallback "diff grep" "$build_utilities_path\GnuWin\bin"
…
```

Yet the dependency on both of these seems due to the CI setup, not actual build dependencies. The only usages I have been able to identify are:
* usages of `grep` within windows/bin/setup-build-utilities.ps1 itself
* usages of `grep` within .gitlab-ci.yml
* usages of `diff` in rtest/rtest.py (these look replaceable by [`difflib`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/difflib.html) or even `filecmp`)

@magjac does this sound accurate? This came up because I'm looking to replace the use of PowerShell and, while replicating the tool setup, it jumped out to me that some of the tools being configured don't actually seem used by any CMakeLists.txt or .vcxproj file.

- Output: https://github.com/xkszltl/Roaster/blob/0287edfc495590ff5d0efdb3692cce893a7c93e1/doc/arch.pdf

summary: Out-of-source build has broken includes
description:
With recent update from **2.44.1** to **2.47.1**, we started hitting out-of-source build time issues again.

The problem is that while most header files are located in the source directory, generated files like `exparse.h` are not there, resulting in errors like:

```
.../graphviz-2.47.1/lib/expr/expr.h:37:10: fatal error: expr/exparse.h: No such file or directory
   37 | #include <expr/exparse.h>
```

The fix is to look for header files in the build directory as well. The patch that fixed this for us is attached: [oos-build-fix.patch](/uploads/ff76bf1c0acc410706e1ddd566b2fee5/oos-build-fix.patch)

summary: tapered edges cut short by edge concentration
description:
```dot
digraph {
  edge [
    style="tapered"
  ];

  concentrate=true;

  a -> b
  b -> c
  a -> d
  b -> d
  c -> d
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

A daisy-chain a -> b -> c -> d, plus edges a -> d and b -> d joining together from `concentrate`.

## Actual Behaviour

![vanishing-edge](/uploads/5eef19392c1ccd91897b0d22e2e73950/vanishing-edge.png)

The taper goes to nothing in the top half of the a -> d and b -> d edges, leaving the shared "concentrated" part invisible.

## OS Version

Linux, kernel 5.11.16-arch1-1.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.47.1 (0)

summary: Wrong edge ordering in case of multiple edges between two nodes
description:
When a digraph has multiple edges, `ordering = "out"` does not seem to be fulfilled by the second occurrence of the edge.
I hope I am not missing anything important from the documentation.

## Steps to reproduce

`mwe.dot`:

```dot
digraph G {
  ordering = "out"
  1 -> 3
  1 -> 2 -> 3
  1 -> 3
}
```

`dot -Tsvg mwe.dot -o mwe.pdf` produces the following output

![mwe.svg](/uploads/38418975a062b2c98315e317c1fb8dfd/mwe.svg)


## Expected Behaviour

I would expect the second `1 -> 3` edge to be placed on the right of the `1 -> 2` edge.


## Actual Behaviour

Cf. above: it seems that the "same placement" as for the first `1 -> 3` edge is applied to the second one.


## OS Version

OS = Archlinux. 
Output of `uname -a`:

`Linux [hostname] 5.12.4-arch1-2 #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat, 15 May 2021 20:58:02 +0000 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

summary: Why do texts with non-ASCII characters have right padding?
description:
If you look at the image below, you will see that if the text has non-ASCII characters it is pushed away from the right margin, and if it has emoji it is pushed closer to the margin. Do you know why is that? [![enter image description here][1]][1] Here is the code graph { node [shape=plain] A [label=<
Text with ASCII characters only
>]; B [label=<
Text with non-ASCII charắcters
>]; C [label=<
Text with emoji 😂 very funny hahahahaha
>]; } I am using the [GraphvizOnline](https://dreampuf.github.io/GraphvizOnline/#graph%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20node%20%5Bshape%3Dplain%5D%0A%0AA%20%5Blabel%3D%3C%0A%3Ctable%20border%3D%220%22%20cellborder%3D%221%22%20cellspacing%3D%220%22%3E%0A%20%20%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3EText%20with%20ASCII%20characters%20only%3C%2Ftd%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%0A%3C%2Ftable%3E%3E%5D%3B%0A%0AB%20%5Blabel%3D%3C%0A%3Ctable%20border%3D%220%22%20cellborder%3D%221%22%20cellspacing%3D%220%22%3E%0A%20%20%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3EText%20with%20non-ASCII%20char%E1%BA%AFcters%3C%2Ftd%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%0A%3C%2Ftable%3E%3E%5D%3B%0A%0AC%20%5Blabel%3D%3C%0A%3Ctable%20border%3D%220%22%20cellborder%3D%221%22%3E%0A%20%20%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3EText%20with%20emoji%20%F0%9F%98%82%20very%20funny%20hahahahaha%3C%2Ftd%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%0A%3C%2Ftable%3E%3E%5D%3B%0A%7D), so I don't know what the version is. summary: Error on more than 128 cluster subgraphs
Assertion error when using `dot` in `ortho.c` in `convertSPtoRoute` in graphviz 2.47.2 (not an issue in graphviz 2.46.1)
description:
As folks here may already know, diagrams (https://diagrams.mingrammer.com/), a python package, uses graphviz.

I have been trying out the examples on https://diagrams.mingrammer.com/docs/getting-started/examples and when I try grouped workers and any diagram which groups nodes, I get the assertion error on `ortho.c`:

```
Assertion failed: (sz >= 2), function convertSPtoRoute, file ortho.c, line 155.
[1]    23017 abort      dot -Tpng grouped_workers
```

I ran `dot` separately with the dot file that `diagrams` created and I attach below what I see in verbose mode:

```
$ dot -v -Tpng grouped_workers
dot - graphviz version 2.47.2 (20210527.0053)
Using render: cairo:cairo
Using device: png:cairo:cairo
libdir = "/usr/local/Cellar/graphviz/2.47.2/lib/graphviz"
Activated plugin library: libgvplugin_dot_layout.6.dylib
Using layout: dot:dot_layout
The plugin configuration file:
	/usr/local/Cellar/graphviz/2.47.2/lib/graphviz/config6
		was successfully loaded.
    render	:  cairo dot dot_json fig gd json json0 map mp pic pov ps quartz svg tk visio vml vrml xdot xdot_json
    layout	:  circo dot fdp neato nop nop1 nop2 osage patchwork sfdp twopi
    textlayout	:  textlayout
    device	:  bmp canon cgimage cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot dot_json eps exr fig gd gd2 gif gv icns ico imap imap_np ismap jp2 jpe jpeg jpg json json0 mp pct pdf pic pict plain plain-ext png pov ps ps2 psd sgi svg svgz tga tif tiff tk vdx vml vmlz vrml wbmp webp xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4 xdot_json
    loadimage	:  (lib) bmp eps gd gd2 gif jpe jpeg jpg pdf png ps svg webp xbm
fontname: "Sans-Serif" resolved to: (PangoCairoCoreTextFont) "Helvetica" 
pack info:
  mode   undefined
  size   0
  flags  0
  margin 8
pack info:
  mode   node
  size   0
  flags  0
network simplex:  7 nodes 10 edges maxiter=2147483647 balance=1
network simplex: 7 nodes 10 edges 0 iter 0.00 sec
Maxrank = 2, minrank = 0
mincross: pass 0 iter 0 trying 0 cur_cross 0 best_cross 0
mincross Grouped Workers: 0 crossings, 0.00 secs.
network simplex:  17 nodes 24 edges maxiter=2147483647 balance=2
network simplex: 17 nodes 24 edges 4 iter 0.00 sec
Assertion failed: (sz >= 2), function convertSPtoRoute, file ortho.c, line 155.
[1]    23022 abort      dot -v -Tpng grouped_workers
```

I am wondering if there is a fix at this point, because this is show stopping for us.

I am trying to get this working on a Mac OS X 11.3.1 with xcode installed. Any help is appreciated.

Last, here's the `diagrams` python code I am working on in this case is the first example in https://diagrams.mingrammer.com/docs/getting-started/examples.


## Steps to reproduce

1. Download graphviz 2.47.2 (brew install graphviz).
2. Download diagrams from https://diagrams.mingrammer.com/ using pip3.9 (pip3.9 install diagrams).
3. Run the first example in https://diagrams.mingrammer.com/docs/getting-started/examples titled "grouped workers" using Python 3.9.


The dot file parsing fails with the above assertion error.

## Expected Behaviour

The png file for the grouped workers is created.

## Actual Behaviour

```
Assertion failed: (sz >= 2), function convertSPtoRoute, file ortho.c, line 155.
[1]    23022 abort      dot -v -Tpng grouped_workers
```

## OS Version

Mac OS X 11.3.1

## Graphviz Version

2.47.2

## Additional info
### Workaround

1. Uninstall diagrams: pip3.9 uninstall diagrams
2. Uninstall graphviz: brew uninstall graphviz
3. Download the source for graphviz 2.46.1 from the graphviz website and then compile and install it for my Mac OS X 11.3.1.

summary: Windows CI hard codes Python 3.9
description:
While working on #2000, we upgraded the version of Python in the Windows CI tasks to 3.9. More specifically, we setup the task to install the latest Python 3 from Chocolatey. When you install a new package via Chocolatey, you need to update your `$PATH` (or is it `%PATH%` on Windows?) to see the new software. I hard coded some manipulation of this in 8274d59b88a2ccaabdedfa7dffc27b26c763df41 to Python 3.9.

This is obviously suboptimal and doomed to break when Python 3.10 is available through Chocolatey. However, I could not get `refreshenv` (the documented way of doing this update, and what Chocolatey suggests) to work.

This issue is to remind us this needs debugging/resolving. Or we'll at least need to remember to bump the hard coded path when new Python versions become available.

summary: Segmentation fault with concentrate=true
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I ran

    dot -Tpng -O graph.gv

with this input:

```
digraph {
	graph [concentrate=true]
	n1 -> n2
	n1 -> n3
	n1 -> n5
	n1 -> n5
	n4 -> n2
	n4 -> n3
	n2 -> n5
	n5 -> n1
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

it renders a graph

## Actual Behaviour

It dies with a segmentation fault

## OS Version

I have reproduced this on Debian Stable (Buster), Debian Testing (Bullseye) and Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS

## Graphviz Version

run $ dot -V

`dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)`


## Additional info

(none)

summary: "label: area too large for rtree" with sfdp/neato/fdp . Was OK with version 2.38.0
description:
## Steps to reproduce

List what commands you ran, any errors you see. If you run commands over some input, attaching the input to the issue will help us track down the bug.

dot -K fdp -Tsvg C:/Users/rchat/AppData/Local/Temp/survol_graph_to_svg.8760.dot -o C:/Users/rchat/AppData/Local/Temp/survol_graph_to_svg.8760.svg -v -Goverlap=false

[survol_graph_to_svg.8760.dot](/uploads/dfa672f5c66a47decef1e09ca9888f40/survol_graph_to_svg.8760.dot)

Output is:
![survol_graph_to_svg.8760.svg](/uploads/45c5b0b1db96126190d64ff1be8d784b/survol_graph_to_svg.8760.svg)

## Expected Behaviour
Here is what happens with version 2.38.0 :
It outputs the result in one second, and the nodes are densely packed without overlapping.
It should output in less than one second.

## Actual Behaviour
It logs the error message hundred of times (a bit more than the number of boxes):
```
Error: label: area too large for rtree
Error: label: area too large for rtree
Error: label: area too large for rtree
Error: label: area too large for rtree
Error: label: area too large for rtree
1001 objs 700 xlabels force=1 bb=(-0.33,0.08) (113826.60,75339.55)
700 out of 700 labels positioned.
```

- The nodes are very distant, very sparse, taking too much space.
- It runs more than 10 times slower, and sometimes it even crashes the computer.

## OS Version
Windows 10.

## Graphviz Version
dot - graphviz version 2.47.3 (20210619.1520)
Same problem with version 2.43
It used to work with version 2.38.0 on Windows 7 and on Linux.

## Additional info
Same problem with fdp, sfdp and neato.

summary: null pointer deference  in dot in function endpath  and beginpath
description:
## Steps to reproduce


poc crash at endpath
```sh
echo "digraph{dn->n:n->{{dn->n:n}}graph[concentrate=true]}" | ./bin/dot

```
poc crash at beginpath

```sh
echo "digraph{graph[concentrate=true]n	dn->n:n->{n:n->dn[0=0]}}" | ./bin/dot
```

In the for loop at line 479 and line 673 in `splines.c`, didn't check whether `orig` is vaild.

summary: AddressSanitizer: odr-violation in lib/ortho with CMake
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Build Graphviz using CMake with AddressSanitizer enabled.

Run e.g. the test case in https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/blob/add-cpp-test-suite/tests/test_simple.cpp

## Expected Behaviour

No error.

## Actual Behaviour

```
==204644==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: odr-violation (0x7fccf296eca0):
  [1] size=4 'odb_flags' ../lib/ortho/ortho.c:44:5
  [2] size=4 'odb_flags' ../lib/ortho/ortho.c:44:5
These globals were registered at these points:
  [1]:
    #0 0x7fccf2b13938 in __asan_register_globals ../../../../src/libsanitizer/asan/asan_globals.cpp:341
    #1 0x7fccf25db597 in _sub_I_00099_1 (/home/magjac/graphviz/build/plugin/dot_layout/libgvplugin_dot_layout.so.6+0x3b0597)
    #2 0x7fccf34dc96d  (/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2+0x1196d)

  [2]:
    #0 0x7fccf2b13938 in __asan_register_globals ../../../../src/libsanitizer/asan/asan_globals.cpp:341
    #1 0x7fccf1c8d999 in _sub_I_00099_1 (/home/magjac/graphviz/build/plugin/neato_layout/libgvplugin_neato_layout.so.6+0x5a8999)
    #2 0x7fccf34dc96d  (/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2+0x1196d)

==204644==HINT: if you don't care about these errors you may set ASAN_OPTIONS=detect_odr_violation=0
SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: odr-violation: global 'odb_flags' at ../lib/ortho/ortho.c:44:5
==204644==ABORTING
```

## OS Version

Ubuntu 21.04.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.47.4~dev.20210706.0621 (20210706.0621)

## Additional info

The reason for this problem is that the `lib/ortho` object files are not included in the `gvc` library when built with CMake, which has the effect that they end up both in libgvplugin_dot_layout.so and in libgvplugin_neato_layout.so which causes the ASan ODR violation.

When built with autotools, the `gvc` library correctly contains those object files and the problem does not arise.

summary: [Windows CI] Output from cmake to stderr might cause an issue in PowerShell (`NativeCommandError`)
description:
I'm afraid that this is an issue on Windows CI.

Please, close this, if it is an intended behavior.

## Steps to reproduce

Just cherry-pick [this commit][cmake_stderr] in order to add some [`message()`][cmake-message] into `./CMakeLists.txt`

[cmake_stderr]: https://gitlab.com/test.cases/graphviz/-/commit/618de90c2faa618225531c674cd83460f005ae01
[cmake-message]: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/message.html


```diff
diff --git a/CMakeLists.txt b/CMakeLists.txt
index bd8a27d5b..a363d7f0d 100644
--- a/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -1,3 +1,6 @@
+message(STATUS "CMAKE_VERSION: ${CMAKE_VERSION} (STDOUT)")
+message("This message might cause an issue on Windows CI (STDERR)")
+
 cmake_minimum_required (VERSION 3.1 FATAL_ERROR)
 project (Graphviz)
```

## Expected Behaviour

Windows CI would pass with the messages added.

## Actual Behaviour

`cmake` stopped on the way like this (Windows CI):

https://gitlab.com/test.cases/graphviz/-/jobs/1402028193#L159

```
$ python ci/build_windows.py --build-system $env:build_system --platform $Env:project_platform --configuration $env:configuration 2>&1 | tee -a $logfile
-- CMAKE_VERSION: 3.17.20032601-MSVC_2 (STDOUT)
python : This message might cause an issue on Windows CI (STDERR)
At line:1 char:1
+ python ci/build_windows.py --build-system $env:build_system --platfor ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (This message mi...ows CI (STDERR):String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError```
```

- The first [message][cmake-message] (to stdout) was properly output.
- But, the second one (to stderr) was not properly output, and seemed to be trapped by PowerShell.

## OS Version

The version which GitLab CI uses (`.gitlab-ci.yml`)

## Graphviz Version

`main` branch (https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/6e182a7a6fdfd98e7b1b17f4d1519677cb6a51ab), but not specific to it.

## Additional info

Seems similar to cases treated in [Execution of external commands in PowerShell done right][mnaoumov-wordpress], and [Invoke-NativeApplication][mnaoumov-Invoke-NativeApplication].

[mnaoumov-wordpress]: https://mnaoumov.wordpress.com/2015/01/11/execution-of-external-commands-in-powershell-done-right/
[mnaoumov-Invoke-NativeApplication]: https://github.com/mnaoumov/Invoke-NativeApplication

summary: CMake build is failing for 2.47.3
description:
## Steps to reproduce

    wget -c https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/archive/2.47.3/graphviz-2.47.3.tar.gz

summary: reduce memory usage of string interning
Feature request: allow specifying units in size attributes
description:
Scnorth mentions: "I don’t see any harm in our someday adding dimensions to input units (e.g. 2.0i, 100px, 18pt, etc.) as this could be done in way that is completely backward compatible and it might be constructive." At https://forum.graphviz.org/t/svg-is-huge-no-matter-the-actual-graph-size/742/5.

I agree, css did this well for example. There may be some outputs that only work in inches or pixels, but hopefully with the dpi we can convert between.

summary: gvpr doesn't build on macOS but MKDEFS_EXECUTABLE points to wrong directory
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I updated graphviz (first time since 6 months).  
gvpr was added to build in between, and there the CMakeLists.txt in lib/gvpr 
```
# Generate gdefs.h from sources
if (WIN32)
    set (MKDEFS_EXECUTABLE "${CMAKE_CFG_INTDIR}/mkdefs")
else()
    set (MKDEFS_EXECUTABLE "./mkdefs")
endif()
add_custom_command(
    OUTPUT gdefs.h
    MAIN_DEPENDENCY gprdata
    DEPENDS mkdefs
    COMMAND ${MKDEFS_EXECUTABLE} gdefs.h < ${TOP_SOURCE_DIR}/lib/gvpr/gprdata
)
```

this creates during cmake a script called: `Script-119F8DF11A775838BE6D69EF.sh`

```
#!/bin/sh
set -e
if test "$CONFIGURATION" = "Debug"; then :
  cd /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr
  ./mkdefs gdefs.h < /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/lib/gvpr/gprdata
fi
if test "$CONFIGURATION" = "Release"; then :
  cd /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr
  ./mkdefs gdefs.h < /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/lib/gvpr/gprdata
fi
if test "$CONFIGURATION" = "MinSizeRel"; then :
  cd /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr
  ./mkdefs gdefs.h < /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/lib/gvpr/gprdata
fi
if test "$CONFIGURATION" = "RelWithDebInfo"; then :
  cd /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr
  ./mkdefs gdefs.h < /Users/klauskneupner/xcode/graphviz/lib/gvpr/gprdata
fi
```

the mkdefs file is located like this:
![directory structure](/uploads/80bdb5c001767c01d3459c7e06c2c8cf/Untitled_7.png)

Run a cmake on macOS but it doesn't build.

## Expected Behaviour

No problems during build.

## Actual Behaviour

```
PhaseScriptExecution Generate\ lib/gvpr/gdefs.h /Users/userName/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr/Graphviz.build/Release/gvpr.build/Script-119F8DF11A775838BE6D69EF.sh (in target 'gvpr' from project 'Graphviz')
    cd /Users/userName/xcode/graphviz
    /bin/sh -c /Users/userName/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr/Graphviz.build/Release/gvpr.build/Script-119F8DF11A775838BE6D69EF.sh
/Users/userName/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr/Graphviz.build/Release/gvpr.build/Script-119F8DF11A775838BE6D69EF.sh: line 9: ./mkdefs: No such file or directory
Command PhaseScriptExecution failed with a nonzero exit code

** BUILD FAILED **


The following build commands failed:
	PhaseScriptExecution Generate\ lib/gvpr/gdefs.h /Users/userName/xcode/graphviz/_build/lib/gvpr/Graphviz.build/Release/gvpr.build/Script-119F8DF11A775838BE6D69EF.sh
```

no real surprise, `mkdefs` is not in current directory, but in a subdirectory, named after the configuration (debug or release).  

## OS Version

macOS 11.4

## Graphviz Version

updated 9th July from main directory. 

## Additional info

Fill in with anything else that might be important.

summary: Add MinGW builds to CI
description:
We currently do not have any build using MinGW on Windows. This makes it very cumbersome to make changes that affect such builds. This issue suggests that we add at least one such build using autotools and/or cmake.

References: #1940, !1739, !1760.

summary: expr misinterprets integer <<
description:
I was looking into unwinding the cryptic "IBM compilers can't deal with these shift operators on long long" work arounds. These were added in the initial Git revision in 2004 with no explanation. I cannot locate what exactly this is referring to. Dredging comp.lang archives and Stack Overflow turns up nothing, and the nature of the workaround suggests to me it's not target independent. It looks like working around some kind of register allocator bug.

Anyway, this led me to staring at this code for a while and noticing that integer left shift is pretty clearly incorrectly writing to the `floating` member of the value struct instead of the `integer` member. It's not quite clear to me what the effect of this is as I believe the `floating` member is unioned with the `integer` member. I think we need to construct a test case to stufy what exactly is going on and whether it leads to incorrect behavior.

summary: abbreviate CI job names
description:
I'm sure we are all no strangers to looking at the CI pipeline (below) and having to mouse over anything to figure out what on earth it is. Ah yes, 9 identical tasks appearing as "docker_build_...", that is exactly what I hoped to see...

What about if we rename these to shorter text that fits? E.g. "F32" for "Fedora 32", which is how the Fedora folk refer to it anyway. The macOS builds could even be " Autotools" if such UTF-8 wizardry is accepted by the CI gods.

![Screen_Shot_2021-07-23_at_17.32.52](/uploads/93b3600581019dcf5fe7d9cbae04444f/Screen_Shot_2021-07-23_at_17.32.52.png)

summary: Header not found in Cmake project
description:
## Steps to reproduce
1. Setup project
1. Create C++ project named "Example" in Clion, add main.cpp, add folder named "external"
1. Clone graphviz from gitlab https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/ into "external" directory of the project
1. Enter graphviz dir and get everything via _git submodule update --init --recursive_
1. Add environment variable as stated here http://graphviz.org/doc/winbuild.html at the top

2. Configure project
2. Add CmakeLists.txt in project directory
`cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.17)
project(Example)
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)
set(SOURCES
        main.cpp
        )
add_subdirectory(external/graphviz)
add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} ${SOURCES})`
2. In main.cpp insert
`include "external/graphviz/lib/gvc/gvc.h"
int main() {
return 0;}`
2. Configure toolchain for LLVM Clang-Cl

3. Building
3. When you run Cmake now you will get an error that Bison (and Flex) could not be found. Add this to the Cmake options 
> -DBISON_EXECUTABLE="c:\Projekte\Example\external\graphviz\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities\winflexbison\win_bison.exe" -DFLEX_EXECUTABLE="c:\Projekte\Example\external\graphviz\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities\winflexbison\win_flex.exe"
3. Cmake runs now successfully:
```
"C:\Program Files\JetBrains\CLion 2020.3.2\bin\cmake\win\bin\cmake.exe" -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug "-DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=C:/Program Files/LLVM/bin/clang-cl.exe" "-DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=C:/Program Files/LLVM/bin/clang-cl.exe" -GNinja -DBISON_EXECUTABLE=c:\Projekte\Example\external\graphviz\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities\winflexbison\win_bison.exe -DFLEX_EXECUTABLE=c:\Projekte\Example\external\graphviz\windows\dependencies\graphviz-build-utilities\winflexbison\win_flex.exe -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS=-m64 -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS=-m64 C:\Projekte\Example
-- Could NOT find ANN (missing: ANN_LIBRARY ANN_INCLUDE_DIR) 
-- Could NOT find GD (missing: GD_LIBRARY GD_INCLUDE_DIR GD_RUNTIME_LIBRARY) 
-- Graphviz version: 2.48.1~dev.20210804.0331
-- The following OPTIONAL packages have been found:
 * Cairo
 * EXPAT
 * LTDL
 * PangoCairo
 * ZLIB
 * Python3
 * NSIS
-- The following REQUIRED packages have been found:
 * AWK
 * BISON (required version >= 3.0)
 * FLEX
 * Git
 * Getopt
-- The following OPTIONAL packages have not been found:
 * ANN
 * PkgConfig
 * GD
-- Configuring done
-- Generating done
-- Build files have been written to: C:/Projekte/Example/cmake-build-debug_clang
[Finished]
```

## Expected Behaviour

I expect the project gets build.

## Actual Behaviour

```
====================[ Build | Example | Debug_Clang ]===========================
"C:\Program Files\JetBrains\CLion 2020.3.2\bin\cmake\win\bin\cmake.exe" --build C:\Projekte\Example\cmake-build-debug_clang --target Example
[1/2] Building CXX object CMakeFiles\Example.dir\main.cpp.obj
FAILED: CMakeFiles/Example.dir/main.cpp.obj 
C:\PROGRA~1\LLVM\bin\clang-cl.exe  /nologo -TP   -m64 /Zi /Ob0 /Od /RTC1 -MDd -std:c++17 /showIncludes /FoCMakeFiles\Example.dir\main.cpp.obj /FdCMakeFiles\Example.dir\ -c -- ..\main.cpp
In file included from ..\main.cpp:4:
../external/graphviz/lib/gvc/gvc.h(14,10): fatal error: 'types.h' file not found
#include "types.h"
         ^~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

Just for fun I added the graphviz/lib/common directory to my Cmake file
_target_include_directories(${PROJECT_NAME} PUBLIC ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/external/graphviz)/common_
but then the next header is not found. Something's wrong with recursively getting the header files.

## OS Version

Windows 10, 64bit

## Graphviz Version

2.48.1~dev.20210804.0331

## Additional info

I assume it's a cmake problem and tried different things in the cmake file. On Stackoverflow I opened a thread looking for help, you can check my attempts there https://stackoverflow.com/questions/68652171/graphviz-in-cmake-project-build-fails-header-not-found

Befuddlement

## OS Version

all

## Graphviz Version

all (see the web page https://graphviz.org/docs/attrs/searchsize/)

## Additional info
Current **searchsize** documentation:
> searchsize
>      During network simplex, maximum number of edges with negative cut  
>      values to search when looking for one with minimum cut value.

Web searches did not lead to any help.  
Understanding **cut** values would probably help, but might not be sufficient.

summary: the neato (mode=hier) implementation may have a redundant step to make the graph acyclic
description:
I'm recently interested in the Digcola paper(https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1532130) and trying to use Graphviz to reproduce some results in it. Surprisingly, I found that the results produced by neato -Gmode=hier are a bit different from the results in the paper. Through reviewing the source code, I believe an extra acyclic step in neatoinit.c is the cause of this difference.

The author of this algorithm stressed that one of the biggest benefits of it is the ability to handle cyclic digraphs, and it's actually designed to deal with cyclic digraphs, adding an acyclic step seems quite redundant it's affecting the performance of this program. Or is there a specific reason for doing this?

Here are two results by the neato -Gmode=hier command, with and without acyclic step (levelsgap=0.17): 

![image](/uploads/f7ddd5caa9607ffd85c2913ed215736b/image.png)
![image](/uploads/1be883618e658f05d5b6a1a91aaa1ea8/image.png)

Here is the same graph presented in the Digcola paper
![image](/uploads/84165ed1854fbd0b3bc30100c8316d8f/image.png)

summary: Saltatory effect of weight upon nodes inside clusters
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Process with `dot` the following source:

    digraph
    {   {   rank=same
            c->d->e
        }

        subgraph cluster_ab
        {   a b  }

        edge[weight=127]; // try with various values of this weight: 127, 128, 129
        a->c;
        b->e;
    }

specifying various weights for edges `a->c` and` `b->e`.

## Expected Behaviour

As the weight increases, the legths of edges `a->c` and `b->e` gradually decrease.

## Actual Behaviour

The lengths of edges `a->c` and `b->e` remain the same for weights from 1 to
[127](/uploads/bea624bc8b866b469ffea3947ee1bc7b/w_127.png),
then suddenly shorten at weight
[128](/uploads/0101e9b10bfce2ab570b3f91f3f779a3/w_128.png),
and become shotest at weight
[129](/uploads/c6240f8144177a40cf0ca8181ef0a654/w_129.png), that is three steps for the entire continuum of weight values!

Since edge-length optimisation is a smooth procedure optimising a smooth target function, the effect of weight should not be so saltatory.

## OS Version

*Windows XP*

## Graphviz Version

    graphviz version 2.38.0 (20140413.2041)

## Additional info

Your latest *Windows* binary does not work on *Windows XP*, but if the error is fixed, I will try to build *Graphviz* from sources.

summary: remove sed build dependency
description: 05cca29d2f04880def0bdce0eef7d7eca135026d removed `sed` as a build dependency on Windows. It looks like we are now within striking distance of removing `sed` as a build dependency on any platform. I think we should go ahead and do this.

summary: graphviz : arrows missing between some nodes in SVG file
description:
## Steps to reproduce

#### Summary :
Arrows from nodes **a to d**, and **f to c** are missing, apparently **because** these nodes are **side by side horizontally**.

![output.svg](/uploads/e3a9fb192a36c8392715cebd8756f934/output.svg)

#### Reproduce :
Command line used :
~~~
dot -Tsvg graph.dot > output.svg
~~~

With following DOT code in the "graph.dot" file:

~~~
digraph Q {

  node [shape=record];

  subgraph cluster_A {
    a -> b -> c
  }
  
  subgraph cluster_B {
    d -> e -> f
  }
  
  // The two arrows between these nodes are missing (when 2 nodes are next to each other, side to side)!
  a -> d
  f -> c
  
  // This arrow appears correctly (nodes are in a diagonal relative position) !
  e -> c

}
~~~

## Expected Behaviour

Arrows should apprear between a -> d and f -> c in the SVG "output.svg" file.

## Actual Behaviour

Instead, arrows are missing in the SVG file whenever nodes are side by side horizontally.

## OS Version

Windows 10

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.49.0 (20210828.1703)

## Additional info

graphviz was installed using the pre-compiled 64 bits installer

summary: autotools on MacOS (and maybe anywhere else) doesn't build gvedit with QT6
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```
brew install qt@6
./autogen.sh; ./configure --with-qt  blablabla
make install
```
You may need to edit configure.ac to refer to Qt6* instead of Qt5*.
The build succeeds, without gvedit

## Additional info

In the configure script, the probe for Qt6Core fails because it relies on pkg-config. Qt6 dropped support for pkg-config as they rely on Cmake dependencies instead.

Although graphviz has a working rough draft of a Cmake build, it doesn't include gvedit either.

I wonder if we wait long enough, some kind stranger will make a pkg-config compatibility layer for Qt6. I'm sure we're not the only project that faces this.

summary: Include graphviz source in SVG file
description:
## Steps to reproduce

1. Use dot to create SVG output, and examine it. 

## Expected Behaviour

Find the source code (ready to copy and paste if you want to reproduce in graphviz) as something similar to a comment

## Actual Behaviour

The feature isn't implemented yet, so you won't find the graphviz source code anywhere in the xml file.
(there are plenty of other comments)

## OS Version

irrelevant, but it's MX Linux: Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304)

## Additional info

It would be trivial to do this by inserting above the closing </svg> tag like the following:

```
<!-- Graphviz source: -->
<defs>
<![CDATA[

graph example {
  hello -- world
}

]]>
</defs>
```
It should be trivial to implement by dumping the source between those literals unless maybe "]]>" appears in the source, in which case you could warn that the source code is not being output and just skip inserting it. (probably not even worth escaping the pattern for that rare case)

## Use cases

This would allow a person or machine to copy the text verbatim in order to retrieve it from an SVG file.

If the DOT source ever got separated from its SVG output, it could be retrieved from within the output file itself and easily modified by grabbing the dot source from within.

Another use case I had today was I wanted to give someone a SVG file and not confuse them with extra files that were used in creating it, but giving them the opportunity make changes and send it back to me. 

Also when archiving dot programs, they could be archived within SVG files this way and easy to browse and see what they all are.

## Why use CDATA instead of a normal XML comment?

Note that placing the source code in a regular XML comment using "< ! - -" and "- - >" won't work because SGML/XML/SVG prohibits double-dash in that context, but double-dash appears frequently in graphs.

2.49.1~dev.20210907.1517

But the problem likely occurs in any environment with a case-insensitive file system.

Commit 39b9344811200555a47ccc2c65a9701aa9c35bd4.

## Additional info

The root of the repository is in the include path (so config.h can be picked up), but a side effect of this is that the generated `VERSION` file is visible and eligible for inclusion. Unfortunately [C++20 standardized a `<version>` header](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/header/version), that now collides with the generated Graphviz file.

summary: macOS: Installing Graphviz into a non-standard location results in error
description:
## Steps to reproduce

`./dot -T<output_type> test.dot`

## Expected Behaviour

Pretty graphs should be generated

## Actual Behaviour

```
$ ./dot 
 
dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libgvc.6.dylib
  Referenced from: /Users/palmerc/Development/graphviz/install/bin/./dot
  Reason: image not found
zsh: abort      ./dot
```

## OS Version

macOS 11.5.2

## Graphviz Version

latest commit

## Additional info

The issue is that the rpath on macOS seems to be completely wrong. To sketch out a fix, it might look like this for each executable target:

```
if (APPLE)
    cmake_policy(SET CMP0068 NEW)
    set_target_properties(dot PROPERTIES
            BUILD_WITH_INSTALL_NAME_DIR off
            BUILD_WITH_INSTALL_RPATH on
            INSTALL_RPATH "${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/${LIBRARY_INSTALL_DIR}"
            )
endif()
```

This makes sense to me, because the expected behavior is that installing 'dot' anywhere should result in a working binary that does not require fixing the rpaths. And the rpaths should be set to wherever the dylibs were installed.

summary: compile errors on macOS when using Bison 3.8
description:
From the CI logs for a recent run, https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/pipelines/369360035:

```
[ 35%] [BISON][Exparse] Building parser with bison 3.8
/Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/lib/expr/exparse.y: warning: 4 shift/reduce conflicts [-Wconflicts-sr]
/Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/lib/expr/exparse.y: note: rerun with option '-Wcounterexamples' to generate conflict counterexamples
[ 35%] Generating exparse.c
[ 35%] Building C object lib/expr/CMakeFiles/expr.dir/excc.c.o
In file included from /Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/lib/expr/excc.c:24:
In file included from /Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/lib/expr/exlib.h:126:
/Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/lib/expr/expr.h:274:14: error: conflicting types for 'exerror'
extern void             exerror(const char*, ...);
                        ^
/Users/gitlab/builds/graphviz/graphviz/build/lib/expr/y.tab.h:260:6: note: previous declaration is here
void exerror (const char *msg);
     ^
1 error generated.
```

and for Autotools:

```
bison -y -Wno-yacc -dv --output=grammar.c ../../lib/cgraph/grammar.y
  CC       grammar.lo
In file included from grammar.c:168:
grammar.h:118:6: error: conflicting types for 'aagerror'
void aagerror (const char *msg);
     ^
../../lib/cgraph/grammar.y:26:13: note: previous declaration is here
extern void aagerror(char *);
            ^
1 error generated.
make[3]: *** [grammar.lo] Error 1
make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

This appears to be a side effect of Bison 3.8 becoming available in Homebrew, and CI now installing that instead of 3.7.6. The [Bison changelog](https://github.com/akimd/bison/blob/master/NEWS) has lots of interesting remarks. In particular:

```
  To comply with the latest POSIX standard, in Yacc compatibility mode
  (options `-y`/`--yacc`) Bison now generates prototypes for yyerror and
  yylex.  In some situations, this is breaking compatibility: if the user
  has already declared these functions but with some differences (e.g., to
  declare them as static, or to use specific attributes), the generated
  parser will fail to compile.  To disable these prototypes, #define yyerror
  (to `yyerror`), and likewise for yylex.
```

summary: Msys experimental packages are included in release artifacts
description:
From https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2167#note_684858659:

> Matt: @magjac you might want to look at the post-merge deployment log for this: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/jobs/1614825713
> 
> The Msys packages resulted in some very weird paths. It looks like there's invalid unicode or something in the path. It didn't seem to upset deploy.py, but I suspect it resulted in some weird artifacts in the 2.49.1 package.
>
> Magnus: I haven't looked at the details yet, but the old deploy script excluded `COLLECTION=experimental` so the artifacts weren't intended to be deployed. My intention is to add test jobs before officially publishing them with `COLLECTION=stable`.
>
> Matt: I wonder if this is due to the `COLLECTION` file being created under PowerShell and then read back under Msys. The deployment log only gives the mojibake “ïƒ¿ïƒ¾experimental” but if you look in [one of the Msys build logs](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/jobs/1614825656), it gives it as “\\377\\376experimental”. Tracing back up through this log, there's this ominous snippet:
>
> ```
> ++ cat COLLECTION
> ci/build.sh: line 20: warning: command substitution: ignored null byte in input
> + COLLECTION=$'\377\376experimental'
> ```
>
> I think what we're seeing here is a [UTF-16 BOM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte_order_mark#UTF-16), but Bash under Msys doesn't seem to understand BOMs.

summary: CMake build system incorrectly aliases gv2gml to gml2gv
description:
This is quite strange, but the CMake build system contains the following:

```
# Aliases to the gml2gv executable (not including '.exe' suffix)
list(APPEND gml2gv_aliases gv2gml)
```

This seems to have the effect of the installed `gv2gml` being a copy of `gml2gv`. I say this is "quite strange" because neither the Autotools nor the MSBuild build systems consider these programs to be aliases. Even the main source files for these two programs, gv2gml.c and gml2gv.c, are distinct files.

summary: "green" SVG
description:
Consider a fill or stroke styled green:

```
		node  [style=filled,color="green"];
```

According to [the documentation](https://graphviz.org/doc/info/colors.html) the correct RGB color for green is 0x00FF00.

With an SVG export (circo -Tsvg) the generated SVG uses the literal color name `green` which is 0x008000 (the same color that CSS associates with "green").

According to the [SVG specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/painting.html#SpecifyingPaint) the named color `green` is based on the [CSS Color Module specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-3/#valuea-def-color) which [defines green as `0x008000`](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-3/#html4)

The SVG exporter *should* write the RGB color `#00FF00` instead of `green`

summary: CI build tasks all write GRAPHVIZ_VERSION, racing each other
description:
Multiple CI tasks appear to write and export the GRAPHVIZ_VERSION file. This makes sense because their downstream test tasks need this file. However, all of these eventually funnel into the deploy task. I think this is a "last one wins" kind of situation, where the deploy task gets the GRAPHVIZ_VERSION produced by the last finishing build task.

“So what?” you say, “they're all writing the same content to the file anyway.” Well, apparently not. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/jobs/1643354881 shows a deployment failure where what I believe has happened is one of the Windows tasks finished last, writing a [BOM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte_order_mark) to its GRAPHVIZ_VERSION preceding the actual version. The deployment task runs on Alpine Linux and apparently does not understand this BOM (tries to interpret it as a UTF-8 character).

summary: {a -> b; c}  ->d . I think it's better that only b and c connect to d. not a, b and c .
add timer subsystem to prevent routines from running too long
description:
## enhancement request

## Actual Behaviour

On occasion, the various Graphviz engines will run (much) longer than the user desires.  
Currently, the user can only (mostly) throttle run-time by setting limits on iterations within the primary subsystems (e.g. nslimit and nslimit1).  The relation between iterations and seconds is very murky.

Adding watch-dog timers to the primary subsystems and new attributes to set time maximums would allow the the user to directly limit total run-time (seconds, minutes, or hours) and/or subsystem run-time (seconds, minutes, hours, or percentage) . 

## OS Version

All

## Graphviz Version

all

summary: Something strange with sfdp.exe
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I tried to run the code of "HARP: Hierarchical Representation Learning for Networks" (https://github.com/GTmac/HARP), but I didn't get the expected results.
The author uses sfdp_linux to produce the graph coarsening.
But when I tried these three standard datasets, I found that the graph was not coarsened.
That is, after the sentence "recursive_graphs, recursive_merged_nodes = [], read_coarsening_info( temp_dir)" of the external_ec_coarsening() function in graph_coarsening.py, the recursive_merged_nodes I received is an empty list.
I want to know what happened because this caused the external_ec_coarsening() function to directly return the original graph.
So, I want to ask can the sfdp in the graphviz library really perform graph coarsening, or am I looking for the wrong place?

## OS Version

Windows/Linux

## Graphviz Version

2.49.1

summary: Border-to-border edges
description:
If I have a simple graph with no node decoration, then `len` works fine:

```
digraph {
    A -> { B1,B2,B3 } [len=3]
} 
```
[![enter image description here][1]][1]

However, if I start adding decorations and titles, then the node in the left has a very short edge

```
digraph {
	node [ style="filled, rounded" fontname="Lato" margin=0.2 ]
	A [ label="Ban điều hành" shape="doubleoctagon" fillcolor="#f4f1de" fontcolor="#000000" ]
	node [ shape="plaintext	" fillcolor="#81b29a" fontcolor="#000000" ]
	B1 [ label="Phát triển cộng đồng" ]
	B2 [ label="Nội dung" ]
	B3 [ label="Quản lý hệ thống" ]
	
	A -> { B1,B2,B3 } [len=3]
}
```
[![enter image description here][2]][2]

I guess it's because the edge length start from the nodes' centers, not their borders.

Is there a way to make them start from the nodes' borders? You can modify length of individual edge, but this won't work if you need to use `A -> { B1,B2,B3 }`

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/nbzlnm.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/DTjZWm.png

Windows 10 Home, GraphViz version 2.47.1 (20210417.1919)

summary: gvpr "split", "tokens", and "index" functions produce incorrect results
stop packaging development versions
description:
Graphviz currently offers packages through [Gitlab's package registry](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/packages). Release versions are there¹ as well as inter-release development versions.²

In my thinking, the latter no longer make sense. Graphviz’ release cadence is not fixed, not tied to particular features, and currently happens about once a month. The release packages are no more or less stable than the development packages. The development versions have cryptic version numbers, in fact _two_ cryptic version numbers, one for the package registry³ and one reported by the compiled binary. The former number is useless. The latter are occasionally quoted in issues⁴ requiring whoever investigates the issue to first reverse this to a commit hash. The existence of development packages also suggests to downstream ecosystems that they should potentially consume these.⁵

I think we should stop packaging the development versions altogether. If you need access to an inter-release Graphviz, build from source. If there are users who cannot do this but require more frequent Graphviz updates, we should shrink the release cadence.

¹ e.g. 2.49.2, https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/packages/3350737

² e.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/packages/3352781

³ the one for https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/packages/3352781 above is 0.0.538615981146443367376526367751936609654005400978

⁴ e.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2138

⁵ e.g. https://trac.macports.org/ticket/62165#comment:4. It sounds like the original motivation was valid, but no longer holds now that release cadence is more frequent.
