```

## Expected Behaviour

A cleaner, graceful handling of this situation.

## Actual Behaviour

Error about missing CMake config files.

## OS Version

Debian 10.

## Graphviz Version

Commit 2bf6408137d38cee48b1cfb7ffb195de9c38ee69.

## Additional info

AFAICT what's happening is that [Catch2 _itself_ provides its CMake config file](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/amd64/catch2/filelist). So without Catch2 installed, you don't get a clean message about Catch2 not found because the detection logic itself is not found.

summary: enable Chocolatey caching in CI
description:
The Windows CI tasks use the Chocolatey package manager to install some dependencies (e.g. Python 3). When swapping the origin of dependencies from [the Windows dependency repo](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz-build-utilities) to Chocolatey there is an acknowledged performance cost to this: installing something from Chocolatey takes much longer.

By default, Chocolatey stores its cache in the system temporary directory. I believe this is not retained across executions on Gitlab runners. However it looks like we can configure the cache location, https://docs.chocolatey.org/en-us/guides/usage/change-cache. And Gitlab also describes what is necessary to cache directories, https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/index.html#cache. Combining these pieces of information, we may be able to accelerate the Windows builds by configuring a reusable cache.

Not high priority as the long pole in CI is currently the macOS tasks, not Windows. But something to think about.

summary: Release Ubuntu 20.04 LTS not 20.10 .deb Package
description:
The variety of packages that you make available with each release is wonderful. Thanks for doing this.

One detail, however: it appears that the build system is creating a .deb package for Ubuntu 20.10. This version of Ubuntu was EOL back in July. It is not the LTS (long term service) version. My guess is that the aim was to build 20.04 (most recent LTS), and this is a typo in the automated builds.

![releases](/uploads/bc54f9b50480af7853fee06ad959fcce/releases.png)

![ubuntu](/uploads/031c8adcf2fffb855e3416e099a96594/ubuntu.png)

summary: Windows Cygwin job times out
description:
It seems near-impossible to pass CI right now. I've retried https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2244 several times and the Windows Cygwin job consistently times out. It barely reaches CMake configuring before hitting the 1hr timeout, let alone even starting the build itself.

@magjac can we temporarily disable this job? I don't know what has changed, but it seems to require significantly longer than the Gitlab 1hr ceiling.

summary: Official website provides Windows 2.38.msi version download
description: We tool use 2.38 version

summary: reduce release artifacts
description:
As discussed on https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2144, it is no longer possible to reliably retrieve all the Graphviz release artifacts (340 files). All lists of this now truncate to an arbitrary 100. For a viable next release, I think we need to get our artifact list under 100 files.

As a slightly less radical plan than what I proposed on #2144, I think we should create a single tarball of all binary Linux artifacts for a given platform. E.g. `centos7-rpms.tar.xz`. Most people consuming these need all the RPMs anyway, as they don't declare dependencies so you typically need to force install all of them and pray. This by itself would dramatically decrease the number of artifacts we ship.

summary: remove COLLECTION
description:
As discussed in #2144, I believe the notion of "collection" in Graphviz builds is inaccurate and unnecessary. We _do_ need to distinguish the CMake builds from others, but beyond that we do not need this label. No package is more "experimental" than any other and we are moving towards dropping "development" releases (#2139).

I think we should just remove the entire notion of COLLECTION in CI and the build system.

summary: remove architecture infixes in package names
description: All the Graphviz release artifacts end up with "\_x86_64_" or some variant in the middle of their filename. This is redundant when they have the architecture as a suffix too. We should drop the infix one.

summary: make CI artifact lists more precise
description:
As part of #2144, I've been looking into getting more explicit about where files are exported from CI jobs and imported into other CI jobs. Something surprising I discovered is that `artifacts` that are not found at runtime are silently ignored. E.g. The `macos-cmake-build` job inherits from the `macos_build_definition` template that claims to export `GRAPHVIZ_VERSION`. But the CMake build does not produce this file, so sure enough if you check the [build log for a recent run of this job](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/jobs/1732395148), you see:

```
WARNING: GRAPHVIZ_VERSION: no matching files 
```

This seems intentional and not strictly a problem. But a side effect of this is that it is impossible to tell where artifacts are coming from and/or being used from .gitlab-ci.yml alone.

I think we need to get more precise about this and, in particular, make `GRAPHVIZ_VERSION` originate from a single location (the `portable-source` job). As I've mentioned previously, it's not clear to me why the macOS jobs contain comments that they cannot consume `portable-source`.

summary: still a tiny bashism in cmd/gvmap/gvmap.sh
description:
Hi,

I think that there is still a bashism in this script.
Here is a patch.
[gvmap.sh_bashism.patch](/uploads/b393d8f980ed140e02c7c48e3d18c7f5/gvmap.sh_bashism.patch)

summary: LUA_INSTALL_DIR portability problem
description:
## Steps to reproduce
```
export CPPFLAGS=-I/sw/include LDFLAGS=-L/sw/lib
./configure --prefix=/sw --enable-lua LUA=lua53
make
make DESTDIR=/sw/build.build/root-libgraphviz238-shlibs-2.49.3-1 install
```

## Expected Behaviour

1. lua is detected (provided by fink in /sw, and has lua.pc but no lualib.pc)
2. graphviz lua module installed in lua subdir somewhere under /sw (because that's where lua is)

## Actual Behaviour
```
checking for lua... lua53
checking for lua... (cached) lua53
checking for Lua headers and libraries with pkg-config...
checking for Lua compiling and linking... 
[...]
mkdir -p /sw/build.build/root-libgraphviz238-shlibs-2.49.3-1/usr/lib/lua/;
if test -w /sw/build.build/root-libgraphviz238-shlibs-2.49.3-1/usr/lib/lua/; then \
                (cd /sw/build.build/root-libgraphviz238-shlibs-2.49.3-1/usr/lib/lua/; \
                        cp -f /sw/build.build/root-libgraphviz238-shlibs-2.49.3-1/sw/lib/graphviz-2.38/graphviz/lua/libgv_lua.so gv.so;) \
        else \
                echo "Warning: /usr/lib/lua/ is not writable."; \
                echo "Skipping system installation of lua binding."; \
        fi
```

Notice the bindings are staged to install in /usr instead of /sw

## OS Version

OS X 10.13

## Graphviz Version

2.49.3

## Additional info

configure.ac line 911 is suspicious two ways (here's starting at 908):
```
                        LUA_VERSION=`$PKG_CONFIG --modversion lua$l`
                        LUA_INCLUDES="$LUA_CFLAGS "`$PKG_CONFIG --cflags lua$l`
                        LUA_LIBS="$LUA_LFLAGS "`$PKG_CONFIG --libs lua$l`
                        LUA_INSTALL_DIR="/usr/lib$LIBPOSTFIX/lua/`$PKG_CONFIG --variable=V lua`"
```
My bug is that 911 hard-codes /usr rather than introspecting via pkg-config. Secondarily, that line checks for package "lua" not "lua$l", even though the surrounding loop might set $l to various non-null strings.

summary: Some lefty files installed when lefty disabled
description:
## Steps to reproduce

./configure ...
make
make install ...

## Expected Behaviour

Now that lefty is disabled by default, lefty should not be compiled and none of its associated files shoule be installed.

## Actual Behaviour

During ./configure:
```
  lefty:         
```
After installation, as compared to my 2.46.0 that had lefty enabled, I now have
* bin/lefty -- not installed
* share/graphviz/lefty/ -- fewer files but still some
* pdf/leftyfguide.pdf -- still installed
* share/man/man1/lefty.1 -- still installed

## OS Version

OS X 10.13

## Graphviz Version

2.49.3

## Additional info

It looks like cmd/lefty/Makefile.am does an incomplete job of wrapping its pieces with ```WITH_LEFTY```. Would it be easier to apply that control to a ```SUBDIRS+=lefty``` in cmd/Makefile.am rather than within the deeper levels?

The leftyguide comes from doc/Makefile.am, where there is no ```WITH_LEFTY``` control.

summary: move some code into C++?
description:
There are a few pieces of Graphviz that are written in C, but are not usable without linking against libc++/libstdc++. E.g. cmd/mingle/minglemain.c. It seems like nothing is gained from this being in C.

Should we consider porting some of this to C++? In the case of minglemain.c for example, this would allow dropping the use of `agxbuf`s and just using `std::ostringstream`.

summary: Feature request: Produce PDF/A compliant PDF for archiving?
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I'm trying to creat a pdf document in latex compliant with `pdf/a-1b`. When I try to include the pdf produced by graphviz, in latex with `\includegraphics{o.pdf}`, latex produces a noncompliant pdf/a. The reason for this is latex incorporated a non pdf/a compliant from graphviz. I wouldn't want to take the hastle to upload graphviz's pdf online to convert it to pdf/a (which I did, and it solved the problem). Is this feature possible?

## Expected Behaviour

graphviz produce a pdf/a compliant pdf with -Tpdf

## Actual Behaviour

graphviz produce a non pdf/a compliant with -Tpdf

## OS Version

Windows 10 64-bit

## Graphviz Version
dot - graphviz version 2.49.3 (20211023.0002)

## Additional info

Fill in with anything else that might be important.

summary: win32/autoconf: libgvc export name does not match filename
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Build graphviz for mingw32 using autoconf.

## Expected Behaviour

The resulting build should work.

## Actual Behaviour

`dot` and similar programs fail with a library dependency error. The reason for this
is that they expect the library to be named `gvc.dll` (because that's specified as
the export name in gvc.def), but the library is actually named libgvc-6.dll

## OS Version

Windows Server 2022

## Graphviz Version

master

## Additional info

It's a bit annoying to convince libtool to note use the `lib` prefix for libraries and it may break linking using `-lgvc`. The path of least resistance is probably to adjust the export name, but of course that breaks compatibility with binaries built using other methods.

summary: Extra TR space not allocated equally in TD
description:
graphviz fails to allocate space equally when TD are smaller than the TR and need to grow. For example, trying to render a node like this table fails (see [bug.gv](/uploads/f29e0477eb16259b8bed7183998dc617/bug.gv)):
This is a very long top row
1 2 3 4 5
The 5 TD don't get equal space in the TR. The first TD get much more space, the second one a little less, and so on. Also, as you can see in the second node, decreasing the size of the TD explicitly leaves the unbalanced distribution. ![](/uploads/968b8d4217190ee59d09985ccbadc289/bug.png) Graphviz Version: 2.43.0

summary: Remove shockwave flash output format
description:
`plugin/ming/gvrender_ming.c` outputs Shockwave Flash files, using the `ming` library: http://www.libming.org/.

This format's pretty dead, with Adobe giving up support: https://www.adobe.com/au/products/flashplayer/end-of-life.html

And the output format isn't documented on https://graphviz.org/docs/outputs/.

I propose we remove this code; perhaps through a deprecation period (maybe flagging it off in a release? then removing it next release?)

summary: MacOS --enable-static   cmd/tools/Makefile, CFLAGS requires -lc++
description:
On macOS 11.6.1, Xcode 13.1
```
configure --enable-static 
make
```
eventually yields 
```
  CCLD     gvpack_static
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
  "std::__1::__vector_base_common<true>::__throw_length_error() const", referenced from:
      void std::__1::vector<Rectangle, std::__1::allocator<Rectangle> >::emplace_back<double&, double&, double&, double&>(double&, double&, double&, double&) in libvpsc_C.a(csolve_VPSC.o)
```
followed by about 250 more lines like this.

This can be fixed by adding -lc++ to CFLAGS.

I'm not sure if adding -lc++ is the best solution, or how best to implement this in automake, and how non-OSX platforms may be affected, and whether they see the same issue.

summary: Memory Issue - vector of vector of nodes
description:
## Steps to reproduce
I am repeating a layout of this file:
[Causal_Loop.dot](/uploads/cb28674dc77438ebd5fd7911977b7ad5/Causal_Loop.dot)

## Expected Behaviour

Repeated layouting without an issue.

## Actual Behaviour

The second time I get a memory issue in routespl.c in common library. 
![image](/uploads/44f2e3c7e6364d663e5bc3742e1c701e/image.png)

## OS Version

macOS

## Graphviz Version

run $ dot -V

## Additional info

I use graphviz as a library. That is a contributing factor. 
The problem at hand happens not during first layouting but during second. 
That makes sense as the cycles pointer is static.
![image](/uploads/1536a9f679b2e4aa22f72638db3d756c/image.png)

Interestingly, `cycles` is a vector of vector of nodes, but the `vec_delete` seems to be infinitely recursive, always expecting that the memory references another vector. That is unproblematic for the DFS vectors, as they all emptied before memory deallocation (all nodes are pushed/popped during DFS). But for the resulting vector this is an issue as the result has cycles, so we have indeed a vector of a vector of nodes, and `vec_delete` called on a node has undefined behaviour.

summary: broken RPATHs
description:
`rpmbuild` acquired a new trick in Fedora 35 to detect `RPATH` problems, https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/Broken_RPATH_will_fail_rpmbuild. When attempting to add Fedora 35 jobs to Graphviz CI, these checks fail the build (log snippet below). It looks like we could set the `QA_RPATHS` mask to `0x0001` to suppress these warnings, but it seems like this is something we should probably fix.

```
+ /usr/lib/rpm/check-rpaths
*******************************************************************************
*
* WARNING: 'check-rpaths' detected a broken RPATH OR RUNPATH and will cause
*          'rpmbuild' to fail. To ignore these errors, you can set the
*          '$QA_RPATHS' environment variable which is a bitmask allowing the
*          values below. The current value of QA_RPATHS is 0x0000.
*
*    0x0001 ... standard RPATHs (e.g. /usr/lib); such RPATHs are a minor
*               issue but are introducing redundant searchpaths without
*               providing a benefit. They can also cause errors in multilib
*               environments.
*    0x0002 ... invalid RPATHs; these are RPATHs which are neither absolute
*               nor relative filenames and can therefore be a SECURITY risk
*    0x0004 ... insecure RPATHs; these are relative RPATHs which are a
*               SECURITY risk
*    0x0008 ... the special '$ORIGIN' RPATHs are appearing after other
*               RPATHs; this is just a minor issue but usually unwanted
*    0x0010 ... the RPATH is empty; there is no reason for such RPATHs
*               and they cause unneeded work while loading libraries
*    0x0020 ... an RPATH references '..' of an absolute path; this will break
*               the functionality when the path before '..' is a symlink
*          
*
* Examples:
* - to ignore standard and empty RPATHs, execute 'rpmbuild' like
*   $ QA_RPATHS=$(( 0x0001|0x0010 )) rpmbuild my-package.src.rpm
* - to check existing files, set $RPM_BUILD_ROOT and execute check-rpaths like
*   $ RPM_BUILD_ROOT=<top-dir> /usr/lib/rpm/check-rpaths

summary: Incorrect ortho edges with port specification

Spline input:
```
digraph {
        layout=fdp

        node1 [pos="0,0!"]
        node2 [pos="2,0!"]
        node1 -> node2:ne;
        node1 -> node2:sw;
}
```

Ortho input:
```
digraph {
        layout=fdp
        overlap=true
        splines=ortho

        node1 [pos="0,0!"]
        node2 [pos="2,0!"]
        node1 -> node2:ne;
        node1 -> node2:sw;
}

```

Spline output looks like expected: ![](/uploads/218c6abbf7067c96ad284ad03efb35bc/splines.svg)

While ortho is not: ![](/uploads/0064658ea5b196969fd7d2fcef525b6e/ortho.svg)

summary: Edge port specification is ignored in bundle description.
description:
Separated edges port specification:

```
digraph G {
        layout=fdp
        node0 -> node1:w
        node0 -> node2:w
        node0 -> node3:w
}
```

Bundle edges port specification:

```
digraph G {
        layout=fdp
        node0 -> {node1:w node2:w node3:w}
}
```


The first output is like expected:

![single.svg](/uploads/7ad9924e4f46e8fdd2a6d0046f452069/single.svg)

The second output expected to be the same, but instead of this port specifications are ignored:

![bundle.svg](/uploads/f6e1a3fce66d391aecd10ed8b5e4ac9b/bundle.svg)

summary: Sub-optimal rounded box output in SVG
description:
Let's use the following simple input:

`digraph { A [label="", style="rounded", shape=box] }`

Generated SVG:

![box.svg](/uploads/cc1bdcd3dae5a4fcb99606c1f87bc48f/box.svg)

Expected SVG:

![box-correct.svg](/uploads/a36d74d51304c0b45c2f348df0910edd/box-correct.svg)

It looks the same, but it's not, while looking inside.
Box itself in the generated SVG:

```
<path fill="none" stroke="black" d="M42,-36C42,-36 12,-36 12,-36 6,-36 0,-30 0,-24 0,-24 0,-12 0,-12 0,-6 6,0 12,0 12,0 42,0 42,0 48,0 54,-6 54,-12 54,-12 54,-24 54,-24 54,-30 48,-36 42,-36"/>
```

Box in the second SVG:
```
<rect fill="none" stroke="black" x="0" y="-36" width="54" height="36" rx="12" ry="12"/>
```

It seems graphviz doesn't use all language tools provided by the SVG.
The second (suggested) output has the following advantages:


1. This is more compact and need less space in file.
2. This is more clear while looking into SVG file in text editor. SVG is a text format, so this is situation is possible. At that, these files can be stored in git and other VCS with subsequent viewing of changes diff. In this case diff of the latter string is understandable, while in first is not so clear.
3. This should improve SVG editing with vector graphic editors. For example, resizing and changing radius of rectangle with rounded corners is not the same, as these operations with set of curves.
4. This is mathematically correct, unlike the current implementation. Bezier curves cannot exactly represent circle sectors.

Graphvis version:

dot - graphviz version 2.50.0 (0), Linux

summary: Static Windows MinGW builds fail
description:
## Steps to reproduce
```
./autogen.sh
./configure --disable-shared --enable-static
make
```
## Expected Behaviour

No errors.

## Actual Behaviour

More than 2000 errors like:
```
C:\Users\magja\graphviz\cmd\dot/dot.c:112: undefined reference to `__imp_agbindrec'
```
## OS Version

MinGW on Windows 10. Both these versions:
* MINGW64_NT-10.0-21364 3.2.0-340.x86_64 x86_64
* MINGW64_NT-10.0-17763 3.3.3-341.x86_64 x86_64

## Graphviz Version

bdec223b95573c75c7f0895cf66ca29de3d9339c (2.50.1~dev.20220102.1736)

## Additional info

The reason for these problems is that the `GVDLL` symbol, which is set by `configure` for shared builds but unset for static builds, is not fully respected everywhere in the code base, causing storage-class attribute declarations to be applied also in static builds.

### Unsuccessful build
https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/jobs/1936359407

### Successful build in a WIP branch
https://gitlab.com/magjac/graphviz/-/jobs/1935936272

summary: Building from scratch with Visual Studio fails
description:
## Steps to reproduce

* Start Visual Studio
* Open `graphviz.sln`
* Click on **Build -> Build Solution** or press **Ctrl-Shift-B**

## Expected Behaviour

No errors.

## Actual Behaviour

Many errors like:
```
3>C:\Users\magja\graphviz\windows\include\config.h(5,10): fatal error C1083: Cannot open include file: 'version.h': No such file or directory
```
## OS Version

Windows 10.

## Graphviz Version

4171a192e58d381578479f039fd961c62656ae6c (2.50.1~dev.20220106.0204 (20220106.0204))

## additional info

Repeating the build gives fewer errors the second time and succeeds the third time.

The reason for this problem is missing project references.

Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.7.2 was used.

This problem does not manifest itself when building from the CLI using MSBuild. Presumably because MSBuild does not build subprojects in parallel.

summary: Plugins are not configured on MinGW
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Just run `dot` without any arguments.

## Expected Behaviour

No error messages.

## Actual Behaviour

```
There is no layout engine support for "dot"
Perhaps "dot -c" needs to be run (with installer's privileges) to register the plugins?
```

## OS Version

Windows 10 - MINGW64_NT-10.0-21364 3.3.3-341.x86_64 2021-12-30 06:18 UTC x86_64

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.50.1~dev.20220106.1056 (20220106.1056)

## Additional info
Running `dot -c` manually doesn't help.

The reason for this problem is that the plugin code expects MinGW DLLs to have version numbers which they don't.

This patch fixes the problem:
```
a/lib/gvc/gvconfig.c b/lib/gvc/gvconfig.c
index 4773a60c3..f9c15e55a 100644
--- a/lib/gvc/gvconfig.c
+++ b/lib/gvc/gvconfig.c
@@ -407,7 +407,7 @@ static bool is_plugin(const char *filepath) {
     }
     len -= strlen(SUFFIX);

-#if defined(_WIN32) && !defined(__MINGW32__) && !defined(__CYGWIN__)
+#if defined(_WIN32) && !defined(__CYGWIN__)
     // Windows libraries do not have a version in the filename

 #elif defined(GVPLUGIN_VERSION)
@@ -442,7 +442,7 @@ static bool is_plugin(const char *filepath) {
     if (len < 2 || isdigit(filepath[len - 2]) || filepath[len - 1] != '.') {
        return false;
     }
-#elif defined(__MINGW32__) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
+#elif defined(__CYGWIN__)
     if (len < 2 || isdigit((int)filepath[len - 2]) || filepath[len - 1] != '-') {
        return false;
     }
diff --git a/lib/gvc/gvplugin.c b/lib/gvc/gvplugin.c
index 31218fb99..10aa34afe 100644
--- a/lib/gvc/gvplugin.c
+++ b/lib/gvc/gvplugin.c
@@ -218,7 +218,7 @@ gvplugin_library_t *gvplugin_library_load(GVC_t * gvc, char *path)
 #else
     strcpy(sym, s + 4);         /* strip leading "/lib" or "/cyg" */
 #endif
-#if defined(__CYGWIN__) || defined(__MINGW32__)
+#if defined(__CYGWIN__)
     s = strchr(sym, '-');       /* strip trailing "-1.dll" */
 #else
     s = strchr(sym, '.');       /* strip trailing ".so.0" or ".dll" or ".sl" */
```

summary: tclpkg Makefile corrupts CFLAGS
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Include "-mno-xop -mbmi" in CFLAGS

## Expected Behaviour

Build runs as usual, using the correct CFLAGS

## Actual Behaviour

The Makefile replaces "-mno-xop -mbmi" with "-mno-mbmi", which is an invalid option and causes the build to fail.

x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-g++: error: unrecognized command-line option ‘-mno-mbmi’; did you mean ‘-mno-bmi’?

git history shows this going back to 2011 (a750d28463a9248fe5a42d3dae5768d38853d837), so I'm not sure how it ever built for me before. Curiously, I had compiled 2.49.0 successfully as recently as October 2020, and am hitting this error on a rebuild of the exact same version.

## OS Version

Gentoo, using GCC 11.2.0

## Graphviz Version

2.49.0

summary: spurious "no hard-coded metrics" warnings on labels with empty lines
description:
Recently, the GraphViz version I use on some builder for my project was updated, and many of my tests started failing because of some new warning occasionally emitted by `dot`. The message is `Warning: no hard-coded metrics for 'Lato'`, where `Lato` is an installed TTF font I use. But the strange part is that the message was not always emitted for all graphs using Lato. After some investigation, it seems to be triggered by labels containing empty lines. ## Steps to reproduce ``` % cat foo.dot digraph "" { 0 -> 1 [fontname="Lato",label=<
1>] } % dot -Tsvg foo.dot >/dev/null Warning: no hard-coded metrics for 'Lato'. Falling back to 'Times' metrics % cat bar.dot digraph "" { 0 -> 1 [fontname="Lato",label=<
1>] } % dot -Tsvg bar.dot >/dev/null ``` The difference between these two files is only the space in the label. Adding the space removes the warning. Also note that if I add `-v`, it appears the font `Lato` is resolved differently depending on whether the label starts with an empty line or not: ``` % dot -v -Tsvg foo.dot >/dev/null 2>foo.stderr % dot -v -Tsvg bar.dot >/dev/null 2>bar.stderr % diff foo.stderr bar.stderr 26,27c26 < Warning: no hard-coded metrics for 'Lato'. Falling back to 'Times' metrics < fontname: "Lato" resolved to: [internal hard-coded] --- > fontname: "Lato" resolved to: (PangoCairoFcFont) "Lato, Regular" /usr/share/fonts/TTF/Lato-Regular.ttf ``` ## Expected Behaviour I would expect no warning, and the font resolved to `Lato-Regular.ttf` in both cases. ## OS Version This was discovered using `graphviz 2.50.0-2` on Arch Linux. ## Graphviz Version ``` % dot -v dot - graphviz version 2.50.0 (0) libdir = "/usr/lib/graphviz" Activated plugin library: libgvplugin_dot_layout.so.6 Using layout: dot:dot_layout Activated plugin library: libgvplugin_core.so.6 Using render: dot:core Using device: dot:dot:core The plugin configuration file: /usr/lib/graphviz/config6 was successfully loaded. render : cairo dot dot_json fig gd json json0 map mp pic pov ps svg tk visio vml vrml xdot xdot_json layout : circo dot fdp neato nop nop1 nop2 osage patchwork sfdp twopi textlayout : textlayout device : canon cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot dot_json eps fig gd gd2 gif gv imap imap_np ismap jpe jpeg jpg json json0 mp pdf pic plain plain-ext png pov ps ps2 svg svgz tk vdx vml vmlz vrml wbmp webp x11 xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4 xdot_json xlib loadimage : (lib) eps gd gd2 gif jpe jpeg jpg png ps svg webp xbm ```

summary: lneato with any argument except -? crashes
description:
## Steps to reproduce

`lneato.exe -V; echo $?`

## Expected Behaviour

Version printed and exit status 0.

## Actual Behaviour

No output and exit status 127.

For Debug builds, this dialog pops up:

![Screenshot_2022-01-16_094837](/uploads/0c5722f43374224fdc949048129aefa4/Screenshot_2022-01-16_094837.png)

## OS Version

Windows 10.

## Graphviz Version

`dot - graphviz version 3.0.0~dev.20220115.2107 (20220115.2107)`

Build on a branch emanating from 0be189b22.

## Additional info

The text in the popup is probably related to this warning:

`C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\magjac\graphviz\cmd\lneato\mswin32\lneato.c(55,36): warning C4476: 'snprintf' : unknown type field character 'N' in format specifier [C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\magjac\graphviz\cmd\lneato\lneato.vcxproj]`

This problem persists after fixing #1934 with !2407.

Printf-debugging shows that the program terminates when [this statement](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/cmd/lneato/mswin32/lneato.c#L55-57) is executed:

```
        snprintf(cmd, sizeof(cmd), "%s -e \"load('dotty.lefty');"
                 "dotty.protogt.lserver='neato';dotty.simple('%Ns');\"", path,
                 pCmdLine);
```

summary: Suboptimal layout with a very simple graph
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Render with `dot` the following graph:

```
digraph G
{	subgraph cluster_1
	{	B;
		C -> A -> F -> G;
	}

	G -> D;
	A -> D -> E -> C;
	E -> F;
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

Nodes *C*, *A*, *F*, and *G* form a vertical line with node *B* to the left. This layout opmises the lengths of the *CA* and *EC* edges:

![expected](/uploads/cc4ef7dd533da7927ebed7e799519c40/expected.png)

## Actual Behaviour

Node *B* is directly over *A*, *F*, and *G*. Node *C* to the left. The lengths of edges *CA* and *EC* are suboptimal:

![actual](/uploads/71a930651edf386ecf5345d975a8dd51/actual.png)

I expect the algorithm to swap *B* and *C* at the horisontal optimisation phase.

```
OS Version      : OS-independent
Graphviz Version: 2.50.0
```

summary: output formats canon, dot, and xdot are not completely faithful to input
description:
## Steps to reproduce
Desired result (without -Tcanon):  
`dot -Tpng bugfile.gv >bugfile.png`  
Incorrect result (with -Tcanon):  
`dot -Tcanon bugfile.gv >bugfile.dot`.  (or dot-Tdot bugfile.gv >bugfile.dot)  
then `dot -Tpng bugfile.dot >bugfile.canon.png`

bugfile.gv:  
```
digraph G {
	subgraph clusterSurround1 {

		subgraph cluster1 {
			graph [color=purple]
			x1 -> y1 
			x1 -> z1 
		}
		subgraph cluster2 {
			graph [color=pink]
			x2 -> y2 
			x2 -> z2
			subgraph cluster2a {
				graph [color=blue  label=C2 boss=worker]			
				x21 ->x22
			}
		}
		q0 -> x2;
		z2 -> x1
	}
	graph [label="My Cool Graph" fontcolor=red id=boss]  //  this line will be repositioned
}

```

## Expected Behaviour

pretty-printed version of input, (dot and xdot formats also add positioning detail), but no semantic changes

## Actual Behaviour

Root graph attributes (label, lp, fontcolor, fontsize, id, and others) can be repositioned in the canon/dot output. This can alter the semantics of the original input file.  (For more info see:https://graphviz.org/faq/#FaqGraphLabel)

## OS Version

Linux -  5.4.0-96-generic #109-Ubuntu

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 3.0.0~dev.20220120.0312 (20220120.0312)

## Additional info

desired graph (dot -Tpng bugfile.gv >bugfile.png):  
![dotAndCanonBug](/uploads/fe60686ed0eb5d71588576aaba768b98/dotAndCanonBug.png)  
incorrect graph (dot -Tcanon bugfile.gv |dot -Tpng >bugfile.canon.png):  
![dotAndCanonBug.canon](/uploads/d5b7db8d6569a5238dee95862b172059/dotAndCanonBug.canon.png)

summary: Stop requiring clusters / subgraphs with attributes to use the cluster_ id prefix
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Create a graph with a subgraph not prefixed with cluster_ , and see its attributes getting ignored

## Expected Behaviour

`subgraph` should be a good enough designator of a subgraph with attributes.

## Actual Behaviour

... but it isn't, and most attributes are ignored.

## OS Version

OpenSUSE SLES 15

## Graphviz Version

dot 2.40.1

## Additional info

In graphviz, cluster names must be prefixed with cluster_. That is counter-intuitive. Please do one of the following:

1. Make all subgraphs clusters
2. Have separate keywords `subgraph` and `cluster` (or `subgraph` and whatever-you-want-to-call-a-non-cluster-subgraph)
3. Default to a subgraph being a cluster, with non-cluster subgraphs requiring a special prefix
4. Use an attribute to decide whether the subgraph is a cluster or not.

summary: Non-default colorschemes cause border to always show
description:
## Steps to reproduce 1. Create a node without borders using: a. `style=filled`; or b. `shape=none` and an HTML-like label with `border="0"` 2. Change the `colorscheme` attribute to any other than `x11` 3. Note the presence of a border now Example: ``` graph { 1 [colorscheme=x11 shape=none style=filled fillcolor=lightblue]; 2 [colorscheme=svg shape=none style=filled fillcolor=lightblue]; 3 [colorscheme=blues9 shape=none style=filled fillcolor=3 ]; 4 [colorscheme=svg shape=none label=<
4
>]; } ``` Above example in online editor: http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20%7B%0A%20%201%20%5Bcolorscheme%3Dx11%20%20%20%20shape%3Dnone%20style%3Dfilled%20fillcolor%3Dlightblue%5D%3B%0A%20%202%20%5Bcolorscheme%3Dsvg%20%20%20%20shape%3Dnone%20style%3Dfilled%20fillcolor%3Dlightblue%5D%3B%0A%20%203%20%5Bcolorscheme%3Dblues9%20shape%3Dnone%20style%3Dfilled%20fillcolor%3D3%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%5D%3B%0A%20%204%20%5Bcolorscheme%3Dsvg%20%20%20%20shape%3Dnone%20label%3D%3C%3Ctable%20bgcolor%3D%22lightblue%22%20border%3D%220%22%20cellspacing%3D%228%22%3E%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%20width%3D%2232%22%3E4%3C%2Ftd%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E%3E%5D%3B%0A%7D ## Expected Behaviour Default border behavior using the `x11` colorscheme should remain the same with all other colorschemes. ## Actual Behaviour Borders show up with non-default colorschemes, regardless of explicit border settings. ## OS Version Debian 11 (Bullseye) ## Graphviz Version 2.43.0

summary: Use "none" instead of "transparent" when creating SVGs
description:
Based on the official SVG 1.1 standards the default value for stroke is "none". "transparent" is not supported in SVG 1.1 as mentioned here: https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/painting.html#SpecifyingPaint

Is it possible to use none instead of transparent? The transparent value causes issues because it is interpreted wrong by Asciidoctor because it only support the official SVG 1.1 spec: https://github.com/mogest/prawn-svg/issues/128

## Steps to reproduce
`mydiagram.dot`
```dot
digraph G {
A -> B
}
```

`dot -Tsvg mydiagram.dot -o output.svg`

## Expected Behaviour

```xml
...
<polygon fill="white" stroke="none" points="-4,4 -4,-112 58,-112 58,4 -4,4"/>
...
```

## Actual Behaviour

```xml
...
<polygon fill="white" stroke="transparent" points="-4,4 -4,-112 58,-112 58,4 -4,4"/>
...
```

## OS Version

Ubuntu 21.10

## Graphviz Version

2.43.0

summary: canon output format should be stable
description:
## Steps to reproduce

I'm using dot graphs as one part of our software documentation. For that I have version controlled the dot files with git. [Example](https://alleninstitute.github.io/MIES/file/_m_i_e_s___analysis_functions___multi_patch_seq_8ipf.html?highlight=msq_#_CPPv415MSQ_FastRheoEst6stringP19AnalysisFunction_V3)

As part of viewing differences of dot files, I would like to minimize the diff between each edit. And therefore I'm trying to standardize the graphs. I'm using `canon` as I think that this gives a canonical output format. Unfortunately it takes always a few calls until it generates no changes anymore. Is that to be expected?

```sh

summary: Preprocessors like tred or unflatten not available through API
description:
## Steps to reproduce

You use [Graphviz as a library](https://www.graphviz.org/pdf/libguide.pdf) and want to use unflatten preprocessor.

## Expected Behaviour

There should be an API available. That is that we would add the preprocessor 

## Actual Behaviour

Preprocessor commands are only available through command line. No API available. The preprocessor code is only accessible from a single file command line creating source code file (.c). No headers exist. The code isn't part of any library. 

## OS Version

All

## Graphviz Version

All

## Additional info

The code to execute the ingenious unflatten (and other preprocessors) can only be called from the command line. This restricts the use to command line interaction and makes it impossible to use for libraries like the [Graphviz WASM](https://github.com/hpcc-systems/hpcc-js-wasm).

I suggest to add the preprocessors as functions to the libgraph library - as they represent conversions from one graph to another.

summary: remove 'NOTUSED' macro?
description:
While reviewing !2450, I recalled the Graphviz tree has various `NOTUSED` macros:

```c
#define NOTUSED(x)    (void) (x)
```

This is wrapping the common idiom for squashing warnings for unused parameters. However, it is used inconsistently in the code base. Thus Graphviz developers still need to know and recognize this idiom when they see it.

Should we remove these macros and write `(void)x;` wherever we are ignoring `x`? My thinking is that only two end states make sense: (1) `NOTUSED` used everywhere, or (2) `NOTUSED` used nowhere and removed. Which should we move towards?

CC @magjac, @makelinux

----

Some elaborating discussion for completeness...

There is a GCC extension for squashing such warnings:

```c
void foo(int x __attribute__((unused))) {
}
```

This GNU attribute is also supported by Clang. In C++, there is a much nicer portable way of expressing this by omitting the parameter name:

```cpp
void foo(int) {
}
```

There has been some discussion over the years of bringing attribute syntax to ISO C. C++11 introduced `[[...]]` syntax for attributes and I have some hope this will come to a future version of ISO C. However I am not aware of any plans for this right now.

So a void cast is the most portable way I'm currently aware of for suppressing such warnings in C.

summary: C++ API not usable after install
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```
$ git clone https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz
$ cd graphviz
$ git log -1
commit 88e538477fdc365f9e4fef9860132cbf44b28a26 (HEAD -> main, origin/main, origin/HEAD)
Merge: 85be1516d 1f2fb60e1
Author: Matthew Fernandez <matthew.fernandez@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Feb 19 07:08:21 2022 +0000

    Merge branch 'smattr/08C6E85C-C8A0-48CB-B812-98567782EBAC' into 'main'

    upgrade Pylint dependency

    See merge request graphviz/graphviz!2442
$ export PREFIX=$(mktemp -d)
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=${PREFIX} -Dwith_cxx_api=ON .. && cmake --build . && cmake --build . --target install
$ echo -e "#include <graphviz/AGraph.h>\nint main(void) { return 0; }" >foo.cc
$ c++ -std=c++2a -I${PREFIX}/include -Wall -Wextra foo.cc
In file included from foo.cc:1:
/tmp/tmp.YTVIQFMuYX/include/graphviz/AGraph.h:6:10: fatal error: cgraph/cgraph.h: No such file or directory
 #include <cgraph/cgraph.h>
          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
```

## Expected Behaviour

Compilation succeeded.

## Actual Behaviour

Compilation failed due to missing cgraph.h.

## OS Version

```
$ uname -rms
Linux 4.19.0-18-amd64 x86_64
```

## Graphviz Version

Commit 88e538477fdc365f9e4fef9860132cbf44b28a26.

## Additional info

This occurs because AGraph.h is including cgraph.h using its source path, rather than its path at installation. I'm not sure the best way to fix this, because the include path needs to be different depending on whether this is compilation time or post-install: `<cgraph/cgraph.h>` vs `<graphviz/cgraph.h>`.

summary: port rtest to pytest
description:
The Graphviz test suite is spread amongst the subdirectories ci/, tests/ and rtest/. Tests are currently orchestrated via Pytest. Within this menagerie, rtest/rtest.py is a former Python (or even Perl?) script that has been dragged into the Pytest world against its will. As a result it is not particularly Pythonic and its failures are reported quite cryptically:

```
Test foo:bar : == Failed == baz.png
```

"OK, cool, but what were the differences between the actual output and the reference output?"

My (partially uninformed) summary of what is happening here is that rtest.py was once expected to be run locally. Hence why it outputs minimal information and instead dumps an informative diff as an HTML page for you to load. Of course this HTML page is inaccessible when it is generated in the CI environment. The CI environment is now the main way Graphviz developers execute the test suite. That is, the ground has shifted underneath rtest.py making its assumptions/expectations no longer accurate.

This issue is a proposal to port/rewrite rtest.py (or more accurately, rtest/tests.txt) into Pytest. This should allow (1) more detailed failure feedback, (2) more fine-grained test case failures, and (3) the ability to run rtest.py test cases in parallel. Note that this will require undoing some assumptions, e.g. that `os.getpid()` is a valid way to construct a temporary filename.

Related to #195.

summary: circo produces some edges that are unnecessarily long
Add a CONTRIBUTING.md to Graphviz
description:
I think Graphviz needs more contributors to be a sustainable project. I propose we should therefore prioritise onboarding of new contributors, by making it clear and transparent how to contribute.

There's emerging standard of a `CONTRIBUTING.md` that goes over how to contribute, how the project accepts and reviews changes, expectations around testing and commit messages, and perhaps even what we're looking for help with.

We already have `DEVELOPERS.md` which is mainly aimed at established contributors. I was thinking of something more aimed at newbies.

Some materials for how to set one up:
- https://mozillascience.github.io/working-open-workshop/contributing/
- https://docs.github.com/en/communities/setting-up-your-project-for-healthy-contributions/setting-guidelines-for-repository-contributors
- https://embeddedartistry.com/blog/2017/12/11/get-others-involved-in-your-project-with-a-contributing-guide/

Examples (more or less randomly chosen)
- https://github.com/github/docs/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
- https://github.com/google/docsy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
- https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
- https://github.com/opengovernment/opengovernment/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

summary: UBSan not fully applied in CI
description:
There are a pair of CI pipes, `ubuntu21.04-cmake-ASan-*` and `ubuntu21-10-cmake-ASan-*`, that run the CMake build and ctest with ASan and UBSan enabled. While looking at something else in this area, I noticed that neither the CMake support for these sanitizers nor .gitlab-ci.yml uses `-fno-sanitize-recover=undefined`. Without this, UBSan warnings display an error but do not abort program execution.

Maybe the above was already known but it was a surprise to me. Enabling `-fno-sanitize-recover=undefined` reveals that the #1906 test case triggers an integer overflow:

```
    def test_1906():
      """
      graphs that cause an overflow during rectangle calculation should result in
      a layout error
      https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1906
      """
    
      # one of the rtest graphs is sufficient to provoke this
      input = Path(__file__).parent / "graphs/root.gv"
      assert input.exists(), "unexpectedly missing test case"
    
      # use Circo to translate it to DOT
      with subprocess.Popen(["dot", "-Kcirco", "-Tgv", "-o", os.devnull, input],
                            stderr=subprocess.PIPE, universal_newlines=True) as p:
        _, stderr = p.communicate()
    
        assert p.returncode != 0, "graph that generates overflow was accepted"
    
>     assert "area too large" in stderr, "missing/incorrect error message"
E     AssertionError: missing/incorrect error message
E     assert 'area too large' in "/builds/smattr/graphviz/lib/label/xlabels.c:35:15: runtime error: signed integer overflow: -1884993080 - 1219985688 cannot be represented in type 'int'\n"
/builds/smattr/graphviz/rtest/test_regression.py:946: AssertionError
```

summary: lib/common assumes unistd.h functions
description:
MSVC reports the compilation warning:

```
  utils.c
C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\graphviz\graphviz\lib\common\utils.c(361,13): warning C4013: 'access' undefined; assuming extern returning int [C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\graphviz\graphviz\build\lib\common\common_obj.vcxproj]
```

Backtracking what is going on here, it seems most uses of unistd.h functions in the code base have something like the following stanza:

```c
#ifdef HAVE_UNISTD_H
#include <unistd.h>
#else
#include <ast/compat_unistd.h>
#endif
```

This is not present in lib/common code because lib/common does not depend on lib/ast. Instead it just does nothing (yolo) if `HAVE_UNISTD_H` prevents the inclusion of unistd.h.

So two relevant things to note:
1. unistd.h “shimming” like this is still an ongoing concern, AFAIK. Windows remains a hold out, that refuses to ship unistd.h.
2. lib/ast, (that I've heard variously referred to as “Abstract Software Toolkit” or “Advanced Software Technology” or “AT&T Software Technology”) is not the base of the dependency tree.

Should we move the unistd.h abstraction to cgraph or somewhere else? Should we try to purge platform-specific usage of such functions? Should we just shim unistd.h in windows/include/config.h that's hard coded anyway?

summary: modernize rsvg usage
description:
The RSVG plugin (plugin/rsvg) uses the deprecated `RsvgHandle` based API. Functions for interacting with this like `rsvg_handle_close` were deprecated in Rsvg 2.45.1 (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/-/blob/main/NEWS) released on 2018-12-11 in favor of the `GInputStream` based functions.

Graphviz should migrate its usage to the latter.

summary: Licensing - commercial plugins
description:
Dear Sir or Madam,

I am considering building a custom layout engine plugin, that I may or may not (partially) commercialize at a later date.
As far as I can see, you are currently using the [EPL v1.0](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/LICENSE), which means that the question "_Do I need to disclose my source code or not_" would basically boil down to: is the plugin a derivative work or not.

With regards to that topic, I find the following on the eclipse [EPL FAQ](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/eplfaq.php):
> 27. **I'm a programmer not a lawyer, can you give me a clear cut example of when something is or is not a derivative work?**
>
> [...]
>
>  For clarity, merely interfacing or interoperating with Eclipse Platform Plug-in APIs (without modification) does not make an Eclipse Platform Plug-in a derivative work.

Before I would undertake such a massive endeavor, I would like to have some clarity from your end on this matter.

Since the above statement is 
1) from the Eclipse Foundation and not from the GraphViz team
2) not part of the license itself

I think I cannot assume that your stance is similar towards the creation of "plugins", although I believe it is within the intended purpose of the EPL to allow such a thing.

So therefore, my question is as following:

> Would you consider a custom layout engine a derivative work if it
> 1) Is based on a completely unmodified copy of GraphViz
> 2) Where the unmodified copy of GraphViz is used _only_ as a linking target, i.e.
>    - My plugin dynamically registers itself via the `gvc` functionalities
>    - In order to do so uses the functionalities as defined in `gvplugin_layout.h` (and possibly `gvplugin_render.h` and/or `gvplugin_textlayout.h`)
>    - As a consequence also uses all transitive data types associated with the aforementioned, for instance:  \
>      `graph_t` -> `Agraph_s` -> `Agobj_t`, `Agdesc_t`, `Dtlink_t`,... => ...
>    - Calls the regular GraphViz API's, e.g. `gvContext`, `gvParseArgs`, `agopen`, `gvRenderJobs`... to create graphs dynamically
>    - All of the above *only* through dynamic linking, i.e. no changes to the original work.

Thank you in advance for considering my question.

Kind regards,  
Dob.

summary: update test coverage mechanism in CI
description:
Gitlab are intending to deprecated the current test coverage mechanism in the next release due to be unleashed on us later this year, https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipelines/settings.html#add-test-coverage-results-using-project-settings-deprecated.

I think we are using this in CI, though I have a hard time discriminating between what applies to Gitlab Enterprise vs Gitlab.org in the docs as well as between Gitlab's terminology for different types of coverage. So it is possible we are not using it at all. If we are though, we should look at migrating to whatever the new shiny is.

summary: update container register settings in CI
description: Gitlab are intending to deprecate some `tags` stuff related to the container register in 15.0 (2022-05-22), https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipelines/settings.html#add-test-coverage-results-using-project-settings-deprecated. I do not understand the full details of this, but it sounds like Graphviz may be affected.

summary: Improve Graphviz output accessibility for screen readers.
description:
Continuing from discussion on https://forum.graphviz.org/t/adding-metadata-to-the-output/1074/1.

First priority: Allow adding `alt` text for an entire Graph, when the Graph is output to SVG format. I think this will give us the most value, by allowing people to summarise entire graphs for visually impaired readers.

Second priority: Allow adding `alt` text for [image nodes](https://graphviz.org/docs/attrs/image/) like you can on the web.

For example, we could add a Graphviz attribute like `alt` or `desc` that outputs a `<description>` tag for SVG output.

Graphviz's attribute would probably want to abstract over various output formats. SVG is probably most important, followed by PDF, then (probably far down the list) HTML image maps (we have an old bug filed about image map alt text: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/265).

Prior art:

HTML:

* https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/alt
* https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/longDesc (deprecated)
* https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/figcaption

SVG:

* https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/title (accessible, short-text description)
* https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/desc (accessible, long-text description)

We may want to, like SVG, allow specifying a long and short variant. Although it's not clear how other formats would support that.

Let’s start with letting the end user specify the alt text. I think auto-generating alt text will be too hard and end up being too verbose for screen readers, but we could explore that later.

The `alt`, `desc`, `longdesc`, and `title` attributes all seem as-yet unused in Graphviz: https://graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html.

I'd be interested in feedback on this plan. Maybe I'm being too ambitious trying to have this abstract across formats, for example.

summary: upstream Gentoo documentation patches
description:
Moving discussion here from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2520#note_907134811:

> @smattr I'm trying to upstream some of the patches we still carry in Gentoo. One of the biggest issues is that graphviz currently abuses/neglects Automake's doc targets. For examples `pdf` vs `dist_pdf_DATA` means graphviz doesn't respect Autoconf's global `--docdir` setting. Here's my suggestion:
>
> 1. `--enable-doc` enables installing of all "big" documentation (PDF files, HTML pages), but installs man pages and info pages unconditionally, because these are expected as part of the standard Unix experience.
> 1. Shift the documentation generation burden to upstream. That is, when you're bootstrapping the tarball, you have to ensure you have `ps2pdf` and `groff` available. This massively improves the UX for users, since the documentation has been generated for them, and they don't have to have these tools installed. While I understand that this slightly increases the burden slightly, most of your infra seems to already have all the bits and pieces in place for these generation tools, so I don't think this practically increases burden on you.

summary: remove itos
description:
Migrating this from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2575#note_907097811:

> I implemented `itos` believing lifetime of an [rvalue](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/value_category) like this to be the extent of the containing expression. However, your question made me delve in to try to find chapter and verse in the C standard to back this up. I realized I'm wrong and I was thinking of the equivalent scenario in C++ (which would involve what they term a [prvalue](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/value_category#prvalue)). In C, the situation apparently differs between C99 and C11, for which there is a helpful example https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/lifetime.
>
> The tl;dr of this is that use of `itos` like this is unfortunately [undefined behavior](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/behavior) in C99, the mode in which we compile Graphviz. We should probably look at removing `itos` and its uses, which is disappointing as I introduced it aiming to solve a number of `sprintf` problems.

summary: CMake: use MODULE instead of SHARED for plugins
description:
Plugins are currently added with `add_library` designating them as `SHARED`. Reading the CMake docs¹ suggests these should have always been designated as `MODULE`:

>  `MODULE` libraries are plugins that are not linked into other targets but may be loaded dynamically at runtime using dlopen-like functionality.

However, attempting to do this exposes that `gvpack` and `test_common` link directly against plugins which CMake does not like. Unclear what the solution is here.

¹ https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.9/command/add_library.html

summary: Facilitate creation of legends for graphs
description:
A challenges many GraphViz users face is the desire to add a legend, which clarifies the choices of colors, shapes, fonts etc. for different categories of nodes (and edges) in the graph.

See, for example, [this popular StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/3499056/1593077https://stackoverflow.com/q/3499056/1593077) about the matter, accessed 38,000 times.

I am not a GraphViz expert, so I can't quite tell whether, using GraphViz' existing facilities, one can easily create and place a legend.

So, I am asking for one of two action items:

1. Add a section to the documentation explaining how to create and place reasonable-looking legends for graphs.
2. Add specific facilities which would help with legends, e.g. perhaps for subgraph positioning, subgraph scaling, spacing within subgraphs etc. (those are just off-the-cuff ideas).

summary: gvedit possible migration to qt6
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Install qt6. Then run the conventional autotools build with autogen.sh, configure, make

## Expected Behaviour

builds gvedit.app

## Actual Behaviour

First requires small changes to configure.ac, cmd/gvedit/imageviewer.cpp mainly, also gvedit/Makefile. Then gvedit.app builds without much drama.

## OS Version

MacOS 12.3.1 Monterey

## Graphviz Version

3.0.1 dev 

## Additional info

With some fixing, gvedit builds and seemingly works with QT6. In gvedit, we don't need to specify UTF-8 encoding in mdichild.cpp any more for QT6 - it is apparently the default. There were a few lines of fluff required in imageviewer.cpp to get QWidget resizing to compile again. QT6 doesn't have pkgconfig, so for testing, I commented out the tests in the top configure.ac, but it needs to be re-enabled.  gvedit/Makefile needed help to include -framework QWidgets and to know the location of QPrinter and QMainWindow for C++ - I am at a loss to explain why these are not linked by Homebrew to an easily discovered place.  That's about it.

It might be possible to avoid code changes using a qt5 shim for qt6, but is that a good idea?  That doesn't seem like it would help with the other problems. 

Is it better to have ifdefs for QT5 and QT6, or just cut over to QT6?

Someone needs to investigate QT6 licensing questions.

Stephen![Screen_Shot_2022-04-20_at_5.57.31_PM](/uploads/79dd1481da4d9f6e7d584775005b0f9a/Screen_Shot_2022-04-20_at_5.57.31_PM.png)

summary: add Ubuntu 22.04 in CI
description:
Ubuntu 22.04 was released recently. I had a brief attempt to add it to our CI repertoire, but ran into two issues:
1. The CMake build fails due to compiler warnings in the Lasi plugin.
2. The Autotools build can't find OCaml headers, which fails packaging.

The first:

```
[ 71%] Building CXX object plugin/lasi/CMakeFiles/gvplugin_lasi.dir/gvrender_lasi.cpp.o
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp: In function 'void lasi_textspan(GVJ_t*, pointf, textspan_t*)':
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp:358:16: error: enumeration value 'PANGO_VARIANT_ALL_SMALL_CAPS' not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]
  358 |         switch (pango_font_description_get_variant(pango_font)) {
      |                ^
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp:358:16: error: enumeration value 'PANGO_VARIANT_PETITE_CAPS' not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp:358:16: error: enumeration value 'PANGO_VARIANT_ALL_PETITE_CAPS' not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp:358:16: error: enumeration value 'PANGO_VARIANT_UNICASE' not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]
/builds/graphviz/graphviz/plugin/lasi/gvrender_lasi.cpp:358:16: error: enumeration value 'PANGO_VARIANT_TITLE_CAPS' not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]
cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors
```

is relatively easy to solve. We need to do some more work like 89edf3fe0ac0378b7d1297a0ca349a15bade3980.

But the second:

```
checking for Lua compiling and linking... checking for ocaml... ocaml
checking for ocamlopt... ocamlopt
checking caml/mlvalues.h usability... no
checking caml/mlvalues.h presence... no
checking for caml/mlvalues.h... configure: WARNING: Unable to find header caml/mlvalues.h. The OCAML packages will not be built
no
...
dh_install: warning: Cannot find (any matches for) "usr/lib/graphviz/ocaml" (tried in debian/tmp, debian/tmp)

dh_install: warning: libgv-ocaml missing files: usr/lib/graphviz/ocaml
dh_install: warning: Cannot find (any matches for) "usr/share/man/man3/gv.3ocaml" (tried in debian/tmp, debian/tmp)

dh_install: warning: libgv-ocaml missing files: usr/share/man/man3/gv.3ocaml
dh_install: error: missing files, aborting
```

is a little more complicated. mlvalues.h is supposed to be [provided by the ocaml package](https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?searchon=contents&keywords=mlvalues.h&mode=exactfilename&suite=jammy&arch=any) which we are installing in CI. So it's not clear to me why Autotools can't find it. Someone will have to investigate further.

summary: html text subscripts fail
description:
## Steps to reproduce
Both **svg** & **png** output formats fail to produce proper subscripts on "graphviz version 3.0.1~dev.20220319.1840 (20220319.1840)"   
**png** format is correct for graphiz version 2.43.0,   
**svg** is incorrect for graphiz version 2.43.0,   

```
// from https://forum.graphviz.org/t/keep-nodes-at-their-position/1134
// subscript fails for "dot - graphviz version 3.0.1~dev.20220319.1840 (20220319.1840)"
// subscripts are correct for 2.43.0 & png, incorrect for 2.43.0 & svg
digraph cfg{
	node [shape = circle];
	color=white;
	{ rank=same
		1 -> 2 [label = <x-p<SUB>a</SUB>> ]
		2 -> 3 [xlabel = <0-p<sub>b</sub>> ]
		3 -> 4 [label = <n-p<sub>a</sub>> ]
	        1:n -> 1:n [label =<Np<sub>a</sub>/x-p<sub>a</sub>> ]
		2:n -> 2:n [label =<Np<sub>a</sub>n> constraint=false];
		3:nw -> 2:ne [taillabel =<Np<sub>a</sub>n> constraint=false  labeldistance=4.0]
		4:n -> 4:n [label =<N/x-p<sub>a</sub>>];
		4:s -> 2:s [xlabel =<x-p<sub>a</sub>> labeldistance=10]
	}
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

![subscriptError.good](/uploads/a947345aac734d36cf6163d497038e74/subscriptError.good.png)

## Actual Behaviour

![subscriptError.bad](/uploads/9b9d28814b67da67e770a4f91e17f81f/subscriptError.bad.png)

## OS Version

lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Linuxmint
Description:    Linux Mint 20.1
Release:        20.1
Codename:       ulyssa


## Graphviz Version

dot -V
dot - graphviz version 3.0.1~dev.20220319.1840 (20220319.1840)

## Additional info

summary: fdp clusters are not stable, but random
description:
## Steps to reproduce

[Open link with example of fdp graph with link between clusters and parameter start=1](http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20layout%20%3D%20fdp%3B%0A%09start%20%3D%201%3B%0A%09subgraph%20cluster_1%20%7B%0A%09%20%20%20%09label%3D%221%22%20%3B%0A%09%7D%0A%09subgraph%20cluster_2%20%7B%0A%09%09label%3D%222%22%3B%0A%09%7D%0A%20%20%20%09cluster_1%20--%20cluster_2%3B%0A%7D)

Add and remove a node several times to provided graph.

Or download the source to PC and run `dot` or viewer several times.

## Expected Behaviour

Accordingly https://graphviz.org/docs/attr-types/startType/ positive parameter `start` should provide stable outcome.

The same image in 100% of cases:

![Screenshot_from_2022-05-06_19-27-51](/uploads/5fa09db3e8005effdd55fc2ebf97bc16/Screenshot_from_2022-05-06_19-27-51.png)

## Actual Behaviour

Sometimes on web and almost each other run on a PC the image is different:

![Screenshot_from_2022-05-06_19-28-44](/uploads/9de9ab405c990911d15e62c8d34e8855/Screenshot_from_2022-05-06_19-28-44.png) 

Actually `dot` behaves as [`start=random`](http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20layout%20%3D%20fdp%3B%0A%09start%20%3D%20random%3B%0A%09subgraph%20cluster_1%20%7B%0A%09%20%20%20%09label%3D%221%22%20%3B%0A%09%7D%0A%09subgraph%20cluster_2%20%7B%0A%09%09label%3D%222%22%3B%0A%09%7D%0A%09%0A%20%20%20%09cluster_1%20--%20cluster_2%3B%0A%7D) and not `start=1`

## OS Version

Ubuntu 20.4

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)

http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/

## Additional info

It doesn't happens with only nodes without clusters.

Windows/macOS/Linux/BSD? What version?

run $ dot -V

## Additional info

Fill in with anything else that might be important.

summary: [dotty] Fail to parse unnamed inline subgraphs
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```
$ echo "digraph { 1 -> {2 3} -> 4}" > test.dot
$ dotty test.dot
$ echo "digraph { 1 -> subgraph G {2 3} -> 4}" > test.dot
$ dotty test.dot
$ echo "digraph { 1 -> subgraph {2 3} -> 4}" > test.dot
$ dotty test.dot
```


## Expected Behaviour

The grammar specifies that the rule `edgeRHS` accepts either a `node_id` or a `subgraph`, and `subgraph` is defined as [ **subgraph** [ _ID_ ] ] '**{**' _stmt_list_ '**}**', i.e. subgraphs in EdgeRHS can either be specified with (i) curly brackets only; (ii) **subgraph** followed by brackets; and (iii) **subgraph** followed by an identifier, followed by curly brackets.

The example provided in the _Steps to reproduce_ present a simple example of (i), then (iii), then (ii). All are correct w.r.t. to the grammar and should be accepted by dotty.

## Actual Behaviour

(i) and (iii) works as expected, but (ii) fails with:
```
graph parser: syntax error near line 1
context: ubgraph{ 1 -> subgraph >>>  { <<< 2 3} -> 4}
dotty.lefty: cannot load graph

```

## OS Version

Linux Debian
```
$ uname -a
Linux ##### 5.10.0-14-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 5.10.113-1 (2022-04-29) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```


## Graphviz Version

```
$ dot -V
dot - graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)
$ dotty -V
dotty version 96c (09-24-96)
lefty version 10 Mar 2005
graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)
```

summary: "splines = true" merging multiedges together when using the neato engine
description:
## Steps to reproduce

[URL to example of graph with splines = false](http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20G%20%7B%0D%0A%20%20%20%20bgcolor%20%3D%20grey%0D%0A%20%20%20%20layout%20%3D%20neato%0D%0A%20%20%20%20outputorder%20%3D%20edgesfirst%0D%0A%20%20%20%20splines%20%3D%20false%0D%0A%20%20%20%20%0D%0A%20%20%20%20%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20b%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20b%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20c%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20d%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20e%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20f%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20g%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20h%20%5Bcolor%20%3D%20white%2C%20style%20%3D%20filled%2C%20shape%20%3D%20circle%20%5D%3B%0D%0A%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--b%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--b%20%5Bcolor%3Dblue%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--g%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--f%20%5Bcolor%3Dblue%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--c%20%5Bcolor%3Dblack%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20a--d%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20b--h%20%5Bcolor%3Dblack%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20e--h%20%5Bcolor%3Dblue%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20e--d%20%5Bcolor%3Dblack%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20e--g%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20c--f%20%5Bcolor%3Dblack%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20c--f%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20b--d%20%5Bcolor%3Dblue%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20g--b%20%5Bcolor%3Dblack%5D%0D%0A%20%20%20%20h--a%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%0D%0A%7D)

Then swap splines = false to splines = true to see the difference

Or render using graphviz #graphviz.render('neato', 'png', 'filename').replace('\\', '/')

## Expected Behaviour

When using splines = true I would expect the edges to go around the nodes but without merging the multi-edges between some of the nodes

## Actual Behaviour

When using splines = true, parallel edges (multi-edges) get merged and I loose some of my edges.

![test_graph_example_2](/uploads/9829434f4414871c43af15d5732b4275/test_graph_example_2.png)

![test_graph_example](/uploads/c04b6e39f8da4728ede0ac425bb32674/test_graph_example.png)

## OS Version

Windows - 21H1

## Graphviz Version

neato - graphviz version 2.50.0

## Additional info

As seen in this stackoverflow post parallel edges used to be rendered differently:
[The stackoverflow link in question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16173764/what-is-the-best-way-to-draw-large-graph-using-graphvis?rq=1)
Testing the code in that link the edges dont render like they do now, so this is probably a bug introduced in later updates.
Rendered using http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/, http://viz-js.com/ and python graphviz.render give the same results.

summary: dot generates random layouts every time
description:
## Steps to reproduce

[_demo_3x.gv](/uploads/aae698f48936c337c964838c1a989b60/_demo_3x.gv)

I use `dot -Tpng ` to generate png the .gv file. Also tried as .pdf and .svg. No luck.
I've been searching and trying to figure out the logic behind the output but it seems it's just random. 

![image](/uploads/af06c67b132bb383b9dd7c7a567c49f2/image.png)

I want to order the subgraphs in the order of the labels 1 2 3 4 5 6, top to bottom and aligned. 
Also, tried to add invis edge between consecutive subgraphs like 1 -> 2, 2 -> 3 but again the result wasn't deterministic.

## Expected Behaviour

I'm expecting to get the same output everytime I render the same .gv file.

## Actual Behaviour

I get different layout everytime I generate the graph.

## OS Version

Windows

## Graphviz Version

3.0

## Additional info

This seems relevant: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1644

summary: Man sectioning of dot
description:
## Steps to reproduce

For example, `man ./cmd/dot/dot.1`.

## Expected Behaviour

The file-related information is described in the section 5 of `man`, e.g. `dot(5)`, but not in `dot(1)`.
See [the description of the man sections](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/man.1.html#DESCRIPTION), and e.g. [`crontab(1)`](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/crontab.1.html) and [`crontab(5)`](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/crontab.5.html).

## Actual Behaviour

At the moment, [dot.1](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/bf7ea5dd6209d80cefec04cecc188d63c9fc5712/cmd/dot/dot.1) has the following parts:
- [GRAPH FILE LANGUAGE](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/bf7ea5dd6209d80cefec04cecc188d63c9fc5712/cmd/dot/dot.1#L153-199)
- [GRAPH, NODE AND EDGE ATTRIBUTES](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/bf7ea5dd6209d80cefec04cecc188d63c9fc5712/cmd/dot/dot.1#L200-583)
- [EXAMPLES](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/bf7ea5dd6209d80cefec04cecc188d63c9fc5712/cmd/dot/dot.1#L658-681)

## OS Version

Irrelevant.

## Graphviz Version

HEAD (bf7ea5dd6209d80cefec04cecc188d63c9fc5712).

## Additional info

None.

summary: "Orientation" doesn't work when shape type is cylinder
description:
## Steps to reproduce

The following input.dot file:

```
digraph {
  node [shape=cylinder] # Make all nodes have 'cylinder' shape

    0 [orientation=0]
   45 [orientation=45]
   90 [orientation=90]
  135 [orientation=135]
  180 [orientation=180]
  225 [orientation=225]
  270 [orientation=270]
  315 [orientation=315]
  0 -> 45 -> 90 -> 135 -> 180 -> 225 -> 270 -> 315 -> 0
}
```

And then run `dot -Tpng input.dot -o output.png`

## Expected Behaviour

I expect to see an image such as in the documentation for orientation (https://graphviz.org/docs/attrs/orientation/), but with rotated cylinders instead of houses.

## Actual Behaviour

Instead, the cylinders aren't rotated and the image looks like ![this](/uploads/747ca99ce5d03a41c0b97ceecd34e10e/output.png), with none of the cylinders rotated.

## OS Version

Mac OSX 10.15.7

## Graphviz Version

`dot - graphviz version 3.0.0 (20220226.1711)`

summary: pdf driver: Support splitting big graphs on multiple pages for printing
description:
We use the Gramps Genealogy Software in order to manage family histories. One of the features of that program is to let graphviz render a big family tree.
I have received a couple of requests from people I introduced to the software to be actually able to print out the graphs they generated. Since the graphs are too big most of the time to be readable when printed on a single page, it would be desirable to let the graph spawn multiple A3 / A4 pages as those are the formats they are able to print with their home printers.

According to https://graphviz.org/faq/#FaqMultiPage such a feature exists in graphviz with the postscript driver and in terms of splitting the graph it actually works, however it is not really useful for us, since we are based in Europe where ancestors spawn multiple countries and we can't really get around utf8 encoding.

## Steps to reproduce

First graph was produced via

```
dot -Gpage="8,11" -Gsize="160,10" -Tps2 test.gv > test.ps
```

and second graph via

```
dot -Gpage="8,11" -Gsize="160,10" -Tpdf test.gv > test.pdf
```

## Expected Behaviour

The "page" setting should be honored by the pdf drivers, similarly to postscript. 

## Actual Behaviour

The graph produced with the postscript driver is split accross multiple pages, while the graph produced with the pdf driver is not.
Furthermore the font rendering of the post script graph looks bad compared to the pdf one and utf8 does not work.

To give a brief impression, we have graphviz files containing labels like

```
label="Fornadi, Anna Balmt\n(1736 – 1791-01-05)\n( – Ötteveny, Sterbe.b.Bild 49)\n(third great grandmother)"
```

which is rendered in the following way in case of postscript:

![image](/uploads/cd74ecca34f55ea71a8d3b407635f214/image.png)

while in the pdf output it looks like

![image](/uploads/7e1e73f21fc9ec3ca9e1d031b9be5b14/image.png)

## OS Version

Windows 10 / Ubuntu 21.10

## Graphviz Version

graphviz version 2.43.0 (0)

## Additional notes

It would additionally be great if borders of pages could be honored by the page setting, as some printers can't print border-less and when scaling down the page, scaling might be inconsistent such that the multiple pages do not perfectly fit together in the end.

**Ideally additional constraints could be introduced at the graph building stage, such that no nodes are split between multiple pages, but only the connection lines.**

summary: graphviz-4.0.0: build error: cmd/tools/gvcolor.c:159: undefined reference to `fmax'
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Build graphviz on Fedora Rawhide (37)

## Expected Behaviour

It builds.

## Actual Behaviour

```
/usr/bin/ld: /tmp/ccVTEJPH.ltrans0.ltrans.o: in function `main':
/builddir/build/BUILD/graphviz-4.0.0/cmd/tools/gvcolor.c:159: undefined reference to `fmax'
```

## OS Version

Fedora Rawhide (37)

## Graphviz Version

graphviz-4.0.0

## Additional info

It seems it's missing the explicit link to -lm. We used the following workaround in Fedora:
```
--- a/cmd/tools/Makefile.am
+++ b/cmd/tools/Makefile.am
@@ -122,7 +122,8 @@ gvcolor_SOURCES = gvcolor.c colxlate.c colortbl.h
 
 gvcolor_LDADD = \
 	$(top_builddir)/lib/ingraphs/libingraphs_C.la \
-	$(top_builddir)/lib/cgraph/libcgraph.la
+	$(top_builddir)/lib/cgraph/libcgraph.la \
+	-lm
 
 
 bcomps_SOURCES = bcomps.c
```

summary: Sudden failure "flat edge between adjacent nodes one of which has a record shape "
description:
## Steps to reproduce:

Define graph with two record shaped nodes of the same rank.

### Expected Behaviour

Renders properly. 

[As shown here with `box` shape instead of `rect`](http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20%20%7B%0A%20%20node%20%5Bshape%3Dbox%5D%3B%0A%20%20%7B%20rank%3Dsame%20C%20--%20B%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%20%7D%0A%7D)

![Screenshot_from_2022-06-11_08-18-51](/uploads/91ce0abdd628318b64bee0801944f4db/Screenshot_from_2022-06-11_08-18-51.png)

### Actual Behaviour

[Actual result with missing red link](http://magjac.com/graphviz-visual-editor/?dot=graph%20%20%7B%0A%20%20node%20%5Bshape%3Drecord%5D%3B%0A%20%20%7B%20rank%3Dsame%20C%20--%20B%20%5Bcolor%3Dred%5D%20%7D%0A%7D)

## OS Version

Many OSs. I've  tested on Ubuntu. 

## Graphviz Version

summary: `dot -c` (post-install) can silently fail due to strcpy() misuse
Missing layout functions via libgvc in external package
description:
In the `pygraphviz` project we are working on packaging up binary wheels to make installing much easier for Python users - see https://github.com/pygraphviz/pygraphviz/pull/421.

We have had good success so far getting the appropriate graphviz libraries, namely `libgvc`, `libcgraph`, and `libcdt`, incorporated into the wheel (at least for Linux) and I am fairly confident that all of the linking and runtime library loading is being handled correctly. However, when it comes to actually *using* the layout functions via `libgvc`, I am noticing that the list of available layouts for the platform is empty. Here is a quick example:

```python
>>> import pygraphviz as pgv
>>> A = pgv.AGraph()
>>> A.add_path([1, 2, 3, 4])
>>> A.layout(prog="neato")
Error: Layout type: "neato" not recognized. Use one of:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/root/pgv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1494, in layout
    raise ValueError(f"Program {prog} is not a valid layout program.")
ValueError: Program b'neato' is not a valid layout program.
```

Note that the Traceback originates from `pygraphviz`, but the `Error:` statement prior originates from graphviz itself, specifically here:

https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/lib/gvc/gvc.c#L51-61

From the `agerr` message, it is clear that the `gvplugin_list(gvc, API_layout, engine)` is empty, i.e. there are no recognized layout plugins installed. I was initially very confused by this because from the graphviz configuration, it seems that at least some of the layout functions should always be available. Here is the output from `./configure` for the build that gave the above results:

```
plugin libraries:
  dot_layout:    Yes (always enabled)
  neato_layout:  Yes (always enabled)
  core:          Yes (always enabled)
  devil:         No (missing library)
  gd:            No (gd headers not found)
  gdiplus:       No (disabled by default - Windows only)
  gdk:           
  gdk_pixbuf:    No (gdk_pixbuf library not available)
  ghostscript:   No (missing headers)
  glitz:         No (disabled by default - incomplete)
  gtk:           No (gtk library not available)
  lasi:          No (missing pangocairo support)
  pangocairo:    No (pangocairo library not available)
  poppler:       No (poppler library not available)
  quartz:        No (disabled by default - Mac only)
  rsvg:          No (rsvg library not available)
  visio:         Yes
  webp:          No (webp library not available)
  xlib:          Yes
```

So it doesn't seem to be a graphviz build problem. My next thought was that the plugin libraries (e.g. `gvplugin_neato_layout`) were not being packaged/discovered correctly in the wheel, but fixing that problem (see https://github.com/pygraphviz/pygraphviz/pull/421/commits/a9277e99bb0d94d24de351d07bdab379cf19d60e) yielded the same results - an empty layout list.

After reading through the graphviz source code and [related issues](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1642) more closely, I now suspect that the problem is related to a missing configuration/layout registration step. For example, [the addingLayouts.txt](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/doc/addingLayout.txt) doc references running `dot -c` to generate a `config6` file, which presumably is used for layout discovery. I have spent some time in the code trying to tease out specifically how/where this config is loaded/used, but haven't quite grokked it yet. Given the current state of my investigations, I figured it might be worthwhile ping you all to see if I'm on the right track. So, to any `libgvc` experts:
 - Does my assumption that the missing link here is the layout configuration seem likely? And if so:
 - Is there a recommended best-practice for generating/loading the configuration programatically? For our purposes it would be best if we could generate a `config6` file during the build, distribute it with the package, and modify/configure `libgvc` to know where to look for the configuration within the package.

summary: remove GV_FILE_PATH?
description:
Graphviz contains a mechanism for restricting what files can be read via the environment variable `$GV_FILE_PATH`. This is used when running in a CGI-based webserver environment when the variable `$SERVER_NAME` is set.

While this was probably quite useful previously, the web has moved on considerably since the days when CGI was in vogue. To sandbox web-reachable tools these days, I think the usual practice is to use the file system restriction mechanisms built into your webserver itself (Nginx, Apache, etc.). These are both more well tested and more reliable than asking a tool to sandbox itself.

I suggest we deprecate and remove these mechanisms within Graphviz and point users elsewhere.

If we were to retain a Graphviz-specific sandbox, I would recommend it be a standalone tool using operating system recommended sandboxing mechanisms (e.g. Seccomp). It's much easier to audit the code of a small sandboxer utility than to audit the entirety of Graphviz for security bypasses (many of which we know exist). Though my first preference is to provide no sandboxing at all, as even desktop operating systems are finally beginning to gain their own native sandboxes for running truly untrusted binaries (Bubblewrap, App Sandbox, Firejail, ...).

summary: Mechanism for using a specific TTF font file
description:
In integrating support for graphviz into a documentation theme, I have run into great difficulty in getting graphviz to compute the label sizes using a specified TTF font file in a platform-independent manner:

https://github.com/jbms/sphinx-immaterial/pull/144

Essentially the LibGD plugin provides exactly the behavior I want, where the font can be specified by an actual path to a TTF file.  On Linux and macOS builds of graphviz, the libgd plugin is normally included and with a hack can override the default graphviz config file to ensure LibGD used for textlayout.  (More difficult because graphviz doesn't allow spaces in plugin paths.)  Unfortunately, the default Windows builds of graphviz exclude libgd so that isn't an option.

If the published Windows builds included LibGD, then the same hack could be used to ensure it is used for textlayout.

It would be even better if there were command-line options to modify the plugin configuration, though.
