summary: order of operations problems in 'MAX' calls
description:
If you survey the calls to `MAX` in the code base, you will find quite a few fitting a pattern like:

```c
foo = MAX((int) 0.2 * bar, baz);
```

You can see what this code is trying to do: take the maximum of ⅕ of `bar` and `baz`. But casts have a higher precedence than multiplication. So this code ends up casting the `0.2` to an `int`, resulting in `0`, then performing the multiplication, also yielding `0`. As a result, the entire expression is equivalent to:

```c
foo = baz;
```

In many instances this looks like it could lead to out-of-bounds writes (e.g. in lib/sfdpgen/spring_electrical.c). No one has specifically reported problems that have been root caused to this, so I'm guessing the arrays in question end up never exceeding `baz` (`10` in most of these instances).

summary: regression: assert fail in aaglex for multiple calls to agmemread
description:
I've added some comments to: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/2d7852a049b729fb0db71c5a8ef2366215ae2035

Basically with this change, SBuf isn't properly reset between calls to aaglex (such as through using agmemread) if a graph contains unterminated quoted strings or html. Subsequent calls will then abort.

The obvious fix is to call `agxbuse(&Sbuf)` in `aagerror`.

summary: improvements to CMake design
description:
Spawning this from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2808#note_1086712985 ...

----

While we're on this topic, the way the headers are setup is going to require workarounds and hacks forever. None of this is related to the C++ libs, and obviously hindsight is 20/20, and perhaps the “sane” way of managing headers only emerged after Graphviz’ birth. But let me outline my template for a CMake project that avoids all of this:

```
├ CMakeLists.txt
├ mybin/
│  ├ CMakeLists.txt
│  └ src/
│     └ main.c
└ libfoo/
   ├ CMakeLists.txt
   ├ include/
   │  └ foo/
   |     ├ foo.h
   │     ├ other_header_a.h
   │     └ other_header_b.h
   └ src/
      └ some_source.c
```

The top-level CMakeLists.txt does no include path fiddling. It simply does:

```cmake
add_subdirectory(mybin)
add_subdirectory(libfoo)
```

mybin/CMakeLists.txt also does no include path fiddling. It simply does:

```cmake
add_executable(mybin src/main.c)
target_link_libraries(mybin PRIVATE libfoo) # ← all include stuff dealt with by this line
```

libfoo/CMakeLists.txt is where include paths are set:

```cmake
add_library(libfoo src/some_source.c)
target_include_directories(libfoo
  PUBLIC
    $<BUILD_INTERFACE:${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/include>
    $<INSTALL_INTERFACE:include>
)

# make sure library output is called “libfoo” and not “liblibfoo”
set_target_properties(libfoo PROPERTIES PREFIX "")
```

Now you write code inside libfoo that uses `<>` paths:

```c
// libfoo/src/some_source.c

#include <foo/other_header_a.h>
```

Code in mybin is written as if it were a third-party external consumer, just like anyone else. But the only thing it should include is the all-encompassing API header:

```c
// mybin/src/main.c

#include <foo/foo.h>
```

This work because foo.h’s entire contents are:

```c
#pragma once

#include <foo/other_header_a.h>
#include <foo/other_header_b.h>
```

Note how (1) all C code accesses libfoo’s headers uniformly, regardless of where it lives (within libfoo, in mybin, or out-of-tree) and (2) libfoo is an actual non-porous abstraction in CMake (mybin knows nothing of libfoo’s internal structure and this structure can be rearranged at will without needing to update mybin). I omitted some details, but you can see a full real world embodiment of this in https://github.com/Smattr/vimcat.

I don't have any answers to how we get to the above, or if this is even desirable given other trade offs. But I just wanted to spell this out in case it gave anyone else ideas.

summary: Neato initial layout
description:
I am not sure if this is the right place to ask this. But I was wondering if it is possible to provide an initial layout for neato
s algorithm to find the location of the nodes. Based on what I have understood (from [here](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/lib/neatogen/neatoinit.c#L953))and you can only provide seed that is used to generate the initial layout that then the algo uses. 

networkx for instance allows in their both Fruchterman-Reingold and Kamada-Kawai algorithms to input a dictionary of positions that one can define seperately. This has a usecase in a problem I am exploring as well as multilayered algorithms that many researchers define.

I looked for closed and open issues here as well as stack overflow before opening an issue here. Hope someone can answer what I am looking for. 
Cheers!

summary: Rankdir.LR|RL layout produces wrong margin
Rebuild of graphviz is failing with prepared SWIG 4.1.0
description:
SWIG 4.1.0 is closed to final release and I trying to rebuild all its dependencies in Fedora.

I tried to rebuild graphviz with prepared SWIG 4.1.0 and I found that the build is failing with following error:
```
 /usr/bin/mkdir -p '/builddir/build/BUILDROOT/graphviz-5.0.1-2.fc38.x86_64/usr/lib64/graphviz/php'
 /usr/bin/install -p -m 644 ./gv.php '/builddir/build/BUILDROOT/graphviz-5.0.1-2.fc38.x86_64/usr/lib64/graphviz/php'
/usr/bin/install: cannot stat './gv.php': No such file or directory
make[5]: *** [Makefile:2713: install-pkgphpDATA] Error 1
```
The complete build log is [here](https://download.copr.fedorainfracloud.org/results/jplesnik/swig-rebuild/fedora-rawhide-x86_64/04830383-graphviz/builder-live.log.gz).

The SWIG upstream look on it and they found that it is due to:
```
2021-05-04: olly
   [PHP] #1982 #1457 https://sourceforge.net/p/swig/bugs/1339/
   SWIG now only use PHP's C API to implement its wrappers, and no
   longer generates PHP code to define classes.  The wrappers should
   be almost entirely compatible with those generated before, but
   faster and without some previously hard-to-fix bugs.

   The main notable difference is SWIG no longer generates a .php
   wrapper at all by default (only if %pragma(php) code=... or
   %pragma(php) include=... are specified in the interface file).
   This also means you need to load the module via extension=...
   in php.ini, rather than letting the dl() in the generated
   .php wrapper load it (but dl() has only worked for command-line
   PHP for some years now).

   *** POTENTIAL INCOMPATIBILITY ***
```
So this file no longer exists and can't be deployed.

summary: Allow configuring default font for all graph elements
description:
Current default font is Times-Roman. It is old fashioned and designed for printing like all serif fonts.
A sans-serif, for example Arial could be more appropriate for displays.
The main challenge is portability and different width of fonts.

Additionally default font can be configured in [environment](https://graphviz.org/doc/info/command.html#environment-variables).

summary: regression in smyrna between GraphViz 2.50 and 5.0.1/6.0.1 (also noticed a warning about signal handlers)
description:
## Steps to reproduce

to reproduce, someone needs to use graphviz 2.50 and compare it to the output of graphviz 6.0.1.

simply execute smyrna and load the attached file: [k124_neighbours.dot](/uploads/8dd4ab410465a38e4e1b0f275e5f6fad/k124_neighbours.dot).

## Expected Behaviour

the expected behaviour is shown in graphviz 2.50, whereas the unexpected regression is shown in 6.0.1.

in other words, you should see a three-dimensional coordinate system with a point at its origin like this:
![Screenshot_2022-09-21_at_4.12.37_PM](/uploads/c00b194fd30d8434286f6f1df4d77bf5/Screenshot_2022-09-21_at_4.12.37_PM.png)

but in 6.0.1 fails to produce anything close:
![Screenshot_2022-09-21_at_4.17.30_PM](/uploads/727abe2411cc92812f5bb6b9a67f27d6/Screenshot_2022-09-21_at_4.17.30_PM.png)

it looks out of focus and the bounding box extends seemingly-infinitely in one direction.

## Actual Behaviour

there is no output per-se, but rather pictures. i've included the dot file so that someone on OSX can verify the problem on the latest graphviz.

## OS Version

OSX 10.14.6

## Graphviz Version

working version is
```
dot - graphviz version 2.50.0 (20211204.2007)
```

non-working 6.0.1 is
```
dot - graphviz version 6.0.1 (20220911.1526)
```

## Additional info

i've noticed that some new text appears on the commandline (at startup only) when running smyrna in either 2.50 or 6.0.1:

in 2.5.0:
```
GagansMacPro:router Gagan$ smyrna

(smyrna:59043): libglade-WARNING **: 15:50:22.586: could not find signal handler 'mAttributesSlot'.

(smyrna:59043): libglade-WARNING **: 15:50:22.586: could not find signal handler 'on_attrSearchBtn_clicked'.

(smyrna:59043): libglade-WARNING **: 15:50:22.586: could not find signal handler 'on_attrRB0_clicked'.
```

in 6.0.1:
```
GagansMacPro:router Gagan$ smyrna

(smyrna:6403): libglade-WARNING **: 16:16:32.131: could not find signal handler 'mAttributesSlot'.

(smyrna:6403): libglade-WARNING **: 16:16:32.131: could not find signal handler 'on_attrSearchBtn_clicked'.

(smyrna:6403): libglade-WARNING **: 16:16:32.131: could not find signal handler 'on_attrRB0_clicked'.

```
graphviz is, and will, be a central and vital tool for mathematicians studying properties of an adjacency matrix whose edges are being depicted using graphviz. i am hopeful this issue can be fixed. if these warnings can be fixed (first time i've seen them) that would be a plus.

summary: Feature request: Minimize edge crossing for neato
description:
This:
~~~
graph test123 {
        graph [splines=true; overlap=false;];
        labelloc="t";
        "A" -- "B"
        "C" -- "B"
        "C" -- "A"
        "G" -- "C"
        "G" -- "B"
        "G" -- "A"
        "G" -- "D"
        "G" -- "E"
        "G" -- "F"
        "D" -- "B"
        "E" -- "B"
        "F" -- "B"
}
neato -Tpdf
~~~
generates:

![image](/uploads/96dcb2ca743ff99ca64adc63253220f5/image.png)

I would like to generate:

![image](/uploads/f8914eb7bf5088e3fc3fe39d9fb4bfc7/image.png)

So the same graph but with fewer crossing edges. Ideally I want the edges to be splines and be more balanced.

As far as I can tell this is not currently possible.

I understand you can easily make graphs where you cannot avoid crossings, but in this case it seems pretty easy:

~~~
for each intersection:
  for each of the 4 nodes connected to the intersection:
    try moving the node to the other side of the intersection.
    if this decreased the number of intersections:
      keep this
      recompute intersections
until no more decreases
~~~

There are probably more advanced algorithms, but this one seems simple.

summary: trailing commas issue with fdp layout
sfdp: beautify=true tries to evenly space leaf nodes around a circle, but overlaps first+last element
description:
Background: I came across this bug while documenting the attribute. I think this is a low-priority bug, given the attribute has been undocumented since it was introduced 10 years ago. Filing for completeness.

`beautify` was introduced in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/ba776ee9271f6af1efec836d4193a621b65b9852

saying:

> Enable beautify feature in sfdp. This tries to draw leaf nodes uniformly on a circle
> around root node.

Here's an example graph:

```
digraph G {
    layout="sfdp"
    beautify=true

    N0 -> {N1; N2; N3; N4; N5; N6}
}
```

I would expect this to show the 6 leaf nodes 60 degrees apart (hexagon).

But instead they are rendered 72 degrees apart (pentagon), and the first and last nodes overlap: see the right-hand node is N1 and N6.

![image](/uploads/3857630882bd4949906f3216e3f2d151/image.png)

The problem will be in the `beautify_leaves` function, or possibly `get_angle`: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/lib/sfdpgen/spring_electrical.c#L365

summary: CMake Warning: gdlib-config not found; skipping feature checks
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Build using CMake on Ubuntu >= 18.04 or Fedora >= 35

## Expected Behaviour

No CMake warning about missing gdlib-config

## Actual Behaviour

```
-- Found GD: /usr/lib64/libgd.so  
CMake Warning at cmake/FindGD.cmake:63 (message):
  gdlib-config not found; skipping feature checks
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  CMakeLists.txt:114 (find_package)
```

## OS Version

Ubuntu >= 18.04 or Fedora >= 35

## Graphviz Version

`dot - graphviz version 6.0.2~dev.20220928.0842 (20220928.0842)`

Commit 682189a69628b03628ced747300a6bfa472aeae5

## Additional info

### Consequences

This causes all the `HAVE_GD_*` pre-processor macros to be undefined. These are used as guards in many places:

```
$ git grep -l HAVE_GD
cmake/FindGD.cmake
config-cmake.h.in
configure.ac
contrib/diffimg/diffimg.c
plugin/gd/gvdevice_gd.c
plugin/gd/gvloadimage_gd.c
plugin/gd/gvrender_gd.c
plugin/gd/gvrender_gd_vrml.c
plugin/gd/gvtextlayout_gd.c
tclpkg/gdtclft/gdtclft.c
windows/include/config.h
```

I discovered the problem when running:

`python3 -m pytest -s -k test_regression_failure tests/test_regression.py`

which (among other things) complains about:

`PNG support is not available`

This message comes from the [`diffimg`](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/contrib/diffimg/diffimg.c#L100) utility.

### `gdlib-config` was deprecated a long time ago

I don't know when it was actually removed, but complaints have been seen since 2016 at least: https://github.com/libgd/libgd/issues/345

### Centos7 still has `gdlib-config`

CMake says:
```
-- Found GD: /usr/lib64/libgd.so  
-- Found gdlib-config: /usr/bin/gdlib-config
-- Detected GD features: GD_XPM GD_JPEG GD_FONTCONFIG GD_FREETYPE GD_PNG GD_GIF GD_GIFANIM GD_OPENPOLYGON
```

### Autotools

The autotools builds seems to [hard code the features since gdlib 2.0.33](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/configure.ac#L2186-2190). Perhaps we can di the same for CMake?

summary: Add SVG output suitable for inlining in HTML
description: Offer a new output format `svg:tag` or `inline_svg` or `svg_inline` or `svg_html`, or maybe even `xhtml`. Naming bikeshed comments welcome, I think it's important that this has a good name. This should output a `` tree suitable for inline inclusion in an HTML5 document, i.e.: ``` $ echo 'digraph {}' | dot -Tinline_svg ``` Extra points if it's suitable for inclusion in an XHTML document too, though I don't think XHTML is very popular these days. I'm not sure if the `xmlns` attributes are required for inclusion in XHTML? If so, this should be a separate output format. This would particularly be helpful for the Graphviz docs, and in other technical docs. I'd love to 'scratch my own itch' here. ## Background Sometimes, I like to embed Graphviz generations into websites. There aren't many great options for this. - `` tags don't let you click on HREFs, can't select text - `

summary: Can't build with autotools on macOS: "No rule to make target `dot_builtins.c', needed by `dot_builtins-dot_builtins.o'"
description:
After working around #2227 by removing `cairo/` from the include header, I thought I could build, but ran into another error:

```
# remove untracked files
$ git clean -Xf

$ ./autogen.sh

$ ./configure

$ make
...
Making all in cmd
Making all in dot
  CC       dot-dot.o
  CC       dot-no_builtins.o
  CCLD     dot
  CC       dot_builtins-dot.o
make[3]: *** No rule to make target `dot_builtins.c', needed by `dot_builtins-dot_builtins.o'.  Stop.
make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

I suspect this is related to the recent move from `dot_builtins.c` to `dot_builtins.cpp`. But I'm not sure how.

`grep` points at the proximate cause in a `.deps` folder (what is that? I'm not familiar with this build system):

```
$ grep "\\bdot_builtins.c\\b" -r .
./cmd/dot/.deps/dot_builtins-dot_builtins.Po:dot_builtins-dot_builtins.o: dot_builtins.c ../../config.h \
```

If I was to guess, I'd say there's some smarts in the build system that looks at a dep for a `.o` file and says "oh, there must be a `.c` file that makes that?"

summary: CMake building with DevIL: I think it's using the wrong variables
description:
https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/module/FindDevIL.html#result-variables mentions that `FindDevIL` CMake module sets the following, frustratingly inconsistent variables:

- `IL_LIBRARIES`
- `IL_INCLUDE_DIR`
- `DevIL_FOUND`

Our code https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/plugin/devil/CMakeLists.txt#L22 uses:

- `DevIL_INCLUDE_DIRS` (wrong?)
- `DevIL_LIBRARIES` (wrong?)
- `DevIL_FOUND` (correct)

I suspect the first two are empty-strings.

I came across this trying to figure out if I could get the macOS build working with more plugins. I don't actually need the DevIL library. It looks a little unmaintained: https://openil.sourceforge.net/, no release since 2017, last merge a year ago. Perhaps we should consider removing the plugin, rather than maintaining it.

I got this error when trying to build:

```
[ 67%] Building C object plugin/devil/CMakeFiles/gvplugin_devil.dir/gvdevice_devil.c.o
/Users/mark/projects/graphviz/plugin/devil/gvdevice_devil.c:14:10: fatal error: 'IL/il.h' file not found
#include <IL/il.h>
         ^~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
```

summary: Parallel edges are merged into one edge when using `splines` attribute set to `polyline` or to `true` values in twopi layout, `overlap=false` doesn't work.
use bit fields for arrowdir_t flags
Tooltips don't pop up in HTML, but link href does
description:
## Steps to reproduce Render the following document to PDF: ``` digraph { my_node [label= <
hover over this area
> shape=plain ]; } ``` View it in a PDF viewer like Preview.app. ## Expected Behaviour I expected to see the text `hi mom` when hovering over the node. ## Actual Behaviour I see `https://example.com` when hovering over the node. ## OS Version ``` ProductName: macOS ProductVersion: 12.6 BuildVersion: 21G115 ``` ## Graphviz Version ``` dot - graphviz version 5.0.1 (20220820.1526) ``` ## Additional info I don't actually need an `HREF` on this node, but according to https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/1425 (and what I observe), no tooltip is displayed at all unless there's an `HREF`. So the primary bug here is that tooltips don't display unless there's a link, and the secondary bug is that even when there's a link, they still don't display as intended. There's a possibility that this depends on the particular PDF viewer, I haven't tried multiple viewers.

summary: Problem building Graphviz-5.0.1: undefined symbols __*_finite
description:
When attempting to wrap `libgvc` after building graphviz-5.0.1 from source, I experienced the following at runtime:

```
... pygraphviz.libs/libgvplugin_core-3e57ffe9.so.6.0.0: undefined symbol: __exp_finite
```

Note that this behavior is observed when building in an environment with glibc-2.17, but installing/running on a system with a newer glibc (2.36).
A quick search turned up others experiencing potential issues with `__*_finite` functions as of glibc-2.31, cf. [here](https://github.com/pure-data/pure-data/issues/975) and [here](https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/info-gnu/2020-02/msg00001.html).

As noted in the above linked sources, we were able to work around this issue by disabling `fast-math`, i.e. removing `-ffast-math` from `configure`:

https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/configure.ac#L404

One potential solution for our use-case would be to add a flag to the `configure` script (e.g. `--disable-fast-math`); at least then we wouldn't need to modify the script itself prior to building. From the surrounding lines above it looks like fast-math is already disabled for e.g. icc.

## OS Version

Build OS: CentOS Linux release 7.9.2009 (Core), glibc-2.17
Run OS: 5.19.12-arch1-1, glibc-2.36

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 5.0.1 (20220820.1526)

summary: Second periphery of a cylinder shaped node is not correct
description:
## Steps to reproduce

echo "digraph {a [shape=cylinder peripheries=2]}" | dot -Tsvg

## Expected Behaviour

Both peripheries should be cylinder shaped.

## Actual Behaviour

The second periphery is not connected correctly:

![two-periphery-cylinder.svg](/uploads/9e4628ff459fb0dd5e25f8ab5bba11bf/two-periphery-cylinder.svg)

Note that the right side of the second periphery is not connected to the second top ellipse.

## OS Version

Ubuntu 22.04.

## Graphviz Version

dot - graphviz version 7.0.0~dev.20221013.0516 (20221013.0516)

Commit: c50674b82582171aae78ea629f2d7c1891010101

## Additional info

This was discovered while trying to fix #372 for the cylinder node shape. The fix uses an invisible extra periphery which got distorted the same way and caused the "inside" function to fail.

The reason for the bug is that the cylinder shape is represented by a polygon during layout and this polygon has several consecutive vertices which are the same point which the periphery creation functionality currently cannot handle (This polygon is replaced with cubic Bezier curves during rendering and the "same"-points are needed as control points to create the straight lines in the cylinder shape).

summary: consider dropping ICC support
description:
Something that caught my eye is that Linux 6.1 will be dropping support for compiling the kernel with the Intel C Compiler (ICC), https://lore.kernel.org/linux-acpi/20221011031843.960217-1-masahiroy@kernel.org/. It seems this was silently broken for a long time. It made me wonder if we could drop the ICC workarounds in Graphviz. I suspect our ICC support is silently broken too, as we don't test it.

I knew ICC had migrated to being LLVM-based in recent times. But I had thought this meant using an LLVM middle end and back end, while still maintaining a custom Intel front end.¹ Contrary to this, https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/developer/articles/technical/adoption-of-llvm-complete-icx.html implies to me their front end is now Clang. If this is the case, then all our ICC workarounds can be dropped, as we already support (and test on several platforms) Clang.

¹ In C/C++ compiler terminology:
- “front end” – lexer, parser, semantic analysis
- “middle end” – optimization pipeline
- “back end” – target-specific code generation

These definitions are a bit hand wavy, and older compilers like GCC don’t have such a strong distinction between the parts. But in the platonic ideal of a compiler, all three could be independent replaceable programs.

summary: smyrna: memory leak in update_columns
agapply misuse
description:
The compiler has some opinions about calls to `agapply`: 

```
  CC       attr.lo
attr.c: In function ‘init_all_attrs’:
attr.c:534:37: warning: cast between incompatible function types from ‘void (*)(Agraph_t *)’ {aka ‘void (*)(struct Agraph_s *)’} to ‘void (*)(Agraph_t *, Agobj_t *, void *)’ {aka ‘void (*)(struct Agraph_s *, struct Agobj_s *, void *)’} [-Wcast-function-type]
  534 |     agapply(root, (Agobj_t *) root, (agobjfn_t) agraphattr_init,
      |                                     ^
...
  CC       node.lo                                                                                                             
node.c: In function ‘agrelabel_node’:                                                                                          
node.c:245:39: warning: cast between incompatible function types from ‘void (*)(Agnode_t *, void *)’ {aka ‘void (*)(struct Agnode_s *, void *)’} to ‘void (*)(Agraph_t *, Agobj_t *, void *)’ {aka ‘void (*)(struct Agraph_s *, struct Agobj_s *, void *)’} [-Wcast-function-type]                                                                                                         
  245 |             agapply(g, (Agobj_t *) n, (agobjfn_t) dict_relabel,                                                        
      |                                       ^                                                                                
```

Pulling the thread on this, neither of these are false positives. The problem is that `agobjfn_t` takes 3 parameters:

```c
typedef void (*agobjfn_t) (Agraph_t * g, Agobj_t * obj, void *arg);
```

In the `agraphattr_init` case, it only takes a single parameter:

```c
void agraphattr_init(Agraph_t * g)
```

So using it in combination with `agapply` is relying on the calling convention for a 1-parameter function and a 3-parameter function being compatible. While this is true on x86-64 and ARM, it is not true on all platforms.

The `dict_relabel` case is even more curious. `dict_relabel` takes 2 parameters, but where `agraphattr_init` is assuming it can elide the second and third parameter, `dict_relabel` is assuming it can elide the _first_:

```c
static void dict_relabel(Agnode_t * n, void *arg)
```

I do not understand how this would work on any of the major platforms we currently support (x86-64/ARM × BSD/Linux/macOS/Windows). It looks to me like it would only ever work with a purely stack-based calling convention that indexed and pushed/popped the arguments last-to-first. Maybe this was written/tested on 32-bit x86? There, I believe the calling convention would make things work. But in contrast, the `agraphattr_init` case would be busted on 32-bit x86.

Does anyone understand how/why any of this was intended to work? It is a bit mysterious to me.

summary: sfio constants conflict with Windows headers
description:
I was attempting to refactor some code that looks up the system page size in https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/commit/c5bec370a42a3280940ba46a63cb99708e859417. This fails numerous Windows CI jobs with rather confusing errors. For example:

```
  sfsetbuf.c
C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Include\10.0.18362.0\um\oaidl.h(322,9): error C2059: syntax error: 'constant' [C:\GitLab-Runner\builds\graphviz\graphviz\build\lib\sfio\sfio.vcxproj]
```

I don't have access to this oiadl.h header, but scouring the internet for a while turns up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13827599/oaidl-h319-error-c2057-expected-constant-expression. This suggests oiadl.h contains:

```c
typedef /* [v1_enum] */ 
enum tagSF_TYPE
    {
        SF_ERROR    = VT_ERROR,
        SF_I1   = VT_I1,
        SF_I2   = VT_I2,
        SF_I4   = VT_I4,
        SF_I8   = VT_I8,
        SF_BSTR = VT_BSTR,
        SF_UNKNOWN  = VT_UNKNOWN,
        SF_DISPATCH = VT_DISPATCH,
        SF_VARIANT  = VT_VARIANT,
        SF_RECORD   = VT_RECORD,
        SF_HAVEIID  = ( VT_UNKNOWN | VT_RESERVED ) 
    }   SF_TYPE; // Line 319
```

I guess `SF_ERROR` is the problem here. Both this header and sfio are trying to define it.

This is a latent problem right now, but it seems we can't use Windows' sysinfoapi.h without running into this.

summary: agxbuf structure packing
Heads up: Next swig release (4.1.0) doesn't generate .php code any more
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Graphviz's PHP bindings rely on SWIG producing a `gv.php` file.
However, the upcoming SWIG 4.1.0 release [only uses PHP's C API to implement its wrappers](https://github.com/swig/swig/blob/867e49d7c50aded9afdd36223f05b84645636f15/CHANGES.current#L1096).

## Expected Behaviour

Adapt [test.php](https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/blob/main/tclpkg/gv/test.php) (and other artifacts below `tclpkg/gv`)

## Actual Behaviour

gv.php does not exist

## OS Version

Any

## Graphviz Version

Any

## Additional info

Discussion at https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/1011258

summary: minimize test_2095
description:
The test case for #2095 is by far the most expensive thing in the test suite. When I wrote it I did not put much thought into it, I just dumped the reproducer the original reporter gave us into the test suite. There have been various attempts at reducing its runtime (e.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/2584), but we should probably attack this in a more principled way.

My current thinking is to rewind to the commit that introduced the test case and use a simple stupid minimizer I wrote (https://github.com/Smattr/mattutils/blob/master/shrink). Open to other suggestions if people have them.

Going in the opposite direction, the current version of this test case is actually a nice work load for profiling runtime. Maybe we can attempt this in parallel and see if we can find some Graphviz acceleration opportunities.

description:

description:
## Steps to reproduce

Problem occurs with all ways of displaying a graphviz image in Jupyter Notebooks.
This includes calling the renderer with just its name aswell as using the function display(dot)\
![should_be_1](/uploads/6797f2421dc4b1ccfb033b95a30777d7/should_be_1.PNG)
![should_be_2](/uploads/eae5a26453f592abc3fbc6abbae545f1/should_be_2.PNG)

## Expected Behaviour

![should_be_1](/uploads/16d92a1373ea0ad9ccd50fc706f0703e/should_be_1.PNG)
![should_be_3](/uploads/48e85f42f58cd035dac2475705ea5c18/should_be_3.PNG)

This is me running the code inside the JupyterLab IDE for Jupyter Notebooks

## Actual Behaviour

When viewed in GitHub with the same code, the image is not being displayed.\
![actually_is_1](/uploads/58b38555cc9106124245ac949d91daf1/actually_is_1.PNG)

Even the [examples](https://github.com/xflr6/graphviz/blob/master/examples/graphviz-notebook.ipynb) from the "Jupyter notebooks" section of the [graphviz user guide](https://graphviz.readthedocs.io/en/stable/manual.html) are affected by the same problem.

Problem occurs when viewed on GitHub in both Google Chrome and Firefox

To be fair, I do not know if this issue is caused by Graphviz or GitHub itself, I nevertheless decided to post it here as the user guide examples are affected aswell.

summary: Wrong linear gradient id used in polygon fill
description:
It looks like #2258 does not solve the id issue completely.

In 5.0.0 (without #2258 fix) the linear gradient id looks like this, id="l_2":

```
<linearGradient id="l_2" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse" x1="15.69" y1="-45.24" x2="67.31" y2="-7.76" >
...
<polygon fill="url(#l_2)" stroke="black" points="78,-53 5,-53 5,0 78,0 78,-53"/>
```

In 6.0.2 it looks like this, id = "G1_node2_l_2":
```
<linearGradient id="G1_node2_l_2" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse" x1="15.69" y1="-45.24" x2="67.31" y2="-7.76" >
...
<polygon fill="url(#l_2)" stroke="black" points="78,-53 5,-53 5,0 78,0 78,-53"/>
```
So the LinearGradient id has been fixed. But the polygon fill still refers to #l_2 (that does not exist)

summary: Margins in octagons often too large
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Compile the following:
```
digraph G {
  foo [shape=octagon, label="one\ntwo", margin="0.0,0.0"];
}
```

## Expected Behaviour

I should see text in an octagon with very little margin on any side, with the text almost touching the octagon itself.

## Actual Behaviour

I see a _whole_ lot of margin both vertical and horizontal:

![one-two](/uploads/1db4b3937987df0ce86477398608914d/xaPyB.png)

## OS Version

Devuan GNU/Linux Daedalus

## Graphviz Version

2.43.0

## Additional info

Let's see some more octagons with margin-zero:
```
graph Y {
  rankdir=LR
  node[margin="0.0,0.0"]
  foo1 [shape=octagon, label="ab\na"]
  foo3 [shape=octagon, label="abcd\nabc"]
  foo5 [shape=octagon, label="abcdef\nabcde"]
  foo7 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefgh\nabcdefg"]
  foo9 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghij\nabcdefghi"]
  foo11 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghijkl\nabcdefghijk"]
  foo13 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghijklmn\nabcdefghijklm"]
  foo15 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghijklmnop\nabcdefghijklmno"]
  foo17 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghijklmnopqr\nabcdefghijklmnopq"]
  foo19 [shape=octagon, label="abcdefghijklmnopqrst\nabcdefghijklmnopqrs"]
}
```
Many of these have passable vertical margins, but overly-wide horizontal ones:

![a](/uploads/414cf06a63c0c11c62c2c41d3709122e/a.png)



See also this StackOverflow question: [Reducing excessive Graphviz octagon margins](https://stackoverflow.com/q/74302541/1593077)

summary: SVG output should link edges to nodes
description:
## Summary

SVGs, regardless of layout, currently consist of node and edge elements that are placed independently on the canvas. That makes them extremely finicky to adjust with manual tweaking (such as in Inkscape) without edges becoming disconnected from their nodes.

It is possible to generate more tool-friendly SVGs in this respect. Namely, the behavior I would most like to see is an approach paraellel to what iGraph employs:
- Nodes and Edges are added as separate layers in the SVG.
- Edges are linked to Nodes via Inkscape's `diagram connector` mechanism

Those two features, together, give users the ability to edit the SVG output in Inkscape when necessary without garbling up its component elements, but also do so _without_ affecting the SVG's readability to read-only tools.

### Quick background

I'm a postgraduate research student currently caught right in between GraphViz and iGraph for a few key bits. GraphViz's output (unlike igraph) preserves `class` attributes, which is fantastic, but I also periodically need to manually make tweaks to graph layout (which puts me in the reverse bind: igraph supports it, but erases the attributes on the nodes and edges).

## Documentation of desired behavior

This is the issue in which the iGraph team implemented the SVG modifications mentioned above:
https://github.com/igraph/igraph/issues/246

This is some Inkscape documentation about the "diagram connector" type:
https://archive.flossmanuals.net/inkscape/toolbox/connector-tool.html
https://wiki.inkscape.org/wiki/Connector_tool_tutorial

I am, of course, aware that this element is not part of the original SVG spec (although that could change); however, it is an extension and the Inkscape-specific parts are ignored, in my tests, by other SVG renderers. And, I suppose, it's worth also noting that Inkscape is FOSS and thus is not locking-in the user or the document.

## OS Version

Personally I run Linux; mostly Ubuntu LTS, at the moment 22.04, but I think this is corss-platform.

## Graphviz Version

2.43.0 (0)

## Additional info

I know this is a feature request, and I know not everyone CARES about manually tweaking SVG output. But in some fields, it makes a huge difference when you're trying to communicate network concepts.

summary: Change vertical line spacing in multi-line label
description:
Hi, Apologies if this is the wrong place to ask questions. I would like to be able to fine-tune the spacing between lines in a multi-line label. My label mixes font weights and as a result, is specified with HTML tags. Each new line is obtained using a `
` tag. However a single `
` produces a space that is too small for the font I'm using (Futura Std) resulting in a bit of overlap between lines. Two `
` tags produce too big a space between lines. I haven't been able to find anything in the documentation that explains how to control the line vertical spacing or line height. Is it at all doable? If so, what would you recommend? -G

summary: CMake: if 'with_foo=ON' fail the build if Foo not found?
description:
I just noticed the CMake build system has an odd setup where, e.g., with `with_expat=ON` if Expat is not found the build silently continues, falling back to building without Expat. This is presumably intentional because this option defaults to `ON`. But it would seem a little surprising if the user explicitly supplied `-Dwith_expat=ON` on the command line.

Maybe we should switch some (all?) of these options to tristate variables auto/on/off, with auto being the default.

summary: radial gradients of angle 0 mis-rendered?
description:
While doing some warning squashing drudgery, the compiler pointed me at:

```
gvrender_core_svg.c: In function ‘svg_rgradstyle’:
gvrender_core_svg.c:590:15: warning: comparing floating-point with ‘==’ or ‘!=’ is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
  590 |     if (angle == 0.) { 
      |               ^~
```

Looking at the pointed-to code, we see:

```c
if (angle == 0.) {                                                                                                             
    ifx = ify = 50;                                                                                                            
} else {                                                                                                                       
    ifx = round(50 * (1 + cos(angle)));                                                                                        
    ify = round(50 * (1 - sin(angle)));                                                                                        
}                                                                                                                              
```

This looks like classic Graphviz micro-optimization code; branching for the case in which the (assumed expensive) calls to math functions will be redundant. I.e. the rounding and trigonometry calls are an expensive way just to compute `50`. Except this is not true. `cos(0.0)` is `1`. So it seems like `ifx` should really be `100` here.

Looking at 2f6d5b337fb2032e2dc2bfd64e33e87ce307c88c that introduced this code, it makes this assumption (that `cos(0.0) == 0`) in 3 separate places.

Is this a bug? I don't know much about radial gradients, so maybe an angle of 0° is somehow a degenerate case where the `x` value is irrelevant.

summary: gradientangle can't apply to individual nodes, only to `node []`
description:
So this is a strange bug.

We were recently looking at `gradientangle`, and I saw the example was pretty strange, it would set up a default value for all nodes, then just use it on a single node at a time:

```
		node [shape = circle,style=filled,fillcolor="white:black",
			gradientangle=360 label="n9:360" fontcolor="black" ] "n9"; 
		node [gradientangle=315 label="n8:315"] "n8"; 
```

Instead of the more natural, defining the property directly on the node:

```
		n9 [shape = circle,style=filled,fillcolor="white:black",
			gradientangle=360 label="n9:360" fontcolor="black" ];
		n8 [gradientangle=315 label="n8:315"];
```

I thought this was just a case of silliness, and updated the example to use the latter: https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz.gitlab.io/-/commit/c2573588ca17e7a660a9debd4b704a8b70f08936

But tonight, looking through the code of `gradientangle`, I saw that I don't think the latter actually works!

There are two places we parse `gradientangle`. 1 in `input.c` (one for the graph default, one for the `node` default), and one for the HTML lexer (which isn't in play here, we aren't parsing HTML-like labels):

```
> rg \"gradientangle\"
lib/common/input.c
743:    G_gradientangle = agfindgraphattr(g,"gradientangle");
779:    N_gradientangle = agfindnodeattr(g,"gradientangle");

lib/common/htmllex.c
486:    {"gradientangle", (attrFn) gradientanglefn},
511:    {"gradientangle", (attrFn) gradientanglefn},
```

There is no handling of `gradientangle` for individual nodes, only as a "node default".

I'll revert this

summary: Memory leak in lib/cgraph/attr.c at static Agraph_t *ProtoGraph
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Creating and freeing any context will cause the leak:

GVC_t* gvc = gvContext();
gvFreeContext(gvc);

Function gvContext will call agattr(NULL, ...) which in turn will do ProtoGraph = agopen(0, ProtoDesc, 0);
This pointer is never freed.

## Expected Behaviour

No memory leaks if all the gvFree*** functions are called correctly.

## Actual Behaviour

ProtoGraph pointer is allocated on the first gvContext() but never freed, causing a leak.

## OS Version

Tested on Windows.
Should happen on all OSs.

## Graphviz Version

2.49.1 (0)

summary: Graphviz 7.0.1 NetBSD compilation failure
description:
From my email:


```
On 11/18/22 04:28, Michael Bäuerle wrote:
> Hi Matthew,
> 
> Issue #370 was closed, but the patches associated with it are still
> required for NetBSD:
> 
> | ./configure: 3865: Syntax error: Bad substitution
> 
> Patch:
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> --- configure.ac.orig	2022-11-09 15:09:45.000000000 +0000
> +++ configure.ac
> @@ -101,8 +101,15 @@ case "${host_os}" in
>   	# For the build number: months since Jan 2000, day of month from the timestamp
>   	# For the revision number: hour, minute from the timestamp
>   	if test $GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO != "0"; then
> -		GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_BUILD=`expr \( ${GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO:0:4} - 2000 \) \* 12 + ${GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO:4:2}`${GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO:6:2}
> -		GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_REVISION=${GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO:9:4}
> +		# JR: patch from Michael van Elst:
> +		#     if we have a shell, we should have a working awk, too
> +		eval `echo "$GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_MICRO" | awk '{
> +			print "GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_BUILD=" \
> +				(substr($1,1,4)-2000)*12+substr($1,5,2) \
> +				substr($1,7,2)
> +			print "GRAPHVIZ_VERSION_REVISION=" \
> +				substr($1,10,4)
> +		}'`
>   	fi
>   	;;
>   esac
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> | checking for FREETYPE2... yes
> | checking for FONTCONFIG... yes
> | checking for GTS... yes
> | ./configure: 28539: Syntax error: Bad substitution
```

Normally we would consider this a release blocker. But I'm going to continue with 7.0.2 to unblock the macOS people and then hopefully deal with this as a fast follow in 7.0.3.

summary: Semitransparent, thick edges are not rendered properly
description:
The renderer does not render edges properly if both edge transparency (color alpha channel) and penwidth are modfied, see example below. The error seems to occur for all image output formats (tested gif, bmp, jpeg).

## Steps to reproduce
```dot
digraph {
"A" -> "B" [color="#00000080", penwidth="20"] 
"C" -> "B" [color="#00000080", penwidth="10"] 
}
```

## Expected Behaviour
One semi-transparent arrowhead is drawn per edge.

## Actual Behavior
Two semi-transparent arrowheads are drawn per edge, one of which is too big.

![image](/uploads/886fe616f23c697010449bfadec26092/image.png)

## OS Version
Windows 10 Pro 22H2

## Graphviz Version
6.0.1 (build h8f5d4a1_0 installed via conda-forge)

summary: Incorrect removal of the `alt=""` tag
description:
In the issue https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/265 it was requested to remove the `alt=""` tags and this was implemented in the version 7.0.2 though:

On the page https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_area.asp I see under Attributes:

> | alt | text | Specifies an alternate text for the area. Required if the href attribute is present |

Also in the file https://www.w3.org/TR/2018/SPSD-xhtml1-20180327/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd I see:

```
<!ELEMENT area EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST area
  %attrs;
  %focus;
  shape       %Shape;        "rect"
  coords      %Coords;       #IMPLIED
  href        %URI;          #IMPLIED
  nohref      (nohref)       #IMPLIED
  alt         %Text;         #REQUIRED
  >
```

and in https://www.w3.org/TR/2018/SPSD-xhtml1-20180327/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd I see:

```
<!ELEMENT area EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST area
  %attrs;
  %focus;
  shape       %Shape;        "rect"
  coords      %Coords;       #IMPLIED
  href        %URI;          #IMPLIED
  nohref      (nohref)       #IMPLIED
  alt         %Text;         #REQUIRED
  target      %FrameTarget;  #IMPLIED
  >
```

So as far as I can see the removal of the `alt=""` is not correct.

summary: Unhealthy cross-references between directories
description:
The problem with cross-references is that they break the hierarchy and create spaghetti code.

Proper design should consider [Dependency inversion principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_inversion_principle) and [Loose coupling](Loose coupling).

Doxygen extracts and visualizes dependencies between directories:
[![image](/uploads/c1468fc424bcc5ee62ee334a56cfbadd/image.png)](https://makelinux.gitlab.io/graphviz-doxygen/dir_3f537abc6203949508366497267ed719.html)

Just suspected dependencies:

common → fdpgen Relation

| File in graphviz/lib/common | Includes file in graphviz/lib/fdpgen |
|-----------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| args.c                      | fdp.h                                |
| args.c                      | tlayout.h                            |
| globals.c                   | fdp.h                                |
  

common → label Relation

| File in graphviz/lib/common | Includes file in graphviz/lib/label |
|-----------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| postproc.c                  | xlabels.h                           |


label → common Relation

| File in graphviz/lib/label | Includes file in graphviz/lib/common |
|----------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| rectangle.c                | arith.h                              |
| xlabels.h                  | geom.h                               |


common → gvc Relation

| File in graphviz/lib/common | Includes file in graphviz/lib/gvc |
|-----------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| args.c                      | gvc.h                             |
| emit.c                      | gvc.h                             |
| input.c                     | gvc.h                             |
| output.c                    | gvc.h                             |
| psusershape.c               | gvio.h                            |

| render.h                    | gvcjob.h                          |
| render.h                    | gvcproc.h                         |
| render.h                    | gvplugin.h                        |
| types.h                     | gvcext.h                          |
| utils.c                     | gvc.h                             |

gvc → common Relation

|--------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| gvc.c                    | const.h                              |
| gvc.h                    | types.h                              |

summary: Missing code examples
description: I just went over https://graphviz.org/docs/attr-types/style/ to reproduce some of the images provided there as examples. There are no code examples, the source code is not provided, and an extensive google search has not yielded anything. In particular, it is not covered anywhere how the new "striped" and "wedged" style attributes can be used. A bit of trial and error has landed me at ```style = "striped"; fillcolor = "lightpink;0.5:lightyellow"```--so it is it just a colorList with separating black lines? See https://graphviz.org/docs/attr-types/colorList/. It is also not obvious that there is a way to combine multiple styles, e.g., ```style = "bold,rounded,striped"```.

summary: unsafe retained pointers in 'parse_style'
description:
`parse_style` uses an agxbuf with initial local storage:

```c
static char outbuf[SMALLBUF];
static agxbuf ps_xb;
…
agxbinit(&ps_xb, SMALLBUF, outbuf);
```

It then goes on to both write data into this agxbuf as well as retain internal pointers into the buffer:

```c
  parse[fun++] = agxbnext(&ps_xb);
}
agxbput_n(&ps_xb, c.start, c.size);
```

However an agxbuf with external storage like this can switch to being heap allocated if too much data is pushed into it. For example, it looks to me like the following sequence of actions can occur:

1. `ps_xb` is initialized with `outbuf` living at 0x1000
2. enough data is pushed into `ps_xb` to almost fill `outbuf`
3. the above line takes a pointer into `ps_xb`, finding `agxbnext(&ps_xb)` to be 0x103e
4. a greater-than-2-byte string is immediately pushed into it in the next line, `agxbput_n(&ps_xb, c.start, c.size)`, causing `ps_xb` to be relocated to the heap

Now the last entry of `parse` that we wrote (`parse[fun++]`) contains a pointer to a garbage _unterminated_ string. This most likely goes on to cause a difficult-to-debug crash when a read later walks off the end of this string.

Compounding this problem, there's a variant of the same issue where `ps_xb` has _already_ been heap allocated but is expanded by the call to `agxbput_n`. In this case, we've retained not a pointer to an unterminated string but a pointer into now-freed data. In fact _all prior_ pointers in the `parse` array now point into freed data.

This is a pretty severe issue and, given the size of `outbuf` is only 64 bytes, I'm surprising this hasn't caused problems in the past. The leading comment to this function itself is actually quite damning, but its author appears to have not spotted the above described further bug:

```c
/* parse_style:
 * This is one of the worst internal designs in graphviz.
 * The use of '\0' characters within strings seems cute but it
 * makes all of the standard functions useless if not dangerous.
 * Plus the function uses static memory for both the array and
 * the character buffer. One hopes all of the values are used
 * before the function is called again.
 */
```

summary: invalid memcpy in printTok
description:
1349b895eca0bb04855ba46162d0ec7ba3c65010 removed use of `agxbstart`. Unfortunately what I overlooked at the time was that the `agxbput` introduced in this commit bottoms out in a `memcpy` with overlapping destination and source, something that is undefined behavior in C.

The obvious fix to this would be to adjust `agxbput` to call `memmove` instead of `memcpy`. But I'm not sure we want to do this, as it has negative performance implications for other uses of `agxbuf`s with large strings.

summary: With pack=1, dot does no longer respect the order of the nodes
description:
## Steps to reproduce

[15trees.gv](/uploads/4eb5b471cfaed26a30e024621b11e569/15trees.gv)

This input file does not respect the order of the nodes. For the trees represents AST, left sides of the '=' sign only could contain a single word/variable name. Not multiple or a number. Remove pack=1 and this order is correctly, while this should not be an influence as far as I know.

## Expected Behaviour

The same as now, but order of child nodes correctly.

## Actual Behaviour

Incorrect order of child nodes.

## OS Version

Online version.

## Graphviz Version

2.40.1

## Additional info

I would really like to have this resolved.
Thank you for all the other features!

summary: stack overflow in graph with a long chain
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Create a graph using something like the following script:

```python
print("digraph {")
for i in range(800000):
  print(f"  N{i} -> N{i + 1}")
print("}")
```

Run this through `dot -Tsvg -o /dev/null foo.dot`.

## Expected Behaviour

Run to completion successfully.

## Actual Behaviour

The function `dfs` recurses until it overflows the stack.

## OS Version

```
$ uname -rms
Linux 5.15.0-56-generic x86_64
```

## Graphviz Version

Commit 1cf4370134528b2777e3153802d8cd8259ff9c4d.

description:
Apparently what I experienced on https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/3003 was not the old Windows commit message bug. The Cygwin jobs now report: ``` $ wget https://cygwin.com/setup-x86_64.exe -OutFile C:\setup-x86_64.exe wget : 403 Forbidden

Forbidden

You don't have permission to access this resource.

At line:1 char:1 + wget https://cygwin.com/setup-x86_64.exe -OutFile C:\setup-x86_64.exe + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ + CategoryInfo : InvalidOperation: (System.Net.HttpWebRequest:HttpWebRequest) [Invoke-WebRequest], WebExc eption + FullyQualifiedErrorId : WebCmdletWebResponseException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeWebRequestCommand ``` I'm going to disable the Cygwin jobs until we can figure out what's going on.

summary: an orthogonal edge doesn't connect to a triangle node
ERROR: AddressSanitizer: attempting double-free
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Debug build with `-fsanitize=address` enabled, custom shared object build using:
```c++
    const auto demand_loading = false;
    auto gvc = std::make_shared<GVC::GVContext>(lt_preloaded_symbols, demand_loading);
    auto g = std::make_shared<CGraph::AGraph>(dot);
    const auto layout = GVC::GVLayout(gvc, g, engine);
    const auto result = layout.render(format);
    m_result = result.string_view();
```

DOT layout with JSON or SVG output:

Test Case (I suspect the high values of the weights are the trigger):  [dot003.dot](/uploads/6ff6f7092eb320b87db4ff1611fb20c9/dot003.dot)

Fails on cleanup

To just work

## Actual Behaviour

summary: Python 3.12 no longer has distutils
description:
In graphviz's configure.ac, it uses distutils.sysconfig to determine the Python platform library directory. With Python 3.12, distutils will be removed, so this logic will no longer work:

~~~
PYTHON_INSTALL_DIR="`$PYTHON -c 'from distutils import sysconfig; print(sysconfig.get_python_lib(1,0))'`"
...
PYTHON3_INSTALL_DIR="`$PYTHON3 -c 'from distutils import sysconfig; print(sysconfig.get_python_lib(1,0))'`"
~~~

The replacement function in Python 3.12 (works in older Python3 as well) is to use get_path() from sysconfig (not to be confused with distutils.sysconfig):

~~~
PYTHON3_INSTALL_DIR="`$PYTHON3 -c 'import sysconfig; print(sysconfig.get_path("platlib"))'`"
~~~

I'm not entirely sure what to do about the PYTHON_INSTALL_DIR call. Presumably, that is to catch python2 cases, but on systems which are only Python3 (e.g. all current versions of Fedora), that gets invoked by python3 and needs to be changed as well... but for older systems, there might need to be some logic in there to use the old distutils function if python2 is detected.

summary: Line number mismatch in GitLab test coverage visualization
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Check the test coverage in an MR, e.g. https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/3036/diffs?commit_id=98202680a76541742c2b472bec177b46873ea7e1#c71069aee28dfb548eec697dc1b581b16602f701_181_163

## Expected Behaviour

Adjacent lines without branching should have the same coverage.

## Actual Behaviour

Adjacent lines without branching does not have the same coverage and some lines does not have any marking at all:

![image](/uploads/edc457e06236bd2f9aaa9a68a5359676/image.png)

- line 181 has 0 hits.
- line 182 doesn't have any hit indication at all.
- line 183 has 55 hits

## OS Version

Ubuntu 22.10.

## Graphviz Version

N/A, but the main branch is at 00344efdc84a90ce6a864697acd6833a9f193cf7.

## Additional info

The generated HTML pages by both lcov and gcov does not exhibit this problem.

From the artifacts of the [ubuntu-22.10-cmake-ASan-test-including-ctest](https://gitlab.com/smattr/graphviz/-/jobs/3541615755) job of !3036:

From the [lcov report](https://smattr.gitlab.io/-/graphviz/-/jobs/3541615755/artifacts/coverage/gcovr/index.ccomps.c.889f0c3dc4182886202b657fbd0f65d8.html#l175):

![image](/uploads/faef21c8928c68d06f756e2a99ca1f95/image.png)

The line numbers are actually 175-177 and correctly have the same coverage. Lines 181-183 are not the lines indicated by GitLab.

From the [gcov report](https://smattr.gitlab.io/-/graphviz/-/jobs/3541615755/artifacts/coverage/lcov/lib/pack/ccomps.c.gcov.html):

![image](/uploads/3873b3c891ad453860c9491821a655f8/image.png)

This shows the same as the lcov report.

Checking out the https://gitlab.com/smattr/graphviz/-/tree/smattr/gitlab-1950 branch and checking the line numbers with an external editor shows that the lcov and gcov line numbers are correct and the line numbers in the GitLab UI are wrong.

From https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/testing/test_coverage_visualization.html#limits:

> A limit of 100 <source> nodes for Cobertura format XML files applies. If your Cobertura report exceeds 100 nodes, there can be mismatches or no matches in the merge request diff view.
> 
> A single Cobertura XML file can be no more than 10MiB. For large projects, split the Cobertura XML into smaller files. See this issue for more details. When submitting many files, it can take a few minutes for coverage to show on a merge request.
> 
> The visualization only displays after the pipeline is complete. If the pipeline has a blocking manual job, the pipeline waits for the manual job before continuing and is not considered complete. The visualization cannot be displayed if the blocking manual job did not run.

This seems like a plausible but absurd explanation. The issue mentioned is https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328772.

summary: dot -Tcanon is slow because it does unnecessary layout
description:
Forked off an issue from https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/issues/2328#note_1230999525

@steveroush mentions:

> dot -Tcanon

> I guess that dot is going through the layout phase even though canon will ignore it.


Indeed, I tried profiling -Tcanon with https://github.com/mstange/samply:

```
$ samply record --rate 100 /usr/local/bin/dot -Tcanon ~/Downloads/dot-causes-abend.dot
```

And I see it's spending a lot of time in dotLayout function: https://share.firefox.dev/3vNpo1k

I don't think this is particularly important, but I thought I'd file it here to track as an issue: `-Tcanon` is the closest thing to an autoformatter (a la gofmt/rustfmt) that we have for Graphviz. And autoformatters should be fast. Maybe we could skip the layout if we're doing `-Tcanon`. Or maybe that would have other, bad side-effects, I'm not sure.

summary: SFIO mismatched definitions
description:
When building with LTO enabled, the compiler notices:

```
[ 84%] Linking C executable gvpr
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/gvpr/../sfio/sfio.h:174:29: warning: type of ‘sfstderr’ does not match original declaration [-Wlto-type-mismatch]
  174 |     SFIO_API extern Sfio_t *sfstderr;
      |                             ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:34:9: note: ‘sfstderr’ was previously declared here
   34 | Sfio_t *sfstderr = &_Sfstderr;
      |         ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:34:9: note: code may be misoptimized unless ‘-fno-strict-aliasing’ is used
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/gvpr/../sfio/sfio.h:172:29: warning: type of ‘sfstdin’ does not match original declaration [-Wlto-type-mismatch]
  172 |     SFIO_API extern Sfio_t *sfstdin;
      |                             ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:32:9: note: ‘sfstdin’ was previously declared here
   32 | Sfio_t *sfstdin = &_Sfstdin;
      |         ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:32:9: note: code may be misoptimized unless ‘-fno-strict-aliasing’ is used
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/gvpr/../sfio/sfio.h:173:29: warning: type of ‘sfstdout’ does not match original declaration [-Wlto-type-mismatch]
  173 |     SFIO_API extern Sfio_t *sfstdout;
      |                             ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:33:9: note: ‘sfstdout’ was previously declared here
   33 | Sfio_t *sfstdout = &_Sfstdout;
      |         ^
/tmp/tmp.0FKCznWrdj/graphviz/lib/sfio/sfextern.c:33:9: note: code may be misoptimized unless ‘-fno-strict-aliasing’ is used
```

This is sort of analogous to a violation of C++’s One Definition Rule (ODR). What’s happening is that the definition of the underlying struct of the typedef `Sfio_t`, `_sfio_s`, is seen twice, once with `_SFIO_PRIVATE` defined and once without. So different parts of the compilation see a different struct behind `Sfio_t`. Normally the compiler is blind to this because the differences occur between translation units. But LTO allows it to see across this boundary.

The risk of a problem here is relatively low (most `Sfio_t` usage is by pointer only), but we should probably address this for the sake of avoiding future miscompilations as compiler optimizations become more aggressive.

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: [graphviz 7.0.6] Nonportable syntax in configure.ac
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2023 12:25:44 +0100
From: Michael Bäuerle
Organization: STZ Elektronik

Hi Matthew,

version 7.0.6 has a nonportable check in "configure.ac".

----------------------------------------------------------------------

   # required for linking with QT
   CXXFLAGS="${CXXFLAGS} -fPIE -fPIC"
   AC_CHECK_PROGS([QMAKE], [qmake6 qmake-qt5 qmake5 qmake], [false])
-  AS_IF([test "$QMAKE" == "qmake6"], [
+  AS_IF([test "$QMAKE" = "qmake6"], [
     # Qt6
     AC_CHECK_FILE($(${QMAKE} -query QT_INSTALL_HEADERS)/QtCore/QtCore, [
       QTCORE_CFLAGS="-I$(${QMAKE} -query QT_INSTALL_HEADERS) -I$(${QMAKE} -query QT_INSTALL_HEADERS)/QtCore"
----------------------------------------------------------------------

-- 
Regards,
Michael Bäuerle
```

summary: gv2gxl, gxl2gv do not behave correctly when called via absolute or relative path
description:
## Steps to reproduce

```python
gv2gxl = shutil.which("gv2gxl")
print(gv2gxl) # prints C:/Graphviz/bin/gv2gxl.EXE

```

## Expected Behaviour

gv2gxl translates Graphviz to GXL.

## Actual Behaviour

gv2gxl fails to set a mode and falls back on gxl2gv behavior.

## OS Version

Windows in Graphviz CI.

## Graphviz Version

5c24c6e81cbe74c95b3552f1d18029258614be33

The problem seems to be that it looks at `argv[0]` to decide how to behave and does not anticipate finding an absolute or relative path here. It then falls back on examining the file extension of its inputs, which also fails if its input is being piped into it.

summary: fdp cluster->cluster edges were correct but now drawn incorrectly
Label of edge not displayed when having "rank=sink"
consider applying 'black'
description:
Python in the Graphviz repository is checked in CI by Pylint. The .pylintrc file used for this was based on a subjective style agreed upon by the maintainers when it was added.

Meanwhile the Python ecosystem has more or less universally standardized on the opinionated [black formatter](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/). This issue proposes that Graphviz too should adopt black.

The Python code in the repository is not a core part of Graphviz, so I don't think this proposal is controversial. But applying it will incur a large diff, mainly due to the migration from 2-space indenting to 4-space indenting. But I think the pay off is worth it. In return for this one off churn, we no longer need to care about Python formatting and simply run black prior to committing.

summary: dotguide document is unclear regarding dot's four phases
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Read unclear documentation

## Expected Behaviour

the [dotguide.pdf](http://www.graphviz.org/pdf/dotguide.pdf) document states that dot is comprised of _four_ phases.  I expect it to then list the _four_ phases.

## Actual Behaviour

The document then seems to list _five_ "steps" (apparently step==phase).  My guess is that steps 1 & 2 == phase 1, but this is only a guess.

## OS Version
web-site based documentation

## Graphviz Version
all

## Additional info

From page 2, slightly reformatted:

> **dot** draws graphs in _four_ main phases. Knowing this helps you to understand
> what kind of layouts dot makes and how you can control them. The layout procedure used by dot relies on the graph being acyclic.
> 
> Thus, the _first_ step is to break
> any cycles which occur in the input graph by reversing the internal direction of
> certain cyclic edges.  
> The _next_ step assigns nodes to discrete ranks or levels. In a 
> top-to-bottom drawing, ranks determine Y coordinates. Edges that span more than
> one rank are broken into chains of “virtual” nodes and unit-length edges.  
> The _third_ step orders nodes within ranks to avoid crossings.   
> The _fourth_ step sets X coordinates of nodes to keep edges short,  
> and the _final_ step routes edge splines.

summary: Setting "mindist" graph attribute for circo layout causes GraphViz library to crash with "access violation in cgraph.dll" on gvLayout (checked for Windows only)
Triangulation code takes pointers into realloced array
description:
The code in lib/pathplan/shortest.c has logic like the following:

```c
for (...) {
...
  loadtriangle(...)
...
}
...
static int loadtriangle(...) {
...
  growtris(...)
...
  trip->e[ei].ltp = trip;
...
}
```

The assignment to `ltp` is storing a pointer into the global `tris` array. This array is realloced in `loadtriangle`, potentially relocating its backing memory. So the following sequence of events is possible:
1. `loadtriangle` is called
2. `growtris` is called, and allocates `tris` at 0x42
3. 0x42 (a pointer to the 0-th entry) is stored into `ltp`
4. 20 further calls to `loadtriangle` happen
5. `loadtriangle` is called
6. `growtris` is called because the array is now full; its `realloc` moves the array to 0x80

`ltp` is now a dangling pointer into freed memory at 0x42 and it may be dereferenced later.

This may be the underlying problem behind #1332, #274, #1323, #2003.

summary: ctest failures invisible
description:
I’m trying to resurrect https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/merge_requests/3029 on which progress seems to have stalled. I think I’ve solved all the failures except a single unit test in the ctest suite. You can see the failure here, https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/jobs/3899795706. As observable, the failure output is quite unhelpful.

Running the equivalent steps locally, I can reproduce the failure. Locally I get no output at all, not even the cryptic “suppressions used…” text. Toggling `--output-on-failure` and `$CTEST_OUTPUT_ON_FAILURE` has no effect. Trying `--verbose` and `--extra-verbose` alters the output, but still provides no information about the test failure.

Bypassing ctest altogether and running the unit test directly finally gets us the failure information:

```bash
$ env LD_LIBRARY_PATH=${PREFIX}/lib ./tests/test_edge_node_overlap_all_node_shapes

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
test_edge_node_overlap_all_node_shapes is a Catch v2.13.8 host application.
Run with -? for options

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overlap all node shapes
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
/tmp/tmp.npCMjCmmIL/graphviz/tests/test_edge_node_overlap_all_node_shapes.cpp:10
...............................................................................

/tmp/tmp.npCMjCmmIL/graphviz/tests/test_edge_node_overlap_utilities.cpp:223: FAILED:
  CHECK( head_node_edge_overlap <= check_options.max_node_edge_overlap + check_options.svg_rounding_error * 2 )
with expansion:
  1.1804219191 <= 0.51
with messages:
  Node shape: plain
  Head node overlap:
    width:  8.400
    height: 1.180

===============================================================================
test cases:   1 |   0 passed | 1 failed
assertions: 362 | 361 passed | 1 failed
```

Does anyone know how we get this level of information to actually show in CI? I was under the impression `--output-on-failure` did this, but it seems kind of useless. I am unsure if our problem here is due to ctest, catch2, or some interaction between the two. I am also wondering if this is some kind of stderr buffering or line discipline issue.

summary: ortho and concentrate used together cause a crash

Result:

$ env UBSAN_OPTIONS=print_stacktrace=1 LD_LIBRARY_PATH=${PREFIX}/lib ${PREFIX}/bin/dot -Tpng -Gcharset=Latin1 -o /dev/null /tmp/1501.gv 
splines.c:222:12: runtime error: member access within null pointer of type 'struct Agobj_t'

    #5 0x7fbf25cba78b in dot_splines /tmp/tmp.FpMlosEKrT/graphviz/lib/dotgen/dotsplines.c:524

summary: neatogen: incorrect qsort optimization

description:
I unfortunately just merged something in eb9f228f29987921af39a9f8e13db937665fcc0c not realizing macOS would have different behavior than the other platforms we test on. It fails the test introduced in that merge due to XType warnings we’ve seen before:

```

E         +  b'sible.\n2023-03-17 22:18:43.471 dot[40758:82312] XType: XTFontStaticRegis'

summary: deploy script no longer recognizes the Windows artifacts
Unable to build Tcldot
description:
## Steps to Reproduce

I’m building Graphviz and Tcldot using:

```console
$ ./configure --enable-swig=yes --with-tclsh=/path/to/tclsh8.6 --enable-tcl=yes
```

## Expected Behaviour

I expect the build to finish successfully.

## Actual Behaviour

```
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
  "_Gdtclft_Init", referenced from:
      _Tcldot_Init in libtcldot_builtin_la-tcldot.o
ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
```

## OS Version

macOS 12.6.3; however, I have a custom Tcl/Tk installation and am not using the one shipped with macOS, which is rather broken.

## Graphviz Version

I’m attempting to build from commit f9f1280b6.

## Additional Info

The following patch seems to fix the issue:

```diff
diff --git a/tclpkg/tcldot/Makefile.am b/tclpkg/tcldot/Makefile.am
index 115cf9c96..14d45039d 100644
--- a/tclpkg/tcldot/Makefile.am
+++ b/tclpkg/tcldot/Makefile.am
@@ -76,7 +76,7 @@ libtcldot_builtin_la_SOURCES = \
 libtcldot_builtin_la_CPPFLAGS = $(AM_CPPFLAGS) -DDEMAND_LOADING=1
 libtcldot_builtin_la_LDFLAGS = -no-undefined -module -avoid-version
 
-libtcldot_builtin_la_LIBADD = $(TCLHANDLE_LIBS) \
+libtcldot_builtin_la_LIBADD = $(TCLHANDLE_LIBS) $(GDTCLFT_LIBS) \
 	$(top_builddir)/plugin/dot_layout/libgvplugin_dot_layout_C.la \
 	$(top_builddir)/plugin/neato_layout/libgvplugin_neato_layout_C.la \
 	$(top_builddir)/plugin/core/libgvplugin_core_C.la \
```

summary: Gitlab releases at gitlab repackaged with unusual directory name
description:
When you go to

https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/releases

and download some source code of a release, say

https://gitlab.com/graphviz/graphviz/-/archive/8.0.1/graphviz-8.0.1.tar.gz

and extract it, it creates a directory named
```
graphviz-8cd5300e2e31c80dbbfcdd65aad697187e5ac0b0
```

instead of `graphviz-8.0.1`. This suddenly happened also for all past releases which seem to be repackaged with the new directory name. I noticed when using

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk-osx

and graphviz 2.47.0 from the module

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk-osx/-/blob/master/modulesets-stable/gtk-osx-random.modules#L45

failed because of a different checksum. I think I was able to build it without any problems during the weekend so this seems to be some recent problem.

summary: Invalid values prev 1 and next 1 in routesplines
When building from HEAD, Tcl complains about version format due to ~dev${date}
description:
## Steps to Reproduce

Build Graphviz from HEAD with Tcldot enabled.

## Expected Behaviour

I expect Tcldot to be usable.

## Actual Behaviour

`package require Tcldot` complains about `8.0.2~dev${date}` not being a valid version format.

## OS Version

macOS 12.6.3; custom build of Tcl/Tk 8.6.13.

## Graphviz Version

Graphviz built from 24937ce0505e39a0e2b23e58ef8bc9874ea34797.

## Additional Info

Removing the entire `~dev${date}` logic from [gen_version.py](../24937ce0505e39a0e2b23e58ef8bc9874ea34797/gen_version.py) fixes the issue but is overkill.
I suppose one could make the files in [tclpkg](../24937ce0505e39a0e2b23e58ef8bc9874ea34797/tclpkg) use some sort of `PACKAGE_VERSION` with the `~dev${date}` suffix stripped as opposed to `PACKAGE_VERSION` itself.

summary: Suboptimal node ordering and edge routing in dot
description:
## Steps to reproduce

Compile the attached [Source.gv](/uploads/3d8466291014163004a06e78e2a3a742/Source.gv) with `dot -Tsvg Source.gv > Source.svg`.

## Description

In the generated graph, there are seven (7) rows, each made of a subgraph. Note that clusters will not work here because I desire edges crossing over subgraph. The first six (6) subgraphs, labeled A-F, should contain horizontal lines that connect the nodes of the subgraph. The nodes are numbered `0..N` (depending on the subgraph) and connected `0 -> 1 -> 2 ... -> N` from left to right. The seventh (7th) subgroup is just a collection of unrelated notes that look pretty when drawn in a horizontal line, thus they are grouped together.

In addition to the horizontal subgroup edges, there are some edges that traverse from one subgraph to another. These are allowed to cross over other edges. The internal edges (i.e. one between nodes in the same subgraph) of subgraphs `A-C, E-F` behave correctly, but subgraph `D`'s internal nodes and edges "go crazy". Specifically, nodes 2 and 3 are swapped such that the placement from left to right is `D0, D1, D3, D2, D4`, causing edges `D1:e -> D2:w`, `D2:e -> D3:w`, and `D3:e -> D4:w` to take suboptimal routes. Instead of short, straight, horizontal lines, they are bendy/curvy abominations.

The attached DOT source is a real graph (i.e. a production asset), but I have stripped all the additional attributes (labels, URLs, colors, height/width, etc.). The same graphic anomaly occurs when all the lipstick is applied, but this test-case is (hopefully) a tad easier to read. Additionally, this sighting occurs in other graphs as well. The more edges that cross over subgraphs, the more likely `dot` is to make a strange decision.

## Actual Behaviour

What follows is the actual result of the DOT file included below:

![Actual.svg](/uploads/7f10bcb80baf5d29e62934b0deba4ebc/Actual.svg)

## Expected Behaviour

A more reasonable graph is produced when `constraint=false` is applied to edge `D2 -> Y`. Unfortunately this is not a valid solution, as this graph is one of an infinite number of graphs generated on-the-fly from a constantly-evolving dataset. But this small manual tweak does produce a more visually appealing graph.

![Expected.svg](/uploads/b97c270b8d1a735c6f7f7289585b9f47/Expected.svg)

## OS Version / Graphviz Version

I confirmed the same input generates roughly the same output on the following configurations:

- CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810, dot - graphviz version 2.40.1 (20161225.0304)
- CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810, dot - graphviz version 7.1.0 (20230121.1956)
- CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810, dot - graphviz version 8.0.1 (20230327.1645)
- MacOS Ventura 13.2.1 - dot - graphviz version 8.0.1 (20230327.1645)

## Additional information

In some scenarios, I have luck performing a little post-processing and iterative rewiring of the graph. To do this, I:
- Render DOT -> placed DOT (`dot -Tdot in > out`) which outputs a DOT file with `pos` attributes on all nodes and edges.
- Detect nodes in a subgraph that are not placed in the proper order.
- Shuffle the `dot`-generated `pos` attributes to redistribute the nodes in the desired order.
  - In the 'Actual' graph above, this equates to swapping the `pos` attributes for nodes `D2` and `D3`.
- Find all edges that begin/end at the relocated nodes and remove their `pos` attributes.
- Render DOT -> DOT again (`neato -Tdot -n2 in > out`)
  - Sometimes this needs to be done iteratively -- first I break and then reroute the "vertical" edges (the ones that traverse from one subgraph to another, e.g. `A2 -> Y` which travels north-to-south over the `D1 -> D2 -> D3` region), then I break/re-reoute the "horizontal" edges (e.g. `D1 -> D2, D2 -> D3, D3 -> D4`).
  - For this specific graph, `neato` goes into an infinite loop when trying to re-route either `D2 -> D3` or `D3 -> D4`. In other graphs, this approach works wonderfully

This is most definitely a hack, and not a pretty one.

Other techniques I have tried include pre-computing the number of vertical edge crossings in the north-source (e.g. `A2 -> Y`, `D4 -> A4`, etc.), apply a weighting factor to each crossing based on domain-specific knowledge of the input data-set, and then re-ordering all but the bottom-most subgraph in order to minimize the number of edge crossing. This works sometimes, but not all of the time.

More test-cases are available upon request.
